How many traditions of Allahâ€™s Messenger have become extinguished, After (the interpretation of) verses of the Qurâ€™an were extinguished? Allah might remove from a people their intellects, Until it is that which finishes off the head.", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 678, "bookId": "Maani-al-Akhbar-Saduq", "book": "MaÊ¿ÄnÄ« al-Ê¾AkhbÄr", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "The meaning of an opinion", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Basel Kadem", "englishText": "1.\tWe were told by Muhammed bin Hasan bin Ahmad bin Waleed, may Allah grant him mercy, that he said: We were told by Muhammed bin Hasan al-Saffar, from Harun bin Muslim, from Masâ€™ada bin Sadaqa, from Jaâ€™far bin Muhammed, from his father, from his fathers, that he said: The Prophet, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, said: Indeed, Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, surely hates the weak believer who has no opinion. He also said: He is the one who does not forbid evil. I have found in the writing of al-Barqi, may Allah grant him mercy, that opinion refers to intellect, and hence, the meaning of the report is that Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, hates the one who has no intellect. Some people have said: He, Exalted and Glorious is He, hates the weak believer who has no anus, and that he is the one who does not refrain from passing wind in every place. The first is more correct.", "arabicText": "Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ¯ - Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ - Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø§Ù„ØµÙØ§Ø±ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ù‡Ø§Ø±ÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ù…Ø³Ø¹Ø¯Ø© Ø¨Ù† ØµØ¯Ù‚Ø©ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¢Ø¨Ø§Ø¦Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ù„ÙŠØ¨ØºØ¶ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¶Ø¹ÙŠÙ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ Ø²Ø¨Ø± Ù„Ù‡. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†ÙƒØ±. ÙˆØ¬Ø¯Øª Ø¨Ø®Ø· Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø±Ù‚ÙŠ - Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ - Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø²Ø¨Ø± Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚Ù„ ÙÙ…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø¨Ø±: Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙŠØ¨ØºØ¶ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù‚Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‚ÙˆÙ…: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙŠØ¨ØºØ¶ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¶Ø¹ÙŠÙ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ Ø¯Ø¨Ø± Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ…ØªÙ†Ø¹ Ù…Ù† Ø¥Ø±Ø³Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±ÙŠØ­ ÙÙŠ ÙƒÙ„ Ù…ÙˆØ¶Ø¹ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø£ÙˆÙ„ Ø£ØµØ­.", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/28/1/387/1", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 387, "thaqalaynSanad": "1.\tWe were told by Muhammed bin Hasan bin Ahmad bin Waleed, may Allah grant him mercy, that he said: We were told by Muhammed bin Hasan al-Saffar, from Harun bin Muslim, from Masâ€™ada bin Sadaqa, from Jaâ€™far bin Muhammed, from his father, from his fathers, that he said: ", "thaqalaynMatn": "The Prophet, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, said: Indeed, Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, surely hates the weak believer who has no opinion. He also said: He is the one who does not forbid evil. I have found in the writing of al-Barqi, may Allah grant him mercy, that opinion refers to intellect, and hence, the meaning of the report is that Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, hates the one who has no intellect. Some people have said: He, Exalted and Glorious is He, hates the weak believer who has no anus, and that he is the one who does not refrain from passing wind in every place. The first is more correct.", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 407, "bookId": "Maani-al-Akhbar-Saduq", "book": "MaÊ¿ÄnÄ« al-Ê¾AkhbÄr", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "The meaning of the intellects of women and the beauty of men", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Basel Kadem", "englishText": "1.\tWe were told by Muhammed bin Umar bin Muhammed bin Salem bin Baraaâ€™ al-Juâ€™abi, the Keeper, al-Baghdadi, that he said: I was told by Ahmad bin Ubaidullah al-Thaqafi, Abuâ€™l-Abbas, that he said: We were told by Isa bin Muhammed, the Scribe, that he said: I was told by al-Madaâ€™ini, from Ghiyath bin Ibrahim, from Jaâ€™far bin Muhammed, from his father, from his grandfather, peace be upon them, that he said: Ali bin Abi Talib, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him, said: The intellects of women are in their beauty, and the beauty of men is in their intellects.", "arabicText": "Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ø± Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø³Ø§Ù„Ù… Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø¹Ø§Ø¨ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø§ÙØ¸ Ø§Ù„Ø¨ØºØ¯Ø§Ø¯ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ø¨ÙŠØ¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø«Ù‚ÙÙŠ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ø³ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ§ØªØ¨ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¯Ø§Ø¦Ù†ÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù† ØºÙŠØ§Ø« Ø¨Ù† Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ…ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¬Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ ØµÙ„ÙˆØ§Øª Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡: Ø¹Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø³Ø§Ø¡ ÙÙŠ Ø¬Ù…Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ù†ØŒ ÙˆØ¬Ù…Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ø§Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡Ù….", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/28/1/244/1", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 244, "thaqalaynSanad": "1.\tWe were told by Muhammed bin Umar bin Muhammed bin Salem bin Baraaâ€™ al-Juâ€™abi, the Keeper, al-Baghdadi, that he said: I was told by Ahmad bin Ubaidullah al-Thaqafi, Abuâ€™l-Abbas, that he said: We were told by Isa bin Muhammed, the Scribe, that he said: I was told by al-Madaâ€™ini, from Ghiyath bin Ibrahim, from Jaâ€™far bin Muhammed, from his father, from his grandfather, peace be upon them, that he said: ", "thaqalaynMatn": "Ali bin Abi Talib, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him, said: The intellects of women are in their beauty, and the beauty of men is in their intellects.", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 539, "bookId": "Al-Tawhid-Saduq", "book": "Al-Tawá¸¥Ä«d", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "2", "chapter": "A Session of al-Ridha (ASâ€¬â€¬) with Theologians from Among the Rhetoricians and Variousâ€¬â€¬ Religions about Unity in the presence of al-Ma`mun", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Sayed Ali Raza Rizvi", "englishText": "1. Abu Muhammad Ja`far ibn `Ali ibn Ahmad the jurist resident of Qum then of al-Iylaq (RAâ€¬â€¬ â€«â€ªsaid: Abu Muhammad al-Hasan ibn Muhammad ibn `Ali ibn Sadaqah al-Qummi reported to usâ€¬â€¬ â€«â€ªthat Abu `Amr Muhammad ibn `Umar ibn `Abd `Aziz al-Ansari al-Kajji related to me that oneâ€¬â€¬ â€«â€ªwho heard from al-Hasan ibn Muhammad al-Nawfali al-Hashimi related to me thatâ€¬â€¬ When `Ali ibn Musa al-Rida (AS) came to see al-Ma`mun, al-Ma`mun ordered al-Fadl ibn Sahl to summon the prominent theologians from among the rhetoricians such as the Catholicos [al-jathaliq]. The Head of the Rabbis [ra`s al-jalut], the heads of the Sabians, the High Priest [al-hirbidh] of Zoroaster and his followers, Castile Nestus, the Roman medical scientist, and the rest of the theologians in order to hear their words and those of al-Rida (AS). Al-Fadl ibn Sahl gathered them together, then informed al-Ma`mun about their meeting. Al-Ma`mun said: `Let them enter my presence.â€™ So he did, and then received them with hospitality. He then introduced himself to them saying, `Verily, I have gathered you for something good, and want you to debate with this cousin of mine from medina, who has come tome. Come to me tomorrow morning. None of you should be absent.â€ They said: â€œO Commander of the Faithful! We listen and obey you. Allah willing,, we will be here first thing in the morning.â€ Al-Hasan ibn Muhammad al-Nawfali said: â€œWe were talking to Abu al-Hasan (AS) when Yasir, the servant who was in the charge of serving Abu al-Hasan, entered and told him, O My Master! Verily, the Commander of the Faithful expressed his greetings to you and said: `May you brother be your ransom! Verily, the rhetoricians, scholars from all religions, and theologians from all nations have all gathered together here with me. Would you like to come to us and have a discussion with them? If you do not wish to do so, do not bother yourself. However, if you prefer, we can come visit you. Abu al-Hasan (AS) then said: â€œExpress my greetings to him, and tell him that I understand what you intend. Allah willing, I will come to you myself tomorrow morning.â€ Al-Hasan ibn Muhammad al-Nawfali said; â€œWhen Yasir went out, the Imam (AS) turned to me and said: â€œO Nawfali! You are an Iraqi, and an Iraqiâ€™s heart is not hard. So, what do you think? What is your cousinâ€™s intention in setting up a meeting between me and the pagans and rhetoricians?â€ Al-Nawfali says I answered, â€œMay I be yoiur ransom! He intends to test you, and wants to know how much knowledge you possess. Verily, he has based his assumption on shaky grounds. By Allah, what he has set up is evil.â€ The Imam (AS) asked, â€œAnd what has he set up?â€ Al-nawfali said: The heretics and the theologians are different from the learned. That is because a learned does not deny the undeniable, whereas rhetoricians, theologians, and polytheists are people who deny things and try to prove what is not true. If you argue with them and tell them that God is One, they would say, `Confirm His Oneness.â€™ And if you say that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, they would say, `Prove his Prophethood.â€™ May I be your ransom! They confuse you and make you disprove your own proofs. They continue to falsify until you back off. Beware of them! May I be your ransom!â€ Al-Nawfali added, â€œThe Imam (AS) then smiled, and told me, `O Nawfali! Do you fear that they will defeat my arguments?â€ Al-Nawfali said: `No, by Allah! I have no worries about you. Allah willing, I hope that Allah will make you victorious over them!â€™ The Imam (AS) asked again, `O Nawfali! Would you like to know when Al-Ma`mun will regret his actions?â€ He answered, `Yes.â€™ The Imam (AS) said: When he hears me argue with the people of the Torah quoting their own Torah, with the people of the Gospel quoting their own Gospel with the people of the Psalms quoting their own Psalms, with the Sabians in their own Hebrew language, with the Zoroastrian priests in their own Persian, with the Romans in their own Latin, and with the rhetoricians using their very own languages. So, if I close the avenues of argument in the face of each arguing party and disprove his claim, making him renounce his statement from its onset and referring to my own statement, then al-Ma`mun will realize that he has not achieved what he aspires to achieve. It is then that he will feel regret. And there is no power and no strength save in Allah, the Most High, the Most Great. On the following day, al-Fadl ibn Sahl went in a hurry to see the Imam (AS) and told him, â€œMay I be your ransom! Your cousin is waiting for you. The people have gathered together. When will you go to him?â€ Al-Rida (AS) told him, â€œYou go ahead, Allah willing, I will come to you.â€ Then he made ablutions for praying, drank some sawiq, quenched us from it as well, and then we all left. When we reached al-Ma`munâ€™s place, the meeting was full of people. Muhammad ibn Ja`far, some of the Talibites and Hashimites, and the Commanders of the Army were among those present. When al-Rida (AS) entered, al-Ma`mun stood up, Muhammad ibn Ja`far, and all the Hashimites who were present there, also stood up for him. The Imam (AS) and alMa`mun sat down while all the people were still standing, until al-Ma`mun ordered them to sit down. Al-Ma`mun talked to the Imam for a while. Then al-Ma`mun turned to the Catholicos and said: â€œO Catholicos! This is my cousin `Ali ibn Musa ibn Ja`far (AS). He is one of the children of Fatimah (AS), the daughter of our Prophet (SA), and `Ali ibn Abu Talib (AS). I would like you to debate with him, but be fair with him.â€ The Catholicos said: â€œO Commander of the Faithful! How can I argue with a man who argues with me using a Book I reject, and who believes in a prophet who I do not believe in? Al-Rida (AS) told him, â€œO Christian! Will you accept to debate with me if I present proofs from your Gospel?â€ The Catholicos answered, â€œHow could I reject the words of the Bible? I swear to God that I will accept your arguments, even if I dislike them.â€ Al-Rida (AS) told him, â€œAsk whatever you wish, and you shall receive an answer.â€ The Catholicos said: â€œwhat is your opinion about the Prophethood of Jesus and his Book? Do you deny either one of them?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: I accept the Prophethood of Jesus. I accept his Book. And I accept what he taught his nation, and what was accepted by his disciples. However, I reject the Prophethood of any Jesus who has not professed the Prophethood of Muhammad, his Book, and what he taught his people. The Catholicos said: â€œTwo witnesses are required to validate a testimony. Is that correct?â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œYes.â€ The Catholicos Archbishop said: â€œif that is the case, I challenge you to select who witnesses who are neither Muslim nor Christina, but who do not reject the Prophethood of Muhammad (SA). Likewise, you may ask a similar question from people other than our own nation.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œO Christian! Now you are speaking fairly. Do you accept a just person who was given preference (over others) by the Messiah, Jesus, the son of Mary?â€ The Catholicos replied, â€œWho is the just one? Name him for me.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œWhat is your opinion of John al-Daylami?â€ The Catholicos responded, â€œBravo! Bravo! You have mentioned the person most loved by the Messiah.â€ The Imam (AS) said: Then I ask you to swear by God, and tell me whether or not the Bible says that John said: `The Messiah has informed me of the religion of Muhammad, the Arab, and has given me the glad tidings about him who will be (a Prophet) after him. Therefore, I have the glad tidings of him to the disciples and they believed in him.â€™ The Catholicos said: â€œJohn did quote this from the Messiah. He did give the glad tidings concerning the coming of a Prophet, his Household, and his Successor. He has not specified when this would happen, and has not named them so that we could identify them.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œIf we bring someone here who can recite the Bible, and he recites to you Muhammadâ€™s name, his Household, and his nation, will you believe in him?â€ The Catholicos replied, â€œWhat a sound suggestion!â€ Al-Rida (AS) turned to Nestus the Roman, and asked hi, â€œhave you memorized the third Book of the Bible?â€ He answered, â€œI have thoroughly memorized it.â€ Then the Imam (AS) addressed the Catholicos and said: â€œCan you recite the Bible?â€ The Catholicos said: â€œYes, of course.â€ The Imam said: â€œThen I will recite to you (some verses from) the third Book. If Muhammad (SA), his Household (AS), and his nation were mentioned in it, then bear witness! And if they have not been mentioned therein, then do not bear witness.â€ Then the Imam (AS) recited to him some of the verses of the third Book until he reached the reference to the Prophet. He stopped reading and said: â€œO Christina! I challenge you to swear by the Messiah and his mother. Have you realized that I have knowledge of the Bible?â€ He replied, â€œyes.â€ The Imam (AS) recited to him some verses from the third Book concerning the reference to the Prophet, his Household, and his nation. Then the Imam (AS) said: O Christian! What do you think now? These are the words of Jesus, the son of Mary. If you deny what the Bible says, then you will deny both the Jesus and Moses. If you deny them, then it is incumbent to kill you for blasphemy against your Lord, your Prophet, and your Book. The Catholicos said: â€œI do not deny the clear things in the Bible. On the contrary, I profess them.â€ The Imam (AS) asked others who were present, â€œBear witness to his profession.â€ Then the Imam (AS) said to the Catholicos, â€œO Catholicos! Ask me any other question that you wish to ask.â€ The Catholicos asked, â€œWhat about the disciples of Jesus, the son of Mary? How many were they? And tell me about the scholars of the Bible. How many were then?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: You have found the expert! As for (the number of) the disciples, they were twelve men. The best and the most learned of them was Aluqas (Luke). As for the (number of) Christian scholars, there were three men: John (Yohanna), `the greatâ€™ at Aj, John at Qirqisiya, and john al-Daylami at Zijan, who made reference to Prophet Muhammad, his Household and his nation. It is he who gave glad tidings to the nation of Jesus and the Children of Israel about him. The Imam (AS) added, â€œO Christian! By Allah, we believe in Jesus, who believed in Muhammad. We have nothing against Jesus except for his weakness and the paucity of his fasting and prayer. The Catholicos replied, â€œBy Allah, you have corrupted your knowledge! You affair has become weak! I though that you were the most learned of the Muslims!â€ Al-Rida (AS) asked, â€œWhy?â€ The Catholicos said: â€œYou said that Jesus was weak in fasting and prayer when, in fact, he never broke fasting during the day, and never slept during the night. He always fasted during the day, and he always prayed throughout the night.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œFor whom did he fast and pray?â€ The Catholicos did no answer, not knowing what to say. Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œI want to ask you a question.â€ The Catholicos said: â€œAsk. I will respond if I have the answer.â€ Al-Rida (AS) asked, â€œWhy do you deny that Jesus gave life to the dead with the permission of Allah, the Mighty and High?â€ The Catholicos said: â€œI deny that because whoever is able to give life to the dead, and to heal the blind and the leprous is a Lord worthy of service.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: Very well. However, Elijah [al-Yasaâ€™] performed the same miracles as Jesus did. He walked on water, gave life to the dead, and healed the blind and the leprous Why did his nation not adopt him as a Lord? Why did no anyone worship him as a god other than Allah? The Prophet Ezekiel [Hizqil] did just what Jesus did. He gave life to thirty-five men sixty years after their death. Then the Imam (AS) turned towards the Head of the Rabbis and asked him, O Head of the Rabbis! Do you find the following about some of the youth of the Children of Israel in the Torah? When Nebuchadnezzar [Bakht Nasr] invaded Jerusalem, he enslaved the Children of Israel and brought them to Babylonia. Then Allah, the Mighty and High, sent al-Yasa` from them, and he gave life to them. This is in the Torah. No one but an unbeliever of you would deny it. The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œI have heard about this and know it.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œYou have spoken the truth.â€ Then the Imam (AS) said: â€œO Jewish man! See if I read from the following Book of the Torah properly.â€ The Imam (AS) then recited some of the verses from the Torah for us. The Jewish man, who was surprised at hearing how the Imam (AS) was reciting the Torah, kept moving his body. He then faced the Christian and asked, â€œO Christian! Were these words revealed before Jesus or were they revealed after him?â€ The Catholicos answe3red, â€œThey were revealed before him.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: The people of Quraysh gathered around the Messenger of Allah (SA) and asked him to give life to their dead. He sent along `Ali ibn Abu Talib (AS) with them and told him, â€œgo to the cemetery, and loudly call the people about whom they have asked, say, â€œO soand-so, so-and-so, etc.â€ Tell them, â€œAllahâ€™s Messenger Muhammad says, `Rise with the permission of Allah, the Mighty and Highâ€™ Then they all rose and brushed off the dust from their heads.â€ The people from the tribe of Quraysh walked towards them and asked them about their affairs. They told them that Muhammad (SA) has been raised as a Prophet. The people who had risen from the dead said: â€œWe wish we had lived in his age and believed in him!â€ He healed the blind, the leprous, and the insane. He spoke with the beasts, the birds, the jinn, and demons. Still, we do not adopt him as a Lord other than Allah, the Mighty and High. We do not deny the miracles of the prophets. Since you have adopted Jesus as a Lord, why do you not adopt al-Yasa` and Hizqil as lords, for they performed the same miracles as did Jesus, the son of Mary, such as giving life to the dead? Moreover, thousands of the Children of Israel left their homeland in fear of death due to the plague. Allah made them die immediately. The people of the village build a fence around them, and left them there until their bones decayed. One of the prophets of the Children of Israel passed by, and he was amazed when he saw so may decayed bones. Allah, the Mighty and high, revealed to him, â€œWould you like Me to bring them to life so that you can admonish them?â€ The Prophet said: â€œYes, O Lord!â€ Then Allah, the Mighty and High, revealed to him, â€œThen call them.â€ He said: â€œO decayed bones! Rise with Allahâ€™s permission.â€ They all rose while brushing off the dust from their heads.â€ Likewise when Abraham (AS), the friend of the Most Compassionate, took the birds, cut them into pieces, and put each piece on a mountain top. He called out to them and they came towards him. Also Moses (AS) the son of `Imran, his companions, and seventy of the men whom he had chosen went to the mountain. They told Moses, â€œYou have seen Allah. So show Him to us like you have seen Him.â€ Moses told them, â€œI have not seen Him.â€ But they said: â€œWe shall never believe in you until we see Allah manifestly.â€ A thunderbolt struck them, and burned them all up. Only Moses survived. Moses said: `O my Lord! I chose seventy men from among the Children of Israel and brought them to the mountain. Shall I return by myself? How shall my people believe what I must tell them? If You desired You could have destroyed al of us long before. Would you destroy us all for the deeds of the foolish ones among us?â€™ Then Allah, the Mighty and High, gave life to them after their death. You cannot deny all these things which I have told you, for the Torah, the Bible, the Psalms and the Qurâ€™an have mentioned them. If all those who gave life to the dead, healed the blind, the leprous and the mad, were adopted as lords other than Allah, then you should also adopt them as Lords. O Christians! What is your opinion? The Catholicos said: â€œYes. You are right. There is no god but Allah.â€ Then the Imam (AS) turned towards the Head of Rabbis and told him. O Jewish man! Turn to me. Swear to me by the Ten Commandments which were sent down to Moses, the son of `Imran, that the following statement about the Prophet Muhammad (SA) and his nation is not found in the Torah: When the people of the last nation, who are followers of the Rider of the Camel, who glorifies the Lord enormously, new glorification in new churches (implying mosques), then let the Children of Israel flee towards them and their dominion so that their hearts may be tranquil, since there will be swords in their hands with which they will take revenge on the unbelievers around the globe. Is this not written in the Torah? The Head of the Rabbis said; â€œYes, we have found that written in this manner.â€ Then the Imam (AS) asked the Catholicos, â€œO Christian! How is your knowledge of the Book of Sha`ya? He answered, â€œI know it letter by letter.â€ Then the Imam asked them both, â€œDo you know that the following statement is made by him, `O people! I have seen the picture of the Donkey. He was wearing gowns of light. And I have seen the Rider of the Camel, who is as bright as the moon.â€™â€ They answered, â€œVerily, Sha`1ya did say that!â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: O Christian! Do you know that Jesus said: `I am going to my Lord and your Lord, and the Paraclete [farqilita] is coming who shall testify to my truth just as I testified for him, and he shall explain everything to you, and he shall be the one to expose all the sins of nations, and he shall be the one to smash down the pillars of unbelief?â€™ The Catholicos said: â€œWe accept whatever you cite from the Bible.â€ The Imam said: â€œO Catholicos! Have you found this in the Bible?â€ The Catholicos said: â€œYes.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œO Catholicos, when you lost the first Bible, with whom did you find it?â€ The Catholicos said: â€œWe only lost the Bible for one day. Then we found it fresh (in its original state). John and Matthew brought it back to us.â€ Al-Rida (AS) asked him, How little you know of the Bible and its scholars! If what you say is correct, then why do you have so many disputes between yourselves regarding the Bible? The source of controversy lies in the Bible which you have in your hands today. Had it been the same as the fist Bible, there would be no dispute over it, However, I will prove this for you myself. Know that when the first Bible was lost, the Christians gathered around their scholars and said to them, `Jesus the son of Mary has been killed, and we have lost the Bible. You are the scholars. What do you have?â€™ Luke, Mark and John told them, `We have memorized the Bible. Do not worry about it. Do not forsake the churches. We will recite each Gospel of the Bible for you on each Sunday until we put it all together.â€™ Then Luke, Mark, John and Matthew gathered together and put together this Bible after you had lost the first one. These four students were of the first students. Did you know that?â€ The Catholicos said: â€œI did not know this before. Now I have learned it from you due to your noble knowledge of the Bible. I heard things from you which I knew deep down, and which my heart acknowledges to be the truth. As a result, I have grown in understanding.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œDo you accept the evidence I have presented?â€ The Catholicos said: â€œI completely accept the evidence as correct, and bear witness that it is true.â€ Al-Rida (AS) then told al-Maâ€™mun, his family, and the others who were present, â€œBe witnesses to this.â€ They said: â€œWe bear witness.â€ Then the Imam (AS) told the Catholicos, I swear by the Son and his Mother to tell us whether you know that Matthew said the following, `The Messiah is the son of David, the son of Abraham, the son of Issac, the son of Jacob, the son of Yehuda, the son of Khadrun.â€™ Mark said the following regarding the lineage of Jesus, the son of Mary, `He is Allahâ€™s Word placed in the human body. So it turned into the human form.â€™ Moreover, Luke said: `Jesus the son of Mary and his mother wee humans made of flesh and blood. Then the Holy Sprit entered into them.â€™ Testify as well that Jesus said the following about himself, `O disciples! I will tell you the truth. No one will ascend to Heaven, except for him who descends there from, except for the Rider of the Camel, the Seal of the Prophets, for he will ascend to the Heavens, and then will descend therefrom. What do you have to say about that? The Catholicos said; â€œThese are the words of Jesus. We do not deny them.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œIf so, what do you say about the testimonies of Luke, Mark and Matthew regarding Jesus and the lineage they attributed to him?â€ The Catholicos said: â€œThey ascribed likes to Jesus.â€ Al-Rida (A) said: â€œO people! Did he not just bear witness that they (Luke, Mark and Matthew) are the Scholars of the Bible, and what they said was the truth?â€ The Catholicos said: â€œO Scholar of the Muslims! I would like you to excuse me from discussing about these men.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œFine, I will excuse you from that, O Christian! Ask me whatever you wish to ask.â€ The Catholicos said: â€œLet someone else ask you questions. By Jesus, I did not think that there was a scholar like you among the Muslims.â€ Al-Rida (AS) turned towards the Head of the Rabbis and said: â€œWill you ask me questions or should I ask?â€ The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œI will ask. However, I will not accept any proofs from you except those form the Torah, the Bible, the Psalms of David, or the Scriptures of Abraham and Moses.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œDo not accept any of my proofs unless they are from the Torah as expressed by Moses, the son of `Imran, the Bible as expressed by Jesus, the son of Mary, or the Psalms of David as expressed by David.â€ The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œHow can you prove the Prophethood of Muhammad (SA)?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œMoses, the son of `Imran, Jesus, the son of Mary and David, the Vicegerent of Allah on the Earth, have testified to his Prophethood.â€ The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œProvide evidence of the testimony of Moses, the son of `Imran.â€ Al-Rida (AS) told him, O Jewish man! Do you know that Moses said the following to the Children of Israel, `A prophet will come to you fro among your brethren. Believe in him, and obey him.â€™ Do you know that the Children of Israel have no brethren other than the Children of Ishamel? Do you know about the ties of kinship between Israel and Ishmael and the relationship that existed between them from the past through Abraham? The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œThese are the words of Moses. I do not deny them.â€ Al-Rida (AS) asked him, â€œHas any Prophet other than Muhammad (SA) come from among the brethren of the Children of Israel?â€ He replied, â€œNo.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œIs this not correct in your opinion?â€ The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œYes, but I want you to prove its correctness from the Torah.â€ Al-Rida (AS) asked him, â€œDo you deny that the Toray says the following to you? `There came light from Mount Sinai. Light shined upon us from Mount Sa`ir and it became apparent to us from Mount Faran.â€™â€ The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œI am familiar with these words, but I do not know what they mean.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: I will inform you about them. What is meant when it says `There came light from Mount Sinai` is a reference to the revelations of Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, to Moses on mount Sinai. And what is meant when it says, `Light shined upon us from Mount Sa`irâ€™ is a reference to the mountain upon which Allah, the Mighty and High, sent revelations of Jesus, the son of Mary. Jesus was on that mountain. And what is meant when it says, `and it became apparent to us from Mount Faran.â€™ Faran is a mountain that is one day away from Mecca. As you and your friends said: the Prophet Sha`ya has said in the Torah that `I have seen the picture of the Rider of the Donkey. He was wearing gowns of light. And I have seen the Rider of the Camel, who is as bright as the moon.â€™ Who is the Rider of the Donkey? Who is the Rider of the Camel? The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œI do not know who they are.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œThe Rider of the Donkey is Jesus, and the Rider of the Camel is Muhammad (SA). Do you deny that this is from the Torah?â€ The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œNo, I do not deny that.â€ Then al-Rida (AS) said: â€œDo you know the Prophet Hayqua?â€ The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œYes, I know him.â€ The Imam (AS) said: He said the following which your Book has also stated, `Allah brought down the Bayan from Mount Faran. The heavens are filled with the praise of Ahmad and his nation. He will lead his troops at sea just as he carries them on land. He will bring us a new Book after the destruction of the Holy House (in Jerusalem).â€™ Did you know the, and do you believe in it? The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œIn fact, the Prophet Hayquq has said this. I will not deny his words. Al-Rida (AS) said: David said in his Psalms which you have also read, `O my Allah! Appoint him who will establish the practice after the cessation (of the prophets). Did you know of any prophet other than Muhammad (SA) who has established the practice after the end of the period of prophecy? The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œthis is what David said. We do not deny it. However, he was referring to Jesus, as it was with him that the age of prophecy came to a close.â€ Al-Rida (AS) told him, You are wrong. In fact, Jesus endorsed the practices [sunah] of the Torah until Allah raised him up to Himself. It is written in the Bible. The son of the pious woman will go, and the Paraclete will come after him. It is he who will preserve the bonds, explain everything to you, and testify to my truth just as I testified for him. I have brought you the examples, and he will bring you the interpretations. Do you believe that this statement is in the Bible? The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œYes.â€ Al-Rida (AS) replied to him, â€œO the Head of the Rabbis! I want to ask you about your Prophet Moses.â€ The Jewish man said: â€œHe brought miracles which the prophets before him had not brought.â€ The Imam (AS) asked, â€œCould you give me an example?â€ The Head of the Rabbis replied, â€œHe split the sea, turned the cane into a slithering serpent, made springs gush from stones, showed his hand white and shining to the onlookers, and other signs the like of which other creatures were unable to bring.â€ Al-Rida (AS) replied to him, â€œYou are right. They are proofs of his Prophethood. He brought the like of which other creatures were unable to brig. Is it obligatory on you to believe in whoever claims Prophethood, and performs something which all other creatures are unable to perform?â€ The head of the Rabbis said: â€œNo, since there is no one like Moses considering his position near his Lord and his closeness to Him. It is not incumbent upon us to profess the Prophethood of whoever claims it, unless he brings us miracles similar to those brought by Moses. The Imam (AS) said: Then how come you admit the Prophethood of the other prophets who preceded Moses who did not split the sea; nor did they make twelve springs gush forth from the stones, nor did they show a white shining hand as Moses did, nor did they turn the came into a slithering serpent. The Jewish man replied: I told you that if they performed miracles as evidence for their Prophethood which all other creatures were unable to perform, and if they brought something the like of which Moses had brought, or they followed what Moses had brought, then it is incumbent upon us to believe in them. Al-Rida (AS) replied to him, â€œO Head of the Rabbis! What has prevented you from professing (the Prophethood of) Jesus, the son of Mary? Jesus brought the dead to life, healed the blind and the leprous, made birds formed of clay and breathed life into them with Allahâ€™s permission.â€™â€ The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œIt is said that he did that but we did not see it.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œHave you seen the miracles performed by Moses? Have you not received the news by way of Mosesâ€™s closest trustworthy companions who said he did them?â€ The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œYes. That is so.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œWell. The news about the miracles of Jesus, the son of Mary, have reached you in a similar fashion. Why then did you acknowledge Moses and believe in him, but you did not believe in Jesus?â€ The Head of the Rabbis did not answer. Al-Rida (AS) said: The same is true about Muhammad (SA) and his miracles. The same is true about any other prophet (AS) appointed by Allah. One of the miracles of Muhammad (SA) was that he was a poor hired shepherd. He had not been taught anything. He did not have any teachers. However, the Qurâ€™an which he brought contains the stories of the prophets and the associated news letter by letter. It has narrated news of the past, and the things to come in the future all the way up until the Day of Resurrection. The Qurâ€™an provided information about what people did in hiding or in their homes. The Prophet brought innumerable miracles. The Head of the Rabbis said: â€œNeither the account about Jesus nor that about Muhammad (SA) is considered correct by us. It is not permissible to admit their Prophethood through what is not correct.â€ Al-Rida (AS said: â€œHas the witness who testified for Jesus (AS) and Muhammad (SA) then given false testimony?â€ The Head of the Rabbis did not answer him. Then the Imam (AS) called the Zoroastrian High Priest. Al-Rida (AS) said to him, â€œLet me know about Zoroaster who considered himself to be a prophet. What is your proof of his Prophethood?â€ The Zoroastrian High Priest said: â€œHe performed miracles which no one ever had performed before him. Of course, I have not seen him, but the stories of our ancestors tell us that he made legitimate for us things which others had not made legitimate. Therefore, we follow him.â€ The Imam (AS) asked, â€œYou believed in the stories which came to you about him, so you followed him, did you not?â€ He replied, â€œYes.â€ The Imam (AS) said: This is the case with all other nations. Stories came to them about what the prophets had accomplished, and what Moses, Jesus, and Muhammad (AS) had all brought to them. So why did you not believe in any of these prophets, having believed in Zoroaster through the stories that came to you about him saying that he brought forth what others did not? The Zoroastrian High Priest froze in his place. Then al-Rida (AS) said: â€œO people! If any of you is opposed to Islam, and wants to ask me any questions, then they should ask me and not be shy.â€ `Imran the Sabian, who was an expert in theology, stood up and said: O Scholar of the people! I would not have asked you any questions if you had not invited me to ask. I have been to Kufa, Basra, Syria, and Algeria. There I have met many theologians. However, none of them have been able to establish for me the proof that there is One who has no second other than Him, and that he is One Sole Being. Will you permit me to ask you this question? Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œIf `Imran the Sabian is present among the people here, it must be you.â€ He said: â€œYes. It is I.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œO `Imran! Ask, but I advise you to be fair. Avoid vain talk and nonsense.â€ `Imran said: â€œMy Master! By Allah, I just want you to prove something which I can adhere to for me. Then I need not seek anything else.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œAsk whatever you wish to ask.â€ The crowds moved closer to `Imran and crowded in on him. `Imran the Sabian asked, â€œlet me know of the first thing and what it created.â€ Al-Rida (AS) replied to him. You asked. Now try to understand. As for the One. He has always been One Being. He has no limits nor does He have transient qualities. He will always remain so. Then, without precedence, He created a different creature with transient qualities and various different limits. He neither places it in anything, not did He limit it by anything. He neither created it like anything, nor did He create other things like it. He then created the creatures in various shapes: pure and impure, different and alike, with various colors, flavors and tastes. He did not create them out of a need for them, nor did He create them to attain a higher rank. He did not sense any increase or decrease in Himself due to this creation. O `Imran! Do you understand this? `Imran said: â€œBy Allah, yes my Master!â€ The Imam (AS) added, O `Imran! Know that if He had created what He created due to His need for them, then He would have only created things by which He could fulfill His need. In that case, it would have been better for Him to create several times more than what He created, since the more the helpers there were, the more powerful their master would be. O `Imran! In that case, His need would be a never-ending one. The more He would crate, the more newer needs would appear for Him. That is why we say that He did not create the creatures out of need. Through creation He transfers the needs of some of them to others. And He makes some of them nobler than others without any need of the nobler one or without wanting to take any revenge against those whom He had abased. That is how He has created. `Imran asked, â€œMy Master! Was the Being known to Himself by His Own Self?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: Knowledge of something is required to distinguish it from other things, and to prove its existence through what is negated about it. However, there was nothing else there to oppose Him to make it necessary to negate. Since there was only Him, there was no need to establish limits. O `Imran Do you understand? `Imran said: â€œYes, by Allah, my Master! Then tell me: Through what means did He come to know what He knew. Was it done by conscience or by something else?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œIf His Knowledge was acquired through conscience. Can we place any limit to His Conscience, which will end in recognition? `Imran answered, â€œthere is no way out.â€ The Imam (AS) then asked him, â€œThen what is that conscience?â€ `Imran could not provide any answer. Al-Rida (AS) said: Never mind. O `Imran! If I now ask you about that conscience and whether you can recognize it through another conscience, an you answer in the affirmative, have you not then disproved your own statement and claim? O `Imran! Is it not more proper for you to know that the One cannot be described by a conscience? And that the most that can be said about Him is that He has done something, or created something? He is not such that one can conceive any directions or parts for Him as can be imagined for the creatures and their parts. Understand this and base your proper knowledge on it. `Imran asked, â€œO my Master! Can you let me know what types of limits His creatures have? What are their meanings? And how many varieties of creatures has He created?â€ The Imam (AS) said: You asked. Now understand. In fact, there are six types of limits for His Creatures. These are the unsubtle; the weighable; the visible; those that have no weight, that is, the spirit; those that are visible but are without any weight, are untouchable, subtle, colorless, and tasteless; and the measurable that are the widths, the forms, width and height. Included among them are deeds and movements which make things, act upon them, change them from one state to another, increase them or reduce them. As for deeds and movements, they pass by since they have no more time than that which is ordained for their need. Whenever a deed is finished and the movement is stopped it ends, but its effects remain just like talking, which ends but its effect remains. `Imran said: â€œO my Master! Will you let me know about the Creator? If He is One, there is nothing other than Him, and there is nothing with Him, has He not changed (His Essence) by creating the creatures?â€ Al-Rida (AS) told him, â€œThe Mighty and High does not change through the creation of creatures. The creatures, however, change, due to the changes He has subjected them to.â€ `Imran asked, â€œO my Master! By means of what can we recognize Him\u003Eâ€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œBy means of other than Him.â€ `Imran asked, â€œWhat is other than Him,â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œHis Will, His Name, His Attribute, and everything else that was created, has emerged and is managed (by Him).â€ `Imran said: â€œO my Master! Then what is He?â€ The Imam (AS) replied, â€œHe is Light. That means that He guided His Creatures from among the inhabitants of the heavens and the earth. You have no rights incumbent upon me more than my professing His Unity to you.â€ `Imran said: â€œO my Master! Was He not silent before creating the creatures, and then He spoke?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: Silence doe not exist unless there is some utterance before it. An example of this is that it is not said that the lamp is silent and does not utter; not is it said that the lamp shines, implying that it want to do something to us. The light shining from the lamp is not considered to be the act of the lamp. It is not something separate from the lamp. Therefore, when it is illuminating us we say that it was lit for us, by which we found our way around. Through this example you can find what you are after and become enlightened in your affairs. `Imran said: â€œO my Master! I though that the Ever-Existent changed His State through the act of creation.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: O `Imran! You claim that the Ever-Existent Being can change in some way as a result of His Action. O `Imran! Have you ever seen that the changes in fire change it? Have you ever seen heat burn itself? Have you ever seen an eye see itself? `Imran said: â€œNo, I have not. O my Master! Will you let me know whether He is in the creatures or the creatures are in Him?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: O `Imran! He is greater than that. He is not in the creatures; not are the creatures in Him. He is Exalted above that. I will teach you what you do not know. There is no power and no strength save Allah. Tell me about the mirror: are you in it or is it in you? O `Imran! If neither one of you are in the other; then, how can you see your reflection in it? `Imran said; â€œThrough the light between me and the mirror.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œCan you see more light in the mirror than what you perceive with your own eyes?â€ He answered, â€œYes.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œThen show it to us!â€ It was then that the man was too baffled to say a word. The Imam (AS) said: â€œI do not see the light except that it leads to both of you, the mirror and yourself, without being in either one of you. There are many more examples which the ignorant simply cannot comprehend. Allah is the highest such example.â€ Then the Imam (AS) turned to al-Ma`mun and told him, â€œIt is time to pray.â€ `Imran said: â€œO my Master! Do not interrupt my questions since I am feeling inclined towards you in my heart.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œWe will pray and come back.â€ Then the Imam (AS) stood up. Al-Ma`mun got up as well. Al-Rida (AS) prayed inside and the people prayed outside, led by Muhammad ibn Ja`far. Then the Imam (AS) came out, returned to the meeting called out to `Imran, and said: â€œO `Imran! Ask your questions.â€ `Imran said: â€œO my Master! Will you let me know whether the Unity of Allah, the Mighty and High, is perceived through reality or through description?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: Certainly, Allah is the Only Initiator and the first Ever-Being. He has always been One without anything to accompany Him. He is the Peerless, and there is no second with Him. He is neither definite nor indefinite. He is neither decisive nor allegorical. He is neither mentioned nor forgotten. No name can describe Him. Time cannot measure His beginning. And time cannot measure His End. He has not been standing upon anything else, nor will He be standing upon anything. There is nothing which supports Him. There is nothing on which He leans. He has all these attributes before creating anything, when there was nothing but Him. Whatever you attribute to Him will be originated attributes which are the only means for understanding Him, which anyone possessing understanding can comprehend. Know that innovation, will, and intent are different words that express the same meaning. His foremost innovation, intent and will were the letters which He established as the origin of everything, the evidence for all perceived things, and the separator for all vague things. Everything was separated by these letters; thing such as the names for right and wrong, action and object, meaning and meaningless. All affairs were run based on them. He did not establish any limited meaning for them other than what they were themselves when He originated the letters. He did not establish for them any existence other than themselves since they were originated via innovation. Light is Allahâ€™s first action. He is the Light of the heavens and the earth. It was through that action that the letters became object. They are the letters upon which speech is based. Expressions are all from Allah, the Mighty and High, who taught them to His Creatures. There are thirty-three letters. Twenty-eight of them are the letters on which the Arabic language is based. Twenty-two of Twenty-eight letters show the letters of the Assyrian and Hebrew languages. Five of them were separated, and are in the rest of the languages of non-Arabs in the regions. These are the five letters which were separated from the twenty-eight letters. Therefore, there are thirty-three letters. It is not permissible to mention more about them than what we have mentioned regarding these fie letters which were separated. He then established the letters after counting them and numbering them as His own action, like the Word of the Mighty and High: `Be,â€™ and it is. Here `beâ€™ refers to His Creation, and `what is createdâ€™ refers to the creature. Thus, the first creation by Allah, the Mighty and High, is innovation which has neither weight nor any movement. It is neither heard nor does it have color or touch. And the second thing that was created are the letters which have neither weight nor color. They are neither heard nor described. They are not visible. The third creature includes all the various kinds of things which are perceptible, touchable, tasteable, and visible. Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, existed before innovation as there has been nothing before the Mighty and High, and nothing with him. Innovation was created before the letters were created, and the letters do not indicate anything other than themselves. Al-Ma`mun asked, â€œHow come they do not indicate anything other than themselves?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œVerily, Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, never combines any of them together unless to mean something, When He combines several letters together, say four, five or six or more, He uses them to originate a new meaning which did not exist before.â€ `Imran asked, â€œHow can we understand them?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: This is how it can be understood. When you only want to refer to the letters and not anything else, you mention them one by one and say, a b c d â€¦ to the end. Here you find no meaning in them other than themselves. But when you put several letters together y construct names and attributes for a meaning which you have in mind. They will not demonstrate the meaning for which they were intended. Did you understand this? `Imran said: â€œYes.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: Know that an attribute cannot be without what it describes. Also, a name cannot be without a meaning. A limit cannot be without the limited. All attributes and names indicate perfection and existence. They do not indicate encompassment, as the limits do. Limits make squares, make triangles, and make hexagons. Verily, the recognition of Allah, the Mighty and High, is perceived by attributes and names, not by limits such as length, width, smallness, largeness, color, weight, and the like. No such limits are applicable to Allah, the High and the All-Holy, so that His creatures could recognize Him by recognizing themselves. This is certain as I said: but the attributes of Allah, the Mighty and High, prove Him. He can be understood through His Names. He can be reasoned upon by referring to His creatures. A true seeker doe not need to see Him with his own eyes, hear Him with his own ears, touch Him with his own hands, or encompass Him with his own heart. Were it not the case that His attributes proved Him, Exalted is His Praise, and His Names denoted Him, it was not possible for the taught knowledge of the creatures to perceive Him. Then the creatures would have worshipped His Names and Attributes instead of His meaning. Were it any different, the only worshipped one would have been other than Allah, the Exalted, since his Attributes and Names are other than Him. Did you understand?â€ `Imran said: â€œYes, my Master, Please tell me more.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: Beware of the saying of the ignorant ones, those whose hearts are blind, and who are in loss. They are those who claim that Allah, the Mighty and High and the All-Holy, is present in the hereafter for the Reckoning concerning rewards and punishments, but He is not present in this world for the acts of obedience and hope.â€™ If it were that Allah, the Mighty and Highâ€™s, presence was a source of His being defective in this world. He would not be present in the Hereafter either. However, these people have gone astray and have become blind and deaf towards the truth regarding what they do not know. That is the Word of the Mighty and High: But whosoever is blind in this (world), he shall also be blind in the Hereafter, and more erring from the way, i.e. blindness from existing realities. Intellectuals know that reasoning about what exists in the Hereafter is only possible through what exists in this world. Whoever tries to adopt knowledge of that world based upon his own personal views, and seek its existence, or tries to perceive it through his own soul and not through anything else would only get more distant from the facts about that world. That is because Allah, the Mighty and High, has given the knowledge of that world to a special group of people who think, know, and understand. `Imran asked, â€œO My Master, please inform me: Is innovation a created being or not?â€ Imam al-Rida (AS) answered, It is still creation which cannot be perceived through stillness. It is a created being since it has emerged. And it is Allah who made it emerged. Thus, it has become a creature. In other words, there only exist Allah, the Mighty and High, and His Creatures. There exists no third thing in between, and there is no third thing other than them. Whatever Allah, the Mighty and High, creates dos not disobey from being His Creature. What is crated is ether still, moving, different, harmonious, known, or ambiguous. Whatever is bounded is the creature of Allah, the Mighty and High. Moreover, know that all the things which the senses find for you are meanings perceived by the senses, and every sense demonstrates what Allah, the Mighty and High, has placed in its perception, and the heart understands all of that. Know that the One who is Ever-Standing without any ordination or bounds created creatures ordained by bounds and ordination. What He created were two creatures: the ordination and the ordained. Neither one had any color, taste or weight. He established one as the means of perceived the other and made them such that they could be perceived on their own. He did not create anything which could stand alone relying only on itself, so as to provide a means for arguing about and proving His Existence. Thus, Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, is Peerless and One. There is no second to support Him in order to enable Him to stand, or to assist Him or protect Him. However, the creatures support one another through the permission and will of Allah. People have differences of opinion over this subject to the extent that they have gone astray, become perplexed, and seek salvation from darkness by means of darkness through describing Allah using their own qualities. In this way, they have strayed far from the truth. Had they described Allah, the Mighty and High, using His Attributes, and described the creatures with the qualities of the creatures, they would have spoken through understanding and certitude and would not have come up with so many differences of opinion over Him. Since they sought what would perplex them, they entrapped themselves and became confused. Allah guides whomsoever He wills to the Straight Path. `Imran said: â€œO my Master! I bear witness that He is just as you have described. However, I still have one more question to ask.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œAsk whatever you wish to ask.â€ `Imran said: â€œI want to ask you what the All-Wise is contained in. Has anything encompassed Him? Does He change from one state to another? Is He in need of anything?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: O `Imran! I will tell you, so understand. The one whom you question is the most ambiguous issue which the creatures face. As for those who are deficient in understanding, they do not recognize Him. As for those who are just and can reason, they are not incapable of understanding Him. First of all, if He had created the creatures due to need, then it would be proper to say that He changes His location to the location of what He creates because of His need for them. However, the Mighty and High, has not created anything out of need. He is always stable, neither in something, nor on something. However, it is the creatures which hold each other, enter into one another, and leave one another. Allah, the Mighty and High and the All-Holy, holds all of that by his Might. He does not enter anything and does not leave anything. Its preservation does not tire Him, nor is He incapable of holding it. None of the creatures know how that is, except for Allah, the Mighty and high, and His Messengers, the people who know His Secrets, those who run the affairs, and His Guardians who carry out His laws. In fact, His command is like the twinkling of an eye, or even closer that that. If He wills a thing, He only says to it `Be,â€™ and it is, according to His Will and Intent. Nothing that he has created is closer to Him than any other thing, nor is He father away from anything than another. O `Imran Have you understood? `Imran said: â€œYes, my Master. I have understood. I bear witness that Allah is as you described Him to be and as you have described His Unity. I also bear witness that Muhammad is His Servant, who is appointed to guide and lead to the right religion.â€ He then faced the direction of Mecca, and fell into prostration. Al-Hasan ibn Muhammad al-Nawfali said: When the other rhetoricians heard what `Imran the Sabian said, who was very hard to defeat in arguments and no one had ever defeated him before in arguments, not of them dared approach al-Rida (AS), and they asked him no more questions. It became nightfall. Then al-Ma`mun and al-Rida stood up, went inside and the people left. I was sitting alone with some of my friends when Muhammad ibn Ja`far called me in. I went to see him. He asked me, â€œO Nawfali! Did you see what your friend (the Imam) did?â€ Al-Nawfali replied, â€œNo, by Allah! I did not think that `Ali ibn Musa al-Rida (AS) could plumb such depths. We did not know him in this way. He never spoke about theology in Medina, and theologians never gathered around him.â€ I further said: â€œThe pilgrims used to come to him and ask him about the lawful and the unlawful and he answered them. Sometimes rhetoricians came to him and argued with him.â€ Muhammad ibn Ja`far said: â€œO Abu Muhammad, I fear that this man (al-Ma`mun) will envy him, poison him or inure him. So advise him to refrain from these things.â€ Al-Nawfali added, â€œHe will not listen to me. This man (al-Ma`mun) only intended to test him to see whether he possesses the knowledge of his forefathers.â€ He said to me, â€œTell him that his uncle does not like him to do such things, and wants him to stop them for different characteristics.â€ When we returned to Al-Ridaâ€™s house, I related to him the message from his uncle. Then the Imam smiled and said: â€œMay Allah protect my uncle. I know him well. Why is he upset? Young man! Go to `Imran the Sabian, and bring him here.â€ I said: â€œMay I be your ransom! I know where he is. He is with some of the Shi`ite brethren.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œDo not worry. Get a horse for him to ride on, and bring him here.â€ I went and brought `Imran. The Imam welcomed him, and asked for a robe of honor which he (AS) put on `Imran. The Imam also gave him a horse, and asked for ten thousand dinars which he (AS) donated to `Imran. `Imran said: â€œMay I be your ransom! You have followed in the footsteps of your grandfather, the Commander of the Faithful (AS).â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œWe prefer this.â€ Then the Imam (AS) ordered dinner, had me sit on his right side, and had `Imran sit on his left side. After eating dinner, the Imam (AS) told `Imran, â€œGo now and come back in the morning. Then I will give you food from medina.â€ From then do many people came to `Imran to debate. He used to respond to their arguments and disprove them until they left. Al-Ma`mun granted him ten thousand dirhams. Al-Fadl also gave him some money. Then he appointed him as the director over the alms in (the city of) Balkh where he attained much good.", "arabicText": "1 - Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ù…ÙŠ Ø«Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¥ÙŠÙ„Ø§Ù‚ÙŠ Ø±Ø¶ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† ØµØ¯Ù‚Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ù…ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø¹Ù…Ø±Ùˆ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ø± Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø²ÙŠØ² Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù†ØµØ§Ø±ÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ¬ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø³Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù†ÙˆÙÙ„ÙŠ Ø«Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ø§Ø´Ù…ÙŠØŒ ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„: Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø¯Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù…Ø± Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø¨Ù† Ø³Ù‡Ù„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¬Ù…Ø¹ Ù„Ù‡ Ø£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‚Ø§Ù„Ø§Øª Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ Ùˆ Ø±Ø£Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ù„ÙˆØª ÙˆØ±Ø¤Ø³Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„ØµØ§Ø¨Ø¦ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù‡Ø±Ø¨Ø° Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙƒØ¨Ø± ÙˆØ£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨ Ø²Ø±Ø¯Ù‡Ø´Øª ÙˆÙ‚Ø³Ø·Ø§Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø±ÙˆÙ…ÙŠ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…ØªÙƒÙ„Ù…ÙŠÙ† Ù„ÙŠØ³Ù…Ø¹ ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù‡ ÙˆÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ¬Ù…Ø¹Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø¨Ù† Ø³Ù‡Ù„ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ø§Ø¬ØªÙ…Ø§Ø¹Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ø¯Ø®Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠØŒ ÙÙØ¹Ù„ØŒ ÙØ±Ø­Ø¨ Ø¨Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡Ù…: Ø¥Ù†ÙŠ Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ø¬Ù…Ø¹ØªÙƒÙ… Ù„Ø®ÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø­Ø¨Ø¨Øª Ø£Ù† ØªÙ†Ø§Ø¸Ø±ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù…ÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¯Ù†ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¯Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø¨ÙƒØ±Ù‡ ÙØ§ØºØ¯ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØªØ®Ù„Ù Ù…Ù†ÙƒÙ… Ø£Ø­Ø¯ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø¹ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ø¹Ø© ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ù†Ø­Ù† Ù…Ø¨ÙƒØ±ÙˆÙ† Ø¥Ù† Ø´Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù†ÙˆÙÙ„ÙŠ: ÙØ¨ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ù†Ø­Ù† ÙÙŠ Ø­Ø¯ÙŠØ« Ù„Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¥Ø° Ø¯Ø®Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ†Ø§ ÙŠØ§Ø³Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø§Ø¯Ù… ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠØªÙˆÙ„Ù‰ Ø£Ù…Ø± Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø³ÙŠØ¯ÙŠ Ø¥Ù† Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† ÙŠÙ‚Ø±Ø¦Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„: ÙØ¯Ø§Ùƒ Ø£Ø®ÙˆÙƒ Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ Ø§Ø¬ØªÙ…Ø¹ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠ Ø£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‚Ø§Ù„Ø§Øª ÙˆØ£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¯ÙŠØ§Ù† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…ØªÙƒÙ„Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ù…Ù† Ø¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù„Ù„ ÙØ±Ø£ÙŠÙƒ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¨ÙƒÙˆØ± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø¥Ù† Ø£Ø­Ø¨Ø¨Øª ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ±Ù‡Øª ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù‡Ù… ÙÙ„Ø§ ØªØªØ¬Ø´Ù… ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ø£Ø­Ø¨Ø¨Øª Ø£Ù† Ù†ØµÙŠØ± Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙƒ Ø®Ù Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ†Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø£Ø¨Ù„ØºÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙˆÙ‚Ù„ Ù„Ù‡: Ù‚Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Øª Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø±Ø¯ØªØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù†Ø§ ØµØ§Ø¦Ø± Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙƒ Ø¨ÙƒØ±Ø© Ø¥Ù† Ø´Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡. Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ù†ÙˆÙÙ„ÙŠ Ø£ØªØ®Ø§Ù Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ‚Ø·Ø¹ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø­Ø¬ØªÙŠØŸ Ù‚Ù„Øª: Ù„Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø§ Ø®ÙØª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒ Ù‚Ø· ÙˆØ¥Ù†ÙŠ Ù„Ø£Ø±Ø¬Ùˆ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¸ÙØ±Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ù‡Ù… Ø¥Ù† Ø´Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„ÙŠ: ÙŠØ§ Ù†ÙˆÙÙ„ÙŠ Ø£ØªØ­Ø¨ Ø£Ù† ØªØ¹Ù„Ù… Ù…ØªÙ‰ ÙŠÙ†Ø¯Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ù‚Ù„Øª: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø³Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ø­ØªØ¬Ø§Ø¬ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„ØªÙˆØ±Ø§Ø© Ø¨ØªÙˆØ±Ø§ØªÙ‡Ù… ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ Ø¨Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø²Ø¨ÙˆØ± Ø¨Ø²Ø¨ÙˆØ±Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ØµØ§Ø¨Ø¦ÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ø¹Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù†ÙŠØªÙ‡Ù… ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ø±Ø§Ø¨Ø°Ø© Ø¨ÙØ§Ø±Ø³ÙŠØªÙ‡Ù… ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±ÙˆÙ… Ø¨Ø±ÙˆÙ…ÙŠØªÙ‡Ù… ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‚Ø§Ù„Ø§Øª Ø¨Ù„ØºØ§ØªÙ‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ù‚Ø·Ø¹Øª ÙƒÙ„ ØµÙ†Ù ÙˆØ¯Ø­Ø¶Øª Ø­Ø¬ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØªØ±Ùƒ Ù…Ù‚Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ±Ø¬Ø¹ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¶Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø¨Ø³Ø¨ÙŠÙ„Ù‡ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø¨Ù…Ø³ØªØ­Ù‚ Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ØªÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¯Ø§Ù…Ø© Ù…Ù†Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø­ÙˆÙ„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù‚ÙˆØ© Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ…. ÙÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ø£ØµØ¨Ø­Ù†Ø§ Ø£ØªØ§Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø¨Ù† Ø³Ù‡Ù„ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡: Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Øª ÙØ¯Ø§Ùƒ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ùƒ ÙŠÙ†ØªØ¸Ø±ÙƒØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ø§Ø¬ØªÙ…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ… ÙÙ…Ø§ Ø±Ø£ÙŠÙƒ ÙÙŠ Ø¥ØªÙŠØ§Ù†Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ØªÙ‚Ø¯Ù…Ù†ÙŠ ÙØ¥Ù†ÙŠ ØµØ§Ø¦Ø± Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù†Ø§Ø­ÙŠØªÙƒÙ… Ø¥Ù† Ø´Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø«Ù… ØªÙˆØ¶Ø£ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙˆØ¶ÙˆØ¡ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ„Ø§Ø© ÙˆØ´Ø±Ø¨ Ø´Ø±Ø¨Ø© Ø³ÙˆÙŠÙ‚ ÙˆØ³Ù‚Ø§Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø®Ø±Ø¬ ÙˆØ®Ø±Ø¬Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ø¯Ø®Ù„Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¬Ù„Ø³ ØºØ§Øµ Ø¨Ø£Ù‡Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± ÙÙŠ Ø¬Ù…Ø§Ø¹Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ÙŠÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù‡Ø§Ø´Ù…ÙŠÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆØ§Ø¯ Ø­Ø¶ÙˆØ±ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ø¯Ø®Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù… Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù… Ø¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ø¨Ù†ÙŠ Ù‡Ø§Ø´Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ…Ø§ Ø²Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ ÙˆÙ‚ÙˆÙØ§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¬Ø§Ù„Ø³ Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù„ÙˆØ³ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ù…Ù‚Ø¨Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙŠØ­Ø¯Ø«Ù‡ Ø³Ø§Ø¹Ø©. Ø«Ù… Ø§Ù„ØªÙØª Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù…ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ - Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù…Ù† ÙˆÙ„Ø¯ ÙØ§Ø·Ù…Ø© Ø¨Ù†Øª Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙ†Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙØ£Ø­Ø¨ Ø£Ù† ØªÙƒÙ„Ù…Ù‡ ÙˆØªØ­Ø§Ø¬Ù‡ ÙˆØªÙ†ØµÙÙ‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ØŒ ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† ÙƒÙŠÙ Ø£Ø­Ø§Ø¬ Ø±Ø¬Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ­ØªØ¬ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø£Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ù†ÙƒØ±Ù‡ ÙˆÙ†Ø¨ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ùˆ Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ù‡. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠ ÙØ¥Ù† Ø§Ø­ØªØ¬Ø¬Øª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒ Ø¨Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„Ùƒ Ø£ØªÙ‚Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: ÙˆÙ‡Ù„ Ø£Ù‚Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¯ÙØ¹ Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ø·Ù‚ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ØŸ Ù†Ø¹Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ù‚Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø±ØºÙ… Ø£Ù†ÙÙŠØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø³Ù„ Ø¹Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØ§ÙÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¬ÙˆØ§Ø¨ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ù…Ø§ ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙÙŠ Ù†Ø¨ÙˆØ© Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙˆÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡ Ù‡Ù„ ØªÙ†ÙƒØ± Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø£Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ù‚Ø± Ø¨Ù†Ø¨ÙˆØ© Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ ÙˆÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø¨Ø´Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ Ø£Ù…ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ£Ù‚Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙˆØ§Ø±ÙŠÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ§ÙØ± Ø¨Ù†Ø¨ÙˆØ© ÙƒÙ„ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙ‚Ø± Ø¨Ù†Ø¨ÙˆØ© Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ù„Ù… Ùˆ Ø¨ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ¨Ø´Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ Ø£Ù…ØªÙ‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ø£Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ØªÙ‚Ø·Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø­ÙƒØ§Ù… Ø¨Ø´Ø§Ù‡Ø¯ÙŠ Ø¹Ø¯Ù„ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¨Ù„Ù‰ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ£Ù‚Ù… Ø´Ø§Ù‡Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ù…Ù† ØºÙŠØ± Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ù…Ù„ØªÙƒ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù†Ø¨ÙˆØ© Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ù…Ù…Ù† Ù„Ø§ ØªÙ†ÙƒØ±Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ© ÙˆØ³Ù„Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ù† ØºÙŠØ± Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ù…Ù„ØªÙ†Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù† Ø¬Ø¦Øª Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµÙØ© ÙŠØ§ Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠØŒ Ø£Ù„Ø§ ØªÙ‚Ø¨Ù„ Ù…Ù†ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¯Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‚Ø¯Ù… Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø±ÙŠÙ…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¯Ù„ØŸ Ø³Ù…Ù‡ Ù„ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ø§ ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙÙŠ ÙŠÙˆØ­Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ„Ù…ÙŠØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¨Ø® Ø¨Ø® Ø°ÙƒØ±Øª Ø£Ø­Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ£Ù‚Ø³Ù…Øª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒ Ù‡Ù„ Ù†Ø·Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙˆØ­Ù†Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø±Ø¨ÙŠ ÙˆØ¨Ø´Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯Ù‡ ÙØ¨Ø´Ø±Øª Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙˆØ§Ø±ÙŠÙŠÙ† ÙØ¢Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ø¨Ù‡ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ù‚Ø¯ Ø°ÙƒØ± Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙŠÙˆØ­Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ ÙˆØ¨Ø´Ø± Ø¨Ù†Ø¨ÙˆØ© Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙˆØ¨Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ ÙˆÙˆØµÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠÙ„Ø®Øµ Ù…ØªÙ‰ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ³Ù… Ù„Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ… ÙÙ†Ø¹Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙØ£Ù† Ø¬Ø¦Ù†Ø§Ùƒ Ø¨Ù…Ù† ÙŠÙ‚Ø±Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ ÙØªÙ„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒ Ø°ÙƒØ± Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ ÙˆØ£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ£Ù…ØªÙ‡ Ø£ØªØ¤Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ù‡ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø³Ø¯ÙŠØ¯Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ù„Ù‚Ø³Ø·Ø§Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø±ÙˆÙ…ÙŠ: ÙƒÙŠÙ Ø­ÙØ¸Ùƒ Ù„Ù„Ø³ÙØ± Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù„Ø« Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø­ÙØ¸Ù†ÙŠ Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø§Ù„ØªÙØª Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø£Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ù„ÙˆØª ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡: Ø£Ù„Ø³Øª ØªÙ‚Ø±Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¨Ù„Ù‰ Ù„Ø¹Ù…Ø±ÙŠ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ®Ø° Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙØ± Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù„Ø«ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø°ÙƒØ± Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ ÙˆØ£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ£Ù…ØªÙ‡ Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… ÙØ§Ø´Ù‡Ø¯ÙˆØ§ Ù„ÙŠ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø°ÙƒØ±Ù‡ ÙÙ„Ø§ ØªØ´Ù‡Ø¯ÙˆØ§ Ù„ÙŠØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø±Ø£ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙØ± Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù„Ø« Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø¨Ù„Øº Ø°ÙƒØ± Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ù„Ù… ÙˆÙ‚ÙØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ø¥Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø³Ø£Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ø­Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ ÙˆØ£Ù…Ù‡ Ø£ØªØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ø«Ù… ØªÙ„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø°ÙƒØ± Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ ÙˆØ£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ£Ù…ØªÙ‡ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ø§ ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙŠØ§ Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø±ÙŠÙ…ØŸ! ÙØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ°Ø¨Øª Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙ†Ø·Ù‚ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ ÙƒØ°Ø¨Øª Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ùˆ Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ…ØªÙ‰ Ø£Ù†ÙƒØ±Øª Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙƒØ± ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒ Ø§Ù„Ù‚ØªÙ„ Ù„Ø£Ù†Ùƒ ØªÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù‚Ø¯ ÙƒÙØ±Øª Ø¨Ø±Ø¨Ùƒ ÙˆÙ†Ø¨ÙŠÙƒ ÙˆØ¨ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ÙƒØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù†ÙƒØ± Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø¯ Ø¨Ø§Ù† Ù„ÙŠ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ ÙˆØ¥Ù†ÙŠ Ù„Ù…Ù‚Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø§Ø´Ù‡Ø¯ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¥Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø±Ù‡. Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ Ø³Ù„ Ø¹Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ Ù„ÙƒØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù† Ø­ÙˆØ§Ø±ÙŠ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø±ÙŠÙ… ÙƒÙ… ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø¹Ø¯ØªÙ‡Ù…ØŸ ÙˆØ¹Ù† Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ ÙƒÙ… ÙƒØ§Ù†ÙˆØ§ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø¨ÙŠØ± Ø³Ù‚Ø·ØªØŒ Ø£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙˆØ§Ø±ÙŠÙˆÙ† ÙÙƒØ§Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ø´Ø± Ø±Ø¬Ù„Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† Ø£ÙØ¶Ù„Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ£Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡Ù… Ø£Ù„ÙˆÙ‚Ø§ ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ§Ø±Ù‰ ÙÙƒØ§Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ø«Ù„Ø§Ø«Ø© Ø±Ø¬Ø§Ù„: ÙŠÙˆØ­Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙƒØ¨Ø± Ø¨Ø£Ø¬ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙˆØ­Ù†Ø§ Ø¨Ù‚Ø±Ù‚ÙŠØ³ÙŠØ§ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙˆØ­Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ„Ù…ÙŠ Ø¨Ø²Ø¬Ø§Ù† ÙˆØ¹Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø°ÙƒØ± Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ù„Ù… ÙˆØ°ÙƒØ± Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ£Ù…ØªÙ‡ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø¨Ø´Ø± Ø£Ù…Ø© Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ ÙˆØ¨Ù†ÙŠ Ø¥Ø³Ø±Ø§Ø¦ÙŠÙ„ Ø¨Ù‡. Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù†Ø§ Ù„Ù†Ø¤Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø¢Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ù„Ù… ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù†Ù†Ù‚Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ø§ ÙƒÙ… Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¶Ø¹ÙÙ‡ ÙˆÙ‚Ù„Ø© ØµÙŠØ§Ù…Ù‡ ÙˆØµÙ„Ø§ØªÙ‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ø£ÙØ³Ø¯Øª ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ùƒ ÙˆØ¶Ø¹ÙØª Ø£Ù…Ø±ÙƒØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ ÙƒÙ†Øª Ø¸Ù†Ù†Øª Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù†Ùƒ Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙˆÙƒÙŠÙ Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ù…Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ùƒ: Ø¥Ù† Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ø§ ÙƒÙ… ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø¶Ø¹ÙŠÙØ§ Ù‚Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„ØµÙŠØ§Ù… Ù‚Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ„Ø§Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø£ÙØ·Ø± Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ ÙŠÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù‚Ø· ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù†Ø§Ù… Ø¨Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ù‚Ø·. ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø²Ø§Ù„ ØµØ§Ø¦Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‡Ø±ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„ÙŠÙ„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙÙ„Ù…Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠØµÙˆÙ… ÙˆÙŠØµÙ„ÙŠØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ®Ø±Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ ÙˆØ§Ù†Ù‚Ø·Ø¹. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ø¥Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø³Ø£Ù„Ùƒ Ø¹Ù† Ù…Ø³Ø£Ù„Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø³Ù„ ÙØ¥Ù† ÙƒÙ„ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡Ø§ Ø£Ø¬Ø¨ØªÙƒØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ù†ÙƒØ±Øª Ø£Ù† Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠØ­ÙŠÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØªÙ‰ Ø¨Ø¥Ø°Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ø£Ù†ÙƒØ±Øª Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ù† Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø£Ù† Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø­ÙŠÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØªÙ‰ ÙˆØ£Ø¨Ø±Ø£ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙƒÙ…Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø£Ø¨Ø±Øµ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ Ø±Ø¨ Ù…Ø³ØªØ­Ù‚ Ù„Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙØ¥Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙŠØ³Ø¹ Ù‚Ø¯ ØµÙ†Ø¹ Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ù…Ø§ ØµÙ†Ø¹ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ù…Ø´Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ£Ø­ÙŠÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØªÙ‰ ÙˆØ£Ø¨Ø±Ø£ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙƒÙ…Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø£Ø¨Ø±Øµ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØªØ®Ø°Ù‡ Ø£Ù…ØªÙ‡ Ø±Ø¨Ø§ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ¹Ø¨Ø¯Ù‡ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù‚Ø¯ ØµÙ†Ø¹ Ø­Ø²Ù‚ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ù…Ø§ ØµÙ†Ø¹ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø±ÙŠÙ… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙØ£Ø­ÙŠØ§ Ø®Ù…Ø³Ø© ÙˆØ«Ù„Ø§Ø«ÙŠÙ† Ø£Ù„Ù Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ù…ÙˆØªÙ‡Ù… Ø¨Ø³ØªÙŠÙ† Ø³Ù†Ø©ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø§Ù„ØªÙØª Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø£Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ù„ÙˆØª ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡: ÙŠØ§ Ø±Ø£Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ù„ÙˆØª Ø£ØªØ¬Ø¯ Ù‡Ø¤Ù„Ø§Ø¡ ÙÙŠ Ø´Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ Ø¨Ù†ÙŠ Ø¥Ø³Ø±Ø§Ø¦ÙŠÙ„ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªÙˆØ±Ø§Ø©ØŸ! Ø§Ø®ØªØ§Ø±Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ø®Øª Ù†ØµØ± Ù…Ù† Ø³Ø¨ÙŠ Ø¨Ù†ÙŠ Ø¥Ø³Ø±Ø§Ø¦ÙŠÙ„ Ø­ÙŠÙ† ØºØ²Ø§ Ø¨ÙŠØª Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‚Ø¯Ø³ Ø«Ù… Ø§Ù†ØµØ±Ù Ø¨Ù‡Ù… Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¨Ø§Ø¨Ù„ ÙØ£Ø±Ø³Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… ÙØ£Ø­ÙŠØ§Ù‡Ù… Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªÙˆØ±Ø§Ø© Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯ÙØ¹Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ ÙƒØ§ÙØ± Ù…Ù†ÙƒÙ… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø±Ø£Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ù„ÙˆØª: Ù‚Ø¯ Ø³Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ø§ Ø¨Ù‡ Ùˆ Ø¹Ø±ÙÙ†Ø§Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ØµØ¯Ù‚ØªØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ ÙŠÙ‡ÙˆØ¯ÙŠ Ø®Ø° Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙØ± Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØªÙˆØ±Ø§Ø© ÙØªÙ„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØªÙˆØ±Ø§Ø© Ø¢ÙŠØ§ØªØŒ ÙØ£Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ÙˆØ¯ÙŠ ÙŠØªØ±Ø¬Ø­ Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø¡ØªÙ‡ ÙˆÙŠØªØ¹Ø¬Ø¨ Ø«Ù… Ø£Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ø¤Ù„Ø§Ø¡ ÙƒØ§Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø£Ù… Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù‚Ø¨Ù„Ù‡Ù…ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¨Ù„ ÙƒØ§Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ù‚Ø¨Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù„Ù‚Ø¯ Ø§Ø¬ØªÙ…Ø¹Øª Ù‚Ø±ÙŠØ´ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙØ³Ø£Ù„ÙˆÙ‡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ­ÙŠÙŠ Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ù…ÙˆØªØ§Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙÙˆØ¬Ù‡ Ù…Ø¹Ù‡Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡: Ø§Ø°Ù‡Ø¨ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø¨Ø§Ù†Ø© ÙÙ†Ø§Ø¯ Ø¨Ø£Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ù‡Ø¤Ù„Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‡Ø· Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† ÙŠØ³Ø£Ù„ÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ØµÙˆØªÙƒ ÙŠØ§ ÙÙ„Ø§Ù† Ùˆ ÙŠØ§ ÙÙ„Ø§Ù† ÙˆÙŠØ§ ÙÙ„Ø§Ù† ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡: Ù‚ÙˆÙ…ÙˆØ§ Ø¨Ø¥Ø°Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù…ÙˆØ§ ÙŠÙ†ÙØ¶ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„ØªØ±Ø§Ø¨ Ø¹Ù† Ø±Ø¤ÙˆØ³Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ£Ù‚Ø¨Ù„Øª Ù‚Ø±ÙŠØ´ ØªØ³Ø£Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ù…ÙˆØ±Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±ÙˆÙ‡Ù… Ø£Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ù‚Ø¯ Ø¨Ø¹Ø« Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: ÙˆØ¯Ø¯Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ø¯Ø±ÙƒÙ†Ø§Ù‡ ÙÙ†Ø¤Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ù‚Ø¯ Ø£Ø¨Ø±Ø£ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙƒÙ…Ù‡ Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨Ø±Øµ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø¬Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ† ÙˆÙƒÙ„Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ù‡Ø§Ø¦Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø·ÙŠØ± ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬Ù† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´ÙŠØ§Ø·ÙŠÙ† ÙˆÙ„Ù… Ù†ØªØ®Ø°Ù‡ Ø±Ø¨Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… Ù†Ù†ÙƒØ± Ù„Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ù‡Ø¤Ù„Ø§Ø¡ ÙØ¶Ù„Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ…ØªÙ‰ Ø§ØªØ®Ø°ØªÙ… Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø±Ø¨Ø§ Ø¬Ø§Ø² Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ø£Ù† ØªØªØ®Ø°ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„ÙŠØ³Ø¹ ÙˆØ­Ø²Ù‚ÙŠÙ„ Ø±Ø¨Ø§ Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø¯ ØµÙ†Ø¹Ø§ Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ù…Ø§ ØµÙ†Ø¹ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ù…Ù† Ø¥Ø­ÙŠØ§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØªÙ‰ØŒ ÙˆØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ Ø£Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ù†ÙŠ Ø¥Ø³Ø±Ø§Ø¦ÙŠÙ„ Ù‡Ø±Ø¨ÙˆØ§ Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ù„Ø§Ø¯Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ø¹ÙˆÙ† ÙˆÙ‡Ù… Ø£Ù„ÙˆÙ Ø­Ø°Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØª ÙØ£Ù…Ø§ØªÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø³Ø§Ø¹Ø© ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø©ØŒ ÙØ¹Ù…Ø¯ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ ØªÙ„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±ÙŠØ© ÙØ­Ø¸Ø±ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø­Ø¸ÙŠØ±Ø© ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ù†Ø®Ø±Øª Ø¹Ø¸Ø§Ù…Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØµØ§Ø±ÙˆØ§ Ø±Ù…ÙŠÙ…Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ…Ø± Ø¨Ù‡Ù… Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¡ Ø¨Ù†ÙŠ Ø¥Ø³Ø±Ø§Ø¦ÙŠÙ„ ÙØªØ¹Ø¬Ø¨ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù… ÙˆÙ…Ù† ÙƒØ«Ø±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¸Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙŠØ©ØŒ ÙØ£ÙˆØ­Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£ØªØ­Ø¨ Ø£Ù† Ø£Ø­ÙŠÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ù„Ùƒ ÙØªÙ†Ø°Ø±Ù‡Ù…ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù… ÙŠØ§ Ø±Ø¨ØŒ ÙØ£ÙˆØ­Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ù† Ù†Ø§Ø¯Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£ÙŠØªÙ‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¸Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙŠØ© Ù‚ÙˆÙ…ÙŠ Ø¨Ø¥Ø°Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù…ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ø­ÙŠØ§Ø¡ Ø£Ø¬Ù…Ø¹ÙˆÙ† ÙŠÙ†ÙØ¶ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„ØªØ±Ø§Ø¨ Ø¹Ù† Ø±Ø¤ÙˆØ³Ù‡Ù… . Ø«Ù… Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø®Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù† Ø­ÙŠÙ† Ø£Ø®Ø° Ø§Ù„Ø·ÙŠÙˆØ± ÙˆÙ‚Ø·Ø¹Ù‡Ù† Ù‚Ø·Ø¹Ø§ Ø«Ù… ÙˆØ¶Ø¹ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙƒÙ„ Ø¬Ø¨Ù„ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù† Ø¬Ø²Ø¡Ø§ Ø«Ù… Ù†Ø§Ø¯ÙŠÙ‡Ù† ÙØ£Ù‚Ø¨Ù„Ù† Ø³Ø¹ÙŠØ§ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ø±Ø§Ù† ÙˆØ£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø³Ø¨Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ø®ØªØ§Ø±Ù‡Ù… ØµØ§Ø±ÙˆØ§ Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø¨Ù„ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ù„Ù‡: Ø¥Ù†Ùƒ Ù‚Ø¯ Ø±Ø£ÙŠØª Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø³Ø¨Ø­Ø§Ù†Ù‡ ÙØ£Ø±Ù†Ø§Ù‡ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø±Ø£ÙŠØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡Ù…: Ø¥Ù†ÙŠ Ù„Ù… Ø£Ø±Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: Ù„Ù† Ù†Ø¤Ù…Ù† Ù„Ùƒ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ù†Ø±Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¬Ù‡Ø±Ø©ØŒ ÙØ£Ø®Ø°ØªÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„ØµØ§Ø¹Ù‚Ø© ÙØ§Ø­ØªØ±Ù‚ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù† Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ¨Ù‚ÙŠ Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ ÙˆØ­ÙŠØ¯Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø±Ø¨ Ø§Ø®ØªØ±Øª Ø³Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ† Ø±Ø¬Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ù†ÙŠ Ø¥Ø³Ø±Ø§Ø¦ÙŠÙ„ ÙØ¬Ø¦Øª Ø¨Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ£Ø±Ø¬Ø¹ ÙˆØ­Ø¯ÙŠØŒ ÙÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠØµØ¯Ù‚Ù†ÙŠ Ù‚ÙˆÙ…ÙŠ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ„Ùˆ Ø´Ø¦Øª Ø£Ù‡Ù„ÙƒØªÙ‡Ù… Ù…Ù† Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ ÙˆØ¥ÙŠØ§ÙŠ Ø£ÙØªÙ‡Ù„ÙƒÙ†Ø§ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙØ¹Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙÙ‡Ø§Ø¡ Ù…Ù†Ø§ØŒ ÙØ£Ø­ÙŠØ§Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ù…ÙˆØªÙ‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙƒÙ„ Ø´Ø¦ Ø°ÙƒØ±ØªÙ‡ Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ØªÙ‚Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¯ÙØ¹Ù‡ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„ØªÙˆØ±Ø§Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø²Ø¨ÙˆØ± ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙØ±Ù‚Ø§Ù† Ù‚Ø¯ Ù†Ø·Ù‚Øª Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø­ÙŠÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØªÙ‰ ÙˆØ£Ø¨Ø±Ø£ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙƒÙ…Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø£Ø¨Ø±Øµ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø¬Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ† ÙŠØªØ®Ø° Ø±Ø¨Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙØ§ØªØ®Ø° Ù‡Ø¤Ù„Ø§Ø¡ ÙƒÙ„Ù‡Ù… Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø§Ø¨Ø§ØŒ Ù…Ø§ ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙŠØ§ Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ùƒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡. Ø«Ù… Ø§Ù„ØªÙØª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø£Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ù„ÙˆØª ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ ÙŠÙ‡ÙˆØ¯ÙŠ Ø£Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø£Ø³Ø£Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø´Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ§Øª Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ Ø£Ù†Ø²Ù„Øª Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ø±Ø§Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ù‡Ù„ ØªØ¬Ø¯ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªÙˆØ±Ø§Ø© Ù…ÙƒØªÙˆØ¨Ø§ Ù†Ø¨Ø£ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ ÙˆØ£Ù…ØªÙ‡: Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø¬Ø§Ø¡Øª Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø®ÙŠØ±Ø© Ø£ØªØ¨Ø§Ø¹ Ø±Ø§ÙƒØ¨ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠØ± ÙŠØ³Ø¨Ø­ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¨ Ø¬Ø¯Ø§ Ø¬Ø¯Ø§ ØªØ³Ø¨ÙŠØ­Ø§ Ø¬Ø¯ÙŠØ¯Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ†Ø§Ø¦Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø¯Ø¯ØŒ ÙÙ„ÙŠÙØ±Øº Ø¨Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ø¥Ø³Ø±Ø§Ø¦ÙŠÙ„ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… ÙˆØ¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ù„ÙƒÙ‡Ù… Ù„ØªØ·Ù…Ø¦Ù† Ù‚Ù„ÙˆØ¨Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† Ø¨Ø£ÙŠØ¯ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø³ÙŠÙˆÙØ§ ÙŠÙ†ØªÙ‚Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ù… Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ§ÙØ±Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø£Ù‚Ø·Ø§Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø±Ø¶ØŒ Ù‡ÙƒØ°Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªÙˆØ±Ø§Ø© Ù…ÙƒØªÙˆØ¨ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø±Ø£Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ù„ÙˆØª: Ù†Ø¹Ù… Ø¥Ù†Ø§ Ù„Ù†Ø¬Ø¯Ù‡ ÙƒØ°Ù„ÙƒØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù„Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: ÙŠØ§ Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠ ÙƒÙŠÙ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ùƒ Ø¨ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø´Ø¹ÙŠØ§ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ø¹Ø±ÙÙ‡ Ø­Ø±ÙØ§ Ø­Ø±ÙØ§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ù„Ù‡Ù…Ø§: Ø£ØªØ¹Ø±ÙØ§Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ù† ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù‡: (ÙŠØ§ Ù‚ÙˆÙ… Ø¥Ù†ÙŠ Ø±Ø£ÙŠØª ØµÙˆØ±Ø© Ø±Ø§ÙƒØ¨ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù…Ø§Ø± Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ø³Ø§ Ø¬Ù„Ø§Ø¨ÙŠØ¨ Ø§Ù„Ù†ÙˆØ±ØŒ ÙˆØ±Ø£ÙŠØª Ø±Ø§ÙƒØ¨ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠØ± Ø¶ÙˆØ¤Ù‡ Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø¶ÙˆØ¡ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ù…Ø±)ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„Ø§: Ù‚Ø¯ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø´Ø¹ÙŠØ§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ù‡Ù„ ØªØ¹Ø±Ù ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰: Ø¥Ù†ÙŠ Ø°Ø§Ù‡Ø¨ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø¨ÙŠ ÙˆØ±Ø¨ÙƒÙ… ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙØ§Ø±Ù‚Ù„ÙŠØ·Ø§ Ø¬Ø§Ø¡ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙŠØ´Ù‡Ø¯ Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø´Ù‡Ø¯Øª Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙŠÙØ³Ø± Ù„ÙƒÙ… ÙƒÙ„ Ø´Ø¦ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙŠØ¨Ø¯ÙŠ ÙØ¶Ø§Ø¦Ø­ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙŠÙƒØ³Ø± Ø¹Ù…ÙˆØ¯ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙØ±ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ù…Ø§ Ø°ÙƒØ±Øª Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ Ù…Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ†Ø­Ù† Ù…Ù‚Ø±ÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£ØªØ¬Ø¯ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ Ø«Ø§Ø¨ØªØ§ ÙŠØ§ Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ Ø£Ù„Ø§ ØªØ®Ø¨Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙˆÙ„ Ø­ÙŠÙ† Ø§ÙØªÙ‚Ø¯ØªÙ…ÙˆÙ‡ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ù…Ù† ÙˆØ¬Ø¯ØªÙ…ÙˆÙ‡ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ÙˆØ¶Ø¹ Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡: Ù…Ø§ Ø§ÙØªÙ‚Ø¯Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙˆÙ…Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙˆØ¬Ø¯Ù†Ø§ ØºØ¶Ø§ Ø·Ø±ÙŠØ§ ÙØ£Ø®Ø±Ø¬Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ†Ø§ ÙŠÙˆØ­Ù†Ø§ ÙˆÙ…ØªÙ‰ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ù‚Ù„ Ù…Ø¹Ø±ÙØªÙƒ Ø¨Ø³Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙƒÙ…Ø§ ØªØ²Ø¹Ù… ÙÙ„Ù… Ø§Ø®ØªÙ„ÙØªÙ… ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø®ØªÙ„Ø§Ù ÙÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙÙŠ Ø£ÙŠØ¯ÙŠÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙˆÙ… ÙÙ„Ùˆ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‡Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙˆÙ„ Ù„Ù… ØªØ®ØªÙ„ÙÙˆØ§ ÙÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„ÙƒÙ†ÙŠ Ù…ÙÙŠØ¯Ùƒ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ Ø§Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ø§ÙØªÙ‚Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ø¬ØªÙ…Ø¹Øª Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ§Ø±Ù‰ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ù‡Ù… ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ù„Ù‡Ù…: Ù‚ØªÙ„ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø±ÙŠÙ… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙˆØ§ÙØªÙ‚Ø¯Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ ÙˆØ£Ù†ØªÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ ÙÙ…Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒÙ…ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø£Ù„ÙˆÙ‚Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ø± Ù‚Ø§Ø¨ÙˆØ³: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ ÙÙŠ ØµØ¯ÙˆØ±Ù†Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ø­Ù† Ù†Ø®Ø±Ø¬Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙƒÙ… Ø³ÙØ±Ø§ Ø³ÙØ±Ø§ ÙÙŠ ÙƒÙ„ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ØŒ ÙÙ„Ø§ ØªØ­Ø²Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØªØ®Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ†Ø§Ø¦Ø³ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù†Ø§ Ø³Ù†ØªÙ„ÙˆÙ‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒÙ… ÙÙŠ ÙƒÙ„ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø³ÙØ±Ø§ Ø³ÙØ±Ø§ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ù†Ø¬Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ Ù„ÙƒÙ… ÙƒÙ„Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø¹Ø¯ Ø£Ù„ÙˆÙ‚Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ø± Ù‚Ø§Ø¨ÙˆØ³ ÙˆÙŠÙˆØ­Ù†Ø§ ÙˆÙ…ØªÙ‰ ÙˆÙˆØ¶Ø¹ÙˆØ§ Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ù…Ø§ Ø§ÙØªÙ‚Ø¯ØªÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙˆÙ„ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù‡Ø¤Ù„Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹Ø© ØªÙ„Ø§Ù…ÙŠØ° Ø§Ù„ØªÙ„Ø§Ù…ÙŠØ° Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙ†ØŒ Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù…Øª Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ø£Ù…Ø§ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ÙÙ„Ù… Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØªÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¨Ø§Ù† Ù„ÙŠ Ù…Ù† ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ùƒ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ ÙˆØ³Ù…Ø¹Øª Ø£Ø´ÙŠØ§Ø¡ Ù…Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØªÙ‡ Ø´Ù‡Ø¯ Ù‚Ù„Ø¨ÙŠ Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø­Ù‚ ÙØ§Ø³ØªØ²Ø¯Øª ÙƒØ«ÙŠØ±Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù…. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙÙƒÙŠÙ Ø´Ù‡Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ù‡Ø¤Ù„Ø§Ø¡ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¬Ø§Ø¦Ø²Ø©ØŒ Ù‡Ø¤Ù„Ø§Ø¡ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ ÙˆÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ø§ Ø´Ù‡Ø¯ÙˆØ§ Ø¨Ù‡ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ Ø­Ù‚ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ù„Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø­Ø¶Ø±Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡Ù…: Ø§Ø´Ù‡Ø¯ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: Ù‚Ø¯ Ø´Ù‡Ø¯Ù†Ø§ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ø¨Ø­Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† ÙˆØ£Ù…Ù‡ Ù‡Ù„ ØªØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù† Ù…ØªÙ‰ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: (Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø¯Ø§ÙˆØ¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ø¨Ù† Ø¥Ø³Ø­Ø§Ù‚ Ø¨Ù† ÙŠØ¹Ù‚ÙˆØ¨ Ø¨Ù† ÙŠÙ‡ÙˆØ¯Ø§ Ø¨Ù† Ø­Ø¶Ø±ÙˆÙ† )ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù…Ø±Ù‚Ø§Ø¨ÙˆØ³ ÙÙŠ Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ø© Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† - Ù…Ø±ÙŠÙ…: (Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ ÙƒÙ„Ù…Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ø­Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø¬Ø³Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ø¯Ù…ÙŠ ÙØµØ§Ø±Øª Ø¥Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù†Ø§)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ù„ÙˆÙ‚Ø§: (Ø¥Ù† Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø±ÙŠÙ… ÙˆØ£Ù…Ù‡ ÙƒØ§Ù†Ø§ Ø¥Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ù…Ù† Ù„Ø­Ù… ÙˆØ¯Ù… ÙØ¯Ø®Ù„ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø±ÙˆØ­ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¯Ø³)ØŸ Ø«Ù… Ø¥Ù†Ùƒ ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ù…Ù† Ø´Ù‡Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡: Ø­Ù‚Ø§ Ø£Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ù„ÙƒÙ… ÙŠØ§ Ù…Ø¹Ø´Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙˆØ§Ø±ÙŠÙŠÙ†: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØµØ¹Ø¯ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ø²Ù„ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø±Ø§ÙƒØ¨ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠØ± Ø®Ø§ØªÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¡ ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠØµØ¹Ø¯ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆÙŠÙ†Ø²Ù„ØŒ ÙÙ…Ø§ ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ù„Ø§ Ù†Ù†ÙƒØ±Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ: ÙÙ…Ø§ ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙÙŠ Ø´Ù‡Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø£Ù„ÙˆÙ‚Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ø± Ù‚Ø§Ø¨ÙˆØ³ ÙˆÙ…ØªÙ‰ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù†Ø³Ø¨ÙˆÙ‡ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚: ÙƒØ°Ø¨ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ù‚ÙˆÙ… Ø£Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ù‚Ø¯ Ø²ÙƒØ§Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ´Ù‡Ø¯ Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ ÙˆÙ‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡Ù… Ø­Ù‚ØŸ!
