the servant of the Sam Clan - that Aba Abdullah as-Sadiq (MGB) said, ", "thaqalaynMatn": "â€œOneâ€™s intellect can be measured by three things: long beard, marking on his ring and nickname.â€", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 304, "bookId": "Al-Amali-Mufid", "book": "Al-AmÄlÄ«", "category": "Thirty Third Assembly", "categoryId": "33", "chapter": "The meaning of Islam, Iman and its pillars", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Muá¸¥ammad al-MufÄ«d", "translator": "Mulla Asgharali M M Jaffer", "englishText": "3. He said: Abu Ubaidullah Muhammad ibn Imran al-Marzbani reported to me from Ahmad ibn Sulaiman al-Tusi, from al-Zubair ibn Bakkar, from Abdullah ibn Wahab, from al-Suddi, from Abd Khair, from Qubaisah ibn Jabir al-Asadi, who said: A man visited Amirul Muâ€™mineen â€˜Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him, and questioned him about Faith. So, Imam stood up to deliver this address: \"Praise to Allah who set the laws of Islam, and made its ways easy for whoever arrived at it, and entrenched its basis against those who came to destroy it. And made it an honour for those who supported it, and a security for those who entered it. He made it a guidance for those who followed it, and an adornment for those who adopted it. He made it a protection for those who sought refuge in it, and a strong rope for those who adhered to it. He made it a proof for those who spoke for it, a light for those who sought to be illuminated by it, a strong witness against those who disputed it, and a victory for those who argued for it. He made it a (good) knowledge for those who contained it and a (worthy) tradition for those who narrated about it. He made it the (best) basis of judgement for those who adjudged by it, (full of) wisdom for those who experienced, source of intellect for those who pondered, an understanding for those who grasped, certitude for those who recognized, an insight for those who are intent, a sign for those who perceive, an admonition for those who draw lesson, salvation for those who confirmed its truth. He made it a way of divine love for those who reformed (themselves) and a path of proximity (to Allah) for those who expected it, and a place of trust for those who entrusted. He made it a repose for those who handed over the charge of their affairs (to Allah) and a shield for those who endure. Truth is its way, guidance its (prime) quality, kindness its distinctive feature. It is the most clear path, the towering beacon, the most brilliant light. (Using an equestrian metaphor, he said), It has the highest flag, facile racetrack, an encompassing arena, a contestant for winning the race, and noble horsemen. Confirming the truth is its track, good deeds are its beacons, learning Islam is its light, death is its flag (at the destination), the world is its racetrack, and the Day of Reckoning is its arena; and attaining Paradise its victory, and hellfire its resentment. Taqwa is its implement and people of good deeds are its horsemen. From Faith, one seeks guidance to good and righteous deeds, and with the righteous deeds, learning of Islam is (truly) maintained. And with the knowledge of Islam, death is dreaded, and with death comes the end of (life in) the world. And it is through this world (life) that one passes over to Resurrection, and it will be with the Resurrection, that Paradise will be brought close to the God-fearing, and justify hell for those who have gone astray. So Faith is supported by four pillars: Endurance, Certitude, Justice and struggle (in the way of Allah). And endurance among them is subdivided into four branches: motivation, fear, renunciation and anticipation. Know you that one who is motivated by the yearning for Paradise keeps away from base desires, and one who fears hell abandons the forbidden acts, and one who renounces (by detachment from the) world, finds it easy to face the worldly ordeals, and who anticipates death, hastens to do charitable deeds. And certitude has four branches: intelligent discernment, wise interpretation, drawing lesson from the events, and (studying) the example of the previous generations. So, he who discerns with intelligence will be able to unravel (the secrets of) wisdom, and he who perceives wisdom understands the tradition (handed down) and for he who understands the tradition, it will be as if he belongs to the past generation. And justice has four branches: subtle insight, abundant knowledge, being sensibly judicious and drilled in patience. So he who has an insight, deserves the beauty of knowledge, and he who has knowledge, knows the ways of dispensing justice, and he who is judicious, never goes astray. And he who is patient and enduring never neglects his affairs and thus lives among the people highly appreciated. And struggle (in the way of Allah) has four branches: enjoining good, forbidding evil, being truthful in all situations, and detestation of the impious. So he who enjoins good, lends strength to the believer, and he who forbids evil earns the scorn of the unbelievers; and he who is truthful in all situations (fearlessly) judges against himself, and he who abhors the impious displays anger for the sake of Allah; and he who displays anger for His sake is a true believer. This is then the definition of Faith and its props.\" The questioner rose and said: \"You have indeed guided, O Amirul Muâ€™mineen, and advised. May Allah reward you best on behalf of Islam.\"", "arabicText": "3 - Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø¹Ø¨ÙŠØ¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ø±Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø²Ø¨Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø·ÙˆØ³ÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø²Ø¨ÙŠØ± Ø¨Ù† Ø¨ÙƒØ§Ø± Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ù† ÙˆÙ‡Ø¨ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø¯ÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø®ÙŠØ±ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ù‚Ø¨ÙŠï¿½ï¿½Ø© Ø¨Ù† Ø¬Ø§Ø¨Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø³Ø¯ÙŠ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‚Ø§Ù… Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙØ³Ø£Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø®Ø·ÙŠØ¨Ø§ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø´Ø±Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙØ³Ù‡Ù„ Ø´Ø±Ø§ÙŠØ¹Ù‡ Ù„Ù…Ù† ÙˆØ±Ø¯Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø¹Ø² Ø£Ø±ÙƒØ§Ù†Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ù† Ø¬Ø§Ø² Ø¨Ù‡ ØŒ ÙˆØ¬Ø¹Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø²Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ³Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø¯Ø®Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø¯Ù‰ Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø§Ø¦ØªÙ… Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ²ÙŠÙ†Ø© Ù„Ù…Ù† ØªØ­Ù„Ù‰ Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¹ØµÙ…Ø© Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø§Ø¹ØªØµÙ… Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø¨Ù„Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† ØªÙ…Ø³Ùƒ Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¨Ø±Ù‡Ø§Ù†Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† ØªÙƒÙ„Ù… Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ†ÙˆØ±Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø§Ø³ØªØ¶Ø§Ø¡ Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ´Ø§Ù‡Ø¯Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø®Ø§ØµÙ… Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙÙ„Ø¬Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø­Ø§Ø¬ Ø¨Ù‡ ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† ÙˆØ¹Ø§Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø¯ÙŠØ«Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø±ÙˆØ§Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ­ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† Ù‚Ø¶Ù‰ Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø¬Ø±Ø¨ ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø¨Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† ØªØ¯Ø¨Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† ÙØ·Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ‚ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ù‚Ù„ØŒ ÙˆØ¨ØµÙŠØ±Ø© Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ø²Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ¢ÙŠØ© Ù„Ù…Ù† ØªÙˆØ³Ù… ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ø¨Ø±Ø© Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø§ØªØ¹Ø¸ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ø¬Ø§Ø© Ù„Ù…Ù† ØµØ¯Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆÙ…ÙˆØ¯Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø£ØµÙ„Ø­ ØŒ ÙˆØ²Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø§Ø±ØªÙ‚Ø¨ ØŒ ÙˆØ«Ù‚Ø© Ù„Ù…Ù† ØªÙˆÙƒÙ„ØŒ ÙˆØ±Ø§Ø­Ø© Ù„Ù…Ù† ÙÙˆØ¶ØŒ ÙˆØ¬Ù†Ø© Ù„Ù…Ù† ØµØ¨Ø±. Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ Ø³Ø¨ÙŠÙ„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù‡Ø¯Ù‰ ØµÙØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù†Ù‰ Ù…Ø£Ø«Ø±ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ Ø£Ø¨Ù„Ø¬ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§Ø¬ØŒ Ù…Ø´Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†Ø§Ø± ØŒ Ù…Ø¶Ø¦ Ø§Ù„Ù…ØµØ§Ø¨ÙŠØ­ØŒ Ø±ÙÙŠØ¹ Ø§Ù„ØºØ§ÙŠØ©ØŒ ÙŠØ³ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¶Ù…Ø§Ø±ØŒ Ø¬Ø§Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù„Ø¨Ø©ØŒ Ù…ØªÙ†Ø§ÙØ³ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø¨Ù‚Ø©ØŒ ÙƒØ±ÙŠÙ… Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ø³Ø§Ù†. Ø§Ù„ØªØµØ¯ÙŠÙ‚ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§Ø¬Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØµØ§Ù„Ø­Ø§Øª Ù…Ù†Ø§Ø±Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙÙ‚Ù‡ Ù…ØµØ§Ø¨ÙŠØ­Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØª ØºØ§ÙŠØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ Ù…Ø¶Ù…Ø§Ø±Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ø­Ù„Ø¨ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø© Ø³Ø¨Ù‚ØªÙ‡ ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø± Ù†Ù‚Ù…ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ‰ Ø¹Ø¯ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø­Ø³Ù†ÙˆÙ† ÙØ±Ø³Ø§Ù†Ù‡. ÙØ¨Ø§Ù„Ø¥ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† ÙŠØ³ØªØ¯Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ØµØ§Ù„Ø­Ø§ØªØŒ ÙˆØ¨Ø§Ù„ØµØ§Ù„Ø­Ø§Øª ÙŠØ¹Ù…Ø± Ø§Ù„ÙÙ‚Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¨Ø§Ù„ÙÙ‚Ù‡ ÙŠØ±Ù‡Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØªØŒ ÙˆØ¨Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØª ØªØ®ØªÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ØŒ [ÙˆØ¨Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ ØªØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© ] ÙˆØ¨Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© ØªØ²Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø© Ù„Ù„Ù…ØªÙ‚ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØªØ¨Ø±Ø² Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø­ÙŠÙ… Ù„Ù„ØºØ§ÙˆÙŠÙ†. ÙØ§Ù„Ø¥ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ Ø¯Ø¹Ø§Ø¦Ù…: Ø§Ù„ØµØ¨Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ø¯Ù„ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬Ù‡Ø§Ø¯. ÙˆØ§Ù„ØµØ¨Ø± Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ Ø´Ø¹Ø¨: Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙˆÙ‚ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø´ÙØ§Ù‚ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø²Ù‡Ø§Ø¯Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„ØªØ±Ù‚Ø¨. Ø£Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ø´ØªØ§Ù‚ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø© Ø³Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø´Ù‡ÙˆØ§ØªØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø£Ø´ÙÙ‚ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø± Ø±Ø¬Ø¹ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø­Ø±Ù…Ø§ØªØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø²Ù‡Ø¯ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ Ù‡Ø§Ù†Øª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…ØµÙŠØ¨Ø§Øª ØŒ [ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø§Ø±ØªÙ‚Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØª Ø³Ø§Ø±Ø¹ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙŠØ±Ø§Øª. ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ Ø´Ø¹Ø¨: Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ØªØ¨ØµØ±Ø© Ø§Ù„ÙØ·Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØªØ£ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø© ØŒ Ùˆ Ù…ÙˆØ¹Ø¸Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø±Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ³Ù†Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙ†. ÙÙ…Ù† ØªØ¨ØµØ± ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙØ·Ù†Ø© ØªØ¨ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØªØ¨ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø© Ø¹Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø¹Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù†Ø© ÙÙƒØ£Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙ†. ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ø¯Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ Ø´Ø¹Ø¨: Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ØºØ§Ù…Ø¶ Ø§Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù… ØŒ ÙˆØºÙ…Ø±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ²Ù‡Ø±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ… ÙˆØ±ÙˆØ¶Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù„Ù…. ÙÙ…Ù† ÙÙ‡Ù… ÙØ³Ø± Ø¬Ù…Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø¹Ø±Ù Ø´Ø±Ø§ÙŠØ¹ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø¹Ø±Ù Ø´Ø±Ø§ÙŠØ¹ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ… Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¶Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø­Ù„Ù… Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙØ±Ø· [ÙÙŠ] Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù‡ ÙˆØ¹Ø§Ø´ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø­Ù…ÙŠØ¯Ø§. ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬Ù‡Ø§Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ Ø´Ø¹Ø¨: Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø± Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹Ø±ÙˆÙØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†Ù‡ÙŠ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†ÙƒØ±ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØµØ¯Ù‚ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ§Ø·Ù†ØŒ ÙˆØ´Ù†Ø¢Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ø³Ù‚ÙŠÙ†. ÙÙ…Ù† Ø£Ù…Ø± Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹Ø±ÙˆÙ Ø´Ø¯ Ø¸Ù‡Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ù†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†ÙƒØ± Ø£Ø±ØºÙ… Ø£Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ§ÙØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØµØ¯Ù‚ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ§Ø·Ù† Ù‚Ø¶Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø´Ù†Ø¦ Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ø³Ù‚ÙŠÙ† ØºØ¶Ø¨ Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØºØ¶Ø¨ Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù† Ø­Ù‚Ø§. ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ ØµÙØ© Ø§Ù„Ø¥ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† ÙˆØ¯Ø¹Ø§Ø¦Ù…Ù‡. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø¦Ù„: Ù„Ù‚Ø¯ Ù‡Ø¯ÙŠØª ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ£Ø±Ø´Ø¯ØªØŒ ÙØ¬Ø²Ø§Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø®ÙŠØ±Ø§] . ", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/13/33/3/1", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 3, "thaqalaynSanad": "3. He said: Abu Ubaidullah Muhammad ibn Imran al-Marzbani reported to me from Ahmad ibn Sulaiman al-Tusi, from al-Zubair ibn Bakkar, from Abdullah ibn Wahab, from al-Suddi, from Abd Khair, from Qubaisah ibn Jabir al-Asadi, who said:", "thaqalaynMatn": " A man visited Amirul Muâ€™mineen â€˜Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him, and questioned him about Faith. So, Imam stood up to deliver this address: \"Praise to Allah who set the laws of Islam, and made its ways easy for whoever arrived at it, and entrenched its basis against those who came to destroy it. And made it an honour for those who supported it, and a security for those who entered it. He made it a guidance for those who followed it, and an adornment for those who adopted it. He made it a protection for those who sought refuge in it, and a strong rope for those who adhered to it. He made it a proof for those who spoke for it, a light for those who sought to be illuminated by it, a strong witness against those who disputed it, and a victory for those who argued for it. He made it a (good) knowledge for those who contained it and a (worthy) tradition for those who narrated about it. He made it the (best) basis of judgement for those who adjudged by it, (full of) wisdom for those who experienced, source of intellect for those who pondered, an understanding for those who grasped, certitude for those who recognized, an insight for those who are intent, a sign for those who perceive, an admonition for those who draw lesson, salvation for those who confirmed its truth. He made it a way of divine love for those who reformed (themselves) and a path of proximity (to Allah) for those who expected it, and a place of trust for those who entrusted. He made it a repose for those who handed over the charge of their affairs (to Allah) and a shield for those who endure. Truth is its way, guidance its (prime) quality, kindness its distinctive feature. It is the most clear path, the towering beacon, the most brilliant light. (Using an equestrian metaphor, he said), It has the highest flag, facile racetrack, an encompassing arena, a contestant for winning the race, and noble horsemen. Confirming the truth is its track, good deeds are its beacons, learning Islam is its light, death is its flag (at the destination), the world is its racetrack, and the Day of Reckoning is its arena; and attaining Paradise its victory, and hellfire its resentment. Taqwa is its implement and people of good deeds are its horsemen. From Faith, one seeks guidance to good and righteous deeds, and with the righteous deeds, learning of Islam is (truly) maintained. And with the knowledge of Islam, death is dreaded, and with death comes the end of (life in) the world. And it is through this world (life) that one passes over to Resurrection, and it will be with the Resurrection, that Paradise will be brought close to the God-fearing, and justify hell for those who have gone astray. So Faith is supported by four pillars: Endurance, Certitude, Justice and struggle (in the way of Allah). And endurance among them is subdivided into four branches: motivation, fear, renunciation and anticipation. Know you that one who is motivated by the yearning for Paradise keeps away from base desires, and one who fears hell abandons the forbidden acts, and one who renounces (by detachment from the) world, finds it easy to face the worldly ordeals, and who anticipates death, hastens to do charitable deeds. And certitude has four branches: intelligent discernment, wise interpretation, drawing lesson from the events, and (studying) the example of the previous generations. So, he who discerns with intelligence will be able to unravel (the secrets of) wisdom, and he who perceives wisdom understands the tradition (handed down) and for he who understands the tradition, it will be as if he belongs to the past generation. And justice has four branches: subtle insight, abundant knowledge, being sensibly judicious and drilled in patience. So he who has an insight, deserves the beauty of knowledge, and he who has knowledge, knows the ways of dispensing justice, and he who is judicious, never goes astray. And he who is patient and enduring never neglects his affairs and thus lives among the people highly appreciated. And struggle (in the way of Allah) has four branches: enjoining good, forbidding evil, being truthful in all situations, and detestation of the impious. So he who enjoins good, lends strength to the believer, and he who forbids evil earns the scorn of the unbelievers; and he who is truthful in all situations (fearlessly) judges against himself, and he who abhors the impious displays anger for the sake of Allah; and he who displays anger for His sake is a true believer. This is then the definition of Faith and its props.\" The questioner rose and said: \"You have indeed guided, O Amirul Muâ€™mineen, and advised. May Allah reward you best on behalf of Islam.\"", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 75, "bookId": "Al-Tawhid-Saduq", "book": "Al-Tawá¸¥Ä«d", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "2", "chapter": "The Definition of One, Divine Unity, and the Believer in Divine Unity", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Sayed Ali Raza Rizvi", "englishText": "3. Muhammad ibn Ibrahim ibn Ishaq al-Taliqani (RA) said: Muhammad ibn Sa`id ibn Yahya al-Buzuri said: Ibrahim ibn al-Haytham al-Baladi said: My father said on the authority of alMu`afi ibn `Imran, on the authority of Isra`il, on the authority of al-Miqdad ibn Shurayh ibn Haniâ€™, on the authority of his father that On the Day of Battle of Jamal, a Bedouin stood before the Commander of the Faithful (AS), and asked, â€œO Commander of the Faithful! Do you say that Allah is One?â€ He says: the people attacked him saying that â€œO Bedouin! Do you not see the state of mind of the Commander of the Faithful?â€ So the Commander of the Faithful (AS) said: â€œLeave him alone. Verily, what this Bedouin seeks to know is what we are seeking to establish by fighting these people.â€ He (the Commander of the Faithful) then said: O Bedouin! The statement that `Allah is Oneâ€™ is of four types: Two types cannot be applied to Allah, the Mighty and High; while the two other types can be applied to Him. As for the two types of statements that cannot be applied to Him, the first is the claim that Allah is One in a numerical sense. Such a statement cannot be applied to Allah, because as the One, He has no second, and He is not subject to mathematic calculation. Do you not see that he who claims that Allah is the third of the three has disbelieved (in Him)? The second statement which cannot be applied to Allah is the claim that He is One with humankind. Since He derives the species from the genus, He cannot be described through anthropomorphism [tashbih]. Our Lord is Higher and more Exalted than this. As for the two types of statements that can be applied to Allah, the first would be to say that He is the One who resembles none. The second statement which can apply to Allah is the statement that He, the Mighty and High, is Alone, in the sense that He is Indivisible in Existence [wujud], Intellect [`aql], and Thought [wahm]. That is another dignified description of our Lord, he Mighty and High. The Compiler of this book says: I have heard the following from a person I trust due to the fact that he is religious and due to his mastery of both Classical and colloquial Arabic: Verily, the words one, two three, and so forth, were developed in order to express quantity, and not to express quality. They have no meaning outside of counting, and determining units of measure in the tens, hundreds, and thousands. Likewise, when someone intends to inform another person about the exact quantity of a thing, he names it by its specific name, and applies the number `oneâ€™ to it, describing its quantity, as opposed to its attributes. This is why one says: one pound [dirham], and one intends only a pound, while it could be a pound in weight or a pound in number. So, if the persons want to convey the meaning of weight, he would say: one pound in weight, but if he wants to convey the meaning of number, he says; one pound in number. On the basis, if a person says â€œone man,â€ the man can be one in the sense that he is one human being, as opposed to two. Or, he could be unique in merits, unique in knowledge, unique in generosity or unique in bravery. Thus, if a person intends to convey the sense of quantity, he says: â€œone man;â€ in the sense that he is one man as opposed to two men. However, if he intends to describe someoneâ€™s excellence, he says: he is one of a kind (there is no `oneâ€™ like him). This indicates that nobody compares to him. If he wanted to stress the knowledge of a person, he would say: he is unique in knowledge. Hence, since the word `oneâ€™ can indicate excellence, as well as quantity, it means that whoever called him `oneâ€™ under these circumstances meant that there he had no second. In other words, there was no scholar like him, and no person like him in quality. When this is not the case, then it is correct to say that `oneâ€™ merely indicates quantity. Otherwise, there, would be no sense in saying `one of a kindâ€™ or limiting the meaning of knowledge or bravery. It has been established that when a person uses the word â€œoneâ€ on its own, it indicates quantity. However, depending on the context, it can also mean â€œoneâ€ or â€œuniqueâ€ in knowledge, excellence, and generosity. As we have already explained, `oneâ€™ pound [dirham] can be one pound in weight, one pound in number or count. It can also be two pounds in weight, and one pound in number or count. Sometimes it is six dawaniq,1 and sixty fulus,2 and has many fractions. Likewise, a slave can be one salve, and not two slaves; a person can be one person, and not two people, when in reality they are composed of many parts which are composed of many more parts. In this sense, the slave cannot be `one.â€™ Verily, the slave is not one or unique [wahid], because every slave has someone who is similar to him. It makes perfect sense for a slave to have someone who is the same as him in attributes and qualities. Hence it is necessary that Allah, the Mighty and High, be Unique in His Attributes and Most Beautiful Names. This is what makes Him truly One God, who has no likeness; the One, who has no associates; and there is no god but He. Therefore, Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, is the One, the Eternal3 [qadim], and there is no god but He. He is Unique, none is eternal but He, the Existing, who does not change, and is not subject to change. He is the One beyond compare. Nothing is similar to Him. Nothing resembles Him. And nothing is like Him. Thus, He is an Indivisible Being in both Essence and Imagination, a Think unlike other Things, and the One and Only True God. There is no god but Him! In conclusion, in Islamic Law, the titles the One [Wahid], and the Unique [Ahad], apply specifically to Him, and are excluded from others. None but Allah, the Mighty and High, can bear these titles. And, as we have already explained, Allah is a name which can only applied to Him. In addition to these examples, a thing can sometimes be counted with something which is similar to it. It is said: this is a man, these are two men, and these are three men; this is a slave, this is black, these are two slaves, these two are black. Therefore, it is not permissible to say: these are two gods as there is no god but the One God. Thus, Allah cannot be counted in this manner, nor does He enter numbers in this form in any way. Sometimes a thing is counted with something different to it. Hence, it is said: this is the color white, these are white and black colors; this is a recent one [muhdath], these are two recent ones; these are not two ones, and these are not two creatures; One of them is Eternal, and the other is recent; one of them is the Lord, and the other is the servant. So, on this basis, it is acceptable to apply numbers to Him as Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, has said: Nowhere is there a secret counsel between three persons but He is the Fourth of them, not (between) five but He is the Sixth of them, nor less than that nor more but He is with them wheresoever they are.1 Similarly, the statement `Verilyâ€™, he is `one manâ€™ does not merely stress his excellence. Likewise, our statement, `so and so in number two to so and so,â€™ does not simply indicate that he exist. It only does so when it is specified that `he is second to him in excellence, in perfection, or in knowledge.â€™ As for the Unity of Allah, Exalted is His Remembrance, it refers to the Unity between His Exalted Attribute, and His Most Beautiful Names. He is One, without associates, and without similarity. He who affirms this about the Mighty and High on the basis of His Exalted Attribute and Most Beautiful Names with conviction is a true monotheist. Hence, the one who fails to recognize Allah, the Mighty and High, through his Exalted Attributes, and Most Beautiful Names, does not affirm His Oneness, and is not a true monotheist. Sometimes the ignorant people say: Verily, a monotheist is one who professes the Oneness of Allah even if He does profess the Unity of His Attributes. The ignorant people are told: You have rejected Divine Unity. Whoever claims that His Lord is One God, and One Being, and then applies His Attributes to other than Him, is an idolater, an anthropomorphist, and a nonMuslim according to the consensus of every school of thought in the Ummah. Such is the case, even if he claims that His Lord id One God, One Thing and One Being. Accepting Divine Unity, while failing to accept the Divine Attributes, is like saying Allah is separate from His Attributes whereas Divine Unity is the Unity between Allah and His Attributes. I is impossible for another god to exist. Allah is One God without partners, and without similarity. If He was not United with His Attributes, then he would have an associate or something similar to Him. Likewise, if a servant did not embody him own attributes, another servant would have to exist. As a result, he would not be one servant, but two servants. Hence, anyone who professes that Allah is One with His Attributes is a true monotheist, and a Believer in Divine Unity. Allah, the Mighty and High, unites every attribute which is applicable exclusively to Him. These attributes include the Existent since it cannot be conceive that He can dissolve into something or that something can dissolve into Him. Nor is it conceivable that His Existence can come to an end, that He can be destroyed, or that He can suffer any type of decline. He is the First of the First, the Last of the Last, and the Omnipotent. He is not subject to weakness or inability. He is the Most Powerful of the Powerful, and the Subduer [qahir] of all Subduers. He is Omniscient: nothing is hidden from Him, and nothing escapes Him. He is the Most Learned of the Learned. Ignorance, mistakes, errors, doubts, and forgetfulness cannot be attributed to Him. He is the Ever-Living. He is not subject to sleep or death. Nothing benefits Him nor can anything harm Him. He is the One who Remains, the Most Complete of the Complete, and the Doer who is never occupied. Nothing incapacitates Him nor does He miss anything. He is the Lord of the First and Last, the Best of Creators, and the Foremost of those who take account. He is the Wealthy One [ghani], devoid of nothing. He is the Self-Sufficient [mustaghni], devoid of need. He is the Just, devoid of criticism and defects. He is the Wise One, devoid of foolishness. He is the Most Merciful, whose Mercy cannot be increased kindness.2 He is the Forbearing [halim], devoid of emotion and haste. He is the Most Just of the Just, the Best of Judges, and the Foremost of those who take Account. This is because the first of the First cannot be but One. He is the Omnipotent, the Most Learned, the Best of Judges, the Best of Creators, and all such descriptions are correct. Favor is from Allah, as is protection and guidance.", "arabicText": "3 - Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ø¨Ù† Ø¥Ø³Ø­Ø§Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ø±Ø¶ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø³Ø¹ÙŠØ¯ Ø¨Ù† ÙŠØ­ÙŠÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø²ÙˆØ±ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù‡ÙŠØ«Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ù„Ø¯ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ø¨ÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹Ø§ÙÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ø±Ø§Ù†ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¥Ø³Ø±Ø§Ø¦ÙŠÙ„ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‚Ø¯Ø§Ù… Ø¨Ù† Ø´Ø±ÙŠØ­ Ø¨Ù† Ù‡Ø§Ù†Ø¦ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¥Ù† Ø£Ø¹Ø±Ø§Ø¨ÙŠØ§ Ù‚Ø§Ù… ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù…Ù„ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± - Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ø£ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ­Ù…Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ø¹Ø±Ø§Ø¨ÙŠ Ø£Ù…Ø§ ØªØ±Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ù…Ù† ØªÙ‚Ø³Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ù„Ø¨ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø¯Ø¹ÙˆÙ‡ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¹Ø±Ø§Ø¨ÙŠ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù†Ø±ÙŠØ¯Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ…ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ø¹Ø±Ø§Ø¨ÙŠ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙÙŠ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹Ø© Ø£Ù‚Ø³Ø§Ù…: ÙÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ø§Ù† Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ²Ø§Ù† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ØŒ Ùˆ ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ø§Ù† ÙŠØ«Ø¨ØªØ§Ù† ÙÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙØ£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ø°Ø§Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ²Ø§Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„: ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ ÙŠÙ‚ØµØ¯ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¹Ø¯Ø§Ø¯ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ²ØŒ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø®Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¹Ø¯Ø§Ø¯ØŒ Ø£Ù…Ø§ ØªØ±Ù‰ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙƒÙØ± Ù…Ù† Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø«Ø§Ù„Ø« Ø«Ù„Ø§Ø«Ø©. ÙˆÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„: Ù‡Ùˆ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ØŒ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù†ÙˆØ¹ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø³ØŒ ÙØ¨Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ØªØ´Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø±Ø¨Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ùˆ ØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ . ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ø°Ø§Ù† ÙŠØ«Ø¨ØªØ§Ù† ÙÙŠÙ‡ ÙÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„: Ù‡Ùˆ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø´ÙŠØ§Ø¡ Ø´Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø±Ø¨Ù†Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ØŒ ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ†Ù‚Ø³Ù… ÙÙŠ ÙˆØ¬ÙˆØ¯ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¹Ù‚Ù„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙˆÙ‡Ù… ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø±Ø¨Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù…ØµÙ†Ù Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨: Ø³Ù…Ø¹Øª Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø«Ù‚ Ø¨Ø¯ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ø¹Ø±ÙØªÙ‡ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù„ØºØ© ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„: Ø¥Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„: ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø«Ù†ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ«Ù„Ø§Ø«Ø© Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ù‡ Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙˆØ¶Ø¹ ÙÙŠ Ø£ØµÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„ØºØ© Ù„Ù„Ø¥Ø¨Ø§Ù†Ø© Ø¹Ù† ÙƒÙ…ÙŠØ© Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ù„Ø§ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø³Ù…Ù‰ ÙŠØªØ³Ù…Ù‰ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø³ÙˆÙ‰ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØªØ¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù† Ø¨Ù…Ø¹Ø±ÙØ© Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ø§Ø¨ ÙˆÙŠØ¯ÙˆØ± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¹Ù‚Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø£ØµØ§Ø¨Ø¹ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø¶Ø¨Ø· Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ø­Ø§Ø¯ Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø´Ø±Ø§Øª ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø¦Ø§Øª Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù„ÙˆÙØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…ØªÙ‰ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ®Ø¨Ø± ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ Ø¹Ù† ÙƒÙ…ÙŠØ© Ø´Ø¦ Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ Ø³Ù…Ø§Ù‡ Ø¨Ø§Ø³Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø®Øµ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø±Ù† Ù„ÙØ¸ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‚Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙŠØ¯Ù„ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙƒÙ…ÙŠØªÙ‡ Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ø¯Ø§ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ù† Ø£ÙˆØµØ§ÙÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø£Ø¬Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„: Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ù… ÙÙ‚Ø·ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ù… Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ²Ù†ØŒ ÙˆØ¯Ø±Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¶Ø±Ø¨ØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø®Ø¨Ø± Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ®Ø¨Ø± Ø¹Ù† ÙˆØ²Ù†Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ²Ù†ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ®Ø¨Ø± Ø¹Ù† Ø¹Ø¯Ø¯Ù‡ ÙˆØ¶Ø±Ø¨Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¯Ø¯ ÙˆØ¯Ø±Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¶Ø±Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø£ØµÙ„ ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„: Ù‡Ùˆ Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ø¨Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø¥Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù† ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ø¨Ø¥Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ±Ø¬Ù„ ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ø¨Ø±Ø¬Ù„ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ´Ø®Øµ ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ø¨Ø´Ø®ØµÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø®Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¬Ø§Ø¹Ø©ØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ®Ø¨Ø± Ø¹Ù† ÙƒÙ…ÙŠØªÙ‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡Ùˆ Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŒ ÙØ¯Ù„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø¨Ø±Ø¬Ù„ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ®Ø¨Ø± Ø¹Ù† ÙØ¶Ù„Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø¹ØµØ±Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¯Ù„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¯Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ„Ùˆ Ø¯Ù„ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡: ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø¨Ù…Ø¬Ø±Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø¯Ù„ Ø¨Ù…Ø¬Ø±Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ…ÙŠØ© Ù„ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø·Ù„Ù‚ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù„ÙØ¸ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ ÙØ§Ø¶Ù„Ø§ Ù„Ø§ Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ ÙØ¶Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ ÙˆØ¬ÙˆØ§Ø¯Ø§ Ù„Ø§ Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø¬ÙˆØ¯Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ ØµØ­ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø¨Ù…Ø¬Ø±Ø¯Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ù„ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙƒÙ…ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ ÙˆØ¥Ù„Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø¶ÙŠÙ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„: ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø¹ØµØ±Ù‡ ÙˆØ¯Ù‡Ø±Ù‡ Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù„ØªÙ‚ÙŠÙŠØ¯Ù‡ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´Ø¬Ø§Ø¹Ø© Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ØŒ Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠØ¯Ù„ Ø¨ØºÙŠØ± ØªÙ„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø²ÙŠØ§Ø¯Ø© ÙˆØ¨ØºÙŠØ± Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‚ÙŠÙŠØ¯ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ØºØ§ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ ÙˆØºØ§ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´Ø¬Ø§Ø¹Ø©ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ø­ØªÙŠØ¬ Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø²ÙŠØ§Ø¯Ø© Ù„ÙØ¸ Ùˆ Ø§Ø­ØªÙŠØ¬ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‚ÙŠÙŠØ¯ Ø¨Ø´Ø¦ ØµØ­ Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ù„Ù†Ø§Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ ØªÙ‚Ø±Ø± Ø£Ù† Ù„ÙØ¸Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„: ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ù‚ÙŠÙ„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ Ø¯Ù„ Ø¨Ù…Ø¬Ø±Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙƒÙ…ÙŠØªÙ‡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ø³Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø®ØµØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ¯Ù„ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙ‚ØªØ±Ù† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙƒÙ…Ø§Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‰ ØªÙˆØ­Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¨ÙØ¶Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ ÙˆØ¬ÙˆØ¯Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØªØ¨ÙŠÙ† Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù‚Ø¯ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ù…Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ²Ù†ØŒ ÙˆØ¯Ø±Ù‡Ù…Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¯Ø¯ ÙˆØ¯Ø±Ù‡Ù…Ø§ ÙˆØ­Ø¯Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¶Ø±Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ²Ù† Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ù…ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ¨Ø§Ù„Ø¶Ø±Ø¨ Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ù…Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙˆØ§Ù†ÙŠÙ‚ Ø³ØªØ© Ø¯ÙˆØ§Ù†ÙŠÙ‚ ÙˆØ¨Ø§Ù„ÙÙ„ÙˆØ³ Ø³ØªÙŠÙ† ÙÙ„Ø³Ø§ ÙˆÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¬Ø²Ø§Ø¡ ÙƒØ«ÙŠØ±Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø¨ÙˆØ¬Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø´Ø®ØµØ§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø´Ø®ØµÙŠÙ† Ø¨ÙˆØ¬Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø£Ø¬Ø²Ø§Ø¡ ÙƒØ«ÙŠØ±Ø© ÙˆØ£Ø¨Ø¹Ø§Ø¶Ø§ ÙƒØ«ÙŠØ±Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙƒÙ„ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø¨Ø¹Ø§Ø¶Ù‡ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¬ÙˆØ§Ù‡Ø± ÙƒØ«ÙŠØ±Ø© Ù…ØªØ­Ø¯Ø© Ø§ØªØ­Ø¯ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ù‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶ØŒ ÙˆØªØ±ÙƒØ¨ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ø¹ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ ÙˆØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙƒÙ„ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù†Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ù…Ø«Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ¬ÙˆØ¯ Ø£Ùˆ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‚Ø¯ÙˆØ±ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ØµØ­ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù„Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØªÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ø¨Ø£ÙˆØµØ§ÙÙ‡ Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø¬Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ØµØ§Ø± Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ Ù…Ù…Ù„ÙˆÙƒØ§ØŒ ÙˆÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ù„Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù…ØªÙˆØ­Ø¯Ø§ Ø¨Ø£ÙˆØµØ§ÙÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙˆØ£Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù†Ù‰ØŒ Ù„ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¥Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø«Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ù„Ø§ Ø´Ø±ÙŠÙƒ Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù„Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù‡ÙˆØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ÙŠÙ… ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù„Ø§ Ù‚Ø¯ÙŠÙ… Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù‡ÙˆØŒ ÙˆÙ…ÙˆØ¬ÙˆØ¯ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ø¨Ø­Ø§Ù„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ù„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…ÙˆØ¬ÙˆØ¯ ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù‡ÙˆØŒ ÙˆØ´Ø¦ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬Ø§Ù†Ø³Ù‡ Ø´Ø¦ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§ÙƒÙ„Ù‡ Ø´Ø¦ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø¨Ù‡Ù‡ Ø´Ø¦ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø´Ø¦ ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù‡ÙˆØŒ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…ÙˆØ¬ÙˆØ¯ ØºÙŠØ± Ù…Ù†Ù‚Ø³Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ¬ÙˆØ¯ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙ‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ´Ø¦ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø¨Ù‡Ù‡ Ø´Ø¦ Ø¨ÙˆØ¬Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ Ø¨ÙˆØ¬Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØµØ§Ø± Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù†Ø§: ÙŠØ§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø±ÙŠØ¹Ø© Ø§Ø³Ù…Ø§ Ø®Ø§ØµØ§ Ù„Ù‡ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ³Ù…Ù‰ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ØŒ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù†Ø§: Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ø³Ù… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ³Ù…Ù‰ Ø¨Ù‡ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡. ÙˆÙØµÙ„ Ø¢Ø®Ø± ÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ Ù‚Ø¯ ÙŠØ¹Ø¯ Ù…Ø¹ Ù…Ø§ Ø¬Ø§Ù†Ø³Ù‡ ÙˆØ´Ø§ÙƒÙ„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ø§Ø«Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø±Ø¬Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§Ù† Ø±Ø¬Ù„Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙˆØ«Ù„Ø§Ø«Ø© Ø±Ø¬Ø§Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ø³ÙˆØ§Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§Ù† Ø³ÙˆØ§Ø¯Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø£ØµÙ„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡Ø°Ø§Ù† Ø¥Ù„Ù‡Ø§Ù† Ø¥Ø° Ù„Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŒ ÙØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ¬Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø®Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¯Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ¬Ù‡ Ø¨ÙˆØ¬Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ ÙŠØ¹Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ø¹ Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬Ø§Ù†Ø³Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§ÙƒÙ„Ù‡ØŒ ÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¶ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§Ù† Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¶ ÙˆØ³ÙˆØ§Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§Ù† Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§Ù† Ù„ÙŠØ³Ø§ Ø¨Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«ÙŠÙ† ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¨Ù…Ø®Ù„ÙˆÙ‚ÙŠÙ†ØŒ Ø¨Ù„ Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø¯ÙŠÙ… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø± Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø« ÙˆØ£Ø­Ø¯Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ø±Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø± Ù…Ø±Ø¨ÙˆØ¨ØŒ ÙØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ¬Ù‡ ÙŠØµØ­ Ø¯Ø®ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¯Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø­Ùˆ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰: ï´¿Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ù† Ù†Ø¬ÙˆÙ‰ Ø«Ù„Ø§Ø«Ø© Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø±Ø§Ø¨Ø¹Ù‡Ù… ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø®Ù…Ø³Ø© Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø³Ø§Ø¯Ø³Ù‡Ù… ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø£Ø¯Ù†Ù‰ Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø£ÙƒØ«Ø± Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ù…Ø¹Ù‡Ù… Ø£ÙŠÙ†Ù…Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù†ÙˆØ§ - Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ©ï´¾ ÙˆÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù†Ø§: Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙØ¶Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ù…Ø¬Ø±Ø¯Ù‡ ÙÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù†Ø§: ÙÙ„Ø§Ù† Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠ ÙÙ„Ø§Ù†. Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ù„ Ø¨Ù…Ø¬Ø±Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙƒÙˆÙ†Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙØ¶Ù„Ù‡ Ù…ØªÙ‰ Ù‚ÙŠÙ„: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ‡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø£Ùˆ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ…Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…. ÙØ£Ù…Ø§ ØªÙˆØ­ÙŠØ¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ø°ÙƒØ±Ù‡ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ ØªÙˆØ­ÙŠØ¯Ù‡ Ø¨ØµÙØ§ØªÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù†Ù‰ ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¥Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ù„Ø§ Ø´Ø±ÙŠÙƒ Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø´Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ù‡Ùˆ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù‚Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù…Ù† Ø£ÙˆØµØ§ÙÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù†Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¨ØµÙŠØ±Ø© Ù…Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ø¹Ø±ÙØ© ÙˆØ¥ÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù† Ùˆ Ø¥Ø®Ù„Ø§ØµØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ ÙÙ…Ù† Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¹Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù…ØªÙˆØ­Ø¯Ø§ Ø¨Ø£ÙˆØµØ§ÙÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù†Ù‰ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠÙ‚Ø± Ø¨ØªÙˆØ­ÙŠØ¯Ù‡ Ø¨Ø£ÙˆØµØ§ÙÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ ØºÙŠØ± Ù…ÙˆØ­Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆØ±Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¬Ø§Ù‡Ù„ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³: Ø¥Ù† Ù…Ù† ÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ£Ù‚Ø± Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ Ù…ÙˆØ­Ø¯ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ù„Ù… ÙŠØµÙÙ‡ Ø¨ØµÙØ§ØªÙ‡ Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ ØªÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ù…Ù† ÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ Ù…ÙˆØ­Ø¯ ÙÙŠ Ø£ØµÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„ØºØ©ØŒ ÙÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡: Ø£Ù†ÙƒØ±Ù†Ø§ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ù…Ù† Ø²Ø¹Ù… Ø£Ù† Ø±Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ ÙˆØ´Ø¦ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø£Ø«Ø¨Øª Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ Ù…ÙˆØµÙˆÙØ§ Ø¢Ø®Ø± Ø¨ØµÙØ§ØªÙ‡ Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ ØªÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø© ÙˆØ³Ø§Ø¦Ø± Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù„Ù„ Ø«Ù†ÙˆÙŠ ØºÙŠØ± Ù…ÙˆØ­Ø¯ ÙˆÙ…Ø´Ø±Ùƒ Ù…Ø´Ø¨Ù‡ ØºÙŠØ± Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ùˆ Ø¥Ù† Ø²Ø¹Ù… Ø£Ù† Ø±Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ ÙˆØ´Ø¦ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ ÙˆÙ…ÙˆØ¬ÙˆØ¯ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ù…ØªÙˆØ­Ø¯Ø§ Ø¨ØµÙØ§ØªÙ‡ Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ ØªÙØ±Ø¯ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ÙŠØ© Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø¬Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØªÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ­Ø¯Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ© Ù„ØªÙˆØ­Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù„ÙŠØ³ØªØ­ÙŠÙ„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ Ø¢Ø®Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ù„Ø§ Ø´Ø±ÙŠÙƒ Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø´Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø¥Ù† Ù„Ù… ÙŠØªÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù„Ù‡ Ø´Ø±ÙŠÙƒ ÙˆØ´Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØªÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ø¨Ø£ÙˆØµØ§ÙÙ‡ Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø¬Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù„Ù‡ Ø´Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ ÙˆØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙƒÙ„ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ ÙÙ…Ù† Ø¹Ø±ÙÙ‡ Ù…ØªÙˆØ­Ø¯Ø§ Ø¨ØµÙØ§ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ£Ù‚Ø± Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ø±ÙÙ‡ ÙˆØ§Ø¹ØªÙ‚Ø¯ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù…ÙˆØ­Ø¯Ø§ ÙˆØ¨ØªÙˆØ­ÙŠØ¯ Ø±Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ø§Ø±ÙØ§. ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø£ÙˆØµØ§Ù Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ ØªÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØªÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ø¨Ø±Ø¨ÙˆØ¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ Ù„ØªÙØ±Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù‡ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙˆØµØ§Ù Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ ÙŠÙ‚ØªØ¶ÙŠ ÙƒÙ„ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø£Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØµÙˆÙ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø±ÙƒÙ‡ ÙÙŠÙ‡ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙˆØµÙ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù‡ÙˆØŒ ÙˆØªÙ„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙˆØµØ§Ù Ù‡ÙŠ ÙƒÙˆØµÙÙ†Ø§ Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù…ÙˆØ¬ÙˆØ¯ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØµØ­ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø­Ø§Ù„Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø´Ø¦ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ­Ù„Ù‡ Ø´Ø¦ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¯Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙÙ†Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø²ÙˆØ§Ù„ØŒ Ù…Ø³ØªØ­Ù‚ Ù„Ù„ÙˆØµÙ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø£ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ¢Ø®Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø±ÙŠÙ†ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ø¯Ø± ÙŠÙØ¹Ù„ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¶Ø¹Ù ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¹Ø¬Ø²ØŒ Ù…Ø³ØªØ­Ù‚ Ù„Ù„ÙˆØµÙ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø£Ù‚Ø¯Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¯Ø±ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ£Ù‚Ù‡Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ù‡Ø±ÙŠÙ†ØŒ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ®ÙÙ‰ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø´Ø¦ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø²Ø¨ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ Ø´Ø¦ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¬Ù‡Ù„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø³Ù‡Ùˆ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø´Ùƒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù†Ø³ÙŠØ§Ù†ØŒ Ù…Ø³ØªØ­Ù‚ Ù„Ù„ÙˆØµÙ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ†ØŒ Ø­ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…ÙˆØª ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù†ÙˆÙ…ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØªØ±Ø¬Ø¹ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ù†ÙØ¹Ø© ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØªÙ†Ø§Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø¶Ø±Ø©ØŒ Ù…Ø³ØªØ­Ù‚ Ù„Ù„ÙˆØµÙ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø£Ø¨Ù‚Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ù‚ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ£ÙƒÙ…Ù„ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ§Ù…Ù„ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙØ§Ø¹Ù„ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ´ØºÙ„Ù‡ Ø´Ø¦ Ø¹Ù† Ø´Ø¦ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø¬Ø²Ù‡ Ø´Ø¦ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙÙˆØªÙ‡ Ø´Ø¦ØŒ Ù…Ø³ØªØ­Ù‚ Ù„Ù„ÙˆØµÙ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø±ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ£Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ£Ø³Ø±Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø§Ø³Ø¨ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ØºÙ†ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù„Ù‡ Ù‚Ù„Ø©ØŒ Ù…Ø³ØªØºÙ† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù„Ù‡ Ø­Ø§Ø¬Ø©ØŒ Ø¹Ø¯Ù„ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ„Ø­Ù‚Ù‡ Ù…Ø°Ù…Ø© ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ±Ø¬Ø¹ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ù†Ù‚ØµØ©ØŒ Ø­ÙƒÙŠÙ… Ù„Ø§ ØªÙ‚Ø¹ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø³ÙØ§Ù‡Ø©ØŒ Ø±Ø­ÙŠÙ… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù„Ù‡ Ø±Ù‚Ø© ÙÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙÙŠ Ø±Ø­Ù…ØªÙ‡ Ø³Ø¹Ø©ØŒ Ø­Ù„ÙŠÙ… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ„Ø­Ù‚Ù‡ Ù…ÙˆØ¬Ø¯Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¹ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø¹Ø¬Ù„Ø©ØŒ Ù…Ø³ØªØ­Ù‚ Ù„Ù„ÙˆØµÙ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø£Ø¹Ø¯Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ø¯Ù„ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ£Ø­ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø§ÙƒÙ…ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ£Ø³Ø±Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø§Ø³Ø¨ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø£ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙ† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¥Ù„Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ ÙˆÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù‚Ø¯Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¯Ø±ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ£Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ£Ø­ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø§ÙƒÙ…ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ£Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙƒÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ø¬Ø§Ø¡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ²Ù†ØŒ ÙØµØ­ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ù„Ù†Ø§Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¨Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ØªÙˆÙÙŠÙ‚ ÙˆÙ…Ù†Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹ØµÙ…Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„ØªØ³Ø¯ÙŠØ¯. Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ ØªÙØ³ÙŠØ± Ù‚Ù„ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ù‡Ø§ ", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/14/2/3/3", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 3, "thaqalaynSanad": "3. Muhammad ibn Ibrahim ibn Ishaq al-Taliqani (RA) said: Muhammad ibn Sa`id ibn Yahya al-Buzuri said: Ibrahim ibn al-Haytham al-Baladi said: My father said on the authority of alMu`afi ibn `Imran, on the authority of Isra`il, on the authority of al-Miqdad ibn Shurayh ibn Haniâ€™, on the authority of his father that ", "thaqalaynMatn": "On the Day of Battle of Jamal, a Bedouin stood before the Commander of the Faithful (AS), and asked, â€œO Commander of the Faithful! Do you say that Allah is One?â€ He says: the people attacked him saying that â€œO Bedouin! Do you not see the state of mind of the Commander of the Faithful?â€ So the Commander of the Faithful (AS) said: â€œLeave him alone. Verily, what this Bedouin seeks to know is what we are seeking to establish by fighting these people.â€ He (the Commander of the Faithful) then said: O Bedouin! The statement that `Allah is Oneâ€™ is of four types: Two types cannot be applied to Allah, the Mighty and High; while the two other types can be applied to Him. As for the two types of statements that cannot be applied to Him, the first is the claim that Allah is One in a numerical sense. Such a statement cannot be applied to Allah, because as the One, He has no second, and He is not subject to mathematic calculation. Do you not see that he who claims that Allah is the third of the three has disbelieved (in Him)? The second statement which cannot be applied to Allah is the claim that He is One with humankind. Since He derives the species from the genus, He cannot be described through anthropomorphism [tashbih]. Our Lord is Higher and more Exalted than this. As for the two types of statements that can be applied to Allah, the first would be to say that He is the One who resembles none. The second statement which can apply to Allah is the statement that He, the Mighty and High, is Alone, in the sense that He is Indivisible in Existence [wujud], Intellect [`aql], and Thought [wahm]. That is another dignified description of our Lord, he Mighty and High. The Compiler of this book says: I have heard the following from a person I trust due to the fact that he is religious and due to his mastery of both Classical and colloquial Arabic: Verily, the words one, two three, and so forth, were developed in order to express quantity, and not to express quality. They have no meaning outside of counting, and determining units of measure in the tens, hundreds, and thousands. Likewise, when someone intends to inform another person about the exact quantity of a thing, he names it by its specific name, and applies the number `oneâ€™ to it, describing its quantity, as opposed to its attributes. This is why one says: one pound [dirham], and one intends only a pound, while it could be a pound in weight or a pound in number. So, if the persons want to convey the meaning of weight, he would say: one pound in weight, but if he wants to convey the meaning of number, he says; one pound in number. On the basis, if a person says â€œone man,â€ the man can be one in the sense that he is one human being, as opposed to two. Or, he could be unique in merits, unique in knowledge, unique in generosity or unique in bravery. Thus, if a person intends to convey the sense of quantity, he says: â€œone man;â€ in the sense that he is one man as opposed to two men. However, if he intends to describe someoneâ€™s excellence, he says: he is one of a kind (there is no `oneâ€™ like him). This indicates that nobody compares to him. If he wanted to stress the knowledge of a person, he would say: he is unique in knowledge. Hence, since the word `oneâ€™ can indicate excellence, as well as quantity, it means that whoever called him `oneâ€™ under these circumstances meant that there he had no second. In other words, there was no scholar like him, and no person like him in quality. When this is not the case, then it is correct to say that `oneâ€™ merely indicates quantity. Otherwise, there, would be no sense in saying `one of a kindâ€™ or limiting the meaning of knowledge or bravery. It has been established that when a person uses the word â€œoneâ€ on its own, it indicates quantity. However, depending on the context, it can also mean â€œoneâ€ or â€œuniqueâ€ in knowledge, excellence, and generosity. As we have already explained, `oneâ€™ pound [dirham] can be one pound in weight, one pound in number or count. It can also be two pounds in weight, and one pound in number or count. Sometimes it is six dawaniq,1 and sixty fulus,2 and has many fractions. Likewise, a slave can be one salve, and not two slaves; a person can be one person, and not two people, when in reality they are composed of many parts which are composed of many more parts. In this sense, the slave cannot be `one.â€™ Verily, the slave is not one or unique [wahid], because every slave has someone who is similar to him. It makes perfect sense for a slave to have someone who is the same as him in attributes and qualities. Hence it is necessary that Allah, the Mighty and High, be Unique in His Attributes and Most Beautiful Names. This is what makes Him truly One God, who has no likeness; the One, who has no associates; and there is no god but He. Therefore, Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, is the One, the Eternal3 [qadim], and there is no god but He. He is Unique, none is eternal but He, the Existing, who does not change, and is not subject to change. He is the One beyond compare. Nothing is similar to Him. Nothing resembles Him. And nothing is like Him. Thus, He is an Indivisible Being in both Essence and Imagination, a Think unlike other Things, and the One and Only True God. There is no god but Him! In conclusion, in Islamic Law, the titles the One [Wahid], and the Unique [Ahad], apply specifically to Him, and are excluded from others. None but Allah, the Mighty and High, can bear these titles. And, as we have already explained, Allah is a name which can only applied to Him. In addition to these examples, a thing can sometimes be counted with something which is similar to it. It is said: this is a man, these are two men, and these are three men; this is a slave, this is black, these are two slaves, these two are black. Therefore, it is not permissible to say: these are two gods as there is no god but the One God. Thus, Allah cannot be counted in this manner, nor does He enter numbers in this form in any way. Sometimes a thing is counted with something different to it. Hence, it is said: this is the color white, these are white and black colors; this is a recent one [muhdath], these are two recent ones; these are not two ones, and these are not two creatures; One of them is Eternal, and the other is recent; one of them is the Lord, and the other is the servant. So, on this basis, it is acceptable to apply numbers to Him as Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, has said: Nowhere is there a secret counsel between three persons but He is the Fourth of them, not (between) five but He is the Sixth of them, nor less than that nor more but He is with them wheresoever they are.1 Similarly, the statement `Verilyâ€™, he is `one manâ€™ does not merely stress his excellence. Likewise, our statement, `so and so in number two to so and so,â€™ does not simply indicate that he exist. It only does so when it is specified that `he is second to him in excellence, in perfection, or in knowledge.â€™ As for the Unity of Allah, Exalted is His Remembrance, it refers to the Unity between His Exalted Attribute, and His Most Beautiful Names. He is One, without associates, and without similarity. He who affirms this about the Mighty and High on the basis of His Exalted Attribute and Most Beautiful Names with conviction is a true monotheist. Hence, the one who fails to recognize Allah, the Mighty and High, through his Exalted Attributes, and Most Beautiful Names, does not affirm His Oneness, and is not a true monotheist. Sometimes the ignorant people say: Verily, a monotheist is one who professes the Oneness of Allah even if He does profess the Unity of His Attributes. The ignorant people are told: You have rejected Divine Unity. Whoever claims that His Lord is One God, and One Being, and then applies His Attributes to other than Him, is an idolater, an anthropomorphist, and a nonMuslim according to the consensus of every school of thought in the Ummah. Such is the case, even if he claims that His Lord id One God, One Thing and One Being. Accepting Divine Unity, while failing to accept the Divine Attributes, is like saying Allah is separate from His Attributes whereas Divine Unity is the Unity between Allah and His Attributes. I is impossible for another god to exist. Allah is One God without partners, and without similarity. If He was not United with His Attributes, then he would have an associate or something similar to Him. Likewise, if a servant did not embody him own attributes, another servant would have to exist. As a result, he would not be one servant, but two servants. Hence, anyone who professes that Allah is One with His Attributes is a true monotheist, and a Believer in Divine Unity. Allah, the Mighty and High, unites every attribute which is applicable exclusively to Him. These attributes include the Existent since it cannot be conceive that He can dissolve into something or that something can dissolve into Him. Nor is it conceivable that His Existence can come to an end, that He can be destroyed, or that He can suffer any type of decline. He is the First of the First, the Last of the Last, and the Omnipotent. He is not subject to weakness or inability. He is the Most Powerful of the Powerful, and the Subduer [qahir] of all Subduers. He is Omniscient: nothing is hidden from Him, and nothing escapes Him. He is the Most Learned of the Learned. Ignorance, mistakes, errors, doubts, and forgetfulness cannot be attributed to Him. He is the Ever-Living. He is not subject to sleep or death. Nothing benefits Him nor can anything harm Him. He is the One who Remains, the Most Complete of the Complete, and the Doer who is never occupied. Nothing incapacitates Him nor does He miss anything. He is the Lord of the First and Last, the Best of Creators, and the Foremost of those who take account. He is the Wealthy One [ghani], devoid of nothing. He is the Self-Sufficient [mustaghni], devoid of need. He is the Just, devoid of criticism and defects. He is the Wise One, devoid of foolishness. He is the Most Merciful, whose Mercy cannot be increased kindness.2 He is the Forbearing [halim], devoid of emotion and haste. He is the Most Just of the Just, the Best of Judges, and the Foremost of those who take Account. This is because the first of the First cannot be but One. He is the Omnipotent, the Most Learned, the Best of Judges, the Best of Creators, and all such descriptions are correct. Favor is from Allah, as is protection and guidance.", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 39, "bookId": "Al-Tawhid-Saduq", "book": "Al-Tawá¸¥Ä«d", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "2", "chapter": "Divine Unity andâ€¬â€¬ Negation of Anthropomorphism", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Sayed Ali Raza Rizvi", "englishText": "3. `Ali ibn Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn `Imran al-Daqqaq (may Allah have mercy on him) said: Muhammad ibn Abu `Abd Allah al-Kufi said; and (also) Ahmad ibn Yahya ibn Zakariyya al-Qittan, on the authority of Bakr ibn `Abd Allah ibn Habib, on the authority of Tamim ibn Buhlul, on the authority of his father, on the authority of Abu Mu`awiyah, on the authority of al-Hasan ibn Abd al-Rahman, on the authority of his father, on the authority of Abu `Abd Allah (AS) on the authority of his father, on the authority of his grandfather (AS) that The Commander of the Faithful (AS) roused the people to was with Mu`awiyah for the second time. When the people gathered around him, he stood up and addressed them in the following terms: All praise be to Allah, the One and Only who is sought by all, the Unique and the One Who was not created out of anything nor created anything out of pre-existing matter. On the contrary, He created everything through His Might which is manifest in all things. And verily, everything came into existence because of Him. He has no attribute which can be comprehended, nor has He any limit which can be established. In linguistic embellishment, the tongue is crippled when it comes to describing His Attributes. And circumlocution with respect to His Attributes leads to a blind alley. The sharpest of intellects are unable to comprehend His Kingdom. All comprehensive explanation is rendered ineffective in delving deep into His Kingdom. Unseen veils impede even the lowest level of understanding of His Hidden Knowledge. The keenest insights are at a loss when attempting to comprehend the most superficial layer of His Subtleties. Thus, hallowed be Allah who can neither be reached by the most intrepid intellect nor conceived by the deepest insight. Exalted be He who is not subject to time, length, or limit. Purified be He whose Beginning has not beginning, whose End has no end, and who will never be annihilated. Glorified be He! He is as He has described Himself, and the describers cannot reach His Descriptions. He delineated the boundaries of all things at the time of their creation, and completely eradicated the possibility of Him resembling things or of things resembling Him. He cannot be contained by things which could describe Him. He has never been separate from things that can describe Him. He has never bin distant from things which could raise questions as to His whereabouts. Rather, He, the Glorified, has encompassed all the things through His Knowledge, strengthened them, and enumerated them in His Memory. Nothing is hidden from Him behind the veils of the atmosphere, the deep slumber which occurs in darkness, and whatever exists in the highest Heavens, and the lowest Earth. Everything that exists has a custodian and a keeper. All things are surrounded by other things. And He encompasses them all. He is the One, the Unique, and the Besought. He is not subject to time. He does not tire from creating thins. Whatever He willed, He said: â€œBeâ€ and it was. He created everything without precedent, without fatigue, and without planning. Anything which makes something makes it out of something. Allah, however, made His Creation out of nothing. Every scholar acquired knowledge after being ignorant while Allah was never ignorant, and never acquired knowledge. He encompassed all things through His Knowledge even before they were created. Hence, His Knowledge did not increase through their creation. After they came into existence, He knew as much about them as He knew before they came into existence. He never created anything to strengthen His Control. He never created anything out of fear of decay or loss. He never created anything to oppose an adversary. He never created anything to match an equal. He never created anything to become the equal of a dominating partner. He never did anything of the like because all of creation is nurtured by Him, and all things that exist are His Humble Slaves and Servants. Glorified be He who never feels weary from creating, and sustaining. And glorified be He who was not prevented from creating more out of inability or laziness. He knew what He created, and created what He knew. Whatever He created was not the result of deliberation or based on new knowledge. Nor does any doubt arise in Him regarding the things He has not created. What He created, and what He did not create, was the result of His Inviolable Decision. His Firm Knowledge, and His Exact Command. He made Himself Unique in His Lordship, and Specific in (His) Oneness. He earmarked glory and praise for Himself, made Himself Peerless in Unity, Grandeur and Sublimity. He remains Matchless in Praise, and Exalted in His Glory. He is far above parenthood. And he is purified and sanctified against the feminine touch (i.e. sexual relations). He is far too Great and too Mighty to seek the proximity of any participant. Thus, nothing He has created can oppose Him. There is no equal to Him in His Possessions, and there is no partner for Him in His Kingdom. He is the One, the Unique, and the Besought of all. He is the Eternal, the Everlasting, and the Lord of Space. He has always been, and always will be. He is Unique in Eternity. He existed before time and will exist after the end of all affairs. He will never come to an end nor be exhausted. This is how I describe my Lord. Thus, there is no god but Allah. He is the Greatest of the Great. Glorified and Exalted be He. He is the Mightiest of the Mighty. He is far, far, above what the unjust claim about Him. And Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn al-Saqar al-Sa`igh also said this sermon that Muhammad ibn al- `Abbas ibn Bassam said: Abu Zayd Sa`id ibn Muhammad al-Basri related to me that `Umrah bint Aws related to me that My grandfather al-Husayn ibn `Abd al-Rahman related to me on the authority of his father, on the authority of Abu `Ad Allah Jaâ€™â€™far ibn Muhammad (AS), on the authority of his father on the authority of his grandfather (AS) that the Commander of the Faithful (AS) addressed this sermon when he roused the people to the war with Mu`awiyah for the second time.", "arabicText": "3 - Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ø±Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‚Ø§Ù‚ - Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ - Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙˆÙÙŠØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† ÙŠØ­ÙŠÙ‰ Ø¨Ù† Ø²ÙƒØ±ÙŠØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø·Ø§Ù†ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¨ÙƒØ± Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø­Ø¨ÙŠØ¨ØŒ Ø¹Ù† ØªÙ…ÙŠÙ… Ø¨Ù† Ø¨Ù‡Ù„ÙˆÙ„ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ù…Ø¹Ø§ÙˆÙŠØ©ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­ØµÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù†ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¬Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ø£Ù† Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø§Ø³ØªÙ†Ù‡Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ ÙÙŠ Ø­Ø±Ø¨ Ù…Ø¹Ø§ÙˆÙŠØ© ÙÙŠ Ø­Ø±Ø¨ Ù…Ø¹Ø§ÙˆÙŠØ© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ© ÙÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ø­Ø´Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ù‚Ø§Ù… Ø®Ø·ÙŠØ¨Ø§ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù…ØªÙØ±Ø¯ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø´Ø¦ ÙƒØ§Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø´Ø¦ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ù…Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù†ØŒ Ù‚Ø¯Ø±ØªÙ‡ Ø¨Ø§Ù† Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø´ÙŠØ§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆØ¨Ø§Ù†Øª Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø´ÙŠØ§Ø¡ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³Øª Ù„Ù‡ ØµÙØ© ØªÙ†Ø§Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø­Ø¯ ÙŠØ¶Ø±Ø¨ Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø«Ø§Ù„ØŒ ÙƒÙ„ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† ØµÙØ§ØªÙ‡ ØªØ¹Ø¨ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù„ØºØ§Øª ÙˆØ¶Ù„ Ù‡Ù†Ø§Ù„Ùƒ ØªØµØ§Ø±ÙŠÙ Ø§Ù„ØµÙØ§ØªØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø§Ø± ÙÙŠ Ù…Ù„ÙƒÙˆØªÙ‡ Ø¹Ù…ÙŠÙ‚Ø§Øª Ù…Ø°Ø§Ù‡Ø¨ Ø§Ù„ØªÙÙƒÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù†Ù‚Ø·Ø¹ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆØ® ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ø¬ÙˆØ§Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„ØªÙØ³ÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø§Ù„ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† ØºÙŠØ¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙƒÙ†ÙˆÙ† Ø­Ø¬Ø¨ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØºÙŠÙˆØ¨ØŒ ÙˆØªØ§Ù‡Øª ÙÙŠ Ø£Ø¯Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø¯Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø·Ø§Ù…Ø­Ø§Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙÙŠ Ù„Ø·ÙŠÙØ§Øª Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…ÙˆØ± ÙØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¨Ù„ØºÙ‡ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ù…Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙ†Ø§Ù„Ù‡ ØºÙˆØµ Ø§Ù„ÙØ·Ù†ØŒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‚Øª Ù…Ø¹Ø¯ÙˆØ¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø£Ø¬Ù„ Ù…Ù…Ø¯ÙˆØ¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù†Ø¹Øª Ù…Ø­Ø¯ÙˆØ¯ØŒ ÙˆØ³Ø¨Ø­Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ù„Ù‡ Ø£ÙˆÙ„ Ù…Ø¨ØªØ¯Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØºØ§ÙŠØ© Ù…Ù†ØªÙ‡Ù‰ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¢Ø®Ø± ÙŠÙÙ†Ù‰ØŒ Ø³Ø¨Ø­Ø§Ù†Ù‡ØŒ Ù‡Ùˆ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ ÙˆØµÙ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙˆØ§ØµÙÙˆÙ† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¨Ù„ØºÙˆÙ† Ù†Ø¹ØªÙ‡ØŒ Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø´ÙŠØ§Ø¡ ÙƒÙ„Ù‡Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø®Ù„Ù‚Ù‡ Ø¥ÙŠØ§Ù‡Ø§ Ø¥Ø¨Ø§Ù†Ø© Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø´Ø¨Ù‡Ù‡ ÙˆØ¥Ø¨Ø§Ù†Ø© Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø´Ø¨Ù‡Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ­Ù„Ù„ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡Ùˆ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ø¦Ù† ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠÙ†Ø£ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡Ùˆ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ø¦Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ®Ù„ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡: Ø£ÙŠÙ†ØŒ Ù„ÙƒÙ†Ù‡ Ø³Ø¨Ø­Ø§Ù†Ù‡ Ø£Ø­Ø§Ø· Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ£ØªÙ‚Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ØµÙ†Ø¹Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø­ØµØ§Ù‡Ø§ Ø­ÙØ¸Ù‡ØŒ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¹Ø²Ø¨ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ Ø®ÙÙŠØ§Øª ØºÙŠÙˆØ¨ Ø§Ù„Ù‡ÙˆÙ‰ Ù„Ø§ ØºÙˆØ§Ù…Ø¶ Ù…ÙƒÙ†ÙˆÙ† Ø¸Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø¬Ù‰ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø§ÙˆØ§Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø£Ø±Ø¶ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙÙ„Ù‰ØŒ Ù„ÙƒÙ„ Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø­Ø§ÙØ¸ ÙˆØ±Ù‚ÙŠØ¨ØŒ ÙˆÙƒÙ„ Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ø­ÙŠØ· ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø­ÙŠØ· Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø­Ø§Ø· Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ù… ØªØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ ØµØ±ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø²Ù…Ø§Ù† ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØªÙƒØ§Ø¯Ù‡ ØµÙ†Ø¹ Ø´Ø¦ ÙƒØ§Ù†ØŒ Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ø´Ø§Ø¡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ†: ÙƒÙ† ÙÙƒØ§Ù†ØŒ Ø§Ø¨ØªØ¯Ø¹ Ù…Ø§ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø¨Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ø«Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ø¨Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØªØ¹Ø¨ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù†ØµØ¨ØŒ ÙˆÙƒÙ„ ØµØ§Ù†Ø¹ Ø´Ø¦ ÙÙ…Ù† Ø´Ø¦ ØµÙ†Ø¹ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø´Ø¦ ØµÙ†Ø¹ Ù…Ø§ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆÙƒÙ„ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… ÙÙ…Ù† Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø¬Ù‡Ù„ ØªØ¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¬Ù‡Ù„ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØªØ¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ø£Ø­Ø§Ø· Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø´ÙŠØ§Ø¡ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ ÙƒÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ø¯Ø¯ Ø¨ÙƒÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§ØŒ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ø§ ÙƒØ¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ ØªÙƒÙˆÙŠÙ†Ù‡Ø§ØŒ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ø§ Ù„Ø´Ø¯Ø© Ø³Ù„Ø·Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø®ÙˆÙ Ù…Ù† Ø²ÙˆØ§Ù„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù†Ù‚ØµØ§Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø§Ø³ØªØ¹Ø§Ù†Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¶Ø¯ Ù…Ø«Ø§ÙˆØ± ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù†Ø¯ Ù…ÙƒØ§Ø«Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø´Ø±ÙŠÙƒ Ù…ÙƒØ§Ø¦Ø¯ Ù„ÙƒÙ† Ø®Ù„Ø§Ø¦Ù‚ Ù…Ø±Ø¨ÙˆØ¨ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ø¨Ø§Ø¯ Ø¯Ø§Ø®Ø±ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙØ³Ø¨Ø­Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¤Ø¯Ù‡ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ø¨ØªØ¯Ø£ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØªØ¯Ø¨ÙŠØ± Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø±Ø£ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ø¬Ø² ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ù† ÙØªØ±Ø© Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø§ÙƒØªÙÙ‰ØŒ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ù…Ø§ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ ÙˆØ®Ù„Ù‚ Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ØªÙÙƒØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø­Ø§Ø¯Ø« Ø£ØµØ§Ø¨ Ù…Ø§ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø´Ø¨Ù‡Ø© Ø¯Ø®Ù„Øª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ®Ù„Ù‚ØŒ Ù„ÙƒÙ† Ù‚Ø¶Ø§Ø¡ Ù…Ø¨Ø±Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù… Ù…Ø­ÙƒÙ…ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø± Ù…ØªÙ‚Ù†ØŒ ØªÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¨ÙˆØ¨ÙŠØ©ØŒ ÙˆØ®Øµ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ­Ø¯Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ©ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ø³ØªØ®Ù„Øµ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¬Ø¯ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø«Ù†Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙØªÙ…Ø¬Ø¯ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ØªÙ…Ø¬ÙŠØ¯ØŒ ÙˆØªØ­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ØªØ­Ù…ÙŠØ¯ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù† Ø§ØªØ®Ø§Ø° Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨Ù†Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆØªØ·Ù‡Ø± ÙˆØªÙ‚Ø¯Ø³ Ø¹Ù† Ù…Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø³Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø³Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¹Ù† Ù…Ø¬Ø§ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø±ÙƒØ§Ø¡ØŒ ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø¶Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ Ù…Ù„Ùƒ Ù†Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ´Ø±Ùƒ ÙÙŠ Ù…Ù„ÙƒÙ‡ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¨ÙŠØ¯ Ù„Ù„Ø£Ø¨Ø¯ØŒ Ùˆ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§Ø±Ø«ØŒ Ù„Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ù„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ ÙˆØ­Ø¯Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ø²Ù„ÙŠØ§ Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø¨Ø¯Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‡ÙˆØ± ÙˆØ¨Ø¹Ø¯ ØµØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…ÙˆØ±ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¨ÙŠØ¯ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£ØµÙ Ø±Ø¨ÙŠØŒ ÙÙ„Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ… Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø¹Ø¸Ù…Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¬Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø¬Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ø²ÙŠØ² Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø¹Ø²Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù„ÙˆØ§ ÙƒØ¨ÙŠØ±Ø§. ÙˆØ­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø¨Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø·Ø¨Ø© Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‚Ø± Ø§Ù„ØµØ§Ø¦ØºØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ø³ Ø¨Ù† Ø¨Ø³Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø²ÙŠØ¯ Ø³Ø¹ÙŠØ¯ Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¨ØµØ±ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«ØªÙ†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù…Ø±Ø© Ø¨Ù†Øª Ø£ÙˆØ³ Ù‚Ø§Ù„Øª: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø¬Ø¯ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø­ØµÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù†ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ - Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¬Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ø£Ù† Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø®Ø·Ø¨ Ø¨Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø·Ø¨Ø© Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ø³ØªÙ†Ù‡Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ ÙÙŠ Ø­Ø±Ø¨ Ù…Ø¹Ø§ÙˆÙŠØ© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ©. ", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/14/2/2/3", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 2, "thaqalaynSanad": "3. `Ali ibn Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn `Imran al-Daqqaq (may Allah have mercy on him) said: Muhammad ibn Abu `Abd Allah al-Kufi said; and (also) Ahmad ibn Yahya ibn Zakariyya al-Qittan, on the authority of Bakr ibn `Abd Allah ibn Habib, on the authority of Tamim ibn Buhlul, on the authority of his father, on the authority of Abu Mu`awiyah, on the authority of al-Hasan ibn Abd al-Rahman, on the authority of his father, on the authority of Abu `Abd Allah (AS) on the authority of his father, on the authority of his grandfather (AS) that ", "thaqalaynMatn": "The Commander of the Faithful (AS) roused the people to was with Mu`awiyah for the second time. When the people gathered around him, he stood up and addressed them in the following terms: All praise be to Allah, the One and Only who is sought by all, the Unique and the One Who was not created out of anything nor created anything out of pre-existing matter. On the contrary, He created everything through His Might which is manifest in all things. And verily, everything came into existence because of Him. He has no attribute which can be comprehended, nor has He any limit which can be established. In linguistic embellishment, the tongue is crippled when it comes to describing His Attributes. And circumlocution with respect to His Attributes leads to a blind alley. The sharpest of intellects are unable to comprehend His Kingdom. All comprehensive explanation is rendered ineffective in delving deep into His Kingdom. Unseen veils impede even the lowest level of understanding of His Hidden Knowledge. The keenest insights are at a loss when attempting to comprehend the most superficial layer of His Subtleties. Thus, hallowed be Allah who can neither be reached by the most intrepid intellect nor conceived by the deepest insight. Exalted be He who is not subject to time, length, or limit. Purified be He whose Beginning has not beginning, whose End has no end, and who will never be annihilated. Glorified be He! He is as He has described Himself, and the describers cannot reach His Descriptions. He delineated the boundaries of all things at the time of their creation, and completely eradicated the possibility of Him resembling things or of things resembling Him. He cannot be contained by things which could describe Him. He has never been separate from things that can describe Him. He has never bin distant from things which could raise questions as to His whereabouts. Rather, He, the Glorified, has encompassed all the things through His Knowledge, strengthened them, and enumerated them in His Memory. Nothing is hidden from Him behind the veils of the atmosphere, the deep slumber which occurs in darkness, and whatever exists in the highest Heavens, and the lowest Earth. Everything that exists has a custodian and a keeper. All things are surrounded by other things. And He encompasses them all. He is the One, the Unique, and the Besought. He is not subject to time. He does not tire from creating thins. Whatever He willed, He said: â€œBeâ€ and it was. He created everything without precedent, without fatigue, and without planning. Anything which makes something makes it out of something. Allah, however, made His Creation out of nothing. Every scholar acquired knowledge after being ignorant while Allah was never ignorant, and never acquired knowledge. He encompassed all things through His Knowledge even before they were created. Hence, His Knowledge did not increase through their creation. After they came into existence, He knew as much about them as He knew before they came into existence. He never created anything to strengthen His Control. He never created anything out of fear of decay or loss. He never created anything to oppose an adversary. He never created anything to match an equal. He never created anything to become the equal of a dominating partner. He never did anything of the like because all of creation is nurtured by Him, and all things that exist are His Humble Slaves and Servants. Glorified be He who never feels weary from creating, and sustaining. And glorified be He who was not prevented from creating more out of inability or laziness. He knew what He created, and created what He knew. Whatever He created was not the result of deliberation or based on new knowledge. Nor does any doubt arise in Him regarding the things He has not created. What He created, and what He did not create, was the result of His Inviolable Decision. His Firm Knowledge, and His Exact Command. He made Himself Unique in His Lordship, and Specific in (His) Oneness. He earmarked glory and praise for Himself, made Himself Peerless in Unity, Grandeur and Sublimity. He remains Matchless in Praise, and Exalted in His Glory. He is far above parenthood. And he is purified and sanctified against the feminine touch (i.e. sexual relations). He is far too Great and too Mighty to seek the proximity of any participant. Thus, nothing He has created can oppose Him. There is no equal to Him in His Possessions, and there is no partner for Him in His Kingdom. He is the One, the Unique, and the Besought of all. He is the Eternal, the Everlasting, and the Lord of Space. He has always been, and always will be. He is Unique in Eternity. He existed before time and will exist after the end of all affairs. He will never come to an end nor be exhausted. This is how I describe my Lord. Thus, there is no god but Allah. He is the Greatest of the Great. Glorified and Exalted be He. He is the Mightiest of the Mighty. He is far, far, above what the unjust claim about Him. And Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn al-Saqar al-Sa`igh also said this sermon that Muhammad ibn al- `Abbas ibn Bassam said: Abu Zayd Sa`id ibn Muhammad al-Basri related to me that `Umrah bint Aws related to me that My grandfather al-Husayn ibn `Abd al-Rahman related to me on the authority of his father, on the authority of Abu `Ad Allah Jaâ€™â€™far ibn Muhammad (AS), on the authority of his father on the authority of his grandfather (AS) that the Commander of the Faithful (AS) addressed this sermon when he roused the people to the war with Mu`awiyah for the second time.", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 1, "bookId": "Uyun-akhbar-al-Rida-Volume-2-Saduq", "book": "Ê¿UyÅ«n akhbÄr al-Riá¸Ä", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "Traditions about Ar-Ridha (a.s.)", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Dr. Ali Peiravi", "englishText": "31-1 My father and Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn al-Waleed - may God be pleased with them - quoted on the authority of Saâ€™ad ibn Abdullah and Jaâ€™far al-Hemyari, on the authority of Ibrahim ibn Hashem, on the authority of Al-Hassan ibn Al-Jahm that he had heard Abal Hassan Ali ibn Musa (Imam) Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) say, â€œEveryoneâ€™s friend is his intellect and everyoneâ€™s enemy is his ignorance.â€", "arabicText": "1 - Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙ†Ø§ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙŠ ÙˆÙÙ…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†ÙØ§Ù„ÙˆÙÙ„ÙÙŠØ¯Ù - Ø±ÙØ¶ÙÙ‰Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ø§ Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù„Ø§: Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙ†Ø§ Ø³ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡ ÙˆÙØ¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯ÙØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¬ÙØ¹Ù’ÙÙØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙÙ…Ù’ÙŠÙØ±ÙŠÙ‘Ù Ù‚Ø§Ù„Ø§: Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙ†Ø§ Ø¥ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ…Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ù‡Ø§Ø´ÙÙ…ÙØŒ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¬ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù…ÙØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„Ù: Ø³ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰Ù‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ù…ÙÙˆØ³ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¶Ø§Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù ÙŠÙÙ‚ÙÙˆÙ„Ù: ØµÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ‚Ù ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù…Ù’Ø±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙØ¹ÙØ¯ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¬ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù.", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/11/1/1/1", "volume": 2, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 1, "thaqalaynSanad": "31-1 My father and Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn al-Waleed - may God be pleased with them - quoted on the authority of Saâ€™ad ibn Abdullah and Jaâ€™far al-Hemyari, on the authority of Ibrahim ibn Hashem, on the authority of Al-Hassan ibn Al-Jahm that he had heard Abal Hassan Ali ibn Musa (Imam) Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) say, ", "thaqalaynMatn": "â€œEveryoneâ€™s friend is his intellect and everyoneâ€™s enemy is his ignorance.â€", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 364, "bookId": "Uyun-akhbar-al-Rida-Volume-2-Saduq", "book": "Ê¿UyÅ«n akhbÄr al-Riá¸Ä", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "On Ar-Ridhaâ€™s Words on the Reasons for Various Things", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Dr. Ali Peiravi", "englishText": "32-12 Jaâ€™far ibn Muhammad ibn Masroor - may God be pleased with him - narrated that Al-Husayn ibn Muhammad ibn Aamir quoted on the authority of Abu Abdullah al-Sayyari, on the authority of Abi Yaqoob ibn al-Baghdadi that Ibn al-Sikkit asked Abil Hassan Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.), â€œWhy did the Honorable the Exalted God send Moses (a.s.) with the miracles of the rod (turning into a serpent), a white hand, the means of magic and sent Jesus (a.s.) with the miracles of medicine, but sent Muhammad (a.s.) with speech and eloquence. Abul Hassan Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) told him, â€œIndeed magic was popular when the Blessed the Sublime God appointed Moses (a.s.). That is why he was given the miracle of negating the effect of magic by the Honorable the Exalted God, which the people did not possess. There was none like it within their powers. Therefore, he nullified their magic and proved his rightfulness to them. The Blessed the Sublime God appointed Jesus (a.s.) at a time when untreatable illnesses existed and the people needed medicine and a doctor. Therefore he gave them what they did not have the like of from the Honorable the Exalted God with which he (Jesus (a.s.)) brought their dead back to life, gave sight to those born blind, and treated those suffering from elephantiasis and leprosy, all with Godâ€™s permission and thereby proving his rightfulness to them. And the Blessed the Sublime God appointed Muhammad (a.s.) at a time when eloquent speech was common. I think he also added in poetry. Therefore he used the Honorable the Exalted Godâ€™s Book with its wise sayings, decrees, disproof of the claims of the atheists, and the proof of his own claims and perfected his proof for them.â€ Ibn al-Sikkit said, â€˜I swear by God that I have never seen anyone like you in these times. Tell me, who is the Proof of God for the creatures today.â€™ Imam Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) said, â€œIt is the intellect which can recognize him who tells the truth about God, acknowledges Him, and recognizes and denounces one who lies about God.â€ Then Ibn al-Sikkit said, â€˜I swear by God that this is the correct answer.â€™â€", "arabicText": "12 - Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙ†Ø§ Ø¬ÙØ¹Ù’ÙÙØ±Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ø±ÙÙˆØ±Ù Ø±ÙØ¶ÙÙ‰Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ÙØ¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ù‚Ø§Ù„Ù: Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙ†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹Ø§Ù…ÙØ±Ù Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙ†Ø§ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙˆ Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙÙŠÙ‘Ø§Ø±ÙŠØŒ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙŠ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆØ¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¨ÙØºØ¯Ù’Ø§Ø¯ÙŠÙ‘ Ù‚Ø§Ù„Ù: Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø§Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ‘ÙÙŠØªÙ Ù„Ø§Ø¨ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¶ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù Ù„ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø°ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ«Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙˆØ³ÙÙ‰ Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¶ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙˆÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØµÙØ§ ÙˆÙØ¢Ù„ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙØ­Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙØ¨ÙØ¹ÙØ«Ù Ø¹ÙÙŠØ³ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ø·Ù‘ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙØ¨ÙØ¹ÙØ«Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù ÙˆÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø®ÙØ·ÙØ¨Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙˆ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†Ùâ€ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ«Ù Ù…ÙÙˆØ³ÙÙ‰â€ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙØºÙ’Ù„ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙØµÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙØ­Ù’Ø±Ù ÙÙØ£ÙØªÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ ÙÙÙŠ ÙˆÙØ³Ù’Ø¹Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ù…ÙØ«Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙØ¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØ¨Ù’Ø·ÙÙ„Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø³ÙØ­Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙØ£ÙØ«Ù’Ø¨ÙØªÙ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ¬Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ«Ù Ø¹ÙÙŠØ³ÙÙ‰ ÙÙÙŠ ÙˆÙÙ‚Ù’ØªÙ Ø¸ÙÙ‡ÙØ±ÙØªÙ’ ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø²Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù†ÙØ§ØªÙ ÙˆÙØ§Ø­Ù’ØªÙØ§Ø¬Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ø·Ù‘ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù ÙÙØ£ÙØªÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ù…ÙØ«Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙØ¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØ­Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙØ£ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±ÙØ£Ù Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙØ§Ù„Ø£ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±ÙØµÙ Ø¨ÙØ¥ÙØ°Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙØ£ÙØ«Ù’Ø¨ÙØªÙ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ¬Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ«Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙÙŠ ÙˆÙÙ‚Ù’ØªÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙØºÙ’Ù„ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙØµÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø®ÙØ·ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙØ§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù ÙˆÙØ£ÙØ¸ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙˆÙØ§Ù„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ¹Ù’Ø±Ù ÙÙØ£ÙØªÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙÙ…ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ¸ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙØ£ÙØ­Ù’ÙƒÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØ¨Ù’Ø·ÙÙ„Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙØ£ÙØ«Ù’Ø¨ÙØªÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ¬Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø§Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ‘ÙÙŠØªÙ ØªÙØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ø±ÙØ£ÙÙŠÙ’ØªÙ Ù…ÙØ«Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ù‚ÙØ·Ù‘Ù ÙÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ¬Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ùâ€ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„Ù ØªÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙÙ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙ‚Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØªÙØµÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙ‚ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙØ§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙØ§Ø°ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØªÙÙƒÙØ°Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø§Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ‘ÙÙŠØªÙ Ù‡ÙØ°ÙØ§ ÙˆÙØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¨Ù.", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/11/1/2/12", "volume": 2, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 2, "thaqalaynSanad": "32-12 Jaâ€™far ibn Muhammad ibn Masroor - may God be pleased with him - narrated that Al-Husayn ibn Muhammad ibn Aamir quoted on the authority of Abu Abdullah al-Sayyari, on the authority of Abi Yaqoob ibn al-Baghdadi that", "thaqalaynMatn": " Ibn al-Sikkit asked Abil Hassan Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.), â€œWhy did the Honorable the Exalted God send Moses (a.s.) with the miracles of the rod (turning into a serpent), a white hand, the means of magic and sent Jesus (a.s.) with the miracles of medicine, but sent Muhammad (a.s.) with speech and eloquence. Abul Hassan Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) told him, â€œIndeed magic was popular when the Blessed the Sublime God appointed Moses (a.s.). That is why he was given the miracle of negating the effect of magic by the Honorable the Exalted God, which the people did not possess. There was none like it within their powers. Therefore, he nullified their magic and proved his rightfulness to them. The Blessed the Sublime God appointed Jesus (a.s.) at a time when untreatable illnesses existed and the people needed medicine and a doctor. Therefore he gave them what they did not have the like of from the Honorable the Exalted God with which he (Jesus (a.s.)) brought their dead back to life, gave sight to those born blind, and treated those suffering from elephantiasis and leprosy, all with Godâ€™s permission and thereby proving his rightfulness to them. And the Blessed the Sublime God appointed Muhammad (a.s.) at a time when eloquent speech was common. I think he also added in poetry. Therefore he used the Honorable the Exalted Godâ€™s Book with its wise sayings, decrees, disproof of the claims of the atheists, and the proof of his own claims and perfected his proof for them.â€ Ibn al-Sikkit said, â€˜I swear by God that I have never seen anyone like you in these times. Tell me, who is the Proof of God for the creatures today.â€™ Imam Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) said, â€œIt is the intellect which can recognize him who tells the truth about God, acknowledges Him, and recognizes and denounces one who lies about God.â€ Then Ibn al-Sikkit said, â€˜I swear by God that this is the correct answer.â€™â€", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 481, "bookId": "Al-Tawhid-Saduq", "book": "Al-Tawá¸¥Ä«d", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "2", "chapter": "Predestination, Divine Decree, Trials, Means of Sustenance Rates, and Restricted Powers", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Sayed Ali Raza Rizvi", "englishText": "32. Muhammad ibn Musa ibn al-Mutawakkil (RA) said: `Ali ibn al-Husayn al-Sa`dabadi said: Ahmad ibn Abu `Abd Allah al-Barqi said, on the authority of his father, on the authority of Muhammad ibn Sinan, on the authority of Ziyad ibn al-Mundhar, on the authority of Sa`d ibn Tarif, on the authority of al-Asbagh ibn Nubatah that The Commander of the Faithful (AS) said the following concerning the decree: Beware that the decree is a secret from the secrets of Allah, concealment from the concealments of Allah, and a sanctuary from the sanctuaries of Allah. It is raised to the covering of Allah, folded up from the creation of Allah, sealed with the seal of Allah, and precedent in the knowledge of Allah. Allah has taken of its knowledge from the servants, raised it above their witnessing and level of intellect because they cannot attain it with the reality of the Lordship or the power of the Needless. Neither can they attain the greatness of the Light, nor the honor of the solitary, because it is an overflowing ocean purely for Allah, the Exalted. Its depth is between the heaven and the earth, and its width is between the east and the West. It is as dark as the pitch- dark night, full of snakes and fishes. It rises at one time ad drops at another. In its bottom, the sun shines. It ought to be that no one has its information except Allah the One, the Peerless. Thus, whoever becomes informed of I becomes contrary to Allah, the Mighty and High in His Judgement and contest Him in His Rule. He uncovers His Concealment and secret, and buys the anger of Allah. His abode is Hell, and it is the worst place of arrival. The Compiler of this book says, we believe: Verily, Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, has predestined and decreed the good and evil of His Servants, and all that is in the universe. The decree can be in the meaning of information, like Allah, the Mighty and High says: And We had decreed to the children of Israel in the Book. He means that We made known to them. Like Allah, the Mighty and High, says: And We revealed to him this decree, that the roots of these shall be cut off in the morning. He means that We informed him and made it known to him. Therefore, it cannot be refused that Allah the Mighty and High, decrees the actions of the servants and all that which is of good and evil in this meaning, because Allah, the Mighty and High, is the Knower of it all.
