Ø¹ÙØ¨ÙØ¯Ù Ø³ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ØªÙ‘ÙØ®ÙØ°Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ø§Ù‹ ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙˆÙ‘Ø§Ù‹ ÙƒÙØ¨ÙÙŠØ±Ø§Ù‹ Ù†ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ…Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ø§Ø±Ù’ØªÙØ¶ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¬ÙØ¨Ù Ù‚ÙØ¨ÙÙˆÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ´Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙØ­Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙØ§ Ø´ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙƒÙ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ´Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø´ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØªÙØ§Ù†Ù ØªÙØ±Ù’ÙÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ¶ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙÙ„Ù Ø®ÙÙÙ‘Ù Ù…ÙÙŠØ²ÙØ§Ù†ÙŒ ØªÙØ±Ù’ÙÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø«ÙÙ‚ÙÙ„Ù Ù…ÙÙŠØ²ÙØ§Ù†ÙŒ ØªÙÙˆØ¶ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙÙˆÙ’Ø²Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø²Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø·Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ø´Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù ØªÙØ¯Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ø©Ù ØªÙÙ†ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ø«ÙØ±ÙÙˆØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù†ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ„Ø§Ø¦ÙÙƒÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù ÙŠØ§ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø¢Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ§ ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ§ ØªÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù‹ ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù ØªÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙØ§ Ø´ÙØ±ÙÙÙ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙØ§Ù…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ±ÙÙ…Ù Ø£ÙØ¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙÙ‚Ù’ÙˆÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ø±ÙØ²Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙØ±ÙØ¹Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø´ÙÙÙÙŠØ¹Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¬ÙØ­Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ù„ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ§ÙÙÙŠÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙØ§ÙŠÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ù†ÙØ¹Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ù…ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø£ÙØ°Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¨Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’ÙÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¶ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ†ÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙƒÙÙ†Ù’Ø²Ù Ø£ÙØºÙ’Ù†ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ¹Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù‚Ù’ØªÙØµÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙÙ„Ù’ØºÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙÙÙØ§ÙÙ ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù Ø§Ù†Ù’ØªÙØ¸ÙÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ§Ø­ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ¨ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ£Ù Ø®ÙÙÙ’Ø¶Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙØ¹ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØºÙ’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙÙ’ØªÙØ§Ø­Ù Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙØ¹ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ø­Ù’ØªÙÙƒÙØ§Ø±Ù Ù…ÙØ·ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØµÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙØ¯Ù Ø¢ÙÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ±Ù’ØµÙ Ø¯ÙØ§Ø¹Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙÙ‚ÙØ­Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø¯ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ±Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØºÙ’ÙŠÙ Ø³ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ‚ÙŒ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¬ÙØ§Ù…ÙØ¹ÙŒ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙØ³ÙØ§ÙˆÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙŠÙÙˆØ¨Ù Ø±ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù Ø·ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù Ø®ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙ„Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ø°ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙŠÙØ¤ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙŠ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ±Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ©Ù ØªÙØ¦ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø®ÙØ³Ù’Ø±ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙˆÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ·Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ±Ù ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ù†ÙØ§Ø¸ÙØ±Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’ ØªÙØ¹ÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ¶Ù Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙÙ’Ø¶ÙØ­ÙØ§ØªÙ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ¦Ù’Ø³ÙØªÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¨Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙØ§ ÙƒÙÙ†Ù’Ø²Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ÙÙØ¹Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙØ±Ù’ÙÙØ¹Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø­ÙØ³ÙØ¨Ù Ø£ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„ÙØºÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¯ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ù†ÙØµÙØ¨Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¶ÙØ¹Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ØºÙØ¶ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø¬ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø£ÙØ²Ù’ÙŠÙÙ†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø³ÙÙˆÙ’Ø£ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙØ³Ù’ÙˆÙØ£Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙØ°ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø­ÙØ§ÙÙØ¸Ù Ø£ÙØ­Ù’ÙÙØ¸Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ ØºÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¨Ù Ø£ÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±ÙØ¨Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ Ø£ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù†ÙØ¸ÙØ±Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¨Ù Ù†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ø´Ù’ØªÙØºÙÙ„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¨Ù ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø±ÙØ¶ÙÙŠÙ Ø¨ÙØ±ÙØ²Ù’Ù‚Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ£Ù’Ø³ÙÙÙ’ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ§ ÙÙÙŠ ÙŠÙØ¯Ù ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø³ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø³ÙÙŠÙ’ÙÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØºÙ’ÙŠÙ Ù‚ÙØªÙÙ„Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙÙÙØ±Ù Ù„ÙØ£ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ¦Ù’Ø±Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙØ¹Ù ÙÙÙŠÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù‡ÙØªÙÙƒÙ Ø­ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø¨Ù ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù†Ù’ÙƒÙØ´ÙÙÙ Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ’Ø±ÙØ§ØªÙ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’ØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù†ÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ Ø²ÙÙ„ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙØ¹Ù’Ø¸ÙÙ…Ù Ø²ÙÙ„ÙÙ„Ù ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¨Ù Ø¨ÙØ±ÙØ£Ù’ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù Ø¶ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙØºÙ’Ù†ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø²ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙƒÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø°ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø³ÙÙÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø´ÙØªÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ·Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’Ø°ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙÙ…ÙÙ„Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ·ÙÙŠÙ‚Ù Ø¹ÙØ¬ÙØ²Ù Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙØ§ Ù…ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’ÙˆÙØ¯Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±Ù Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙˆÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ¸Ù Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„ÙØºÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØµÙ’Ø­Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙØ¯Ù’Ø¨ÙÙŠØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙÙÙÙƒÙ‘ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ù…ÙØ¸ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ±ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’Ø«ÙÙ‚Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ´ÙØ§ÙˆÙØ±ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙˆÙØ­Ù’Ø´ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¬Ù’Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙˆÙØ±ÙØ¹Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙÙÙ‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ­ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø­ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’Ø³ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙØ´Ù’Ø±Ù Ø®ÙØµÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙŠÙØ¸Ù’Ù‡ÙØ±ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ù„ÙØ³ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù Ø´ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ¯ÙŒ ÙŠÙØ®Ù’Ø¨ÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¶Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø­ÙØ§ÙƒÙÙ…ÙŒ ÙŠÙÙÙ’ØµÙÙ„Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø®ÙØ·ÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙØ§Ø·ÙÙ‚ÙŒ ÙŠÙØ±ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø´ÙØ§ÙÙØ¹ÙŒ ÙŠÙØ¯Ù’Ø±ÙÙƒÙ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ§Ø¬ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙˆÙØ§ØµÙÙÙŒ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙÙ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ´Ù’ÙŠÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ±ÙŒ ÙŠÙØ£Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ ÙˆÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ¸ÙŒ ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ¨ÙÙŠØ­Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ØªÙØ³ÙÙƒÙ‘ÙÙ†Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ø²ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙØ§Ø¶ÙØ±ÙŒ ØªÙØ¬Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¶Ù‘ÙØºÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙˆÙ†ÙÙ‚ÙŒ ØªÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙØ°Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ³Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ø¹Ù Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙØ§ Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙƒÙ’Ù…Ù ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙØ§ Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ø¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ§ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ…Ù’Ù„ÙÙƒÙ’ Ù„ÙØ³ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ¬Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ„Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØªÙØ­ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ±Ù’ØªÙØ¯ÙØ¹Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ‡ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ‡ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙÙˆÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙØ±Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙÙˆÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙØ±Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙÙˆÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØ®Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙƒÙ’ØªÙØ³ÙØ¨Ù’ Ù…ÙØ§Ù„Ù‹Ø§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙØµÙ’Ø±ÙÙÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ¯ÙØ¹Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆØ¯ÙŒ ÙŠÙØ¯ÙØ¹Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ°Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ…ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ø·Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ¹Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ…Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ·Ù’Ù„ÙØ¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù ÙŠÙØ°ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØºÙ’Ù„ÙØ¨Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙˆÙ’Ø±Ù ÙŠÙØºÙ’Ù„ÙØ¨Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙØ§Ù†ÙØ¯Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙØ²ÙÙ…ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙÙ‡Ù’Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙƒÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØ±Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ø³ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙØ¯Ù’ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙØ¨ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±Ù Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ ØºÙØ¶Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØµÙØ±Ù Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ«ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¸ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø±Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…ÙŒ Ù„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…ÙŒ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’ÙƒÙ ÙÙØ¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù„ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙÙ„ÙØ§ ØªÙØ¨Ù’Ø·ÙØ±Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’ÙƒÙ ÙÙØ§ØµÙ’Ø¨ÙØ±Ù’ ÙÙØ¨ÙÙƒÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ ØªÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙØ­ÙÙ†Ù [ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ù†ÙØ³Ù’Ø®ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙÙ„ÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø³ÙÙŠÙØ®Ù’ØªÙØ¨ÙØ±Ù] Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¨Ù Ù…ÙØ§ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’Ø³ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¯Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙƒÙ’Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¶Ù’Ø¯ÙØ§Ø¯ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®ÙÙ„ÙØ§ÙÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø³ÙÙ†ÙØ­Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø£ÙØ°ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø·Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù‡ÙØ§Ø¬Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø·Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„ÙÙƒÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ±Ù’ØµÙ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙŠÙØ£Ù’Ø³Ù Ù‚ÙØªÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ³ÙÙÙ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙØ±ÙØ¶Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ØºÙØ¶ÙØ¨Ù Ø§Ø´Ù’ØªÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø¸Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ³Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¶ÙÙ‰ Ù†ÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙØ­ÙÙÙ‘ÙØ¸Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù†ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø®ÙÙˆÙ’ÙÙ Ø´ÙØºÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ°ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ØªÙ‘ÙØ³ÙØ¹Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙÙ„ÙØ¨ÙØªÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘ÙØ©Ù [ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ù†ÙØ³Ù’Ø®ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙØ®ÙØ°ÙØªÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘ÙØ©Ù] ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¬ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ¯ÙØªÙ’ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù†ÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙØ©ÙŒ Ø£ÙØ®ÙØ°ÙØªÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ù…ÙØ§Ù„Ù‹Ø§ Ø£ÙØ·Ù’ØºÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ØºÙÙ†ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙØ¶Ù‘ÙØªÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ©ÙŒ Ø´ÙØºÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ø¡Ù [ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ù†ÙØ³Ù’Ø®ÙØ©Ù Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙÙƒÙØ§Ø¡Ù] ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØµÙØ§Ø¨ÙØªÙ’Ù‡Ù Ù…ÙØµÙÙŠØ¨ÙØ©ÙŒ ÙÙØ¶ÙØ­ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ²ÙØ¹Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙˆØ¹Ù Ù‚ÙØ¹ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¶Ù‘ÙØ¹Ù’ÙÙ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙÙ’Ø±ÙØ·Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙØ¹Ù ÙƒÙØ¸Ù‘ÙØªÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ·Ù’Ù†ÙØ©Ù ÙÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ØªÙÙ‚Ù’ØµÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ¶ÙØ±Ù‘ÙŒ ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø¥ÙÙÙ’Ø±ÙØ§Ø·Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙØ¯ÙŒ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø°ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¬ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø³ÙØ§Ø¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ«ÙØ±Ù Ù…ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø±ÙØ£ÙØ³Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ«ÙØ±Ù Ø­ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù Ù†ÙØ¨ÙÙ„Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙÙ’ÙƒÙØ±Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø°ÙØ§ØªÙ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ²ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‚Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ø«ÙØ±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’â€Ø¡Ù Ø¹ÙØ±ÙÙÙ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ«ÙØ±Ù Ù…ÙØ²ÙØ§Ø­ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙØ®ÙÙÙ‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ«ÙØ±Ù Ø¶ÙØ­Ù’ÙƒÙÙ‡Ù Ø°ÙÙ‡ÙØ¨ÙØªÙ’ Ù‡ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¨ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ³ÙØ¯Ù Ø­ÙØ³ÙØ¨Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØ¯ÙØ¨ÙŒ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙÙ’Ø¶ÙÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„Ù ØµÙÙŠÙØ§Ù†ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ±Ù’Ø¶Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¬ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ³Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙ„Ù Ø¨ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¬ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ³Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙ„Ù ÙÙÙ„Ù’ÙŠÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ¹ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ„Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù„ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’Ø¬ÙÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ ØºÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙŒ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙÙÙ‚ÙÙŠØ±ÙŒ Ù„ÙØ¥ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ù„ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ ÙŠÙØ´Ù’ØªÙØ±ÙÙ‰ Ù„ÙØ§Ø´Ù’ØªÙØ±ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„ÙØ¬Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙØ¦ÙÙŠÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‡ÙÙˆØ¬Ù Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ„ÙÙˆØ¨Ù Ø´ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù ØªÙØ¬Ù’Ø±ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ÙÙØ³Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ¯Ù’Ø±ÙØ¬ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙÙÙ’Ø±ÙÙŠØ·Ù ÙˆÙ ÙÙØ·Ù’Ù†ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙÙ‡Ù’Ù…Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ¸Ù Ù…ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ¯Ù’Ø¹ÙÙˆ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙÙ’Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ°ÙØ±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø®ÙØ·ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ„ÙÙˆØ¨Ù Ø®ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø·ÙØ±Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‡ÙÙˆÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ‚ÙÙˆÙ„Ù ØªÙØ²Ù’Ø¬ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ ØªÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙŒ Ù…ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ£Ù’Ù†ÙÙÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ø¹Ù’ØªÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙŠÙÙ‚ÙÙˆØ¯Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ´ÙØ§Ø¯Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙÙÙØ§ÙƒÙ Ø£ÙØ¯ÙØ¨Ø§Ù‹ Ù„ÙÙ†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙØ§ ØªÙÙƒÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’ÙƒÙ Ù„ÙØ£ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙƒÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ù…ÙØ«Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ù„ÙÙƒÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ø®ÙØ§Ø·ÙØ±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙØºÙ’Ù†ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙØ±ÙØ£Ù’ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙØ¯ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØ±Ù Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙÙ„Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¯ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ„Ù ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙˆÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¢Ø±ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø¹ÙØ±ÙÙÙ Ù…ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ¹Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø®ÙØ·ÙØ¥Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø³ÙÙƒÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙØ¶ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø¹ÙØ¯ÙÙ„ÙØªÙ’ Ø±ÙØ£Ù’ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ‚ÙÙˆÙ„Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙØµÙ‘ÙÙ†Ù Ø´ÙÙ‡Ù’ÙˆÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’ ØµÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø³ÙÙƒÙ Ù„ÙØ³ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙ†ÙÙ‡Ù Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø­ÙØ§Ø¬ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠ ØªÙÙ‚ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ­Ù’ÙˆÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù Ø¬ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§Ù…Ù ØªÙÙˆØ¶ÙØ­Ù Ù„ÙÙƒÙ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø®ÙØ§Ø·ÙÙÙ Ù…ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙØ¹ÙŒ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ®ÙÙˆØ¶Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ù‘ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙØ±ÙÙÙ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙƒÙ’Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù„ÙØ­ÙØ¸ÙØªÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙŠÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‡ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ´Ù’Ø±ÙÙÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’ØºÙÙ†ÙÙ‰ ØªÙØ±Ù’ÙƒÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±Ù Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ±Ù’ØµÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ®Ù’Ù„Ù Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’ÙƒÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ù‚ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ©ÙŒ Ù…ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙÙÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©ÙŒ ÙˆÙ ÙˆÙØµÙÙˆÙ„ÙŒ Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ…ÙŒ Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¬ÙØ§ÙÙ Ù…ÙÙƒÙ’Ø«ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¹ÙØ¸ÙØ©Ù ÙƒÙÙ‡Ù’ÙÙŒ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙˆÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ·Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‚Ù Ø·ÙØ±Ù’ÙÙÙ‡Ù ÙƒÙØ«ÙØ±Ù Ø£ÙØ³ÙÙÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¬ÙØ¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø±Ù Ø´ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù†ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø³ÙØ¤Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ§ ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’ØµÙÙÙÙƒÙ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙØ³ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù†ÙØ´Ù’Ø±Ù Ù‚ÙØ¨ÙÙŠØ­Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø¥ÙØ­Ù’Ø³ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¶ÙØ§Ù‚Ù Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙ‚ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù†ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙØ·ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ§ ØªÙØµÙ’Ø¯ÙÙ‚ÙÙƒÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¶ÙØ¹Ù ÙŠÙÙƒÙ’Ø³ÙÙˆÙƒÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ø³ÙØ¹ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙØ§Ù‚Ù ÙƒÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ²Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø²ÙØ§Ù‚Ù ÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙØ§ÙƒÙÙÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø°ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¢Ø®ÙØ±Ù Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙØ±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ³ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø«ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø®ÙÙÙÙŠÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù†Ù’Ø­Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙØµÙ’Ø¯Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙØ­ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙØµÙ’Ø¯Ù Ø®ÙÙÙ‘ÙØªÙ’ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤ÙÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ø®ÙÙ„ÙØ§ÙÙ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙÙ’Ø³Ù Ø±ÙØ´Ù’Ø¯ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙØ±ÙÙÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØºÙ’ÙÙÙ„Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ø³Ù’ØªÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø£ÙÙ„ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ¹Ù ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø¬ÙØ±Ù’Ø¹ÙØ©Ù Ø´ÙØ±ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù ÙÙÙŠ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ù„ÙØ©Ù ØºÙØµÙØµØ§Ù‹ Ù„ÙØ§ ØªÙÙ†ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù†ÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙØ©ÙŒ Ø¥ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙØ²ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø£ÙØ®Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø°ÙÙŠ Ø±ÙÙ…ÙÙ‚Ù Ù‚ÙÙˆØªÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø­ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø¢ÙƒÙÙ„ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ù‚ÙÙˆØªÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ Ø§Ø¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ§ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ´ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙØ¬Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¶Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙØµÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙØ·Ù’Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ’Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙŠÙØªÙÙ†ÙØ§Ø²ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù†Ù [ÙŠÙØªÙØ³ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù†Ù] ÙÙÙŠ Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù’Ù…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙŠÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù ÙƒÙÙÙ’Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù„ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙŒ ÙˆÙ ØµÙØ­Ù’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙ„Ù Ø´ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙŒ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙØ±ÙÙ…Ù Ù„ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙÙ„ÙØ§Ù…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙØ¸Ù’Ù‡ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙØ³ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙÙ’Ø´ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø¥ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§ÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø®ÙØ¯ÙÙŠØ¹ÙØ©Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙ‚Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙØ¦ÙÙŠÙ…Ù Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø·ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ¨Ù ÙŠÙØµÙÙŠØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ØºÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¨Ù ÙŠÙØ¦ÙÙˆØ¨Ù Ù„ÙØ§ ØªÙØ±Ù’ØºÙØ¨Ù’ ÙÙÙŠÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø²ÙÙ‡ÙØ¯Ù ÙÙÙŠÙƒÙ Ø±ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙŠØ¯Ù Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±ÙØ¨Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù‚ÙØ±ÙÙŠØ¨Ù Ø³ÙÙ„Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙÙÙÙŠÙ‚Ù Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ø·Ù‘ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ‚Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø£ÙÙ„ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ³Ù’Ø±ÙØ¹Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø£ÙØ¯Ù’Ø±ÙÙƒÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙØ±Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ’Ø±ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙƒÙ ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§ ØªÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙÙÙŠÙƒÙ Ø§ØºÙ’ØªÙÙÙØ±Ù’ Ø²ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ØµÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ‚ÙÙƒÙ Ù„ÙÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù ÙŠÙØ±Ù’ÙƒÙØ¨ÙÙƒÙ Ø¹ÙØ¯ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØºÙØ¶ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¯ÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¶ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø·ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø­ÙØ²Ù’Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙØ°Ù‘ÙØ¨Ù Ù†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®ÙØ§ÙÙ Ø±ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙƒÙÙÙ‘Ù Ø¸ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù [Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®ÙØ§ÙÙ Ø±ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙƒÙÙÙÙŠÙ Ø¹ÙØ°ÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù] ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ²ÙØºÙ’ ÙÙÙŠ ÙƒÙÙ„ÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØ¸Ù’Ù‡ÙØ±Ù ÙÙØ®Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ±Ù‘Ù ÙÙÙ‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’Ø²ÙÙ„ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙÙŠÙ…ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙØ³ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø¥ÙØ¶ÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ø²Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØµÙ’ØºÙØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØµÙÙŠØ¨ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ¹Ù Ø¹ÙØ¸ÙÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ©Ù ØºÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ù‡ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙØ§ØªÙ Ù‡ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙØ§ØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ ØªÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙƒÙØ±Ù’ØªÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¥ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙØ§ ÙÙÙŠÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¹ÙØ§ØµÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ¨Ù ÙÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±ÙØ¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ§Ø­ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙØ¹ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¤Ù’Ø³Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¹ÙÙŠÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ø´ÙØ±Ù‘ÙŒ Ø¨ÙØ´ÙØ±Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙŒ Ø¨ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù†ÙØ¹ÙÙŠÙ…Ù Ø¯ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ­Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆØ±ÙŒ ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø¯ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø¹ÙØ§ÙÙÙŠÙØ©ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù ØªÙØµÙ’Ø­ÙÙŠØ­Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¶Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ±Ù ØªÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯ÙÙˆ Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ±Ù ØªÙØµÙ’ÙÙÙŠÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙÙ„Ù Ø£ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙÙ„Ù ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙÙŠØµÙ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙØ³ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø£ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø·ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ù‡ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙØ§ØªÙ Ù„ÙÙˆÙ’ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙÙ‚ÙÙ‰ Ù„ÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙØ¯Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ±ÙØ¨Ù Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙØ¹ÙØ¯Ù Ù†ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ„ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙˆÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙÙÙ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙ„ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ„ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¯ÙØ±ÙØ¬Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø°ÙØ±Ù’ÙˆÙØ©Ù Ø°ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ø²Ù‘ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ÙŠÙØ©Ù ØºÙØ§ÙŠÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø­ÙØ¶Ù’Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙØ±ÙØ³Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ù…ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙØ§Ù…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø¯ÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø¬ÙÙˆÙ’Ù‡ÙØ±ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø²ÙØ¨ÙØ±Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¯ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ù„ÙØ¤Ù’Ù„ÙØ¤ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù ÙŠÙØ§Ù‚ÙÙˆØªÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø²ÙÙ…ÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ¯ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ø¬ÙØ§Ù†ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù ÙƒÙØ§ÙÙÙˆØ±Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¨ÙØ±Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù ÙŠÙÙ„ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¬ÙÙˆØ¬Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø°ÙÙ‡ÙØ¨Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù ØºÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ù‡ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ù†ÙÙˆØ±Ù Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙÙØªÙ’ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…ÙØ¦ÙØ°Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ¯ÙŒ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙØ§ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’ØªÙØ¯Ù Ø¨ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ’Ø·ÙØªÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø±ÙÙŠÙ’Ø·ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø±ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙÙŠÙ’Ø·ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù†ÙÙˆØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ØªÙØ§Ø¬Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙƒÙ’Ù„ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ³ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ©Ù Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ø£ÙØ´Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‚Ù Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ù‚ÙÙÙ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†ÙØ§ ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…ÙØ¦ÙØ°Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙØ±ÙØ¬ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙÙÙÙŠØ¹ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙŠÙ Ø¯ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø¯ÙØ±ÙØ¬ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø±ÙÙŠÙ’Ø·ÙØªÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø±ÙÙŠÙ’Ø·ÙØ©ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¬ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙˆØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙÙŠÙ’Ø·ÙØ©ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ§ÙÙÙˆØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ³ÙÙ„Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¨ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙÙÙˆØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ±ÙØ§Ù‚ÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ²Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙØ¬ÙØ¬Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙÙˆØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ’Ù…ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙ†ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ ØªÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø­ÙÙ„ÙÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙˆØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙØ±ÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ±ÙØ§Ù†ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ‚ÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ù†ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙŒ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ø³ÙÙ„ÙŒ Ø¥ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙØªÙ Ø¨ÙØ£ÙÙ†Ù’ÙˆÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ†ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙØ¬ÙØ¨Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¶ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ†ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ù„ÙØªÙÙ†ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ…ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ„ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ…ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) ØºÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©ÙŒ Ø¨ÙØ³Ù’Ø·ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØµÙØ±Ù ÙŠÙØ£Ù’ØªÙÙŠ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¯ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙŠÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ù‚ÙÙÙ Ø·ÙÙˆØ¨ÙÙ‰ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ±ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙÙÙØ±Ù ÙÙØ§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¹ÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ³ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ„ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ³ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) Ø¸ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ©ÙŒ ÙŠÙØ£Ù’ØªÙÙŠ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¯ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙŠÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ù‚ÙÙÙ Ø·ÙÙˆØ¨ÙÙ‰ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙÙØ§Ø²Ù Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ¯ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ù†ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙÙˆÙ’Ø­Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ Ø®ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙØ§ØµÙ Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ù‚Ù’ØªÙØ¯ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙØ¬ÙÙˆÙ…ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ ÙÙØ£ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‚ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ§ ÙŠÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù ÙˆÙÙ„ÙØ§ÙŠÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¶Ù ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙˆÙ‡ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ø´ÙØ±ÙÙÙ Ù…ÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¯ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ±ÙÙ…Ù Ù…ÙØ¢Ø¨ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙÙÙˆÙ’Ø²ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø³ÙØ±ÙØ±Ù Ù…ÙØªÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ù†Ù’Ø­ÙØ±ÙØ§ÙÙ ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙØ¯ÙÙˆØ¯Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù Ø°ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ØµÙØ±ÙØ§Ø·ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ²Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‚ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¨ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¯Ù ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙˆÙ‡ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ ØºÙØ¶ÙØ¨Ù Ø±ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¬ÙØ²ÙØ§Ø¡Ù‹ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ ÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙÙ…Ù’ ØªÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙˆÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø³ÙÙ„ÙÙÙ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ù†ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ù…ÙØ¶ÙÙ‰ Ø¥ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù…ÙØ®Ù’Ø¨ÙØ±Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ø³ÙÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¯Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ¨ÙØ´Ù‘ÙØ±Ø§Ù‹ Ø¨ÙØ±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙˆØµÙÙŠØ§Ù‹ Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ§ØªÙ‘ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙŠÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙÙÙˆÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØµÙÙÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙŠÙØªÙ‘ÙØ¨ÙØ¹ÙÙˆÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø´ÙØ±ÙÙŠØ¹ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ¦ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ¶ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙˆØ§ ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠÙÙƒÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù‡ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø¶ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙˆØ¹Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙØ¹Ù’Ø°ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’Ø°ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ¹Ù’ÙŠÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø­ÙØ¬Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙÙÙƒÙØ§Ù†ÙØªÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø±ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ³ÙÙ„Ù ÙˆÙ ÙˆÙØ±ÙÙˆØ¯Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¨ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ¦ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØµÙÙŠØ¨ÙØªÙ’ Ø¨ÙÙÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¯Ù Ù†ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù Ù†ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙØ¸ÙÙ…Ù Ù…ÙØµÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ ÙÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¹ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†ÙØªÙ’ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø³ÙØ¹ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙ„Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ù…ÙØµÙÙŠØ¨ÙØ©ÙŒ Ø¹ÙØ¸ÙÙ…ÙØªÙ’ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø±ÙØ²ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©ÙŒ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØªÙ’ ÙƒÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØµÙÙŠØ¨ÙØ©Ù Ø¨ÙØ±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) Ù„ÙØ£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø®ÙØªÙÙ…Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’Ø°ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙØ¹Ù’Ø°ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ·ÙØ¹Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ø­Ù’ØªÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø¬Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ°Ù’Ø±Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø®ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙØ¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ‡ÙÙŠÙ’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ„Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ù‚ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙØ·ÙØ§Ø¹ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù…ÙØ­Ù’ÙƒÙÙ…Ù ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ·ÙØ¹Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ø£ÙØ·Ø§Ø¹Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙˆÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ ÙÙÙ…Ø§ Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø³ÙÙ„Ù’Ù†Ø§ÙƒÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø­ÙÙÙÙŠØ¸Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ±ÙÙ†Ù Ø·ÙØ§Ø¹ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ·ÙØ§Ø¹ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’ØµÙÙŠÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù’ØµÙÙŠÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø¯ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ„Ù‹Ø§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ§ ÙÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ¶Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø´ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ØªÙ‘ÙØ¨ÙØ¹ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙØµÙØ§Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ†Ù Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙÙŠ ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¶ÙØ¹Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¸ÙÙŠÙ…Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù ØªÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‰ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙØ­Ù’Ø±ÙÙŠØ¶Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ØªÙ‘ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙØ±Ù’ØºÙÙŠØ¨Ù ÙÙÙŠ ØªÙØµÙ’Ø¯ÙÙŠÙ‚ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ¨ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø¨ÙØ¯ÙØ¹Ù’ÙˆÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù’ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙÙ…Ù’ ØªÙØ­ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ§ØªÙ‘ÙØ¨ÙØ¹ÙÙˆÙ†ÙÙŠ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¨Ù’ÙƒÙÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØºÙ’ÙÙØ±Ù’ Ù„ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ Ø°ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ¨ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ ÙÙØ§ØªÙ‘ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) Ù…ÙØ­ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ¶ÙØ§Ù‡Ù ØºÙÙÙ’Ø±ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙÙˆÙ’Ø²Ù ÙˆÙ ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙˆØ¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‘ÙÙˆÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙØ§Ø¶Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙØ§Ø¯Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ØºÙØ¶ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙØ®ÙØ·ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ù…ÙØ³Ù’ÙƒÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙƒÙ’ÙÙØ±Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ø²Ø§Ø¨Ù ÙÙØ§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¹ÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ­ÙÙˆØ¯Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØµÙ’ÙŠÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙƒÙ Ø§Ø³Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù…Ù’ØªÙØ­ÙÙ†Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØªÙÙ„Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠÙØ¯ÙÙŠ Ø£ÙØ¶Ù’Ø¯ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙÙ’Ù†ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ’ÙÙÙŠ Ø¬ÙØ­Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙØ¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø²ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙØ©Ù‹ Ù„ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¶Ù Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙÙŠÙ’ÙÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±ÙÙ…ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø´ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠ Ø£ÙØ²Ù’Ø±Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±ÙÙ…ÙÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙØµÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø´ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙÙÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙØ£ÙØ­Ù’ÙƒÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ø®Ù’ØªÙØµÙ‘ÙÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ØµÙ’Ø·ÙÙÙØ§Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙØ®ÙÙ„ÙØ§ÙÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ø­ÙØ´ÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¬ÙØ±ÙÙˆÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØµÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù†Ù’ØºÙØµÙ‘ÙØªÙ’ Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ­ÙØ§ÙÙÙ„Ù Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ø§Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙŠ ÙƒÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙÙˆØ³ÙÙ‰ Ø¥ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙØ§ Ù†ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙÙŠ ÙÙØ¹ÙÙ‚ÙÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù†ÙØ·ÙÙ‚Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø¥ÙØ°Ù’ Ø¹ÙØ±ÙÙÙÙˆÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙŠ Ù„ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙ Ø¨ÙØ£ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙØ£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù‡ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø£ÙØ®ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙˆØ³ÙÙ‰ Ù„ÙØ£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ ÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ù†ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙØ§Ù‚Ù’ØªÙØ¶ÙÙ‰ Ù†ÙØ¨ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙØ§ÙØ§Ù‹ Ù„ÙÙŠ ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙÙÙ Ù…ÙÙˆØ³ÙÙ‰ Ù‡ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙˆÙ†Ù (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) Ø­ÙÙŠÙ’Ø«Ù ÙŠÙÙ‚ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ø®Ù’Ù„ÙÙÙ’Ù†ÙÙŠ ÙÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù…ÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØµÙ’Ù„ÙØ­Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§ ØªÙØªÙ‘ÙØ¨ÙØ¹Ù’ Ø³ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ( Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ) Ø­ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ØªÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØªÙ’ Ø·ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙÙØ©ÙŒ ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„ÙØªÙ’ Ù†ÙØ­Ù’Ù†Ù Ù…ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù„ÙÙŠ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) ÙÙØ®ÙØ±ÙØ¬Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø­ÙØ¬Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙØ¯ÙØ§Ø¹Ù Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù ØµÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ØºÙØ¯ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø®ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù ÙÙØ£ÙÙ…ÙØ±Ù ÙÙØ£ÙØµÙ’Ù„ÙØ­Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø´ÙØ¨Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¨ÙØ±Ù Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ®ÙØ°Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ¶ÙØ¯ÙÙŠ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ Ø±ÙØ¦ÙÙŠÙ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¶Ù Ø¥ÙØ¨Ù’Ø·ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø±ÙØ§ÙÙØ¹Ø§Ù‹ ØµÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ„Ù‹Ø§ ÙÙÙŠ Ù…ÙØ­Ù’ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙØ§Ù‡Ù ÙÙØ¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙˆÙØ§Ù„ÙØ§Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ§Ù‡Ù ÙÙÙƒÙØ§Ù†ÙØªÙ’ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙÙ„ÙØ§ÙŠÙØªÙÙŠ ÙˆÙÙ„ÙØ§ÙŠÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙØ¯ÙØ§ÙˆÙØªÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙØ¯ÙØ§ÙˆÙØ©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’Ø²ÙÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙ Ù„ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¯ÙÙŠÙ†ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØªÙ’Ù…ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’ÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ Ù†ÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙØªÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ¶ÙÙŠØªÙ Ù„ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙØ³Ù’Ù„Ø§Ù…Ù Ø¯ÙÙŠÙ†Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙÙƒÙØ§Ù†ÙØªÙ’ ÙˆÙÙ„ÙØ§ÙŠÙØªÙÙŠ ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ¶ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø°ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’Ø²ÙÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ø®Ù’ØªÙØµÙØ§ØµØ§Ù‹ Ù„ÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ ØªÙÙƒÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ…Ø§Ù‹ Ù†ÙØ­ÙÙ„ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¸ÙØ§Ù…Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ ØªÙÙÙ’ØµÙÙŠÙ„Ù‹Ø§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ­ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ø±ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„Ø§Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙƒÙ’Ù…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ³Ù’Ø±ÙØ¹Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­Ø§Ø³ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù Ù„ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø°ÙÙƒÙØ±Ù’ØªÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ù„ÙØ¹ÙØ¸ÙÙ…Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ø±Ù’ØªÙÙÙØ§Ø¹Ù ÙÙØ·ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ø³Ù’ØªÙÙ…ÙØ§Ø¹Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ¦ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙ‚ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØµÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¯ÙÙˆÙ†ÙÙŠÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ´Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙØ§Ø²ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙŠ ÙÙÙŠÙ…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙØ­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙÙƒÙØ¨ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø¶ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ø§Ø¹Ù’ØªÙÙ‚ÙØ¯ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙÙÙ„ÙØ¨ÙØ¦Ù’Ø³Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙØ±ÙØ¯ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ¨ÙØ¦Ù’Ø³Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙØ£ÙÙ†Ù’ÙÙØ³ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù‘ÙØ¯ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØªÙÙ„ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙ†ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¯ÙÙˆØ±ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØªÙØ¨ÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ£Ù ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¯Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØµÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙÙ‚ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ†ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’ØªÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙØ§ ÙŠØ§ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’ØªÙ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†ÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†ÙÙƒÙ Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ´Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙÙØ¨ÙØ¦Ù’Ø³Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙÙÙŠÙØ¬ÙÙŠØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ´Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø±ÙØ«ÙÙˆØ«ÙØ©Ù ÙŠÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’ØªÙÙ†ÙÙŠ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø£ÙØªÙ‘ÙØ®ÙØ°Ù’ÙƒÙ Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ„Ù‹Ø§ Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¶Ù’Ù„ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø¥ÙØ°Ù’ Ø¬ÙØ§Ø¡ÙÙ†ÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø´Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ’Ø·ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’Ø³ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø®ÙØ°ÙÙˆÙ„Ù‹Ø§ ÙÙØ£ÙÙ†ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø¶ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ù…ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙÙŠÙ…ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙƒÙÙÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ±Ù’Ø¢Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ø¥ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ù‡ÙØ¬ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙƒÙØ°Ù‘ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø·Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ù†ÙÙƒÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ¦ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø±ÙØªÙØ¹ÙØ§ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ·ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ØµÙØ±ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’ØºÙØ±ÙÙˆØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‚ÙØ·ÙØ¹Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø´ÙÙÙØ§ Ø­ÙÙÙ’Ø±ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø´ÙØ±Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙØ±ÙÙˆØ¯Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø£ÙØ®Ù’ÙŠÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙÙÙÙˆØ¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ø±ÙÙˆØ¯Ù ÙŠÙØªÙØµÙØ§Ø±ÙØ®ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙØ¹Ù’Ù†ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØªÙÙ†ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³Ù’Ø±ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø±ÙØ§Ø­ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙØ°ÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯ÙÙˆØ­ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ²ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø£ÙØµÙ’Ù†ÙØ§Ù…Ù ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙØ¯ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’Ø«ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙŠÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ…ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ§Ø³ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’ØµÙØ¨ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØªÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØªÙ‘ÙØ®ÙØ°ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ¬Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ­ÙÙŠØ±ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ„ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¨ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ§Ù…Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ³Ù’ØªÙÙ‚Ù’Ø³ÙÙ…ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ²Ù’Ù„ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø¹ÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ‡ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù Ø°ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ´ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø·ÙØ¹ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ø¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙØ­Ù’ÙˆÙØ°Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ø´Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ’Ø·ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ ØºÙÙ…ÙØ±ÙØªÙ’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø³ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¯ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ¶ÙØ¹ÙÙˆÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù†Ù’ÙÙØ·ÙÙ…ÙÙˆÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¶ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙÙØ£ÙØ®Ù’Ø±ÙØ¬ÙÙ†ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø±ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ·Ù’Ù„ÙØ¹ÙÙ†ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø±ÙØ£Ù’ÙÙØ©Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ³Ù’ÙÙØ±Ù Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ¬ÙØ¨Ù Ù†ÙÙˆØ±Ø§Ù‹ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù‚Ù’ØªÙØ¨ÙØ³ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙÙØ¶Ù’Ù„Ù‹Ø§ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ØªÙ‘ÙØ¨ÙØ¹ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ£Ù’ÙŠÙÙŠØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØµÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙ‚ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØªÙØ¨ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ¡ÙÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙØ«Ù’Ø±ÙØ©Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙØ§Ø¨ÙØªÙ’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ„ÙÙˆØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¨Ù’ØµÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ°Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ†ÙØªÙ’ Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ±ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø·ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ ØµÙØ§Ø±ÙÙˆØ§ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ù†ÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ°Ù’ÙƒÙÙˆØ±ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ±ÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³ÙÙˆØ±ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø®ÙÙˆÙ’ÙÙ ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ…Ù’Ø¹Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù ÙƒÙÙˆÙ’ÙÙ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¶ÙØ§Ø¡ÙØªÙ’ Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙÙØ§Ø®ÙØ±Ù Ù…ÙØ¹ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙØ¬Ù’Ù†ÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¯ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¯Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„Ù’Ù†ÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¯ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„ÙØ§Ù…Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ´Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù’Ù†ÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø«ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙÙŠÙ…ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙ„ÙØ¬ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙØ§ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯ÙØªÙ’ Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø¢Ø«ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ­ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ù…ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØµÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù†ÙØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙÙƒÙÙÙ Ø²ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù ÙŠÙØ¸Ù’Ù‡ÙØ±ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù†ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ£Ù’ØªÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ«ÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ©Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø¯ÙØ¹ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù†ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙÙÙØ¹ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙƒÙ Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ§ ÙƒÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù’Ø­ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®ÙÙÙ’Ù‚ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ ÙˆÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ¶Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø±ÙØ¬ÙØ¹ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù†Ù’ØªÙÙƒÙØµÙÙˆØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¯Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø·ÙÙ„ÙØ¨ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¸Ù’Ù‡ÙØ±ÙÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ¯ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ ØºÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ±ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¢Ø«ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØºÙØ¨ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ­Ù’ÙƒÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ¯ÙÙˆØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ÙˆÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ„ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙÙÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ„Ù‹Ø§ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙƒÙ Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ§ ÙƒÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù’Ø­ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®ÙÙÙ’Ù‚ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ ÙˆÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ¶Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø±ÙØ¬ÙØ¹ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ù†Ù’ØªÙÙƒÙØµÙÙˆØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¯Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø·ÙÙ„ÙØ¨ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¸Ù’Ù‡ÙØ±ÙÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ¯ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ ØºÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ±ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¢Ø«ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØºÙØ¨ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ­Ù’ÙƒÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ¯ÙÙˆØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ÙˆÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§Ø³Ù’ØªÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ„ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙÙÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ„Ù‹Ø§ Ø§ØªÙ‘ÙØ®ÙØ°ÙÙˆÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¸ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø²ÙØ¹ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ§ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ø®Ù’ØªÙØ§Ø±ÙÙˆØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¢Ù„Ù Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙØ­ÙØ§ÙÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) Ù…ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ø®Ù’ØªÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¬ÙØ±Ù Ø¢Ù„Ù Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙØ­ÙØ§ÙÙØ©Ù Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¬ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØµÙØ§Ø±ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ù†ÙØ§Ù…ÙÙˆØ³Ù Ù‡ÙØ§Ø´ÙÙ…Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯Ù Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙÙ Ø£ÙÙ„ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙÙ„Ù Ø´ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù Ø²ÙÙˆØ±Ù ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙØ¹ÙØªÙ’ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¥ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø´ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØªÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù ØµÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ù…ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙÙÙ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù Ø³ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø±ÙØ¬ÙØ¹ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ( ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ) Ù…ÙØ¶ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø³ÙÙˆØ¡Ù Ø®ÙÙ„ÙØ§ÙÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ„Ù’ÙŠÙÙˆÙ‚ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’ÙˆÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø­ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ‚ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ù’ÙŠÙØ³Ù’ØªÙÙŠÙ’Ù‚ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ ÙŠÙÙˆØ¹ÙØ¯ÙÙˆÙ†Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù ØªÙØ£Ù’ØªÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙÙŠÙ’Ø­ÙØ©Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù Ø°Ù„ÙÙƒÙ ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø®ÙØ±ÙÙˆØ¬Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ§ Ù†ÙØ­Ù’Ù†Ù Ù†ÙØ­Ù’ÙŠÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØµÙÙŠØ±Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù ØªÙØ´ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙÙ‚Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¶Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø³ÙØ±Ø§Ø¹Ø§Ù‹ Ù€ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¢Ø®ÙØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙˆØ±ÙØ©Ù Ù€ .", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/1/1/4/1", "volume": 8, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 4, "thaqalaynSanad": "4. Muhammad Bin Ali Bin Maâ€™mar, from Muhammad Bin Ali Bin Ukaayat Al-Tamimy, from Al-Husayn Bin Al-Nazar Al-Fahry, from Abu Amro Al-Awzaiy, from Amro Bin Shimr, from Jabir Bin Yazeed who said: ", "thaqalaynMatn": "â€˜I came up to Abu Jaâ€™far (asws), so I said, â€˜O son (asws) of the Messenger (saww) of Allah (azwj), the differing among the Shiites in this Doctrine causes me painâ€™. He (asws) said: â€˜O Jabir, shall I (asws) not suffice you with the meanings of their differences, from where they are differing, and from which perspective they are separating?â€™ I said, â€˜Yes, O son (asws) of the Messenger (saww) of Allah (azwj)â€™. He (asws) said: â€˜So do not differ if they differ, O Jabir. The one who fights against the Master (asws) of the Era (Imam (asws) of his time) is like the one who has fought against the Messenger (saww) of Allah (azwj) in his (saww) days. O Jabir, listen attentivelyâ€™. I said, â€˜As you (asws) likeâ€™. He (asws) said: â€˜Listen attentively, and make it reach to wherever your ride takes you, that Amir-ul-Momineen (asws) preached to the People at Al-Medina, seven days after the passing away of the Messenger (saww) of Allah (azwj), and that was when he (asws) was free from collecting the Quran and compiling it. He (asws) said: â€˜Praise be to Allah (azwj) Who has Prevented the imaginations to grasp Him (azwj) except for His (azwj) Existence, and Veiled the intellects to think about His (azwj) Essence due to the restrictions of Him (azwj) having no similarities or images. But He (azwj) is the One in Whose Essence there are not differences nor any division into a number of parts due to the Perfection. He (azwj) is separate from the things, not due to being in a different place, and He (azwj) is in things, not being mixed within them, and He (azwj) Knows these, not by the use of tools. And He (azwj) is not Knowledgeable except by it, and there is nothing between Him (azwj) and His (azwj) Knowledge, any other knowledge. He (azwj) is the Knowledgeable by Himself (azwj). If it is said that He (azwj) was, it would be interpreted as the eternal existence, and if it is said that He (azwj) will never cease (to exist), it would be interpreted as the negation of the non-existence. He (azwj) is Glorious, and higher than the words of those who worship other than Him (azwj) and have taken a god other than Him (azwj). He (azwj) is Higher and Greater. We (asws) Praise Him (azwj) with a Praise of those of His (azwj) creatures who has Pleased Him (azwj), and He (azwj) has Made it to be more than Obligatory upon Himself (azwj) to Accept it. And I (asws) hereby testify that there is no God but Allah (azwj), One, with no Associates for Himself (azwj), and I (asws) testify that Muhammad (saww) is His (azwj) servant and His (azwj) Messenger. These two testimonies elevate the words and increase the deeds. Light is the Scale from which these two are raised from, and heavy is the Scale on which these two are placed. And by these two is the victory of the Paradise, and the salvation from the Fire, and the Permission upon the (crossing of) the Bridge. And it is by the testimony that you will be entering the Paradise, and by the Prayers that you will be consuming the Mercy. Send the greetings frequently upon your Prophet (saww) â€œ[33:56] Surely Allah and His angels bless the Prophet; O you who believe! call for (Divine) blessings on him and salute him with a (becoming) salutationâ€. O you people! There is no nobility higher than Al-Islam, nor a prestige more honourable than the piety, nor a stronghold better than devoutness, nor an intercessor more excellent than repentance, nor a robe more majestic than good health, nor a protection more secure than safety, nor a wealth better at dispelling poverty than contentment with conviction/cetainity, nor a treasure more enriching than being satisfied. And the one lives at the subsistence level and the reduction in comfort, so he has made the preparations for the rest, and the desires is the key to the fatigue, and the monopolisation follows from affliction, and the jealousy is a scourge on the Religion, and the greed is an invitation to the indulgence in the sins and the reason for the deprivation, and the transgression is a driver to the destruction, and greed gathers all the defects. Perhaps a failed greed, a false hope leads to the dispossession and a business trade to incur a loss. The one who gets involved in the matters without looking at the consequences will be exposed to misfortunes, and the most evil of the collars (humiliation) for a Believer is the sin. O you people! There is no treasure more beneficial than the knowledge, and no honour higher than the forbearance, and no nobility more eloquent than the ethics, and no affliction greater than anger, and no majesty more decorative than the intellect, and nothing is more disgraceful than the lies, and no protection safer than silence, and no absentee which is nearer than the death. O you people! The one who looks at his own faults will be too pre-occupied to look at the faults of the others, and the one who is contented with the sustenance of Allah (azwj) will not despair upon what is in the hands of the others, and the one who unsheathes the sword of rebellion will be killed by it, and the one who drills a pit for his brother will fall into it himself, and the one who discloses the veiled (privacy) of others will uncover the privacy of his own house, and the one who forgets his own mistakes will magnify the mistakes of the others, and the one who wonders at his own opinion will go astray, and the one who considers himself to be needless due to his intellect will make mistakes, and the one who is arrogant to the people will be humiliated, and the one who is a fool to the people will be hated, and the one who mixes with the villains will be degraded, and the one who burdens himself with what he cannot endure will be frustrated. O you people! There is no wealth more valuable than the intellect, and no poverty which is more intense than the ignorance, and no preacher which is more profound than the sound advice, and no reasoning like the contemplation, and no worship like the pondering, and no demonstration more reliable than the consultation, and no isolation more severe than the self-conceit, nor piety like refraining from the Prohibitions, and no forbearance like patience and silence. O you people! In the human being there are ten qualities, which are revealed by his tongue and becomes witness to his hidden thoughts, it is a ruler by which he decides between what to be said, and the words by which he returns the answer, and an intercessor (limbs) by which he achieves the needs, and a describer (senses) by which he recognises the things, and a commander (decision) by which he commands for the good, and a preacher by which he prohibits from the ugly (deeds), and a consoler by which he gives solace to the sorrows, and a conscious by which he clears the malice, and an articulator by which he gives pleasure to the ears. O you people! There is no good in keeping silent about the â€˜Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙÙƒÙ’Ù…Ùâ€™ (the Command) just as there is no good in speaking out of ignorance. And know, O you people, that the one who does not control his tongue will regret, and the one who does not learn will be ignorant, and the one who does not forbear will not content, and the one who is not deterred does not learn, and the one who does not know is insulted, and the one who is insulted is not respected, and the one who is not respected is taunted, and the one who acquires wealth from where he has no right to do so will spend it extravagantly in other that the right way, and the one who does not desist when he is praised will desist when he is condemned, and the one who does not give in comfort will also be refused when in the need, and the one who seeks the honour without being deserving of it will be disgraced, the one who overcomes with injustice will also be overpowered, and the one who opposed the truth will necessitate weakness for himself, and the one who ponders will be dignified, and the one who is arrogant will be belittled, and the one who is not good will not be praised. O you people! The death is (better) before the lowliness, and the endurance before the apathy, and the accounting before the Punishment, and the grave is better than the poverty, lowering the sight is better than looking at a great deal, and the time, a day is for you and a day against you. So if it is for you, do not be ungrateful, and if it is against you, observe patience. So with both of them you will be Examined. (And in another copy â€“ â€˜And with both of them you will be Testedâ€™) O you people! The strangest of what is in the human being is his heart, and in it are matters of wisdom and the antibodies to the one who opposes it. When there is prosperity for him, greed humiliates him, and if greed excites him, the thriftiness destroys him, when despair overpowers him, the remorse kills him, and when the anger presents itself, the rage intensifies, and when he is happy and satisfied he forgets to conserve, and when fear seizes him he gets preoccupied by caution, and when security is widened for him his honour makes him complacent (and in another copy â€˜pride takes him overâ€™), and when new bounties come up for him pride takes him over, and when he is benefitted by money his richness makes him oppressive, and when poverty bites him he is preoccupied by the affliction (and in another copy â€˜he strives in the weepingâ€™), and when he is inflicted by hardship anxiety injures him, and when the hunger exhausts him he is disabled by the weakness, and when he over-eats he is upset by indigestion, so every deficiency is harmful to him, and every excess spoils him. O you people! The one who is miserly will be disgraced and the one who is generous will be the master, and the one who increases his wealth becomes the leader and the one who increases his forbearance becomes noble, and the one who ponders regarding the Essence of Allah (azwj) becomes an Atheist, and the one who frequents in something becomes known for it, and the one frequently jokes will be taken lightly, and the one who frequently laughs his prestige goes away, the one who has no ethics will corrupt. The best deed is the maintenance of honour by wealth. There is none who sits with the ignorant ones who is reasonable, for the one who sits with the ignorant ones should ready himself for (a lot of) talk (against him)â€™. And he (asws) said: â€˜Neither did the rich one obtain salvation from death by his wealth, nor did the poor one due to his scarcityâ€™. O you people! Had the death been (a commodity) which could be bought, the good and the honourable ones of the world, as well as the wicked and the greedy ones would have bought it. O you people! There are witnesses for the hearts which hold them back from being the people of excesses, and there is insight for the understanding, which alerts the self and caution it from the danger. And for the heart there are memories of desires, and the intellect admonishes and prohibits from it. And in the experiences there is an appellant, which is a reliable guide to the right way. It is sufficient for yourself what you would not like it to happen to others, and it is upon you that the same should be for your believing brother, and in it upon him, likewise. The one who considers his own opinion to be self-sufficing from him would endanger him, and the pondering before the deeds would keep you safe from remorse. And the one who welcomes different opinions would understand the places of mistakes. And the one who refrains from the useless matters his opinion would balance the intellects. The one who fortifies his carnal desires so he has kept his respect, and the one who restrains his tongue is trusted by the people and will achieve his needs. And in the alteration of the situations the jewels of the men become known, and the passing days make apparent the inner selves. And there is no enjoyment in the swiftness of lightning for the one who goes through darkness. And the one who is recognised by the wisdom, the eyes will notice him with reverence and prestige. The most noble of riches is the avoidance of wishes, and the patience is a shield against poverty, and the greed is a sign of poverty, and the stinginess is the gown of destitution, and the cordiality with the relatives is beneficial, and the sympathy of the poor is better than the disloyal rich. Counselling is like a cave for the one who listens to it, and the one who does not restrain his eyes, his regrets increase. And the (passage of) time has made it to be more than obligatory for the one who avails it, to thank it. The tongue does very little justice in displaying the ugly and the good. The one who constricts his ethics, his family get tired of him. And the one who seeks, achieves it for a long time, and very little of what is wished is sincere. Modesty clothes you with dignity, and in the extensiveness of the morals is a treasure for the sustenance, and how many from the people remain in their sins until the end of their days. And the one who robes himself with bashfulness as his clothing his faults are hidden from the people. And intend moderation in your speech, for the one who intends it will incur light expenses, and in the opposition to the ego is guidance for you. And the one who recognises the â€˜daysâ€™ (his end) will never be oblivious from the preparation. Nay! Along with every sip (of drink) is (possibility of) choking, and in every morsel is (the possibility of) suffocation. Bounties cannot be achieved except by the decline of other (bounties), and for every breath is life, and for every grain is a consumer, and you are the morsel of the death. And know, O you people! The ones who walks upon the face of the earth will end up in its belly, and the nights and the days, they dispute (they accelerate) regarding the destruction of the life-span. O you people! Ingratitude for the bounties is wickedness, and the company of the ignorant is ominous. The softness of the speech is from the prestige. And from the (acts of) worship are displayed by the tongue (make it heard) and increase the greetings. Beware of deceit for it is from the manners of the villains. Every seeker does not get a share, nor does every absentee return. Its not certain that one will get what he wishes and the lost is recovered. Seek (the company) of friends before setting of and ensure (good) neighbourhood before (moving into) the house. Indeed! The one who moves fast will catche up with the slower ones. Conceal the private (matters) of your brother just as he knows regarding you. Forgive the mistakes of your friend for the day that your enemy comes to dominate you. The one who is angry with the one over whom he has no power to injure, his grief would be prolonged and it will punish his soul. The one who fears his Lord (azwj) will refrain from committing injustices. The one who is good with the words would display his pride. And the one who does not recognise the good from the evil, is like an animal. Indeed the corruption destroys the provisions (of the Hereafter). How little is the difficulty (of today) as compared with the great destitution tomorrow. Far it is! Far it is from being compared. And what is your antipathy due to, except for your indulgence in acts of disobedience and the sins. So how close is the rest to the tiredness, and the misery from the Bounties. The hardships are not painful after which there is the Paradise, and the goodtime is not the (lasting) comfort after which there is the Fire. And every bounty apart from the Paradise is insignificant, and every affliction apart from the Fire is healthy. And turning away from correcting the consciences leads to the major sins. Purification of the deeds is more difficult than the deed itself, and the sincerity of the intention from the corruption is more difficulty upon the performer of the deed than the lengthy Jihaad. Far it is! Had it not been for the piety I (asws) would have been the shrewdest of the Arabs. O you people! Allah (azwj) the High Promised His (azwj) Prophet (saww) Muhammad (saww) the Means (Al-Waseela), and His (azwj) Promise is True, and Allah (azwj) does not Go against His (azwj) Promise. Surely Al-Waseela is on the steps of the Paradise and is at the peak of the nearness (to Allah (azwj)), and is a total security at the very end of it. There are a thousand staircases, and what is in between one staircase and the other there is a travel distance by a fine horse of a hundred years. And in between these is a staircase of gems going up to a staircase of jewels, to a staircase of aquamarines, to a staircase of pearls, to a staircase of rubies, to a staircase of emeralds, to a staircase of corals, to a staircase of camphor, to a staircase of ambergris, to a staircase of aloe, to a staircase of gold, to a staircase of clouds, to a staircase of air, to a staircase of Light which encompasses all of the Gardens. And on that Day the Messenger (saww) of Allah (azwj) would be seated wearing two Garments â€“ a Garment of the Mercy of Allah (azwj) and a Garment of the Light of Allah (azwj). On him (saww) will be a Crown of the Prophet-hood and a Garland of the Message, the Light of which will illuminate the whole of the Pausing Place (Station in the Hereafter). And on that Day, I (asws) will be upon the High Level, and it will be lower than his (saww) Level, and on me (asws) would be two Garments â€“ a Garment of purple Light and a Garment of Camphor. And the Messengers (as) and the Prophets (saww) would have paused upon my (asws) staircase, with the Flags of the Eras and the Proof of the ages on our (asws) right, and they (as) will have Majestic Garments of Light and the Prestige. There is no Angel of Proximity, and no Messenger Prophet (saww) who will look at us (asws) except that he will be stunned by our (asws) Light. And stranger than our (asws) Illumination and our (asws) Majesty is the Al-Waseela on our (asws) right, and on the right of the Messenger (saww) of Allah (azwj) will be a cloud stretching out as far as the eye can see. A Call will come out from it: â€˜O people of the Pausing Place! Goodness is for the ones who loved the successor (asws) and believed in the Prophet (saww), the â€˜Ummyâ€™ of the Arabs. And the one who disbelieved, so the Fire is Prepared for him. And on the left of Al-Waseela, from the left of the Messenger (saww) of Allah (azwj) will be a shade. A Call will come out from it: â€˜O people of the Pausing Place! Goodness is for the ones who loved the successor (asws) and believed in the â€˜Ummyâ€™ Prophet (saww), the one (saww) for whom is the High Kingdom. There is no success for anyone, nor happiness for the soul, and the Paradise except for the one who is meeting his Creator (azwj) with the sincerity for these two (asws) and the follower of the stars (Imams (asws)) from these two (asws). Be convinced, O people of Al-Wilayah of Allah (azwj), of the whitening of your faces, and the prestige of your seating, and the honour of your return and your success today, with bliss, facing each other. And O people of the deviation, and the diverters from Allah (azwj), Mighty is His (azwj) Remembrance, and from His (azwj) Messenger (saww), and from His (azwj) Path, and the Flags of the eras, be convinced of the blackening of your faces, and the Wrath of your Lord (azwj), a Recompense of what you used to do before. And there is none from the Messengers (as) who preceded and none from the Prophets (as) of the past except that he (as) had informed his (as) community of the Messenger (saww) to come after him (as), and the good news of the Messenger (saww) of Allah (azwj), and bequeathed to his (as) community, and described him (saww) to his (as) community his (saww) qualities, and that they should follow him (saww) and be upon his (saww) Law, so that they would not stray with regards to him (saww) after him (as). So the ones who would face destruction and straying afterwards would only be after the occurrence of the reasons and the warnings, and having been acquainted with the evidence, and the arguments having been established. So the communities lived in hope about the Messengers (as) and the Prophets (as) to come, if they were in difficult circumstances in the absence of a Prophet (as) after their Prophet (as), in their great difficulties and disasters, so they were at the time in a state of hope. And there have never been a difficulty which was greater, and nor a disaster greater like the difficulties with the Messenger of Allah (saww), because Allah (azwj) Ended the Warnings, and the Reasons, and Cut-off through him (saww) the Arguments, and the Reasons between Him (azwj) and His (azwj) creatures, and Made him (saww) to be His (azwj) Door which was between Him (azwj) and His (azwj) servants, and as His (azwj) Authority which nothing would be Acceptable except by him (saww), nor any nearness to Him (azwj) except by being obedient to him (saww). And He (azwj) Said Decisively in His (azwj) Book: â€œ[4:80] Whoever obeys the Messenger, he indeed obeys Allah and whoever turns back, so We have not sent you as a keeper over themâ€. So He (azwj) Joined obedience to Himself (azwj) with obedience to him (saww), and disobedience to Himself (azwj) with disobedience to him (saww). So that was the Evidence which was Delegated to him (saww), and a Testimony against the one who obeys him (saww), and disobeys him (saww), and between that in other places from the Great Book. So the Blessed and the High Said in the Incitement to follow him (saww), and the Exhortation with regards to his (saww) ratification, and the acceptance of his (saww) Call: â€œ[3:31] Say, (O Muhammad, tell to mankind): If you love Allah, follow me; Allah will love you and forgive you your sinsâ€. So following him (saww) achieves the Love of Allah (azwj) and His (azwj) Pleasure, and the Forgiveness of the sins, and the completeness of the success, and the necessitation of the Paradise. And in the turning away from him (saww) achieves the Enmity of Allah (azwj), and His (azwj) Wrath, and His (azwj) Harshness, and remoteness from Him (azwj), and a dwelling in the Fire and that is His (azwj) Statement: â€œ[11:17] and whoever of the (different) parties disbelieves in it, the Fire will be their promised meeting-placeâ€, meaning the striving against him (saww) and disobedience to him (saww). Allah (azwj), Blessed is His (azwj) Name, Tested His (azwj) servants by me (asws), and killed those that opposed Him (azwj) by my (asws) hand, and annihilated those that strived against Him (azwj) by my (asws) sword, and Made me (asws) to be a Means of nearness to Him (azwj) (Zulfat) for the Believers, and a ground of death for the toughest tyrants, and His (azwj) Sword against the criminals, and Strengthened by me (asws) the back of His (azwj) Messenger (saww), and Honoured me (asws) by helping him (saww), and Privileged me (asws) with his (saww) knowledge, and Gifted me (asws) with his (saww) Laws, and Favoured me (asws) for his (saww) successorship, and Chose me (asws) for his (saww) Caliphate in his (saww) community. So he (saww) said when he (saww) mobilised the Emigrants and the Helpers in their gathering: â€˜O you people! Surely, Ali (asws) is from me (saww) like Haroun (as) was from Musa (as) except that there is no Prophet (as) to come after me (saww). So the Believers understood that the Messenger (saww) was speaking on behalf of Allah (azwj). They recognised me (asws) that I (asws) was not his (saww) brother by his (saww) father (as) or his (saww) mother (as) as was the case with Haroun (saww) who was the brother of Musa (as) from his (as) father and his (as) mother (as), nor was I (asws) a Prophet (as). The Prophet-hood has ended. But, that was from him (saww) appointing me (asws) as the Caliph just as Musa (as) had appointed Haroun (as) as the Caliph when he (as) said: â€œ[7:142] Take my place among my people, and act well and do not follow the way of the mischief-makers.â€ And his (saww) words when a group spoke saying, â€˜We are the friends of the Messenger of Allah (azwj)â€™. So the Messenger (saww) of Allah (azwj) went out to the Farewell Pilgrimage, then came up to Ghadeer Khumm. So he (saww) ordered for something resembling a Pulpit to be prepared to him (saww). Then he (saww) ascended it, grabbed my (asws) arm and raised it to the extent that the whiteness of his (saww) armpits were seen, and said in a raised voice in that forum: â€˜The one to whom I (saww) was the Master of, so Ali (asws) is his Master. Our Allah (azwj)! Befriend the one who befriends him (asws), and be Inimical to the one who is an enemy to him (asws). Thus, upon my (asws) Wilayah is the Wilayah of Allah (azwj), and upon my (asws) enmity is the enmity against Allah (azwj). And Allah (azwj), Mighty and Majestic Revealed in that day: â€œ[5:3] This day have I perfected for you your religion and completed My favor on you and chosen for you Islam as a religionâ€. So upon my (asws) Wilayah was the completion of the Religion, and the Pleasure of the Lord (azwj), Majestic is His (azwj) Remembrance. And Allah (azwj), Blessed and High, Revealed it especially for me (asws) and Honoured the Gifting it for me (asws) as (a sign of) greatness, and its gifting from the Messenger of Allah (saww), and it is the Statement of the High: â€œ[6:62] Then are men returned unto Allah, their protector, the (only) reality: Is not His the command? and He is the swiftest in taking account.â€ If I (asws) were to mention my (asws) merits, its loftiness would be great, and itâ€™s listening prolonged. And about me (asws), two miserable ones before me (asws) disputed with me (asws) regarding that in which they had no rights over it, and they rode its misguidance, and believed in the ignorance. So evil is what was to them, what they returned to, and evil is what they made as a cradle for themselves. They cursed each other in their own houses, and each one of them distanced himself from his companion saying to him when he met him, â€˜Alas! If only there was the distance between the East and the West between me and between youâ€™. So evil is the friend who answered him, the miserable one upon his ragged condition, â€œ[25:28] O woe is me! would that I had not taken such a one for a friend. [25:29] He verily led me astray from the Reminder after it had reached me. Satan was ever manâ€™s deserter in the hour of needâ€. So I (asws) am the Reminder from which he went astray, and the Way from which he deviated, and the Belief which he denied, and the Quran from which he fled, and the Religion which he belied, and the Path from which he digressed. And the debris which they lived upon in their constant pride, they were on it on the verge of the Fire (prepared) for them - an evil return amongst the wicked group, to a condemned destination. They will be shouting curses at each other grumbling in regret. There will be no rest for these two; nor a respite from their inevitable Punishment. The people never ceased to be the worshippers of the idols and being the custodians of the idols, establishing rituals for them, and designated certain offerings for them in order to seek nearness to them. And they made for them titles such as â€˜Al-Baheyra, and Al-Waseyla, and Al-Saâ€™ebat, and Al-Haamâ€™. They distributed these idols by casting lots by arrows, wondering about Allah (azwj) Mighty is His (azwj) Remembrance. They were confused about the guidance, hastening to the remoteness, and they had been overcome by Satan (la) who had flooded them with the darkness of ignorance, having breastfed them with ignorance and weaned them with misguidance. Allah (azwj) Brought us (asws) out to them as a Mercy, and Informed about us (asws) as being higher than them, and Removed the Veil of Light from us (asws) for those that sought us (asws), and Preferred the ones who followed it (the Light), and we (asws) were a support for the ones who ratified it. So honour followed after the disgrace, and the plenty after the scarcity. And their hearts and their eyes revered them, and the tyrants yielded to them, and its respective communities became the people of the Bounties, being worthy of mention, and prestigious, and ease, and security after fear, and â€˜Ø¬ÙÙ…Ù’Ø¹Ùâ€™ union after having been separated. And Maâ€™d Bin Adnan was illuminated (famous) due to us (asws) and we (asws) inserted them in the Door of Guidance, and we (asws) entered them into the House of Peace, and we (asws) clothed them with the garment of Belief, and they became famous due to us (asws) in the worlds, and the effects of the righteous people appeared for them in the days of the Messenger (saww), from a striving protector, and an obedient worshipper, and an ascetic retreater, and they preserved the trusts and became as such until when Allah (azwj) Mighty and Majestic Called back His (azwj) Prophet (saww) and Raised him (saww) to Himself (azwj). That was not after him (saww) except like a moment of pulse, or a glimmer of lightning for them to return back and turn back upon their heels, and sought revenge by forming battalions, and they blocked the Door and destroyed the houses, and changed the effects of the Messenger of Allah (saww), and turned away from his (saww) rulings, and distanced themselves from his (saww) Light, and they changed his (saww) Caliph with an alternate. They took to him, and they were unjust in doing so, and they thought that the one whom they had chosen from the descendants of Abu Kohafa (Abu Bakr) is higher in status than the one (asws) whom the Messenger (saww) of Allah (azwj) had chosen to be in his (saww) place, and that the Emigrants from the progeny of Abu Kohafa were better than the Emigrants and the Helpers of the Rabbi of the Law Hashim Bin Abd Manaf (as). Nay! The first false testimony which occurred in Al-Islam was their testimony that their companion (Abu Bakr) is the one whom the Messenger (saww) of Allah (azwj) had made to be the Caliph. So when the matter of Saâ€™d Bin Ubada was what it was, they retracted from that and said that the Messenger (saww) of Allah (azwj) passed away and did not appoint a Caliph. So the Messenger of Allah (saww), the good, the Blessed, was the first one in Al-Islam against who the false testimony was borne. And after a little while they found out the evil of what (they came to know and found out the consequences of the evil of what) the former ones had established. And they had an alternative and an opportunity to recover from the death, and had the time to turn around from the lure of pride, and be in a tranquil condition, and the realisation of the deeds. Allah (azwj) had respited Shaddaad Bin Aad, and Thamud Bin Abbuwad, and Balâ€™am Bin Baâ€™our, and Bestowed upon them His (azwj) Favours, both apparent as well as hidden, Supplied them with the wealth, and the (prolongation) of their lives, and Granted them the land, so that due to these Blessings they would Remember the Signs of Allah (azwj), and they would recognise and be awed by Him (azwj), and turn to Him (azwj), and bring an end to their arrogance. So before they reached their (allocated) time, and enjoy their meal, Allah (azwj) Mighty and Majestic Grabbed them and cut them down. Some of them from sandstorm, some were overtaken by a scream, and some from being burned by the shadow, and some from the tremors, and some from sinking of the earth. Allah (azwj) was not Unjust to them, but they had been unjust to their own selves. Indeed! For every term there is a writing. So when the writing reaches its term, and it is uncovered for you about what would befall the unjust ones, and what the greatest losers have got to, you will run towards Allah (azwj) Mighty and Majestic from what they had been involved in and to what they are proceeding to. Nay! And I (asws) am among you, O you people, like Haroun (as) was in the people of the Pharaoh (la), and like the Door of Hitta in the Children of Israel, and like the Ark of Noah (as) in the people of Noah (as). I (asws) am the Great News (Al-Nabaa Al-Azeem), and the Great Truthful (Al-Siddique Al-Akbar), And after a little while you will come to know what had been Promised to you. And is this anything else but (was committed) for a morsel of food, and a sip of drink, light sleep. Then the disgrace will be necessitated upon them in the world, and on the Day of Judgement they will be returning to intense Punishment. And Allah (azwj) is not Oblivious (forgetful) of what they have done. So what is the Recompense for the one who turned away from His (azwj) Proof (asws), and denied His (azwj) Argument, and opposed His (azwj) Guides (asws), and turned away from His (azwj) Light and stormed (his way) into the darkness, and exchanged water for the mirage, and Bounties for the Punishment, and the success for the misery, and prosperity for the poverty, and the ease for the hardship. Nay! This is the Recompense of what they had sown and done before. So be certain of the Promise and of its reality, and be assured of what has been Promised on the Day of the coming of the â€˜Screamâ€™ (Dooms Day), with the Truth. â€œ[50:42] The day when they shall hear the cry in truth; that is the day of coming forth. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Dr. Ali Peiravi", "englishText": "40-21 Ahmad ibn Ziyad ibn Jaâ€™far al-Hamadani - may God be pleased with him - narrated that Ali ibn Ibrahim ibn Hashem quoted on the authority of Al-Rayyan ibn al-Salt, â€œThose of the people from the public or the soldiers who pledged allegiance to Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.), but were not, pleased to do so said, â€˜This is one of the plans of Thul-Riasatayn Al-Fadhl ibn Sahl.â€™ This was told to Al-Maâ€™mun. Then he sent for me at midnight. I went to him. He said to me, â€˜O Rayyan! I have been informed that the people say that the pledge of allegiance to Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) was one of the plans of Al-Fadhl ibn Sahl.â€™ I told him, â€˜O Commander of the Faithful! So they say.â€™ He said, â€˜O Rayyan! Woe be to you! Does anyonedare to suggest to a Caliph - born of a Caliph - who possesses the rule (to whom all the people and the troops are obedient), to turn his rule over to someone else with his own hands? Does the intellect allow this?â€™ I said, â€˜O Commander of the Faithful! By God! No one dares to do that.â€™ Al-Maâ€™mun said, â€˜No, it is not as they say, however, I will tell you the reason. When my brother Muhammad ordered me to go to him, I refused to do so. He issued an order to Ali ibn Isa ibn Mahan to arrest me and place a yoke around my neck. I was informed about this order. I dispatched Harthama ibn Aâ€™yan to Sejistan, Kerman and its suburbs. He did not properly manage this affair and was defeated. The governor of Sarir rebelled and captured one of the regions of Khorasan. All this happened within one week. When this happened, I did not have the power to resist. I did not have any wealth either to get some power. I saw nothing but fear and cowardliness in my troops. I decided to seek refuge with the king of Kabul (in Afghanistan) who was a pagan. But then It occurred to me that if my brother Muhammad sends some money for him in return for me, the King might turn me over to him since he is an atheist. I found no better way than to repent to God the Highest of my sins, seek His assistance regarding these affairs, and seek refuge with God the Highest. Then I ordered that they clean this house - (as he pointed to a room). They cleaned it. I made ablutions with water, put on white pants and a smock and said four units of prayers in which I recited whatever of the Qurâ€™an I knew. I prayed to God the Highest, sought refuge in Him, and sincerely made a strong covenant with Him to return the right to its true place and to turn over the Divine Leadership to its proper owner whom God has set - if He helps me overcome these difficulties. Then I calmed down. I sent Tahir towards Ali ibn Isa ibn Mahan. With him things went on as I mentioned before. Again I sent Harthama ibn Aâ€™yan to defeat Rafiâ€™. He defeated him and killed him. I invited the governor of Sarir to make peace and sent him gifts. I treated him with kindness until he quit opposing me. I got stronger and stronger until what happened to (my brother) Muhammad happened. And God the Highest turned all the affairs over to me and I was in power. Since God the Highest had fulfilled what I had asked Him for, and I wanted to honor my covenant with God, I saw that no one but Abil Hassan Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) deserved the right to be in charge. That is why I offered the rule to him, but he refused. Then he accepted it in the way that you know of. This was the reason.â€™ Then I (Rayyan) said, â€˜May God make theCommander of the Faithful successful!â€™ He said, â€˜O Rayâ€™yan! When the morning comes and the people come out, go among the army heads and tell them about the nobilities of the Commander of the Faithful - Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.).â€™ I told him, â€˜I know nothing about him except for what I have heard from you. Should I just restate that?â€™ He said, â€œGlory be to God! I find no one to help me in this affair. I considered the people of Qum to be trustworthy.â€™ I said, â€˜O Commander of the Faithful! Should I tell them the traditions that I have heard from you?â€™ He said, â€˜Yes. Tell them about the nobilities of Ali (a.s.) that you have heard from me.â€™ When the morning came, I went amongst the army heads and said, â€˜The Commander of the Faithful has narrated that his father quoted on the authority of his forefathers, on the authority of Godâ€™s Prophet (S): â€˜Whoever I am the master of, Ali is the master of.â€™ The Commander of the Faithful has narrated that his father quoted (the following) on the authority of his forefathers, on the authority of Godâ€™s Prophet (S): â€˜The position of Ali relative to me is similar to that of Aaron to Moses.â€™ I did not remember the traditions exactly and made some mistakes. I narrated the tradition about Khaybar and other well-known traditions.â€™â€ Then Abdullah ibn Malik al-Khozaâ€™ee said, â€œMay God have Mercy upon Ali. He was a good man.â€ Al-Maâ€™mun had sent a servant to our meeting to hear what we said and report it to him. Then he sent someone after me. When I went there and he saw me, he said, â€œO Rayyan! You know many traditions by heart. I was informed about what that Jew, Abdullah ibn Malik, said, â€˜May God have Mercy upon Ali. He was a good man.â€™ By God! I will kill him - God willing.â€Hisham ibn Ibrahim al-Rashedi al-Hamadani was one of Ar-Ridhaâ€™â€™s (a.s.) especial people before Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) was brought (to Khorasan). He was an intelligent and well-versed scholar. He was in charge of the affairs of Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.). Whatever was brought in from the different areas was first handed to him, before the taking of Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) to Khorasan. Then, after they brought Abul Hassan (a.s.) to Khorasan, Ibrahim joined Thul-Riasatayn. Thul-Riasatayn established him as one of his closest workers. He used to report the news about Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) to Thul-Riasatayn and Al-Maâ€™mun. That is how he got closer to them, and nothing was hidden from them. Al-Maâ€™mun made him the main guard for Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.). He did not let anyone visit Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.), if he himself did not approve of it. He made things terribly difficult for Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) in his house. No one could talk tohim without the consent of Thul-Riasatayn and Al-Maâ€™mun. Al-Maâ€™mun entrusted his son - Al-Abbas to Hisham to train. That is why he was called Abbasid Hisham. Thul-Riasatayn made his real animosity with Abil Hassan Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) apparent, because Al-Maâ€™mun respected the Imam (a.s.) more than him.Al-Maâ€™mun had a nephew whom he loved, and she also loved him. They had thus opened a door from her house to Al-Maâ€™munâ€™s court. That nephew was more inclined towards Abil Hassan (a.s.), and used to gossip about Thul-Riasatayn with Al-Maâ€™mun. Thul-Riasatayn was informed about this. He went to Al-Maâ€™mun and said, â€œIt is not proper for the Caliph that a door be opened to his court from the ladyâ€™s quarter. Al-Maâ€™mun had that door closed. It was a current practice for Al-Maâ€™mun to visit Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) one day, and the next day Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) went to see Al-Maâ€™mun. Abil Hassanâ€™s residence was next to Al-Maâ€™munâ€™s. Once, when Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) entered Al-Maâ€™munâ€™s house and saw the shut door, he (a.s.) said, â€œO Commander of the Faithful! Why is this door shut?â€ He said, â€œThis was Al-Fadhlâ€™s idea. He did not like it (to be open).â€ Then Ar-Ridhaâ€™ (a.s.) said, â€œTo God We belong and to Him is our return.â€ What does Al-Fadhl have to do with the Commander of the Faithful and his family?â€ He asked, â€œWhat do you think?â€ He (a.s.) replied, â€œOpen it and let your nephew visit you. Do not accept what Al-Fadhl forbids or allows.â€ Then Al-Maâ€™mun ordered that the door be re-opened and let his nephew enter. Al-Fadhl heard this and became sad.", "arabicText": "21 - Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙ†Ø§ Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø²ÙÙŠØ§Ø¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¬ÙØ¹Ù’ÙÙØ± Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ…ÙØ°Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ‘ Ø±ÙØ¶ÙÙ‰ÙØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ù‚Ø§Ù„Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙŠØ³ÙÙ‰ Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ù‡Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù† [Ù…ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ§Ù†Ùâ€] ÙÙÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙØ±ÙØ¯ÙØ¯Ù’ØªÙ Ù‡ÙØ±Ù’Ø«ÙÙ…ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø±ÙØ§ÙÙØ¹Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’ÙŠÙÙ†Ù ÙÙØ¸ÙÙÙØ±Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙØªÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙØ¨ÙØ¹ÙØ«Ù’ØªÙ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ØµÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¨Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙØ±ÙÙŠØ±Ù ÙÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙØ¨ÙØ°ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¦Ø§Ù‹ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ Ø±ÙØ¬ÙØ¹Ù ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ²ÙÙ„Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙÙŠ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’ÙˆÙÙ‰ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ù…ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙØ£ÙÙÙ’Ø¶ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙØ§Ø³Ù’ØªÙÙˆÙÙ‰ Ù„ÙÙŠ ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ§ ÙˆÙØ§ÙÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¨Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙÙÙŠÙ Ù„ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù’ØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø£ÙØ±Ù Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙØ­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¶ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù ÙÙÙˆÙØ¶ÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙÙ€Ø§ Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙÙÙÙ‡ÙØ°ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø³ÙØ¨ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙÙÙ‚ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙ ÙˆÙÙÙ‘ÙÙ‚Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙŠÙØ§ Ø±ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù ØºÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙØ­ÙØ¶ÙØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù ÙÙØ§Ù‚Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¯Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ù‡ÙØ¤ÙÙ„Ø§Ø¡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ§Ø¯Ù ÙˆÙØ­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙÙØ¶Ù’Ù„Ù Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø·ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ¨Ùâ€ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙ ÙŠÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ø³ÙÙ†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ¯ÙÙŠØ«Ù Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¦Ø§Ù‹ Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§ Ù…ÙØ§ Ø³ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ÙƒÙ ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø³ÙØ¨Ù’Ø­ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØ¬ÙØ¯Ù Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ ÙŠÙØ¹ÙÙŠÙ†ÙÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù‡ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ù‡ÙÙ…ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ù‚ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ø´ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙŠ ÙˆÙØ¯ÙØ«ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙŠ ÙÙÙ‚ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙ ÙŠÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ†ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ÙƒÙ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø³ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙØ®Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù†ÙØ¹ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø³ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙŠ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙØ¶ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ„Ù ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ØºÙØ¯Ù Ù‚ÙØ¹ÙØ¯Ù’ØªÙ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ§Ø¯Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„Ø§Ù‡Ù ÙÙØ¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„Ø§Ù‡Ù Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ†ÙØŒ Ø¹ÙÙ† Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‡ÙØŒ Ø¹ÙÙ† Ø¢Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ‡Ù Ù‚Ø§Ù„Ù: Ù‚Ø§Ù„Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ùâ€ ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙØ¢Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’Ø²ÙÙ„ÙØ©Ù Ù‡ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙÙˆØ³ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙØ®ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ·Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ¯ÙÙŠØ«Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¶ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¶Ù Ù„Ø§ Ø£ÙØ­Ù’ÙÙØ¸ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙØ¬Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙØ­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«Ù’ØªÙ Ø¨ÙØ­ÙØ¯ÙÙŠØ«Ù Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¨ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙØ¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ°ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙŠØ«Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ´Ù’Ù‡ÙÙˆØ±ÙØ©Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù„ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯Ù
