Ù‡Ù„ ÙŠØ¹Ø±ÙÙˆÙ† Ù‚Ø¯Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø© ÙˆÙ…Ø­Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø§Ø®ØªÙŠØ§Ø±Ù‡Ù…ØŸ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø£Ø¬Ù„ Ù‚Ø¯Ø±Ø§ ÙˆØ£Ø¹Ø¸Ù… Ø´Ø£Ù†Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…ÙƒØ§Ù†Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù…Ù†Ø¹ Ø¬Ø§Ù†Ø¨Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ ØºÙˆØ±Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¨Ù„ØºÙ‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø¨Ø¹Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠÙ†Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙ‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø¢Ø±Ø§Ø¦Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠÙ‚ÙŠÙ…ÙˆØ§ Ø¥Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ø®ØªÙŠØ§Ø±Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø®Øµ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„ÙŠÙ„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙˆØ©ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ø© Ù…Ø±ØªØ¨Ø© Ø«Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙØ¶ÙŠÙ„Ø© Ø´Ø±ÙÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙØ£Ø´Ø§Ø¯ (3) Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ø°ÙƒØ±Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (Ø¥Ù†Ù‰ Ø¬Ø§Ø¹Ù„Ùƒ Ù„Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø¥Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø§) ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„ÙŠÙ„ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) Ø³Ø±ÙˆØ±Ø§ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§: (ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø°Ø±ÙŠØªÙŠ)ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰: (Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ†Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù‡Ø¯ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ†) (4)ØŒ ÙØ£Ø¨Ø·Ù„Øª Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ø¥Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø© ÙƒÙ„ Ø¸Ø§Ù„Ù… Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© ÙˆØµØ§Ø±Øª ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØµÙÙˆØ©ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø£ÙƒØ±Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ø£Ù† Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø°Ø±ÙŠØªÙ‡ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„ØµÙÙˆØ© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø·Ù‡Ø§Ø±Ø©ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆÙˆÙ‡Ø¨Ù†Ø§ Ù„Ù‡ Ø¥Ø³Ø­Ø§Ù‚ ÙˆÙŠØ¹Ù‚ÙˆØ¨ Ù†Ø§ÙÙ„Ø© ÙˆÙƒÙ„Ø§ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Ù†Ø§ ØµØ§Ù„Ø­ÙŠÙ† * ÙˆØ¬Ø¹Ù„Ù†Ø§Ù‡Ù… Ø£Ø¦Ù…Ø© ÙŠÙ‡Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù†Ø§ ÙˆØ£ÙˆØ­ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… ÙØ¹Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙŠØ±Ø§Øª ÙˆØ¥Ù‚Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„ØµÙ„Ø§Ø© ÙˆØ¥ÙŠØªØ§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø²ÙƒØ§Ø© ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ù„Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ø§Ø¨Ø¯ÙŠÙ†) (5). ÙÙ„Ù… ØªØ²Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø°Ø±ÙŠØªÙ‡ ÙŠØ±Ø«Ù‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶ Ø¹Ù† Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶ Ù‚Ø±Ù†Ø§ ÙÙ‚Ø±Ù†Ø§ (6) Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙˆØ±Ø«Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡)ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¬Ù„ Ø¬Ù„Ø§Ù„Ù‡: (Ø¥Ù† Ø£ÙˆÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø¨Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ù„Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø§ØªØ¨Ø¹ÙˆÙ‡ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¡Ø§Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ†) (1) ÙÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ù„Ù‡ Ø®Ø§ØµØ©ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ù„Ø¯Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø¹Ù„ÙŠØ§ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) Ø¨Ø£Ù…Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø³Ù… Ù…Ø§ ÙØ±Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙØµØ§Ø±Øª ÙÙŠ Ø°Ø±ÙŠØªÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø§ØµÙÙŠØ§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¢ØªØ§Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø¨Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ (ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø£ÙˆØªÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ù„Ù‚Ø¯ Ù„Ø¨Ø«ØªÙ… ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø¹Ø«) (2) ÙÙ‡ÙŠ ÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ„Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) Ø®Ø§ØµØ© Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø©ØŒ Ø¥Ø° Ù„Ø§ Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡). ÙÙ…Ù† Ø£ÙŠÙ† ÙŠØ®ØªØ§Ø± Ù‡Ø¤Ù„Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù‡Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø© Ù‡ÙŠ Ù…Ù†Ø²Ù„Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¡ ÙˆØ¥Ø±Ø« Ø§Ù„Ø§ÙˆØµÙŠØ§Ø¡ØŸ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø®Ù„Ø§ÙØ© Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙˆØ®Ù„Ø§ÙØ© Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙˆÙ…Ù‚Ø§Ù… Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) ÙˆÙ…ÙŠØ±Ø§Ø« Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­Ø³ÙŠÙ† (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…)ØŒ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø²Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ† ÙˆÙ†Ø¸Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØµÙ„Ø§Ø­ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ ÙˆØ¹Ø² Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ†ØŒ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø£Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ù…ÙŠ ÙˆÙØ±Ø¹Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ù…ÙŠØŒ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… ØªÙ…Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„ØµÙ„Ø§Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø²ÙƒØ§Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØµÙŠØ§Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­Ø¬ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬Ù‡Ø§Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆØªÙˆÙÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„ÙØ¦ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØµØ¯Ù‚Ø§ØªØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù…Ø¶Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¯ÙˆØ¯ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø­ÙƒØ§Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù†Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø«ØºÙˆØ± ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø·Ø±Ø§ÙØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… ÙŠØ­Ù„ Ø­Ù„Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙŠØ­Ø±Ù… Ø­Ø±Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ‚ÙŠÙ… Ø­Ø¯ÙˆØ¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ°Ø¨ Ø¹Ù† Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ¯Ø¹ÙˆØ§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø³Ø¨ÙŠÙ„ Ø±Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¹Ø¸Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù†Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­Ø¬Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ù„ØºØ©. Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… ÙƒØ§Ù„Ø´Ù…Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø© Ù„Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡ÙŠ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø§ÙÙ‚ Ø¨Ø­ÙŠØ« Ù„Ø§ ØªÙ†Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø§ÙŠØ¯ÙŠ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø¨ØµØ§Ø±ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø¯Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†ÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø³Ø±Ø§Ø¬ Ø§Ù„Ø²Ø§Ù‡Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†ÙˆØ± Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø·Ø¹ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†Ø¬Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ø§Ø¯ÙŠ ÙÙŠ ØºÙŠØ§Ù‡Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø¬Ù‰ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¨Ù„Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙØ§Ø± ÙˆÙ„Ø¬Ø¬ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø­Ø§Ø±ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø°Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ù…Ø£ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¯Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ø¯Ù‰ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ù†Ø¬ÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¯Ù‰ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙØ§Ø¹ (3)ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø§Ø± Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø§ØµØ·Ù„Ù‰ Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¯Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø§Ù„Ùƒ (4)ØŒ Ù…Ù† ÙØ§Ø±Ù‚Ù‡ ÙÙ‡Ø§Ù„ÙƒØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø­Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø·Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØºÙŠØ« Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ø§Ø·Ù„ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´Ù…Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¶ÙŠØ¦Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø±Ø¶ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¨Ø³ÙŠØ·Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„ØºØ²ÙŠØ±Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØºØ¯ÙŠØ± ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø±ÙˆØ¶Ø©. Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø±ÙÙŠÙ‚ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‚ÙŠÙ‚ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø® Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙÙŠÙ‚ØŒ ÙˆÙ…ÙØ²Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ø¯ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø§Ù‡ÙŠØ©ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø£Ù…ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø£Ø±Ø¶Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø¬ØªÙ‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ø¯Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ®Ù„ÙŠÙØªÙ‡ ÙÙŠ Ø¨Ù„Ø§Ø¯Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¯Ø§Ø¹ÙŠ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø°Ø§Ø¨ Ø¹Ù† Ø­Ø±Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø·Ù‡Ø± Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù†ÙˆØ¨ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¨Ø±Ø£ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹ÙŠÙˆØ¨ØŒ Ù…Ø®ØµÙˆØµ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ù…ÙˆØ³ÙˆÙ… Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ù†Ø¸Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ø² Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØºÙŠØ¸ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†Ø§ÙÙ‚ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ¨ÙˆØ§Ø± Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ§ÙØ±ÙŠÙ†ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø¯Ù‡Ø±Ù‡ØŒ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø§Ø¯Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙˆØ¬Ø¯ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ (1) Ø¨Ø¯Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø«Ù„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù†Ø¸ÙŠØ±ØŒ Ù…Ø®ØµÙˆØµ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ ÙƒÙ„Ù‡ Ù…Ù† ØºÙŠØ± Ø·Ù„Ø¨ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ù‡ (2) ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø§ÙƒØªØ³Ø§Ø¨ØŒ Ø¨Ù„ Ø§Ø®ØªØµØ§Øµ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙ‡Ø§Ø¨. ÙÙ…Ù† Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙŠØ¨Ù„Øº Ù…Ø¹Ø±ÙØ© Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠÙ…ÙƒÙ†Ù‡ Ø§Ø®ØªÙŠØ§Ø±Ù‡ØŸ Ù‡ÙŠÙ‡Ø§Øª Ù‡ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ØªØŒ Ø¶Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ØŒ ÙˆØªØ§Ù‡Øª Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù„ÙˆÙ…ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø§Ø±Øª Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø³Ø±Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹ÙŠÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØªØµØ§ØºØ±Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¸Ù…Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆØªØ­ÙŠØ±Øª Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆØªÙ‚Ø§ØµØ±Øª Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆØ­ØµØ±Øª Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø·Ø¨Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆÙƒÙ„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¹Ø±Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ø¬Ø²Øª Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¯Ø¨Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆØ¹ÙŠÙŠØª Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ù„ØºØ§Ø¡ Ø¹Ù† ÙˆØµÙ Ø´Ø£Ù† Ù…Ù† Ø´Ø£Ù†Ù‡ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ ÙØ¶ÙŠÙ„Ø© Ù…Ù† ÙØ¶Ø§Ø¦Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ£Ù‚Ø±Øª Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¬Ø² ÙˆØ§Ù„ØªÙ‚ØµÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠÙˆØµÙ Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠÙ†Ø¹Øª Ø¨ÙƒÙ†Ù‡Ù‡ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù… Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù‡ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠÙˆØ¬Ø¯ Ù…Ù† ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ… Ù…Ù‚Ø§Ù…Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØºÙ†ÙŠ ØºÙ†Ø§Ø¡Ù‡ØŸ Ù„Ø§ØŒ ÙƒÙŠÙ ÙˆØ£Ù†Ù‰ (3) ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¨Ø­ÙŠØ« Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¬Ù… Ù…Ù† Ø£ÙŠØ¯ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…ØªÙ†Ø§ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙ† ÙˆÙˆØµÙ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ØµÙÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙØ£ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø®ØªÙŠØ§Ø± Ù…Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ£ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø¹Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ£ÙŠÙ† ÙŠÙˆØ¬Ø¯ Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ØŸ Ø£Ø¸Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙŠÙˆØ¬Ø¯ ÙÙŠ ØºÙŠØ± Ø¢Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…)ØŸ ÙƒØ°Ø¨ØªÙ‡Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù†ØªÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ø§Ø·ÙŠÙ„ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ø±ØªÙ‚ÙˆØ§ Ù…Ø±ØªÙ‚Ø§ ØµØ¹Ø¨Ø§ Ø¯Ø­Ø¶Ø§ (4)ØŒ ØªØ²Ù„ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¶ÙŠØ¶ Ø£Ù‚Ø¯Ø§Ù…Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ø±Ø§Ù…ÙˆØ§ Ø¥Ù‚Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø¨Ø¹Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø­Ø§Ø¦Ø±Ø© Ø¨Ø§Ø¦Ø±Ø© Ù†Ø§Ù‚ØµØ©ØŒ ÙˆØ¢Ø±Ø§Ø¡ Ù…Ø¶Ù„Ø©ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ø¯Ø§Ø¯ÙˆØ§ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§ØªÙ„Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ù†Ù‰ ÙŠØ¤ÙÙƒÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ù„Ù‚Ø¯ Ø±Ø§Ù…ÙˆØ§ ØµØ¹Ø¨Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø¥ÙÙƒØ§ØŒ ÙˆØ¶Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø¶Ù„Ø§Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠØ¯Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÙˆØ§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙŠØ±Ø©ØŒ Ø¥Ø° ØªØ±ÙƒÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù† Ø¨ØµÙŠØ±Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ²ÙŠÙ† Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙŠØ·Ø§Ù† Ø£Ø¹Ù…Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ù… ÙØµØ¯Ù‡Ù… Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø¨ÙŠÙ„ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ù…Ø³ØªØ¨ØµØ±ÙŠÙ†ØŒ Ø±ØºØ¨ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ø®ØªÙŠØ§Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø®ØªÙŠØ§Ø± Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ø®ØªÙŠØ§Ø±Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† ÙŠÙ†Ø§Ø¯ÙŠÙ‡Ù…: (ÙˆØ±Ø¨Ùƒ ÙŠØ®Ù„Ù‚ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆÙŠØ®ØªØ§Ø± Ù…Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙŠØ±Ø© Ø³Ø¨Ø­Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø±ÙƒÙˆÙ†) (1)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆÙ…Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù† ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†Ø© Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ù‚Ø¶Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø£Ù…Ø±Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙŠØ±Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù‡Ù…) (2)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù„ÙƒÙ… ÙƒÙŠÙ ØªØ­ÙƒÙ…ÙˆÙ† * Ø£Ù… Ù„ÙƒÙ… ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ ÙÙŠÙ‡ ØªØ¯Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ† * Ø¥Ù† Ù„ÙƒÙ… ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ù„Ù…Ø§ ØªØ®ÙŠØ±ÙˆÙ† * Ø£Ù… Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ø£ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ØºØ© Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ø¥Ù† Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ù„Ù…Ø§ ØªØ­ÙƒÙ…ÙˆÙ† * Ø³Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø£ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø²Ø¹ÙŠÙ… * Ø£Ù… Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø´Ø±ÙƒØ§Ø¡ ÙÙ„ÙŠØ£ØªÙˆØ§ Ø¨Ø´Ø±ÙƒØ§Ø¦Ù‡Ù… Ø¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù†ÙˆØ§ ØµØ§Ø¯Ù‚ÙŠÙ†) (3)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØªØ¯Ø¨Ø±ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† Ø£Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‚Ù„ÙˆØ¨ Ø£Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù‡Ø§) (4) Ø£Ù… Ø·Ø¨Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‚Ù„ÙˆØ¨Ù‡Ù… ÙÙ‡Ù… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù‡ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù… (Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø³Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ø§ ÙˆÙ‡Ù… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ³Ù…Ø¹ÙˆÙ† * Ø¥Ù† Ø´Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙˆØ§Ø¨ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø¨ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ù‚Ù„ÙˆÙ† * ÙˆÙ„Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø®ÙŠØ±Ø§ Ù„Ø§Ø³Ù…Ø¹Ù‡Ù… ÙˆÙ„Ùˆ Ø£Ø³Ù…Ø¹Ù‡Ù… Ù„ØªÙˆÙ„ÙˆØ§ ÙˆÙ‡Ù… Ù…Ø¹Ø±Ø¶ÙˆÙ†) (5)ØŒ Ùˆ (Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø³Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ø§ ÙˆØ¹ØµÙŠÙ†Ø§) (6) Ø¨Ù„ Ù‡Ùˆ (ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠØ¤ØªÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ù† ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø°Ùˆ Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ…) (7). ÙÙƒÙŠÙ Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ø®ØªÙŠØ§Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬Ù‡Ù„ØŒ Ø±Ø§Ø¹ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ†ÙƒÙ„ØŒ Ù…Ø¹Ø¯Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¯Ø³ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø·Ù‡Ø§Ø±Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†Ø³Ùƒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø²Ù‡Ø§Ø¯Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ø¯Ø©ØŒ Ù…Ø®ØµÙˆØµ Ø¨Ø¯Ø¹ÙˆØ© Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù†Ø³Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø·Ù‡Ø±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¨ØªÙˆÙ„ØŒ Ù„Ø§ Ù…ØºÙ…Ø² ÙÙŠÙ‡ ÙÙŠ Ù†Ø³Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ‡ Ø°Ùˆ Ø­Ø³Ø¨ØŒ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¨ÙŠØª Ù…Ù† Ù‚Ø±ÙŠØ´ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø°Ø±ÙˆØ© Ù…Ù† Ù‡Ø§Ø´Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹ØªØ±Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø¢Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ (8)ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø´Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø´Ø±Ø§ÙØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙØ±Ø¹ Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ù…Ù†Ø§ÙØŒ Ù†Ø§Ù…ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙƒØ§Ù…Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ù…Ø¶Ø·Ù„Ø¹ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø©ØŒ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙŠØ§Ø³Ø©ØŒ Ù…ÙØ±ÙˆØ¶ Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ø¹Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù… Ø¨Ø£Ù…Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ù†Ø§ØµØ­ Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø­Ø§ÙØ¸ Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡. Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø¦Ù…Ø© ÙŠÙˆÙÙ‚Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙˆÙŠØ¤ØªÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ù…Ù† Ù…Ø®Ø²ÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ ÙˆØ­Ù„Ù…Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¤ØªÙŠÙ‡ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡Ù… ÙÙˆÙ‚ ÙƒÙ„ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø²Ù…Ø§Ù†Ù‡Ù… ÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (Ø£ÙÙ…Ù† ÙŠÙ‡Ø¯Ù‰ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ Ø£Ø­Ù‚ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªØ¨Ø¹ Ø£Ù…Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ‡Ø¯Ù‰ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ‡Ø¯Ù‰ ÙÙ…Ø§ Ù„ÙƒÙ… ÙƒÙŠÙ ØªØ­ÙƒÙ…ÙˆÙ†) (1)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆÙ…Ù† ÙŠØ¤Øª Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø© ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø£ÙˆØªÙ‰ Ø®ÙŠØ±Ø§ ÙƒØ«ÙŠØ±Ø§) (2)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„ÙˆØª: (Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§ØµØ·ÙØ§Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒÙ… ÙˆØ²Ø§Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¨Ø³Ø·Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬Ø³Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠØ¤ØªÙ‰ Ù…Ù„ÙƒÙ‡ Ù…Ù† ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø³Ø¹ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ…) (3)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): (ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒ Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ…Ø§) (4)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¦Ù…Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ¹ØªØ±ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ°Ø±ÙŠØªÙ‡ (ØµÙ„ÙˆØ§Øª Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…): * (Ø£Ù… ÙŠØ­Ø³Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ Ø£ØªØ§Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù† ÙØ¶Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¢ØªÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø¡Ø§Ù„ Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø© ÙˆØ¡Ø§ØªÙŠÙ†Ø§Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù„ÙƒØ§ Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ…Ø§ * ÙÙ…Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù† Ø¡Ø§Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù† ØµØ¯ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆÙƒÙÙ‰ Ø¨Ø¬Ù‡Ù†Ù… Ø³Ø¹ÙŠØ±Ø§) (5). ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ø®ØªØ§Ø±Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù„Ø§Ù…ÙˆØ± Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ø¯Ù‡ØŒ Ø´Ø±Ø­ ØµØ¯Ø±Ù‡ Ù„Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙˆØ£ÙˆØ¯Ø¹ Ù‚Ù„Ø¨Ù‡ ÙŠÙ†Ø§Ø¨ÙŠØ¹ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù„Ù‡Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø¥Ù„Ù‡Ø§Ù…Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ¹ÙŠ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¨Ø¬ÙˆØ§Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ­ÙŠØ± ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ØµÙˆØ§Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù…Ø¹ØµÙˆÙ… Ù…Ø¤ÙŠØ¯ Ù…ÙˆÙÙ‚ Ù…Ø³Ø¯Ø¯ØŒ Ù‚Ø¯ Ø£Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø·Ø§ÙŠØ§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø²Ù„Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ø«Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ®ØµÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù„ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø­Ø¬ØªÙ‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ø¯Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ´Ø§Ù‡Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø®Ù„Ù‚Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ°Ù„Ùƒ ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠØ¤ØªÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ù† ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø°Ùˆ Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ…. ÙÙ‡Ù„ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ø±ÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ÙÙŠØ®ØªØ§Ø±ÙˆÙ‡ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø®ØªØ§Ø±Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ØµÙØ© ÙÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ù…ÙˆÙ‡ØŸ ØªØ¹Ø¯ÙˆØ§ ÙˆØ¨ÙŠØª Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ø¨Ø°ÙˆØ§ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ±Ø§Ø¡ Ø¸Ù‡ÙˆØ±Ù‡Ù… ÙƒØ£Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù…ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ø¯Ù‰ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´ÙØ§Ø¡ØŒ ÙÙ†Ø¨Ø°ÙˆÙ‡ ÙˆØ§ØªØ¨Ø¹ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ù‡ÙˆØ§Ø¡Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ°Ù…Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ù‚ØªÙ‡Ù… ÙˆØ£ØªØ¹Ø³Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø£Ø¶Ù„ Ù…Ù…Ù† Ø§ØªØ¨Ø¹ Ù‡ÙˆØ§Ù‡ Ø¨ØºÙŠØ± Ù‡Ø¯Ù‰ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ‡Ø¯Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ†) (1) ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙØªØ¹Ø³Ø§ Ù„Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ£Ø¶Ù„ Ø£Ø¹Ù…Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ù…) (2)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙƒØ¨Ø± Ù…Ù‚ØªØ§ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¡Ø§Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§ ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ ÙŠØ·Ø¨Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙƒÙ„ Ù‚Ù„Ø¨ Ù…ØªÙƒØ¨Ø± Ø¬Ø¨Ø§Ø±) (3).", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/29/1/97/1", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 97, "thaqalaynSanad": "Abu Ja`far Muhammad b. Ali b. al-Husayn b. Musa b. Babuwayh al-Qummi (ra) narrated to us. He said: Muhammad b. Musa al-Mutawakkil (rh) narrated to us. He said: Muhammad b. Ya`qub narrated to us. He said: Abu Muhammad al-Qasim b. al-`Alaâ€™ narrated to us from `Abd al-`Aziz b. Muslim. He said: ", "thaqalaynMatn": "In the days of `Ali b. Musa al-Rida (as), we were in Marv, and we gathered in a mosque that we would attend on Friday. The people were speaking about the matter of Imamate, and they mentioned the multitude of differences of opinion regarding it. So, I visited my Master al-Rida (as), and I informed him of the peopleâ€™s discord regarding it. So, he (as) smiled, then said: O `Abd al-`Aziz! The people are ignorant, and they are deceived with regards to their religions. Surely, Allah did not cause His Prophet (s) to pass away without perfecting the religion for him. He revealed the Quran to him, in which there is elucidation for everything. In it, the lawful, the forbidden, the limits, and the rulings were made clear; as well as all of what the people need. So, He says, â€œWe have neglected nothing in the Bookâ€ (6:38). At the Farewell Pilgrimage, at the end of his (s) life, this was revealed, â€œThis day I have perfected your religion for you, and I have completed My favour unto you, and I have chosen for you Islam as a religion.â€ (5:3) The matter of Imamate is from the completion of religion. He (s) did not pass away until he clarified to the people the landmarks of their religion. He clarified their paths for them, left them on the way toward truth, and established `Ali (as) as their scholar and Imam. He did not leave anything that the Nation would need except that he clarified it for them. He who alleges that Allah did not perfect His religion has turned away from the Book of Allah, and he who turns away from the Book of Allah is a disbeliever. Do they even know the significance and station of Imamate in respect to the Nation for them to dare give their opinions? Surely, Imamate is of a majestic station and great affair. It is the most exalted position, the most prohibited side, and the furthest valley for the people to try to reach with their intellects, attain with their opinions; or [even] establish an Imam by their own selection. The Imamate is something Allah selected Ibrahim the Friend (s) with after prophethood and friendship as a third rank. It is a virtue that He lauded him with, and He mentions it, â€œSurely, I have made you an Imam for the peopleâ€, so the Friend (as), joyed by it, said, â€œand from my descendants?â€ So, Allah said, â€œMy covenant does not go to the oppressorsâ€ (2:124). This verse invalidates the Imamate (leadership) of every oppressor until the Day of Resurrection; and it went to the elite ones. Allah honoured him by making his progeny the elite, pure people, for He says, â€œWe blessed him with Ishaq and Ya`qub in addition, who We made of the righteous. We made them Imams who guide by Our command. We revealed to them the doing of good works, establishing prayer and giving alms; and they were worshipers of Us.â€ (21:73-74) His progeny did not stop inheriting it, one after the other, century after century, until it was inherited by the Prophet (s). So, He says, â€œThose who have most right to Ibrahim are those who follow him, this Prophet, and those who believe â€“ and Allah is the Guardian of the believers.â€ (3:68) So, it was specifically for him, and the Prophet (s) bequeathed it to `Ali (as) by the command of Allah and in accordance with what Allah has ordained. Then, it went to his progeny, whom Allah gave knowledge and faith â€“ by His saying, â€œAs for those who were given knowledge and faith, they will say: â€˜You remained, in accordance with Allahâ€™s decree, until the Day of Resurrectionâ€™â€ (30:56) â€“ so it is specifically in the progeny of `Ali (as) until the Day of Resurrection; and there is no prophet after Muhammad (s). So, how can these ignorant ones choose [for themselves]? Surely, the Imamate is the station of the prophets and the inheritance of the deputies. Surely, Imamate is the vicegerency (khilafa) of Allah, the vicegerency of the Messenger (s), the rank of Amir al-Muâ€™minin (as), and the inheritance of al-Hasan and al-Husayn (as). Surely, Imamate is the reins of the religion, the order of the Muslims, the rectification of this world, and the glory of the Muslims. Surely, Imamate is the foundation of Islam and its lofty branch. Through the Imam, prayer, alms, fasting, Hajj, jihad, the giving of fayâ€™, charity, the implementation of penalties and rulings, and the frontiers are perfected. The Imam makes permissible what Allah makes permissible and makes forbidden what Allah makes forbidden. He establishes the limits of Allah, defends the religion of Allah, and calls to the way of his Lord with wisdom, goodly exhortations, and clear proof. The Imam is like the Sun that rises over the world, in the horizons where no hands and no vision can encompass it. The Imam is the shining full Moon, the illuminating glow, the dazzling light, and the guiding star in the shroud of darkness, barren wastelands, and depths of the sea. The Imam is fresh water during thirst, the indicator to guidance, and the saviour from apostasy. The Imam is the fire of the highlands, heat for whoever needs it, and the indicator for the wayfarer â€“ he who opposes it is destroyed. The Imam is the raincloud, the falling rain, the illuminating Sun, the soft earth, the abundant river, and the meadowy brook. The Imam is the trustworthy friend, the kind father, the caring brother, and the shelter for servants during catastrophe. The Imam is the trustee of Allah in His Earth, His Proof over His servants, His vicegerent in His lands, the caller to Allah, and the defender of the sanctity of Allah. The Imam is the purifier from sins and the curer of blemishes. He is the specialist of knowledge, bestowed with forbearance, the order of the religion, the glory of the Muslims, the wrath against the hypocrites, and the destruction against the disbelievers. The Imam is the foremost of his time â€“ no scholar is equal to him, and there is no substitute to him. None resemble or match him. He has been wholly specified with virtue, without a need for him to seek it or reap it; surely, he is specified by the Bestower of Virtue and Gifts. So, who is him who reaches full recognition of the Imam or subjects him to their choosing? Far, far have their intellects deviated, their imaginations strayed, their minds bewildered, their eyes perplexed, their great ones drifted, their wise ones confused, their sensible ones fallen short, their preachers confined, their hearts become ignorant, their poets become speechless, and their writers become incapable. The rhetoricians cannot describe one quality of his qualities, or one virtue of his virtues, so they acknowledge their inability and shortcoming. How can [the Imam] be described in his essence? How can one comprehend a thing of his matter? How can one find one present to take his place and his prosperity? How, when he is as far as a star from the hands of the takers and the description of the describers? Where is the choice here? Where are the intellects with respect to this? What is comparable to this? Do they think that this [Imamate] exists outside of the Family of the Messenger (as)? By Allah, they have belied themselves and led themselves into fallacies. They have risen to a confuted difficulty and their feet have slipped to the bottom. They want to establish an Imam with minds that are perplexed, perverted, and partial, and with imprudent perspectives. They do not increase in it except in distance. â€œMay Allah destroy them â€“ how deluded they are!â€ (63:4) They have run into difficulty, spoken calumnies, deviated far astray, and trapped themselves in perplexity because they have abandoned the Imam. Satan has adorned their deeds for them, misguiding them from the path when they were able to see. They have gone from the selection of Allah and His Messenger to their own selection, when the Quran calls to them, â€œYour Lord creates what He wills, and He selects what is good for them. May Allah be glorified from what the pagans [claim].â€ (28:68). He says, â€œIt is not for a believing male or female to have a choice in their affair if Allah and His Messenger commanded something.â€ (33:36) He says, â€œHow is the matter with you? How do you judge? Do you have a scripture which you read that you will have whatever you choose? Or do you have oaths binding on Us until the Day of Resurrection that you will have whatever you decide? Ask them which of them can guarantee that? Or do they have partners? Then let them bring their partners if they are truthful.â€ (68:36-41) He says, â€œDo they not contemplate over the Quran, or are there locks on their hearts?â€ (47:24) Has Allah sealed their hearts, so they cannot understand? Or, â€œthey say: â€˜we listenedâ€™, but they do not listen. Surely, the evillest of creatures to Allah is the deaf and dumb that cannot think. Had Allah known of any good in them, He would have made them listen. If He had made them listen, they would have still turned away whilst refusing.â€ (8:22-23) â€œThey said: â€˜We listen and we disobeyâ€™â€ (2:93) Rather, â€œthat is the blessing of Allah. He bestows it upon whom He wills. Allah is of great blessing.â€ (62:4) So, how would they have a choice in the Imam, when the Imam is knowing and not ignorant? He is a tireless shepherd, and the source of sanctity, purity, offering, asceticism, knowledge, and worship. He is specified by the call of the Messenger. He is of the pure, chaste lineage â€“ he is not of an obscure ancestry, and no nobleman comes close to him. He is of the House from Quraysh, crystallized from Hashim; from the progeny of the Family of the Messenger (s), from Allah's acceptance. He is the noblest of nobles, and he is a branch from `Abd al-Manaf. He is well-versed in knowledge, perfect in forbearance, in charge of leadership, proficient in civilizing, obligatory in obedience, establishing the command of Allah, an advisor to the servants of Allah, and a protector of the religion of Allah. Surely, the prophets and the Imams are supported by Allah. He gives them of His stored knowledge and His forbearance, which is not given to anyone else. Their knowledge is above the knowledge of the people of their time â€“ as per His saying, â€œIs, then, He who guides to the truth more worthy of being obeyed, or he who has no guidance at all unless he is guided [by someone else]?â€ (10:35) Also, His saying, â€œHe who is given wisdom has been given much good.â€ (2:269) Also, His saying with regards to Talut, â€œSurely, Allah has selected him over you, and increased him in knowledge and in physique. Allah gives His kingdom to whomever He wills â€“ and Allah is encompassing in knowledge.â€ (2:247) Also, He said to His Prophet (s), â€œThe blessing of Allah upon you is great.â€ (4:113) He says, regarding the Imams from his Ahl al-Bayt, his progeny and his offspring (s), â€œDo the people envy those whom Allah has given His blessing? For We have given the Family of Ibrahim the Book and the wisdom, and We gave them a great kingdom. From them are those who believe in Him, and from them are those who reject Him â€“ and Hell is a sufficient blaze.â€ (4:54-55) When Allah chooses a servant for the affairs of His worshipers, Allah expands his chest for that, puts fountains of wisdom in his heart, and inspires (ilham) him with knowledge. After that, he is aware of no other answer, and his reasoning remains consistent. He is immaculate, aided, supported, and directed. He is safe from errors, slips, and stumbles â€“ Allah specifies this for him so that he may be His proof over His servants and His witness over His creation. â€œThat is the blessing of Allah. He bestows it upon whom He wills. Allah is of great blessing.â€ (62:4) So, are they capable of being something like this, so that they may select him? Or, is the one that they select capable of taking on this description? They have transgressed, and the House of Allah is the truth. They threw the Book of Allah behind their backs, as though they do not know; and in the Book of Allah is guidance and healing, but they neglected it and followed their whims. So, Allah cursed them, despised them, and made them miserable. He says, â€œWho is more misguided than him who follows his whims without guidance from Allah? Surely, Allah does not guide the oppressive people.â€ (28:50) He says, â€œMay they be doomed and may He render their deeds void.â€ (47:8) He says, â€œIt is greatly hateful in the sight of Allah and in the sight of those who believe. In this way, Allah seals the heart of every arrogant tyrant.â€ (40:35)", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 701, "bookId": "Al-Amali-Saduq", "book": "Al-AmÄlÄ«", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "The Sixty-Sixth Assembly: The Assembly of Tuesday, the Thirteenth of Jumada al-Ula, 368 AH.", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bilal Muhammad", "englishText": "Abu Ja`far Muhammad b. `Ali b. al-Husayn b. Musa b. Babuwayh al-Qummi (ra) narrated to us. He said: Hamza b. Muhammad b. Ahmad b. Ja`far b. Muhammad b. Zayd b. `Ali b. al-Husayn b. `Ali b. Abi Talib (as). He said: Abu `Abdillah `Abd al-`Aziz b. Muhammad b. `Isa al-Bahri narrated to me. He said: Abu `Abdillah Muhammad b. Zakariyya al-Jawhari al-Ghilabi al-Basri narrated to us. He said: Shu`ayb b. Waqid narrated to us. He said: Al-Husayn b. Yazid narrated to us from al-Sadiq Ja`far b. Muhammad from his father from his forefathers from Amir al-Mu'minin `Ali b. Abi Talib (as).\r\nHe said: The Messenger of Allah (s) prohibited eating whilst in a state of sexual impurity. He said: â€œIt bequeaths poverty.â€ He prohibited cutting nails with teeth, using the toothstick in the bathroom, and blowing the nose in the mosques. He prohibited eating from the leftovers of mice. He said: â€œDo not go to the mosque without praying [at least] two units.â€ He prohibited urination under a fruit tree and at the side of a road. He prohibited eating with the left [hand] and eating while lying down. He prohibited plastering graveyards and praying in them. He said: â€œWhen one of you bathes in an expanse of earth, then be mindful of your private. None of you should drink water from the buttonhole of a vessel, for it is a gathering place for dirt.â€ He prohibited anyone from urinating in still water, for it causes a loss in intellect. He prohibited walking with one sandal and putting on sandals while standing. He prohibited urinating while the private is facing the Sun or the Moon. He said: â€œWhen you are defecating, then avoid [the direction of] the qibla.â€ He prohibited screaming during calamities. He prohibited wailing and listening to wailing. He prohibited women from following funeral processions. He prohibited erasing anything from the Book of Allah with saliva or writing in it. He prohibited lying purposely about dreams. He said: â€œAllah will order him to tie a knot in a grain of barley.â€ He prohibited creating images. He said: â€œWhoever creates an image, Allah will order him to blow [life] into it on the Day of Resurrection; and he would not be able to blow [life] into it.â€ He prohibited burning a part of an animal [while alive]. He prohibited insulting the rooster. He said: â€œIt calls to prayer.â€ He prohibited interfering in a deal of his Muslim brother [selling merchandise to a buyer]. He prohibited speaking too much during intercourse. He said: â€œIt causes muteness in the child.â€ He said: â€œDo not sleep while garbage is in your house. Take it out during the day, for it is a sitting place for Satan.â€ He said: â€œDo not sleep while the residue of meat is on your hand, for if you do that, you will be afflicted with mild insanity from Satan, and you will have no one to blame but yourself.â€ He prohibited cleaning oneself with dung. He prohibited women from leaving their house without the permission of their husband; for if she leaves, she will be cursed by every angel in heaven and everything that passes it from the Jinn and the humans until she returns to her house.â€ He prohibited a woman from adorning herself for other than her husband, for if she does that, then it will be a right upon Allah to burn her in the Fire. He prohibited women from saying more than five unnecessary words to those other than their husbands and their relatives. He prohibited women from seeing one another without a robe. He prohibited women from speaking about that which is confidential with regards to their husbands. He prohibited men from having intercourse with their women while facing the qibla or on a paved road, for whoever does that, then the curse of Allah, the angels, and all the people will be on him. He prohibited men from telling men: â€œMarry me to your sister so that I may marry you to my sister.â€ He prohibited visiting fortune-tellers, and he said: â€œWhoever meets him and believes in him has dissociated from what Allah has revealed to Muhammad (s).â€ He prohibited playing with dice, chess, drums, tambourines, and ouds. He prohibited backbiting and listening to it. He prohibited gossiping and listening to it. He said: â€œA backbiter, meaning a gossiper, will not enter Paradise.â€ He prohibited responding to an invitation to food from the depraved people (fasiqin). He prohibited bearing false oaths. He said: â€œIt leads to a loss of houses.â€ He said: â€œWhoever swears a false oath intending to cut a Muslim person away from his wealth will meet Allah while He is angry with him, unless he repents and recants.â€ He prohibited sitting at tablespreads where wine is drunk. He prohibited men from bringing their women to bathhouses. He said: â€œNone of you should enter a bathhouse without an izar (a garment that covers the lower part of one's body).â€ He prohibited conversations that call toward other than Allah. He prohibited slapping the face. He prohibited drinking from a gold or silver vessel. He prohibited men from wearing silk; as for women, then there is no problem. He prohibited selling fruits before they bloom -- meaning, [before they turn] yellow or red. He prohibited selling dates before they ripen and grapes and that which is similar. He prohibited selling dice and chess. He said: â€œWhoever does that is like one who has eaten pork.â€ He prohibited selling wine, buying wine, and providing wine. He (as) said: â€œMay Allah curse wine, its presser, its planter, its drinker, its provider, its seller, its buyer, the one who consumes its wealth, its carrier, and the one it is carried to.â€ He (as) said: â€œWhoever drinks it, then his prayers are not accepted for forty days. If he dies with something of it in his stomach, then it will be a right on Allah to make him drink his own melted flesh, which is the pus of the people of the Fire, as well as that which comes out of the privates of adulterers. That will be gathered in the pots of Hell, and the people of the Fire will drink from it, and it will melt that which is in their stomachs and their flesh.â€ He prohibited consuming usury, bearing false witness, and issuing usury. He (as) said: â€œSurely, Allah curses the consumer of usury, its dealer, its issuer, and the one who witnesses over it.â€ He prohibited lending on the condition of sale. He prohibited [binding interactions] when a buyer and seller [have not yet separated.] He prohibited selling that which you do not have. He prohibited selling that which cannot be guaranteed. He prohibited shaking hands with the dhimmi. He prohibited the recitation (inshad) of poetry or the recitation of misguidance in the mosque. He prohibited the unsheathing of swords in the mosque. He prohibited striking the faces of animals. He prohibited men from looking at the privates of their Muslim brethren. He said: â€œWhoever stares at the private of his brother, then seventy thousand angels curse him.â€ He prohibited women from looking at the privates of women. He prohibited blowing into food or drink or blowing in the place of prostration. He prohibited praying in graveyards, on roads, on roundabouts [that overlook what surround them], in valleys, in camel stalls, and atop the Ka`ba. He prohibited the killing of bees. He prohibited branding the faces of animals. He prohibited swearing on other than Allah. He said: â€œWhoever swears on other than Allah will have nothing to do with Allah.â€ He prohibited swearing on a chapter from the Book of Allah. He said: â€œWhoever swears on a chapter from the Book of Allah must fulfill [the expiation of an unfulfilled] oath â€“ whoever wishes will abide by it, and whoever wishes will disobey.â€ He prohibited the saying of a man to a man: â€œNo, by your life, and by the life of so-and-so.â€ He prohibited sitting in the mosque in a state of sexual impurity. He prohibited nudity at night and in the day. He prohibited cupping (hijama) on Wednesdays and Fridays. He prohibited speaking while the imam is delivering a sermon on Friday â€“ whoever does that has made chatter, and whoever makes chatter will have no Friday [prayer recorded] for him. He prohibited wearing gold and iron rings. He prohibited etching something from the animals on the ring. He prohibited praying at three timings: (1) at sunrise, (2) at sunset, and (3) at its zenith. He prohibited fasting on six days: (1) the day of Fitr, (2) the day of doubt (when it is unsure whether it is Ramadan or Eid), (3) the day of sacrifice (Eid al-Adha), and (4-6) the days of tashriq. He prohibited sipping water in the way animals drink. He said: â€œDrink with your hands, for they are the best of your utensils.â€ He prohibited spitting in the wells that are drunk from. He prohibited hiring a worker before knowing what his wage is. He prohibited ignoring [a person]; and if he must do so, then he cannot ignore his brother for more than three days. Whoever ignores his brother for longer than that, then the Fire is most rightful to him. He prohibited selling gold and silver at one price. He prohibited selling gold for more gold except that which is equal in weight. He prohibited overpraising [others]. He said: â€œThrow dust in the faces of those who overpraise.â€ He (s) said: â€œWhoever supports the argument of an oppressor or supports him in it, when the Angel of Death comes down to him, it will say to him: â€˜I give you tidings of the curse of Allah and the Fire of Hell in the misery of fate.â€™ Whoever praises a tyrannical leader and eases him and incites him for his own benefit, he will follow him into the Fire.â€ He (s) said: â€œAllah says, â€˜And do not be inclined to the oppressors or you will be touched by the Fire.â€™ (11:113)â€\r\nHe (s) said: â€œWhoever recites the Quran, then drinks something forbidden, or was affected by love of this world and its frills, will have made the indignation of Allah obligatory on himself, unless he repents. If he dies without repenting, then he will have deserted the Quran on the Day of Resurrection, and he will be invalidated.â€ Surely, whoever commits adultery with a Muslim woman, a Jewish woman, a Christian woman, or a Zoroastrian woman, free or bond, and does not repent, and dies insistent on that, Allah will open three hundred gates to his grave, from which snakes, scorpions, and serpents of the Fire will come through. He will burn until the Day of Resurrection. When he is resurrected from his grave, the people will seek refuge from the stench of his smell, and he will be recognized for that and for what he did in the abode of this world, until he is sent to the Fire. Surely, it is Allah that forbade the forbidden and set the penalties (or limits), and not one other than Allah. It is none but He who forbade immoral actions. He prohibited looking into the house oneâ€™s neighbour. He said: â€œWhoever intentionally looks at the private of his Muslim brother or the private of one from outside his family, Allah will include him among the hypocrites who would implore about the privates of Muslims. He will not come out of this world until Allah exposes him unless he repents.â€ He (s) said: â€œWhoever is not pleased with what Allah allotted for him of sustenance, and broadcasts his complaints, and does not exercise patience and consideration, his good deeds will not be raised up. He will meet Allah while He is angry unless he repents.â€ He prohibited strutting while walking. He said: â€œWhoever wears a robe and struts in it, Allah will take him to the edge of Hell. He will follow Qarun because he was the first who strutted about his house on Earth. Whoever struts has challenged Allah in His might.â€ He (s) said: â€œWhoever oppresses a woman of her dowry is considered by Allah to be an adulterer. Allah will say to him on the Day of Resurrection: â€˜My servant! I have married you to My maidservant upon My covenant, but you did not fulfill My covenant. You have oppressed My maidservant.â€™ So, she will take from his good deeds in proportion to what is owed to her. If he does not have enough good deeds, he will be ordered to the Fire, having abandoned the covenant. â€˜Surely, you will be accounted for your covenant.â€™ (17:34)â€ He (s) prohibited concealing testimonies. He said: â€œWhoever conceals it, Allah will feed his flesh to the heads of creatures.â€ That is the saying of Allah, â€œDo not conceal the testimony, for whoever conceals it, their hearts are surely sinful.â€ (2:283) The Messenger of Allah (s) said: â€œWhoever harms his neighbour, Allah forbids the fragrance of Paradise from him, and his place will be in Hell in the misery of fate. Whoever squanders the right of his neighbour is not of us. Gabriel has not stopped advising me about the neighbour, to the point where I thought that he would also inherit. He has not stopped advising me about the slaves, to the point where I thought that they would be freed once they reached a certain time. He did not stop advising me about the toothstick, to the point where I thought that he would make it an obligation. He did not stop advising me about standing at night in prayer, to the point where I thought that the best of my Nation would not sleep. Surely, whoever does not take the affairs of a poor Muslim seriously, Allah will not take his rights seriously, and Allah will not take his affairs seriously on the Day of Resurrection, unless he repents.â€ He (s) said: â€œWhoever is generous to a poor Muslim, he will meet Allah on the Day of Resurrection, and He will be pleased with him.â€ He (s) said: â€œWhoever is presented with an indecency or a temptation and avoids them out of the fear of Allah, Allah will forbid the Fire from him. He will safeguard him from the Great Dismay, and He will reward him with what He promised in His Book, in His saying, â€˜For he who fears standing before his Lord is two gardens.â€™ (55:46)â€ Surely, whoever is presented with this world and the Hereafter, and he chooses this world over the Hereafter, he will meet Allah on the Day of Resurrection without a good deed to prevent him from the Fire. Whoever chooses the Hereafter over this world, Allah will be pleased with him, and He will forgive him of his sinful actions. Whoever fills his eye with forbidden things, Allah will fill his eye with fire on the Day of Resurrection. Whoever attaches himself to a woman that is forbidden to him, he will be in a ring of fire with Satan, and they will be cast into the Fire. Whoever cheats a Muslim in buying or selling is not of us, and he will be resurrected on the Day of Resurrection with the Jews, because they cheat the Muslims the most among the creation. The Messenger of Allah (s) prohibited depriving anyone of kindness. He said: â€œWhoever deprives his neighbour of kindness, Allah will deprive him of His goodness on the Day of Resurrection. He will assign him to himself, and whoever is assigned to himself will be in the worst condition!â€ He (s) said: â€œWhen a woman harms her husband with her tongue, Allah does not accept her compulsory, voluntary, or good deeds until she pleases him; even if she fasts during the day, prays during the night, frees slaves, and mounts a horse [to fight] in the cause of Allah, she will be the first to be sent to the Fire. It is the same for the man if was oppressive toward her.â€ Surely, whoever strikes the cheek or the face of a Muslim, Allah will scatter his bones on the Day of Resurrection, and he will be resurrected chained up until he enters Hell, unless he repents. Whoever goes to sleep while having cheated his brother in his heart has slept upon the indignation of Allah and will awake thereupon until he repents. He prohibited backbiting. \r\nHe said: â€œWhoever backbites a Muslim person will have invalidated his fasting and cancelled out his ablution. He will be brought on the Day of Resurrection smelling like a corpse. His smell will harm the people of the stand. If he dies before he repents, he will die allowing that which was forbidden by Allah.â€ He (s) said: â€œWhoever forbears an oppression while he is capable of enforcing [his right], Allah gives him the reward of a martyr.â€ Surely, whoever refutes the backbiting of his brother in a gathering, Allah repels seventy gates of harm from him in this world and the Hereafter. If he does not refute it while he is able to, then he will have the sin of one who backbites seventy times. The Messenger of Allah (s) prohibited betrayal. He said: â€œWhoever betrays a trust in this world and does not give it to its rightful owner, then dies, will have died upon a creed other than mine. He will meet Allah while He is angry.â€ He (s) said: â€œWhoever bears false witness over one of the people, his tongue will be hung with the hypocrites in the lowest depth of the Fire.â€ Whoever knowingly hires a betrayer, then he is like the betrayer. Whoever withholds a right of his Muslim brother, Allah will forbid the blessing of sustenance from him, unless he repents. Surely, whoever hears of an indecency and spreads it, then he is like the one that did it. Whoever is approached by his Muslim brother for a loan, and he is capable of giving it but he does not, Allah will forbid the fragrance of Paradise from him. Whoever exercises patience over the poor manners of a woman, seeking a reward [from Allah], Allah will give him the rewards of the thankful in the Hereafter. Surely, if a woman is not compassionate with her spouse, and she makes him do that which he cannot handle, her good deeds will not be accepted, and she will meet Allah while He is angry. Surely, whoever is generous to his Muslim brother is being generous to Allah. The Messenger of Allah (s) prohibited leading a community [in prayer] without their permission. He said: â€œWhoever leads a community and they are pleased with him, and he gives them his time, and beautifies his prayer in his standing, his recitation, his bowing, his prostration, and his sitting, then he will have a reward like that of the community without decreasing anything of their reward. Surely, whoever leads a community and does not perfect his prayer with him, and does not beautify his humility [before Allah], his bowing, his prostration, and his recitation, his prayer will be rejected and it will not rise above his position. His status will be like that of an oppressive and aggressive leader that cannot rectify his flock and cannot establish any right in them and did not establish an order in them.â€ He said: â€œWhoever walks to his relative with his self and his wealth to connect his blood ties, Allah gives him the reward of one hundred martyrs. He will be given one thousand good deeds for every step that he takes, and forty thousand sins will be erased from him, and he will be raised in rank in proportion to that. It will be as though he worshiped Allah for one hundred years in patience and anticipation.\r\nWhoever takes up a need of a blind person and continues until Allah fulfills the need for him, Allah will dissociate him from hypocrisy and dissociate him from the Fire; and He will fulfill seventy needs for him from the needs of this world, and he will remain in the mercy of Allah until he returns [to Allah]. Whoever becomes ill for a day and a night and does not complain to his visitors, Allah raises him on the Day of Resurrection with His Friend Ibrahim the Friend of the Merciful, until he passes through the Path like a bolt of lightening. Whoever goes intending to fulfill a need for an ill person, and fulfills it or does not fulfill it, he will come out of his sins [and be sinless] like the day his mother gave birth to him.â€\r\nSo, a man from the Ansar said: â€œMay my mother and my father be your sacrifice, O Messenger of Allah! If the ill person were from his family, is there not a greater reward for him who strives to fulfill a need for his family?â€ He said: â€œYes. Surely, whoever relieves a believer of a burden from the burdens of this world, Allah relieves him of seventy-two burdens from the burdens of the Hereafter, and He relieves him of the pain of seventy-two burdens of this world.â€ He said: â€œWhoever invalidates the right of a rightful person when he is capable of fulfilling his need will have tens of sins every day. Surely, whoever whips [a person] in front of a tyrant, Allah will make that whip into a serpent of fire that will be seventy cubits long, and he will be whipped with it in the Fire in the misery of fate. Whoever constrains a good from coming to his brother, Allah invalidates his deeds, makes his sin resolute, and does not thank him for his endeavour.â€\r\nThen, he (s) said: â€œAllah says: â€˜Paradise is forbidden for one who is wealthy yet stingy; as well as for the backbiter, who is the gossiper.â€™ Surely, whoever gives in charity, each silver coin that he gives will be a blessing in Paradise, the weight of each of which is like that of Mount Uhud. Whoever brings a charity [of someone else] to a needy person, he will have the reward of the owner [of the charity] without decreasing a thing of his reward. Whoever prays over a deceased person, seventy-thousand angels will pray over him, and Allah will forgive all his past sins. Whoever attends [the funeral] until he is buried and dirt is thrown onto him, he will be rewarded with a carat for each step that he took; each carat will be like Mount Uhud. Surely, whoever sheds a tear in humility before Allah, he will have a palace in Paradise for each tear, decked with pearl and jewels â€“ in it will be that which no eye has seen, no ear has heard, and no human heart has imagined. \r\nSurely, whoever goes to the mosque seeking congregational prayer will receive seventy thousand good deeds with each step, and he will be raised in rank in proportion to that. If he dies while doing that, Allah will assign one thousand angels to visit him in his grave. They will bring comfort to him in his solitude, and they will seek forgiveness on his behalf until he is resurrected. Surely, whoever gives the call to prayer in anticipation, seeking the face of Allah with it, Allah will grant him the reward of forty thousand martyrs and forty thousand saints. His intercession will encompass forty thousand people from my Nation, and they will go to Paradise. Surely, when the muâ€™adhin says: â€˜I bear witness that there is no god but Allahâ€™, ninety thousand angels will bless him and ask for forgiveness on his behalf. On the Day of Resurrection, he will be in the shade of the Throne until the creatures are finished with the judgment. When he says: â€˜I bear witness that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allahâ€™, forty thousand angels will record his deeds. Whoever secures the first row and the first takbir, and does not harm a Muslim, Allah will reward him with that which is given to the muâ€™adhins in this world and the Hereafter. Surely, whoever aligns with a fortune-teller, Allah will imprison him at the edge of Hell. For every day [he went, he will be there for] one thousand years. He will be resurrected on the Day of Judgment with his hands chained to his neck. When he stands to be judged by Allah, Allah will cast him away. If he was oppressive, he will be sent to the Fire in the misery of fate.â€\r\nHe (s) said: â€œDo not underestimate evil, not matter how small it is in your eyes, and do not overestimate goodness, no matter how much of it is in your eyes. There is nothing too big for repentance, and there is nothing too small for persistence.â€\r\nMuhammad b. Zakariyya al-Ghilabi said: I asked Shu`ayb al-Muzni (the narrator) about the length of this report, so he said to me: O Aba `Abdillah! I asked al-Husayn b. Zayd about the length of this hadith, so he said: Ja`far b. Muhammad b. `Ali b. al-Husayn b. `Ali b. Abi Talib (as) narrated to me that he gathered this hadith from a book that was the dictations of the Messenger of Allah (s) and the handwriting of `Ali b. Abi Talib (as).", "arabicText": "1 - Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙŠØ® Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³ÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ù† Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ÙˆÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ù…ÙŠ (Ø±Ø¶ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡)ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø­Ù…Ø²Ø© Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø²ÙŠØ¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³ÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…)ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø²ÙŠØ² Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù‡Ø±ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø²ÙƒØ±ÙŠØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø¬ÙˆÙ‡Ø±ÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØºÙ„Ø§Ø¨ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¨ØµØ±ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø´Ø¹ÙŠØ¨ Ø¨Ù† ÙˆØ§Ù‚Ø¯ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³ÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ù† ÙŠØ²ÙŠØ¯ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ØµØ§Ø¯Ù‚ Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¢Ø¨Ø§Ø¦Ù‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…)ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§ÙƒÙ„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø§Ø¨Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆØ±Ø« Ø§Ù„ÙÙ‚Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† ØªÙ‚Ù„ÙŠÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¸Ø§ÙÙŠØ± Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø³Ù†Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙˆØ§Ùƒ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù…Ø§Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØªÙ†Ø®Ø¹ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø§Ø¬Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø£ÙƒÙ„ Ø³Ø¤Ø± Ø§Ù„ÙØ£Ø±. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù„Ø§ ØªØ¬Ø¹Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø§Ø¬Ø¯ Ø·Ø±Ù‚Ø§ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ØªØµÙ„ÙˆØ§ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø±ÙƒØ¹ØªÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¨ÙˆÙ„ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ ØªØ­Øª Ø´Ø¬Ø±Ø© Ù…Ø«Ù…Ø±Ø© Ø£Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‚Ø§Ø±Ø¹Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø±ÙŠÙ‚ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ£ÙƒÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù† Ø¨Ø´Ù…Ø§Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù† ÙŠØ£ÙƒÙ„ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù…ØªÙƒØ¦ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ØªØ¬ØµØµ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‚Ø§Ø¨Ø± ÙˆÙŠØµÙ„Ù‰ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø§ØºØªØ³Ù„ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ÙƒÙ… ÙÙŠ ÙØ¶Ø§Ø¡ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø±Ø¶ ÙÙ„ÙŠØ­Ø§Ø°Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹ÙˆØ±ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø±Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø­Ø¯ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø¹Ø±ÙˆØ© Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù†Ø§Ø¡ ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø¬ØªÙ…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ³Ø®ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¨ÙˆÙ„ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø§ÙƒØ¯ ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø°Ù‡Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ…Ø´ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ ÙØ±Ø¯ Ù†Ø¹Ù„ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠØªÙ†Ø¹Ù„ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¨ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙˆÙØ±Ø¬Ù‡ Ø¨Ø§Ø¯ Ù„Ù„Ø´Ù…Ø³ Ø£Ùˆ Ù„Ù„Ù‚Ù…Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø¯Ø®Ù„ØªÙ… Ø§Ù„ØºØ§Ø¦Ø· ÙØªØ¬Ù†Ø¨ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¨Ù„Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù†Ø© Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù…ØµÙŠØ¨Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†ÙŠØ§Ø­Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø³ØªÙ…Ø§Ø¹ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§ØªØ¨Ø§Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø³Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø§Ø¦Ø²ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ…Ø­Ù‰ Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ù† ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø²Ø§Ù‚ Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠÙƒØªØ¨ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒØ°Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø±Ø¤ÙŠØ§Ù‡ Ù…ØªØ¹Ù…Ø¯Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠÙƒÙ„ÙÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¹Ù‚Ø¯ Ø´Ø¹ÙŠØ±Ø© ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø¨Ø¹Ø§Ù‚Ø¯Ù‡Ø§. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ØªØµØ§ÙˆÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† ØµÙˆØ± ØµÙˆØ±Ø© ÙƒÙ„ÙÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†ÙØ® ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ø¨Ù†Ø§ÙØ®ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ­Ø±Ù‚ Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙŠÙˆØ§Ù† Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø³Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙƒØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆÙ‚Ø¸ Ù„Ù„ØµÙ„Ø§Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¯Ø®Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø³ÙˆÙ… (1) Ø£Ø®ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒØ«Ø± Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¬Ø§Ù…Ø¹Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø®Ø±Ø³ Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙ„Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù„Ø§ ØªØ¨ÙŠØªÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙŠÙˆØªÙƒÙ… ÙˆØ£Ø®Ø±Ø¬ÙˆÙ‡Ø§ Ù†Ù‡Ø§Ø±Ø§ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ù‚Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙŠØ·Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¨ÙŠØªÙ† Ø£Ø­Ø¯ÙƒÙ… ÙˆÙŠØ¯Ù‡ ØºÙ…Ø±Ø© (2)ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† ÙØ¹Ù„ ÙØ£ØµØ§Ø¨Ù‡ Ù„Ù…Ù… (3) Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙŠØ·Ø§Ù† ÙÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙ„ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ³ØªÙ†Ø¬ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø±ÙˆØ«ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ØªØ®Ø±Ø¬ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡Ø§ Ø¨ØºÙŠØ± Ø¥Ø°Ù† Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† Ø®Ø±Ø¬Øª Ù„Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ù„Ùƒ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆÙƒÙ„ Ø´Ø¦ ØªÙ…Ø± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ù†Ø³ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ØªØ±Ø¬Ø¹ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ØªØªØ²ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ù„ØºÙŠØ± Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† ÙØ¹Ù„Øª ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø­Ù‚Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ­Ø±Ù‚Ù‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ØªØªÙƒÙ„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ ØºÙŠØ± Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØºÙŠØ± Ø°ÙŠ Ù…Ø­Ø±Ù… Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø£ÙƒØ«Ø± Ù…Ù† Ø®Ù…Ø³ ÙƒÙ„Ù…Ø§Øª Ù…Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯ Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ØªØ¨Ø§Ø´Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ø¨ÙŠÙ†Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ø«ÙˆØ¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ØªØ­Ø¯Ø« Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ØªØ®Ù„Ùˆ Ø¨Ù‡ Ù…Ø¹ Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¬Ø§Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ø£Ù‡Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø³ØªÙ‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¨Ù„Ø© Ø£Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø·Ø±ÙŠÙ‚ Ø¹Ø§Ù…Ø±ØŒ ÙÙ…Ù† ÙØ¹Ù„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙØ¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù„Ø¹Ù†Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ù„Ø§Ø¦ÙƒØ© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø£Ø¬Ù…Ø¹ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ù„Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„: Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø®ØªÙƒ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ø£Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ùƒ Ø£Ø®ØªÙŠ. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø¥ØªÙŠØ§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø±Ø§ÙØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ø£ØªØ§Ù‡ ÙˆØµØ¯Ù‚Ù‡ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¨Ø±Ø¦ Ù…Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ù†Ø²Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡)ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ø¹Ø¨ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø±Ø¯ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´Ø·Ø±Ù†Ø¬ ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙƒÙˆØ¨Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ø±Ø·Ø¨Ø© - ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø¨Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø·Ù†Ø¨ÙˆØ± - ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹ÙˆØ¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ØºÙŠØ¨Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø³ØªÙ…Ø§Ø¹ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù…ÙŠÙ…Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø³ØªÙ…Ø§Ø¹ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø®Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø© Ù‚ØªØ§ØªØŒ ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ Ù†Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø§. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø¥Ø¬Ø§Ø¨Ø© Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ø³Ù‚ÙŠÙ† Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø·Ø¹Ø§Ù…Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙ…ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ§Ø°Ø¨Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ØªØªØ±Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠØ§Ø± Ø¨Ù„Ø§Ù‚Ø¹ (1)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ø­Ù„Ù Ø¨ÙŠÙ…ÙŠÙ† ÙƒØ§Ø°Ø¨Ø© ØµØ¨Ø±Ø§ Ù„ÙŠÙ‚Ø·Ø¹ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù…Ø±Ø¦ Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù… Ù„Ù‚ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ØºØ¶Ø¨Ø§Ù† Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨ ÙˆÙŠØ±Ø¬Ø¹ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù„ÙˆØ³ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ø¯Ø© ÙŠØ´Ø±Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù…Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¯Ø®Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ø­Ù„ÙŠÙ„ØªÙ‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù…Ø§Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø®Ù„Ù† Ø£Ø­Ø¯ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ù…Ø¦Ø²Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø­Ø§Ø¯Ø«Ø© Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ ØªØ¯Ø¹Ùˆ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ ØºÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† ØªØµÙÙŠÙ‚ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ¬Ù‡ (2)ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø±Ø¨ ÙÙŠ Ø¢Ù†ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù‡Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙØ¶Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ù„Ø¨Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø±ÙŠØ± ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠØ¨Ø§Ø¬ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù‚Ø² Ù„Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ø§Ù„ØŒ ÙØ£Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù„Ù†Ø³Ø§Ø¡ ÙÙ„Ø§ Ø¨Ø£Ø³. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ØªØ¨Ø§Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø«Ù…Ø§Ø± Ø­ØªÙ‰ ØªØ²Ù‡Ùˆ - ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ ØªØµÙØ± Ø£Ùˆ ØªØ­Ù…Ø± -ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø­Ø§Ù‚Ù„Ø©ØŒ - ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨ÙŠØ¹ Ø§Ù„ØªÙ…Ø± Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø·Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø²Ø¨ÙŠØ¨ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù†Ø¨ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ø´Ø¨Ù‡ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ -. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø¨ÙŠØ¹ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø±Ø¯ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´Ø·Ø±Ù†Ø¬ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† ÙØ¹Ù„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ ÙƒØ¢ÙƒÙ„ Ù„Ø­Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù†Ø²ÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø¨ÙŠØ¹ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù…Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù† ØªØ´ØªØ±Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù…Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù† ØªØ³Ù‚Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù…Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ù„Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù…Ø± ÙˆØ¹Ø§ØµØ±Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØºØ§Ø±Ø³Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ´Ø§Ø±Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØ³Ø§Ù‚ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ¨Ø§Ø¦Ø¹Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ø´ØªØ±ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ¢ÙƒÙ„ Ø«Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø§Ù…Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø­Ù…ÙˆÙ„Ø© Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ù…Ù† Ø´Ø±Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù„Ù… ØªÙ‚Ø¨Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ ØµÙ„Ø§Ø© Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ† ÙŠÙˆÙ…Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ù…Ø§Øª ÙˆÙÙŠ Ø¨Ø·Ù†Ù‡ Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø­Ù‚Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ³Ù‚ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ù† Ø·ÙŠÙ†Ø© Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ ØµØ¯ÙŠØ¯ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ ÙŠØ®Ø±Ø¬ Ù…Ù† ÙØ±ÙˆØ¬ Ø§Ù„Ø²Ù†Ø§Ø©ØŒ ÙÙŠØ¬ØªÙ…Ø¹ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙÙŠ Ù‚Ø¯ÙˆØ± Ø¬Ù‡Ù†Ù…ØŒ ÙÙŠØ´Ø±Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙÙŠØµÙ‡Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø¨Ø·ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬Ù„ÙˆØ¯. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø£ÙƒÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¨Ø§ ÙˆØ´Ù‡Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø²ÙˆØ± ÙˆÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¨Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù„Ø¹Ù† Ø¢ÙƒÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¨Ø§ ÙˆÙ…ÙˆÙƒÙ„Ù‡ ÙˆÙƒØ§ØªØ¨Ù‡ ÙˆØ´Ø§Ù‡Ø¯ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø¨ÙŠØ¹ ÙˆØ³Ù„ÙØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø¨ÙŠØ¹ÙŠÙ† ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙŠØ¹ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø¨ÙŠØ¹ Ù…Ø§ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø¨ÙŠØ¹ Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¶Ù…Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ù…ØµØ§ÙØ­Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù…ÙŠØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†Ø´Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¹Ø±ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ ØªÙ†Ø´Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¶Ø§Ù„Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø¬Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ³Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙŠÙ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø¬Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø¶Ø±Ø¨ ÙˆØ¬ÙˆÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ù‡Ø§Ø¦Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†Ø¸Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø£Ø®ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† ØªØ£Ù…Ù„ Ø¹ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø£Ø®ÙŠÙ‡ Ù„Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ Ø³Ø¨Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù„Ù Ù…Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ø£Ù† ØªÙ†Ø¸Ø± Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†ÙØ® ÙÙŠ Ø·Ø¹Ø§Ù… Ø£Ùˆ ÙÙŠ Ø´Ø±Ø§Ø¨ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠÙ†ÙØ® ÙÙŠ Ù…ÙˆØ¶Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø¬ÙˆØ¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØµÙ„ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‚Ø§Ø¨Ø± ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø·Ø±Ù‚ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø±Ø­ÙŠØ© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§ÙˆØ¯ÙŠØ© ÙˆÙ…Ø±Ø§Ø¨Ø· Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù„ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¸Ù‡Ø± Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ¹Ø¨Ø©. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ù‚ØªÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø­Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ³Ù… ÙÙŠ ÙˆØ¬ÙˆÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ù‡Ø§Ø¦Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ­Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ø¨ØºÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ø­Ù„Ù Ø¨ØºÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø´Ø¦ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ­Ù„Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ø¨Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ù…Ù† ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ø­Ù„Ù Ø¨Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ù…Ù† ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙØ¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¨ÙƒÙ„ Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙŠÙ…ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙÙ…Ù† Ø´Ø§Ø¡ Ø¨Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø´Ø§Ø¡ ÙØ¬Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ù„Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„: Ù„Ø§ ÙˆØ­ÙŠØ§ØªÙƒ ÙˆØ­ÙŠØ§Ø© ÙÙ„Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ‚Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø¬Ø¯ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¬Ù†Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ØªØ¹Ø±ÙŠ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù„ÙŠÙ„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†Ù‡Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¬Ø§Ù…Ø© ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø±Ø¨Ø¹Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬Ù…Ø¹Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù…Ø¹Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… ÙŠØ®Ø·Ø¨ØŒ ÙÙ…Ù† ÙØ¹Ù„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ù„ØºØ§ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ù„ØºØ§ ÙÙ„Ø§ Ø¬Ù…Ø¹Ø© Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ØªØ®ØªÙ… Ø¨Ø®Ø§ØªÙ… ØµÙØ± Ø£Ùˆ Ø­Ø¯ÙŠØ¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†Ù‚Ø´ Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙŠÙˆØ§Ù† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø§ØªÙ…. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ØµÙ„Ø§Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø«Ù„Ø§Ø« Ø³Ø§Ø¹Ø§Øª: Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø·Ù„ÙˆØ¹ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ù…Ø³ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù†Ø¯ ØºØ±ÙˆØ¨Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ø³ØªÙˆØ§Ø¦Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† ØµÙŠØ§Ù… Ø³ØªØ© Ø£ÙŠØ§Ù…: ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„ÙØ·Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙƒØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø­Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ£ÙŠØ§Ù… Ø§Ù„ØªØ´Ø±ÙŠÙ‚ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ´Ø±Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ ÙƒØ±Ø¹Ø§ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ ØªØ´Ø±Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ù‡Ø§Ø¦Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø§Ø´Ø±Ø¨ÙˆØ§ Ø¨Ø£ÙŠØ¯ÙŠÙƒÙ… ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø£ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø£ÙˆØ§Ù†ÙŠÙƒÙ…ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø²Ø§Ù‚ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø¦Ø± Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ ÙŠØ´Ø±Ø¨ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ³ØªØ¹Ù…Ù„ Ø£Ø¬ÙŠØ± Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø¬Ø±ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ø¬Ø±Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ø¯ ÙØ§Ø¹Ù„Ø§ ÙÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙ‡Ø¬Ø± Ø£Ø®Ø§Ù‡ Ø£ÙƒØ«Ø± Ù…Ù† Ø«Ù„Ø§Ø«Ø© Ø£ÙŠØ§Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ…Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù…Ù‡Ø§Ø¬Ø±Ø§ Ù„Ø§Ø®ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£ÙƒØ«Ø± Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø± Ø£ÙˆÙ„Ù‰ Ø¨Ù‡. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø¨ÙŠØ¹ Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù‡Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙØ¶Ø© Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø³ÙŠØ©ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø¨ÙŠØ¹ Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù‡Ø¨ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù‡Ø¨ Ø²ÙŠØ§Ø¯Ø© Ø¥Ù„Ø§ ÙˆØ²Ù†Ø§ Ø¨ÙˆØ²Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¯Ø­ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø§Ø­Ø«ÙˆØ§ ÙÙŠ ÙˆØ¬ÙˆÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¯Ø§Ø­ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„ØªØ±Ø§Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ù† ØªÙˆÙ„Ù‰ Ø®ØµÙˆÙ…Ø© Ø¸Ø§Ù„Ù… Ø£Ùˆ Ø£Ø¹Ø§Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù†Ø²Ù„ Ø¨Ù‡ Ù…Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØªØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡: Ø£Ø¨Ø´Ø± Ø¨Ù„Ø¹Ù†Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ†Ø§Ø± Ø¬Ù‡Ù†Ù… ÙˆØ¨Ø¦Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ù…ØµÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ù…Ø¯Ø­ Ø³Ù„Ø·Ø§Ù†Ø§ Ø¬Ø§Ø¦Ø±Ø§ ÙˆØªØ®ÙÙ ÙˆØªØ¶Ø¹Ø¶Ø¹ Ù„Ù‡ Ø·Ù…Ø¹Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ‡ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù‚Ø±ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØªØ±ÙƒÙ†ÙˆØ§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¸Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ§ ÙØªÙ…Ø³ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±) (1). ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ù† Ø¯Ù„ Ø¬Ø§Ø¦Ø±Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¬ÙˆØ±ØŒ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù‚Ø±ÙŠÙ† Ù‡Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù† ÙÙŠ Ø¬Ù‡Ù†Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø¨Ù†Ù‰ Ø¨Ù†ÙŠØ§Ù†Ø§ Ø±ÙŠØ§Ø¡ ÙˆØ³Ù…Ø¹Ø© Ø­Ù…Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø±Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø¹Ø© ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù†Ø§Ø± ØªØ´ØªØ¹Ù„ØŒ Ø«Ù… ÙŠØ·ÙˆÙ‚ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ù†Ù‚Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ„Ù‚Ù‰ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ­Ø¨Ø³Ù‡ Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ù‚Ø¹Ø±Ù‡Ø§ØŒ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨. Ù‚ÙŠÙ„: ÙŠØ§ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠØ¨Ù†ÙŠ Ø±ÙŠØ§Ø¡ ÙˆØ³Ù…Ø¹Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ¨Ù†ÙŠ ÙØ¶Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ø³ØªØ·Ø§Ù„Ø© Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¬ÙŠØ±Ø§Ù†Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø¨Ø§Ù‡Ø§Ø© Ù„Ø§Ø®ÙˆØ§Ù†Ù‡. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ù† Ø¸Ù„Ù… Ø£Ø¬ÙŠØ±Ø§ Ø£Ø¬Ø±Ù‡ Ø£Ø­Ø¨Ø· Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù…Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ­Ø±Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø±ÙŠØ­ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ø±ÙŠØ­Ù‡Ø§ Ù„ØªÙˆØ¬Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ±Ø© Ø®Ù…Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ø© Ø¹Ø§Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø®Ø§Ù† Ø¬Ø§Ø±Ù‡ Ø´Ø¨Ø±Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø±Ø¶ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø·ÙˆÙ‚Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ù†Ù‚Ù‡ Ù…Ù† ØªØ®ÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø±Ø¶ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø¹Ø©ØŒ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠÙ„Ù‚Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ù…Ø·ÙˆÙ‚Ø§ØŒ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨ ÙˆÙŠØ±Ø¬Ø¹. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØªØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† Ø«Ù… Ù†Ø³ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…ØªØ¹Ù…Ø¯Ø§ØŒ Ù„Ù‚ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ù…ØºÙ„ÙˆÙ„Ø§ØŒ ÙŠØ³Ù„Ø· Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¨ÙƒÙ„ Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø­ÙŠØ© ØªÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù‚Ø±ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØºÙØ± Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ù† Ù‚Ø±Ø£ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† Ø«Ù… Ø´Ø±Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø­Ø±Ø§Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ùˆ Ø¢Ø«Ø± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø­Ø¨Ø§ Ù„Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ ÙˆØ²ÙŠÙ†ØªÙ‡Ø§ØŒ Ø§Ø³ØªÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø³Ø®Ø· Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨ØŒ Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆØ¥Ù†Ù‡ Ø¥Ù† Ù…Ø§Øª Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ØºÙŠØ± ØªÙˆØ¨Ø© Ø­Ø§Ø¬Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§ÙŠÙ„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ø¯Ø­ÙˆØ¶Ø§. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø²Ù†Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…Ø© Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠÙ‡ÙˆØ¯ÙŠØ© Ø£Ùˆ Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ© Ø£Ùˆ Ù…Ø¬ÙˆØ³ÙŠØ©ØŒ Ø­Ø±Ø© Ø£Ùˆ Ø£Ù…Ø©ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù„Ù… ÙŠØªØ¨ ÙˆÙ…Ø§Øª Ù…ØµØ±Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙØªØ­ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ù‚Ø¨Ø±Ù‡ Ø«Ù„Ø§Ø«Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ø© Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ØŒ ØªØ®Ø±Ø¬ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø­ÙŠØ§Øª ÙˆØ¹Ù‚Ø§Ø±Ø¨ ÙˆØ«Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ ÙŠØ­ØªØ±Ù‚ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹Ø« Ù…Ù† Ù‚Ø¨Ø±Ù‡ ØªØ£Ø°Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ù…Ù† Ù†ØªÙ† Ø±ÙŠØ­Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙŠØ¹Ø±Ù Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØ¨Ù…Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠØ¹Ù…Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø¯Ø§Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ØŒ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠØ¤Ù…Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±. Ø£Ù„Ø§ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø­Ø±Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø±Ø§Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¯ÙˆØ¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø£ØºÙŠØ± Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØºÙŠØ±ØªÙ‡ Ø­Ø±Ù… Ø§Ù„ÙÙˆØ§Ø­Ø´ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ·Ù„Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙŠØª Ø¬Ø§Ø±Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ù†Ø¸Ø± Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø£Ø®ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù… Ø£Ùˆ Ø¹ÙˆØ±Ø© ØºÙŠØ± Ø£Ù‡Ù„Ù‡ Ù…ØªØ¹Ù…Ø¯Ø§ØŒ Ø£Ø¯Ø®Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†Ø§ÙÙ‚ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† ÙƒØ§Ù†ÙˆØ§ ÙŠØ¨Ø­Ø«ÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù† Ø¹ÙˆØ±Ø§Øª Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ®Ø±Ø¬ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠÙØ¶Ø­Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ù† Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ±Ø¶ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø³Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø²Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆØ¨Ø« Ø´ÙƒÙˆØ§Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØµØ¨Ø± ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ­ØªØ³Ø¨ØŒ Ù„Ù… ØªØ±ÙØ¹ Ù„Ù‡ Ø­Ø³Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ„Ù‚Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ØºØ¶Ø¨Ø§Ù†ØŒ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ®ØªØ§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø´ÙŠØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ù„Ø¨Ø³ Ø«ÙˆØ¨Ø§ ÙØ§Ø®ØªØ§Ù„ ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø®Ø³Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø´ÙÙŠØ± Ø¬Ù‡Ù†Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† Ù‚Ø±ÙŠÙ† Ù‚Ø§Ø±ÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù†Ù‡ Ø£ÙˆÙ„ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ø®ØªØ§Ù„ ÙØ®Ø³Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆØ¨Ø¯Ø§Ø±Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø±Ø¶ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø§Ø®ØªØ§Ù„ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ù†Ø§Ø²Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø¬Ø¨Ø±ÙˆØªÙ‡. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ù† Ø¸Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ù…Ù‡Ø±Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø²Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø©: Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ÙŠ Ø²ÙˆØ¬ØªÙƒ Ø£Ù…ØªÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù‡Ø¯ÙŠØŒ ÙÙ„Ù… ØªÙˆÙ Ø¨Ø¹Ù‡Ø¯ÙŠØŒ ÙˆØ¸Ù„Ù…Øª Ø£Ù…ØªÙŠØŒ ÙÙŠØ¤Ø®Ø° Ù…Ù† Ø­Ø³Ù†Ø§ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙÙŠØ¯ÙØ¹ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø¨Ù‚Ø¯Ø± Ø­Ù‚Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ØªØ¨Ù‚ Ù„Ù‡ Ø­Ø³Ù†Ø© Ø£Ù…Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø± Ø¨Ù†ÙƒØ«Ù‡ Ù„Ù„Ø¹Ù‡Ø¯ (Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‡Ø¯ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù…Ø³Ø¦ÙˆÙ„Ø§) (1). ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø¹Ù† ÙƒØªÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø´Ù‡Ø§Ø¯Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† ÙƒØªÙ…Ù‡Ø§ Ø£Ø·Ø¹Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ø­Ù…Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø¤ÙˆØ³ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ø§Ø¦Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØªÙƒØªÙ…ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ù‡Ø§Ø¯Ø© ÙˆÙ…Ù† ÙŠÙƒØªÙ…Ù‡Ø§ ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡ Ø¡Ø§Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ù„Ø¨Ù‡) (2)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ù† Ø¢Ø°Ù‰ Ø¬Ø§Ø±Ù‡ Ø­Ø±Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø±ÙŠØ­ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø£ÙˆØ§Ù‡ Ø¬Ù‡Ù†Ù… ÙˆØ¨Ø¦Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ù…ØµÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø¶ÙŠØ¹ Ø­Ù‚ Ø¬Ø§Ø±Ù‡ ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ù…Ù†Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø²Ø§Ù„ Ø¬Ø¨Ø±Ø¦ÙŠÙ„ ÙŠÙˆØµÙŠÙ†ÙŠ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø± Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ø¸Ù†Ù†Øª Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø³ÙŠÙˆØ±Ø«Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø²Ø§Ù„ ÙŠÙˆØµÙŠÙ†ÙŠ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù…Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙƒ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ø¸Ù†Ù†Øª Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø³ÙŠØ¬Ø¹Ù„ Ù„Ù‡Ù… ÙˆÙ‚ØªØ§ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø¨Ù„ØºÙˆØ§ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙ‚Øª Ø§Ø¹ØªÙ‚ÙˆØ§ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø²Ø§Ù„ ÙŠÙˆØµÙŠÙ†ÙŠ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙˆØ§Ùƒ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ø¸Ù†Ù†Øª Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø³ÙŠØ¬Ø¹Ù„Ù‡ ÙØ±ÙŠØ¶Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø²Ø§Ù„ ÙŠÙˆØµÙŠÙ†ÙŠ Ø¨Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ø¸Ù†Ù†Øª Ø£Ù† Ø®ÙŠØ§Ø± Ø£Ù…ØªÙŠ Ù„Ù† ÙŠÙ†Ø§Ù…ÙˆØ§. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø§Ø³ØªØ®Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‚ÙŠØ± Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø§Ø³ØªØ®Ù Ø¨Ø­Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠØ³ØªØ®Ù Ø¨Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø©ØŒ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ù† Ø£ÙƒØ±Ù… ÙÙ‚ÙŠØ±Ø§ Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…Ø§ØŒ Ù„Ù‚ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ Ø±Ø§Ø¶. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ø±Ø¶Øª Ù„Ù‡ ÙØ§Ø­Ø´Ø© Ø£Ùˆ Ø´Ù‡ÙˆØ©ØŒ ÙØ§Ø¬ØªÙ†Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ù…Ø®Ø§ÙØ© Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ØŒ Ø­Ø±Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ¢Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙØ²Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø§ÙƒØ¨Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù†Ø¬Ø² Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø§ ÙˆØ¹Ø¯Ù‡ ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡: (ÙˆÙ„Ù…Ù† Ø®Ø§Ù Ù…Ù‚Ø§Ù… Ø±Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¬Ù†ØªØ§Ù†) (1). Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø¹Ø±Ø¶Øª Ù„Ù‡ Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ ÙˆØ¢Ø®Ø±Ø©ØŒ ÙØ§Ø®ØªØ§Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ø©ØŒ Ù„Ù‚ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ³Øª Ù„Ù‡ Ø­Ø³Ù†Ø© ÙŠØªÙ‚ÙŠ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø§Ø®ØªØ§Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ (2) Ø±Ø¶ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØºÙØ± Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø³Ø§ÙˆØ¦ Ø¹Ù…Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ù…Ù„Ø§ Ø¹ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø­Ø±Ø§Ù… Ù…Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨ ÙˆÙŠØ±Ø¬Ø¹. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ù† ØµØ§ÙØ­ Ø§Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© ØªØ­Ø±Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø¨Ø§Ø¡ Ø¨Ø³Ø®Ø· Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØªØ²Ù… Ø§Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ø­Ø±Ø§Ù…Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø±Ù† ÙÙŠ Ø³Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø± Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙŠØ·Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙÙŠÙ‚Ø°ÙØ§Ù† ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØºØ´ Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø´Ø±Ø§Ø¡ Ø£Ùˆ Ø¨ÙŠØ¹ ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ù…Ù†Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ­Ø´Ø± ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ÙˆØ¯ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø£ØºØ´ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ù„Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ…Ù†Ø¹ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¹ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ù…Ù†Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø¬Ø§Ø±Ù‡ Ù…Ù†Ø¹Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø®ÙŠØ±Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙˆÙƒÙ„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ÙˆÙƒÙ„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ø³ÙˆØ£ Ø­Ø§Ù„Ù‡! ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ø£ÙŠÙ…Ø§ Ø§Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ø¢Ø°Øª Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ø§ Ø¨Ù„Ø³Ø§Ù†Ù‡Ø§ØŒ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙ‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ØµØ±ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¹Ø¯Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø­Ø³Ù†Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ØªØ±Ø¶ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† ØµØ§Ù…Øª Ù†Ù‡Ø§Ø±Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù…Øª Ù„ÙŠÙ„Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ø¹ØªÙ‚Øª Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‚Ø§Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ù…Ù„Øª Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¬ÙŠØ§Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙŠÙ„ ÙÙŠ Ø³Ø¨ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ø£ÙˆÙ„ Ù…Ù† ÙŠØ±Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ø¸Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ù„Ø·Ù… Ø®Ø¯ Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù… Ø£Ùˆ ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ù‡ØŒ Ø¨Ø¯Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø¸Ø§Ù…Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø´Ø± Ù…ØºÙ„ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠØ¯Ø®Ù„ Ø¬Ù‡Ù†Ù…ØŒ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø¨Ø§Øª ÙˆÙÙŠ Ù‚Ù„Ø¨Ù‡ ØºØ´ Ù„Ø§Ø®ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù… Ø¨Ø§Øª ÙÙŠ Ø³Ø®Ø· Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ£ØµØ¨Ø­ ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ØºÙŠØ¨Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ø§ØºØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù…Ø±Ø¡Ø§ Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…Ø§ØŒ Ø¨Ø·Ù„ ØµÙˆÙ…Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ù‚Ø¶ ÙˆØ¶ÙˆØ¤Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¬Ø§Ø¡ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© ØªÙÙˆØ­ Ù…Ù† ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø±Ø§Ø¦Ø­Ø© Ø£Ù†ØªÙ† Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¬ÙŠÙØ©ØŒ ÙŠØªØ£Ø°Ù‰ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆÙ‚ÙØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† Ù…Ø§Øª Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨ Ù…Ø§Øª Ù…Ø³ØªØ­Ù„Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ø­Ø±Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ù† ÙƒØ¸Ù… ØºÙŠØ¸Ø§ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù‚Ø§Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¥Ù†ÙØ§Ø°Ù‡ ÙˆØ­Ù„Ù… Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ØŒ Ø£Ø¹Ø·Ø§Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ø¬Ø± Ø´Ù‡ÙŠØ¯ØŒ Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØªØ·ÙˆÙ„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø®ÙŠÙ‡ ÙÙŠ ØºÙŠØ¨Ø© Ø³Ù…Ø¹Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ‡ ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø¬Ù„Ø³ ÙØ±Ø¯Ù‡Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ØŒ Ø±Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ Ø£Ù„Ù Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙˆØ¡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ø©ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† Ù‡Ùˆ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ±Ø¯Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù‚Ø§Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø¯Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙƒÙˆØ²Ø± Ù…Ù† Ø§ØºØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡ Ø³Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ† Ù…Ø±Ø©. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙŠØ§Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ø®Ø§Ù† Ø£Ù…Ø§Ù†Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ±Ø¯Ù‡Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù‡Ù„Ù‡Ø§ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø£Ø¯Ø±ÙƒÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØªØŒ Ù…Ø§Øª Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ØºÙŠØ± Ù…Ù„ØªÙŠØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ„Ù‚Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ØºØ¶Ø¨Ø§Ù†. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ù† Ø´Ù‡Ø¯ Ø´Ù‡Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø²ÙˆØ± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ØŒ Ø¹Ù„Ù‚ Ø¨Ù„Ø³Ø§Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†Ø§ÙÙ‚ÙŠÙ† ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø±Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø³ÙÙ„ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø§Ø´ØªØ±Ù‰ Ø®ÙŠØ§Ù†Ø© ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ ÙƒØ§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø®Ø§Ù†Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø­Ø¨Ø³ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø®ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù… Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø­Ù‚ Ø­Ø±Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¨Ø±ÙƒØ© Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø²Ù‚ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø³Ù…Ø¹ ÙØ§Ø­Ø´Ø© ÙØ£ÙØ´Ø§Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ ÙƒØ§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø£ØªØ§Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø§Ø­ØªØ§Ø¬ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ø®ÙˆÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù… ÙÙŠ Ù‚Ø±Ø¶ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠÙØ¹Ù„ØŒ Ø­Ø±Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø±ÙŠØ­ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø©. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØµØ¨Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø§Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ø³ÙŠØ¦Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ø­ØªØ³Ø¨ ÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¬Ø±ØŒ Ø£Ø¹Ø·Ø§Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø«ÙˆØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø§ÙƒØ±ÙŠÙ† ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ø©. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆØ£ÙŠÙ…Ø§ Ø§Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ù„Ù… ØªØ±ÙÙ‚ Ø¨Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ù…Ù„ØªÙ‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ·ÙŠÙ‚ØŒ Ù„Ù… ØªÙ‚Ø¨Ù„ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø­Ø³Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØªÙ„Ù‚Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ ØºØ¶Ø¨Ø§Ù†. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø£ÙƒØ±Ù… Ø£Ø®Ø§Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù… ÙØ¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙƒØ±Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„. ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¤Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ù‚ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø¥Ø°Ù†Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù… Ù‚ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¥Ø°Ù†Ù‡Ù… ÙˆÙ‡Ù… Ø¨Ù‡ Ø±Ø§Ø¶ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙØ§Ù‚ØªØµØ¯ Ø¨Ù‡Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø­Ø¶ÙˆØ±Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø­Ø³Ù† ØµÙ„Ø§ØªÙ‡ Ø¨Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‚Ø±Ø§Ø¦ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ±ÙƒÙˆØ¹Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ø¬ÙˆØ¯Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÙˆØ¯Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù‡ Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø£Ø¬Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ…ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙ†Ù‚Øµ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø¬ÙˆØ±Ù‡Ù… Ø´Ø¦. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø£Ù… Ù‚ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø¨Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù‡Ù… Ø«Ù… Ù„Ù… ÙŠØªÙ… Ø¨Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„ØµÙ„Ø§Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ­Ø³Ù† ÙÙŠ Ø®Ø´ÙˆØ¹Ù‡ ÙˆØ±ÙƒÙˆØ¹Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ø¬ÙˆØ¯Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‚Ø±Ø§Ø¡ØªÙ‡ Ø±Ø¯Øª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ØµÙ„Ø§ØªÙ‡ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ØªØ¬Ø§ÙˆØ² ØªØ±Ù‚ÙˆØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ù…Ù†Ø²Ù„ØªÙ‡ ÙƒÙ…Ù†Ø²Ù„Ø© Ø¥Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø¬Ø§Ø¦Ø± Ù…Ø¹ØªØ¯ØŒ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØµÙ„Ø­ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø¹ÙŠØ©ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠÙ‚Ù… ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø¨Ø­Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù… ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø¨Ø£Ù…Ø±. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ù…Ø´Ù‰ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø°ÙŠ Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø¨Ø© Ø¨Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ø§Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ù„ÙŠØµÙ„ Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù‡ØŒ Ø£Ø¹Ø·Ø§Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø£Ø¬Ø± Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ù‡ Ø´Ù‡ÙŠØ¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¨ÙƒÙ„ Ø®Ø·ÙˆØ© Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù„Ù Ø­Ø³Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ…Ø­Ù‰ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù„Ù Ø³ÙŠØ¦Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ±ÙØ¹ Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø±Ø¬Ø§Øª Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ£Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ø© Ø³Ù†Ø© ØµØ§Ø¨Ø±Ø§ Ù…Ø­ØªØ³Ø¨Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ÙƒÙÙ‰ Ø¶Ø±ÙŠØ±Ø§ Ø­Ø§Ø¬Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø­ÙˆØ§Ø¦Ø¬ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø´Ù‰ Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¶ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ù‡ Ø­Ø§Ø¬Ø©ØŒ Ø£Ø¹Ø·Ø§Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ø¡Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†ÙØ§Ù‚ ÙˆØ¨Ø±Ø§Ø¡Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¶Ù‰ Ù„Ù‡ Ø³Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ† Ø­Ø§Ø¬Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø­ÙˆØ§Ø¦Ø¬ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ ÙŠØ®ÙˆØ¶ ÙÙŠ Ø±Ø­Ù…Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠØ±Ø¬Ø¹. ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ù…Ø±Ø¶ ÙŠÙˆÙ…Ø§ ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙ„Ø© ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ´Ùƒ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹ÙˆØ§Ø¯Ù‡ØŒ Ø¨Ø¹Ø«Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ù…Ø¹ Ø®Ù„ÙŠÙ„Ù‡ Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ø®Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù† Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø§Ù„ØµØ±Ø§Ø· ÙƒØ§Ù„Ø¨Ø±Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø¹ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø³Ø¹Ù‰ Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¶ ÙÙŠ Ø­Ø§Ø¬Ø© Ù‚Ø¶Ø§Ù‡Ø§ Ø£Ùˆ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙ‚Ø¶Ù‡Ø§ØŒ Ø®Ø±Ø¬ Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù†ÙˆØ¨Ù‡ ÙƒÙŠÙˆÙ… ÙˆÙ„Ø¯ØªÙ‡ Ø£Ù…Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù†ØµØ§Ø±: Ø¨Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø£Ù†Øª ÙˆØ£Ù…ÙŠ ÙŠØ§ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¶ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ø¹Ø¸Ù… Ø£Ø¬Ø±Ø§ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø³Ø¹Ù‰ ÙÙŠ Ø­Ø§Ø¬Ø© Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ÙØ±Ø¬ Ø¹Ù† Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù† ÙƒØ±Ø¨Ø© Ù…Ù† ÙƒØ±Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ØŒ ÙØ±Ø¬ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ Ø§Ø«Ù†ØªÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ³Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ† ÙƒØ±Ø¨Ø© Ù…Ù† ÙƒØ±Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ø«Ù†ØªÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ³Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ† ÙƒØ±Ø¨Ø© Ù…Ù† ÙƒØ±Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ù‡ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…ØºØµ. Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙˆÙ…Ù† ÙŠØ¨Ø·Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø°ÙŠ Ø­Ù‚ Ø­Ù‚Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø¯Ø§Ø¡ Ø­Ù‚Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙƒÙ„ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø®Ø·ÙŠØ¦Ø© Ø¹Ø´Ø§Ø±ØŒ Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø¹Ù„Ù‚ Ø³ÙˆØ·Ø§ Ø¨ÙŠÙ† ÙŠØ¯ÙŠ Ø³Ù„Ø·Ø§Ù† Ø¬Ø§Ø¦Ø±ØŒ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙˆØ· ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ø«Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø± Ø·ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø³Ø¨Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø°Ø±Ø§Ø¹Ø§ØŒ ÙŠØ³Ù„Ø· Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙÙŠ Ù†Ø§Ø± Ø¬Ù‡Ù†Ù… ÙˆØ¨Ø¦Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ù…ØµÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø§ØµØ·Ù†Ø¹ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø®ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ø¹Ø±ÙˆÙØ§ ÙØ£Ù…ØªÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ Ø£Ø­Ø¨Ø· Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù…Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ«Ø¨Øª ÙˆØ²Ø±Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ´ÙƒØ± Ù„Ù‡ Ø³Ø¹ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: Ø­Ø±Ù…Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†Ø§Ù† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¨Ø®ÙŠÙ„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù‚ØªØ§ØªØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù…Ø§Ù…. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØªØµØ¯Ù‚ Ø¨ØµØ¯Ù‚Ø©ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù‡ Ø¨ÙˆØ²Ù† ÙƒÙ„ Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø¬Ø¨Ù„ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ù†Ø¹ÙŠÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ù…Ø´Ù‰ Ø¨ØµØ¯Ù‚Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø­ØªØ§Ø¬ØŒ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù„Ù‡ ÙƒØ£Ø¬Ø± ØµØ§Ø­Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ù† ØºÙŠØ± Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†Ù‚Øµ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø¬Ø±Ù‡ Ø´Ø¦ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…ÙŠØª ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ³Ø¨Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù„Ù Ù…Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙˆØºÙØ± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø§ ØªÙ‚Ø¯Ù… Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù†Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† Ø£Ù‚Ø§Ù… Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠØ¯ÙÙ† ÙˆÙŠØ­Ø«ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„ØªØ±Ø§Ø¨ØŒ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨ÙƒÙ„ Ù‚Ø¯Ù… Ù†Ù‚Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ù‚ÙŠØ±Ø§Ø· Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¬Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ±Ø§Ø· Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø¬Ø¨Ù„ Ø£Ø­Ø¯. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø°Ø±ÙØª Ø¹ÙŠÙ†Ø§Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø®Ø´ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨ÙƒÙ„ Ù‚Ø·Ø±Øª Ù‚Ø·Ø±Øª Ù…Ù† Ø¯Ù…ÙˆØ¹Ù‡ Ù‚ØµØ± ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø© Ù…ÙƒÙ„Ù„ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø± ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬ÙˆÙ‡Ø±ØŒ ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ Ø¹ÙŠÙ† Ø±Ø£Øª ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø£Ø°Ù† Ø³Ù…Ø¹ØªØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø®Ø·Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‚Ù„Ø¨ Ø¨Ø´Ø±ØŒ Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ù…Ø´Ù‰ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø³Ø¬Ø¯ ÙŠØ·Ù„Ø¨ ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù…Ø§Ø¹Ø©ØŒ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨ÙƒÙ„ Ø®Ø·ÙˆØ© Ø³Ø¨Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù„Ù Ø­Ø³Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ±ÙØ¹ Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø±Ø¬Ø§Øª Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ù…Ø§Øª ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙˆÙƒÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø³Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ† Ø£Ù„Ù Ù…Ù„Ùƒ ÙŠØ¹ÙˆØ¯ÙˆÙ†Ù‡ (1) ÙÙŠ Ù‚Ø¨Ø±Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ¤Ù†Ø³ÙˆÙ†Ù‡ ÙÙŠ ÙˆØ­Ø¯ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ³ØªØºÙØ±ÙˆÙ† Ù„Ù‡ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠØ¨Ø¹Ø«. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø£Ø°Ù† Ù…Ø­ØªØ³Ø¨Ø§ØŒ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØ¬Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ØŒ Ø£Ø¹Ø·Ø§Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø«ÙˆØ§Ø¨ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ† Ø£Ù„Ù Ø´Ù‡ÙŠØ¯ ÙˆØ£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ† Ø£Ù„Ù ØµØ¯ÙŠÙ‚ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ¯Ø®Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø´ÙØ§Ø¹ØªÙ‡ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù„Ù Ù…Ø³Ø¦ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù…ØªÙŠ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø©ØŒ Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ø°Ù† Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ø´Ù‡Ø¯ Ø£Ù† Ù„Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ØªØ³Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù„Ù Ù…Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙˆØ§Ø³ØªØºÙØ±ÙˆØ§ Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø¸Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø±Ø´ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠÙØ±Øº Ù…Ù† Ø­Ø³Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ø§Ø¦Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙƒØªØ¨ Ø«ÙˆØ§Ø¨ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡: Ø£Ø´Ù‡Ø¯ Ø£Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯Ø§ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù„Ù Ù…Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø­Ø§ÙØ¸ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ Ø§Ù„Ø§ÙˆÙ„ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØªÙƒØ¨ÙŠØ±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø§ÙˆÙ„Ù‰ØŒ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¤Ø°ÙŠ Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…Ø§ØŒ Ø£Ø¹Ø·Ø§Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¬Ø± Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø·Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ø°Ù†ÙˆÙ† ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ø©. Ø£Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØªÙˆÙ„Ù‰ Ø¹Ø±Ø§ÙØ© Ù‚ÙˆÙ…ØŒ Ø­Ø¨Ø³Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø´ÙÙŠØ± Ø¬Ù‡Ù†Ù…ØŒ Ø¨ÙƒÙ„ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø£Ù„Ù Ø³Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø´Ø± ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© ÙˆÙŠØ¯Ø§Ù‡ Ù…ØºÙ„ÙˆÙ„ØªØ§Ù† Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù†Ù‚Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† Ù‚Ø§Ù… ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø¨Ø£Ù…Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ø·Ù„Ù‚Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø¸Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ù‡ÙˆÙ‰ Ø¨Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ù†Ø§Ø± Ø¬Ù‡Ù†Ù… ÙˆØ¨Ø¦Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ù…ØµÙŠØ±. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù„Ø§ ØªØ­Ù‚Ø±ÙˆØ§ Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† ØµØºØ± ÙÙŠ Ø£Ø¹ÙŠÙ†ÙƒÙ…ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØªØ³ØªÙƒØ«Ø±ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ«Ø± ÙÙŠ Ø£Ø¹ÙŠÙ†ÙƒÙ…ØŒ ÙØ§Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙƒØ¨ÙŠØ± Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø³ØªØºÙØ§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØµØºÙŠØ± Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø§ØµØ±Ø§Ø±. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø²ÙƒØ±ÙŠØ§ Ø§Ù„ØºÙ„Ø§Ø¨ÙŠØŒ Ø³Ø£Ù„Øª Ø¹Ù† Ø·ÙˆÙ„ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø«Ø± Ø´Ø¹ÙŠØ¨Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø²Ù†ÙŠØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„ÙŠ: ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ø¨Ø§ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø³Ø£Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³ÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ù† Ø²ÙŠØ¯ Ø¹Ù† Ø·ÙˆÙ„ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¯ÙŠØ«ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³ÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…)ØŒ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø¬Ù…Ø¹ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¯ÙŠØ« Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø¥Ù…Ù„Ø§Ø¡ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙˆØ®Ø· Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) (2).", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/29/1/66/1", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 66, "thaqalaynSanad": "Abu Ja`far Muhammad b. `Ali b. al-Husayn b. Musa b. Babuwayh al-Qummi (ra) narrated to us. He said: Hamza b. Muhammad b. Ahmad b. Ja`far b. Muhammad b. Zayd b. `Ali b. al-Husayn b. `Ali b. Abi Talib (as). He said: Abu `Abdillah `Abd al-`Aziz b. Muhammad b. `Isa al-Bahri narrated to me. He said: Abu `Abdillah Muhammad b. Zakariyya al-Jawhari al-Ghilabi al-Basri narrated to us. He said: Shu`ayb b. Waqid narrated to us. He said: Al-Husayn b. Yazid narrated to us from al-Sadiq Ja`far b. Muhammad from his father from his forefathers from Amir al-Mu'minin `Ali b. Abi Talib (as).\r\nHe said: ", "thaqalaynMatn": "The Messenger of Allah (s) prohibited eating whilst in a state of sexual impurity. He said: â€œIt bequeaths poverty.â€ He prohibited cutting nails with teeth, using the toothstick in the bathroom, and blowing the nose in the mosques. He prohibited eating from the leftovers of mice. He said: â€œDo not go to the mosque without praying [at least] two units.â€ He prohibited urination under a fruit tree and at the side of a road. He prohibited eating with the left [hand] and eating while lying down. He prohibited plastering graveyards and praying in them. He said: â€œWhen one of you bathes in an expanse of earth, then be mindful of your private. None of you should drink water from the buttonhole of a vessel, for it is a gathering place for dirt.â€ He prohibited anyone from urinating in still water, for it causes a loss in intellect. He prohibited walking with one sandal and putting on sandals while standing. He prohibited urinating while the private is facing the Sun or the Moon. He said: â€œWhen you are defecating, then avoid [the direction of] the qibla.â€ He prohibited screaming during calamities. He prohibited wailing and listening to wailing. He prohibited women from following funeral processions. He prohibited erasing anything from the Book of Allah with saliva or writing in it. He prohibited lying purposely about dreams. He said: â€œAllah will order him to tie a knot in a grain of barley.â€ He prohibited creating images. He said: â€œWhoever creates an image, Allah will order him to blow [life] into it on the Day of Resurrection; and he would not be able to blow [life] into it.â€ He prohibited burning a part of an animal [while alive]. He prohibited insulting the rooster. He said: â€œIt calls to prayer.â€ He prohibited interfering in a deal of his Muslim brother [selling merchandise to a buyer]. He prohibited speaking too much during intercourse. He said: â€œIt causes muteness in the child.â€ He said: â€œDo not sleep while garbage is in your house. Take it out during the day, for it is a sitting place for Satan.â€ He said: â€œDo not sleep while the residue of meat is on your hand, for if you do that, you will be afflicted with mild insanity from Satan, and you will have no one to blame but yourself.â€ He prohibited cleaning oneself with dung. He prohibited women from leaving their house without the permission of their husband; for if she leaves, she will be cursed by every angel in heaven and everything that passes it from the Jinn and the humans until she returns to her house.â€ He prohibited a woman from adorning herself for other than her husband, for if she does that, then it will be a right upon Allah to burn her in the Fire. He prohibited women from saying more than five unnecessary words to those other than their husbands and their relatives. He prohibited women from seeing one another without a robe. He prohibited women from speaking about that which is confidential with regards to their husbands. He prohibited men from having intercourse with their women while facing the qibla or on a paved road, for whoever does that, then the curse of Allah, the angels, and all the people will be on him. He prohibited men from telling men: â€œMarry me to your sister so that I may marry you to my sister.â€ He prohibited visiting fortune-tellers, and he said: â€œWhoever meets him and believes in him has dissociated from what Allah has revealed to Muhammad (s).â€ He prohibited playing with dice, chess, drums, tambourines, and ouds. He prohibited backbiting and listening to it. He prohibited gossiping and listening to it. He said: â€œA backbiter, meaning a gossiper, will not enter Paradise.â€ He prohibited responding to an invitation to food from the depraved people (fasiqin). He prohibited bearing false oaths. He said: â€œIt leads to a loss of houses.â€ He said: â€œWhoever swears a false oath intending to cut a Muslim person away from his wealth will meet Allah while He is angry with him, unless he repents and recants.â€ He prohibited sitting at tablespreads where wine is drunk. He prohibited men from bringing their women to bathhouses. He said: â€œNone of you should enter a bathhouse without an izar (a garment that covers the lower part of one's body).â€ He prohibited conversations that call toward other than Allah. He prohibited slapping the face. He prohibited drinking from a gold or silver vessel. He prohibited men from wearing silk; as for women, then there is no problem. He prohibited selling fruits before they bloom -- meaning, [before they turn] yellow or red. He prohibited selling dates before they ripen and grapes and that which is similar. He prohibited selling dice and chess. He said: â€œWhoever does that is like one who has eaten pork.â€ He prohibited selling wine, buying wine, and providing wine.
