ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†: Ù…Ø§ ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ØŒ ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ø¨Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù†ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ØŒ ÙˆÙ„ÙƒÙ†ÙŠ Ø£Ù‚ÙˆÙ„: Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹ØªØ±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ù‡Ø±Ø©. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†: ÙˆÙƒÙŠÙ Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¹ØªØ±Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø©ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ùˆ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø© Ù„ÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ø¨Ø£Ø¬Ù…Ø¹Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø©ØŒ Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰: (ÙÙ…Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø¸Ø§Ù„Ù… Ù„Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù‚ØªØµØ¯ ÙˆÙ…Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ù‚ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙŠØ±Ø§Øª Ø¨Ø¥Ø°Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ¨ÙŠØ±) (1) Ø«Ù… Ø¬Ù…Ø¹Ù‡Ù… ÙƒÙ„Ù‡Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø© ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: (Ø¬Ù†Ø§Øª Ø¹Ø¯Ù† ÙŠØ¯Ø®Ù„ÙˆÙ†Ù‡Ø§ ÙŠØ­Ù„ÙˆÙ† ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø³Ø§ÙˆØ± Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù‡Ø¨) (2) ÙØµØ§Ø±Øª Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ±Ø§Ø«Ø© Ù„Ù„Ø¹ØªØ±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ù‡Ø±Ø© Ù„Ø§ Ù„ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡Ù…. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†: Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹ØªØ±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ù‡Ø±Ø©ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØµÙÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„ÙŠØ°Ù‡Ø¨ Ø¹Ù†ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ø³ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¨ÙŠØª ÙˆÙŠØ·Ù‡Ø±ÙƒÙ… ØªØ·Ù‡ÙŠØ±Ø§) (3)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ø¥Ù†ÙŠ Ù…Ø®Ù„Ù ÙÙŠÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø«Ù‚Ù„ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¹ØªØ±ØªÙŠ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙŠØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù†Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù† ÙŠÙØªØ±Ù‚Ø§ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠØ±Ø¯Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙˆØ¶ØŒ ÙØ§Ù†Ø¸Ø±ÙˆØ§ ÙƒÙŠÙ ØªØ®Ù„ÙÙˆÙ†ÙŠ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ØŒ Ø£ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ù„Ø§ ØªØ¹Ù„Ù…ÙˆÙ‡Ù… ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ù…Ù†ÙƒÙ…. Ù‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡: Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù†Ø§ - ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ø¨Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† - Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹ØªØ±Ø©ØŒ Ø£Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù„ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ ØºÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù„ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù„. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡: ÙÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙŠØ¤Ø«Ø± Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø§Ù…ØªÙŠ Ø¢Ù„ÙŠ. ÙˆÙ‡Ø¤Ù„Ø§Ø¡ Ø£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨Ù‡ ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø¨Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ØªÙØ§Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ…ÙƒÙ† Ø¯ÙØ¹Ù‡: Ø¢Ù„ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù…ØªÙ‡. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±ÙˆÙ†ÙŠ Ù‡Ù„ ØªØ­Ø±Ù… Ø§Ù„ØµØ¯Ù‚Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù„ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: Ù†Ø¹Ù…. Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØªØ­Ø±Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø©ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: Ù„Ø§. Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ÙØ±Ù‚ Ù…Ø§ Ø¨ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ­ÙƒÙ… Ø£ÙŠÙ† ÙŠØ°Ù‡Ø¨ Ø¨ÙƒÙ…ØŒ Ø£Ø¶Ø±Ø¨ØªÙ… Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙƒØ± ØµÙØ­Ø§ØŒ Ø£Ù… Ø£Ù†ØªÙ… Ù‚ÙˆÙ… Ù…Ø³Ø±ÙÙˆÙ†! Ø£Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØªÙ… Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹Øª Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§Ø±Ø«Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø·Ù‡Ø§Ø±Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…ØµØ·ÙÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‡ØªØ¯ÙŠÙ† Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø³Ø§Ø¦Ø±Ù‡Ù…ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø£ÙŠÙ† ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ø¨Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù†ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆÙ„Ù‚Ø¯ Ø£Ø±Ø³Ù„Ù†Ø§ Ù†ÙˆØ­Ø§ ÙˆØ¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… ÙˆØ¬Ø¹Ù„Ù†Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø°Ø±ÙŠØªÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙˆØ© ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ ÙÙ…Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù‡ØªØ¯ ÙˆÙƒØ«ÙŠØ± Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù… ÙØ§Ø³Ù‚ÙˆÙ†) (4) ÙØµØ§Ø±Øª ÙˆØ§Ø±Ø«Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙˆØ© ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ù„Ù„Ù…Ù‡ØªØ¯ÙŠÙ† Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ø³Ù‚ÙŠÙ†ØŒ Ø£Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØªÙ… Ø£Ù† Ù†ÙˆØ­Ø§ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) Ø­ÙŠÙ† Ø³Ø£Ù„ Ø±Ø¨Ù‡: (ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø±Ø¨ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ø¨Ù†ÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„ÙŠ ÙˆØ¥Ù† ÙˆØ¹Ø¯Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ ÙˆØ£Ù†Øª Ø£Ø­ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø§ÙƒÙ…ÙŠÙ†) (1) ÙˆØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙˆØ¹Ø¯Ù‡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†Ø¬ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ£Ù‡Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ Ø±Ø¨Ù‡: (ÙŠØ§ Ù†ÙˆØ­ Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„Ùƒ Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ Ø¹Ù…Ù„ ØºÙŠØ± ØµØ§Ù„Ø­ ÙÙ„Ø§ ØªØ³Ø¦Ù„Ù† Ù…Ø§ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø¥Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø¹Ø¸Ùƒ Ø£Ù† ØªÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ù‡Ù„ÙŠÙ†) (2). ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†: Ù‡Ù„ ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹ØªØ±Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø³Ø§Ø¦Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ø§Ù† ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¹ØªØ±Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø³Ø§Ø¦Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø­ÙƒÙ… ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†: Ø£ÙŠÙ† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ù† ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): ÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§ØµØ·ÙÙ‰ Ø¢Ø¯Ù… ÙˆÙ†ÙˆØ­Ø§ ÙˆØ¢Ù„ Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… ÙˆØ¢Ù„ Ø¹Ù…Ø±Ø§Ù† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ† * Ø°Ø±ÙŠØ© Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶) (3)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: ÙÙŠ Ù…ÙˆØ¶Ø¹ Ø¢Ø®Ø±: (Ø£Ù… ÙŠØ­Ø³Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ Ø£ØªØ§Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù† ÙØ¶Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¢ØªÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø¢Ù„ Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø© ÙˆØ¡Ø§ØªÙŠÙ†Ø§Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù„ÙƒØ§ Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ…Ø§) (4)ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø±Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø®Ø§Ø·Ø¨Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø¥Ø«Ø± Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø³Ø§Ø¦Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: (ÙŠØ§ Ø£ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¢Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ø·ÙŠØ¹ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ£Ø·ÙŠØ¹ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ ÙˆØ£ÙˆÙ„ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø± Ù…Ù†ÙƒÙ…) (5) ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù‚Ø±Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø© ÙˆØ­Ø³Ø¯ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡: (Ø£Ù… ÙŠØ­Ø³Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ Ø£ØªØ§Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù† ÙØ¶Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¢ØªÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø¢Ù„ Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø© ÙˆØ¡Ø§ØªÙŠÙ†Ø§Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù„ÙƒØ§ Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ…Ø§) ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ø¹Ø© Ù„Ù„Ù…ØµØ·ÙÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ù‡Ø±ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙØ§Ù„Ù…Ù„Ùƒ Ù‡Ø§ Ù‡Ù†Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ø¹Ø© Ù„Ù‡Ù…. Ù‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡: ÙØ£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù†Ø§ Ù‡Ù„ ÙØ³Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø§ØµØ·ÙØ§Ø¡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): ÙØ³Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø§ØµØ·ÙØ§Ø¡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ø§Ù‡Ø± Ø³ÙˆÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ø·Ù† ÙÙŠ Ø§Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ø´Ø± Ù…ÙˆØ¶Ø¹Ø§ ÙˆÙ…ÙˆØ·Ù†Ø§ØŒ ÙØ£ÙˆÙ„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆØ£Ù†Ø°Ø± Ø¹Ø´ÙŠØ±ØªÙƒ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù‚Ø±Ø¨ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ±Ù‡Ø·Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø®Ù„ØµÙŠÙ†) (6) Ù‡ÙƒØ°Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø¡Ø© Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† ÙƒØ¹Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡ÙŠ Ø«Ø§Ø¨ØªØ© ÙÙŠ Ù…ØµØ­Ù Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø³Ø¹ÙˆØ¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ù…Ù†Ø²Ù„Ø© Ø±ÙÙŠØ¹Ø© ÙˆÙØ¶Ù„ Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ… ÙˆØ´Ø±Ù Ø¹Ø§Ù„ Ø­ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù„ØŒ ÙØ°ÙƒØ±Ù‡ Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡)ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø©. ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø§ØµØ·ÙØ§Ø¡ØŒ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„ÙŠØ°Ù‡Ø¨ Ø¹Ù†ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ø³ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¨ÙŠØª ÙˆÙŠØ·Ù‡Ø±ÙƒÙ… ØªØ·Ù‡ÙŠØ±Ø§) ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬Ù‡Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ø¹Ø§Ù†Ø¯ Ø£ØµÙ„Ø§ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù†Ù‡ ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø·Ù‡Ø§Ø±Ø© ØªÙ†ØªØ¸Ø±ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ©. ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø©: ÙØ­ÙŠÙ† Ù…ÙŠØ² Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ù‡Ø±ÙŠÙ† Ù…Ù† Ø®Ù„Ù‚Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ£Ù…Ø± Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¨Ø§Ù‡Ù„Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨ØªÙ‡Ø§Ù„ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: Ù‚Ù„ ÙŠØ§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ (ØªØ¹Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ù†Ø¯Ø¹ Ø£Ø¨Ù†Ø§Ø¡Ù†Ø§ ÙˆØ£Ø¨Ù†Ø§Ø¡ÙƒÙ… ÙˆÙ†Ø³Ø§Ø¡Ù†Ø§ ÙˆÙ†Ø³Ø§Ø¡ÙƒÙ… ÙˆØ£Ù†ÙØ³Ù†Ø§ ÙˆØ£Ù†ÙØ³ÙƒÙ… Ø«Ù… Ù†Ø¨ØªÙ‡Ù„ ÙÙ†Ø¬Ø¹Ù„ Ù„Ø¹Ù†Øª Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ§Ø°Ø¨ÙŠÙ†) (1) ÙØ£Ø¨Ø±Ø² Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø¹Ù„ÙŠØ§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­Ø³ÙŠÙ† ÙˆÙØ§Ø·Ù…Ø© (ØµÙ„ÙˆØ§Øª Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ù„Ø§Ù…Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…) ÙˆÙ‚Ø±Ù† Ø£Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ù„ ØªØ¯Ø±ÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆØ£Ù†ÙØ³Ù†Ø§ ÙˆØ£Ù†ÙØ³ÙƒÙ…)ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡: Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø¨Ù‡ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡Ù…. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): ØºÙ„Ø·ØªÙ…ØŒ Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…)ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø­ÙŠÙ† Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù„ÙŠÙ†ØªÙ‡ÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ù†Ùˆ ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ¹Ø© Ø£Ùˆ Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ø¹Ø«Ù† Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø±Ø¬Ù„Ø§ ÙƒÙ†ÙØ³ÙŠØŒ ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…)ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø®ØµÙˆØµÙŠØ© Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØªÙ‚Ø¯Ù…Ù‡ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙØ¶Ù„ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ„Ø­Ù‚Ù‡ ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø¨Ø´Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ´Ø±Ù Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ³Ø¨Ù‚Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø£Ù† Ø¬Ø¹Ù„ Ù†ÙØ³ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ ÙƒÙ†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø©. ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø§Ø¨Ø¹Ø©: ÙØ¥Ø®Ø±Ø§Ø¬Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ù…Ù† Ù…Ø³Ø¬Ø¯Ù‡ Ù…Ø§ Ø®Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¹ØªØ±Ø© Ø­ØªÙ‰ ØªÙƒÙ„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ ÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØªÙƒÙ„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ø³ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ØªØ±ÙƒØª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠØ§ ÙˆØ£Ø®Ø±Ø¬ØªÙ†Ø§! ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ù†Ø§ ØªØ±ÙƒØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ£Ø®Ø±Ø¬ØªÙƒÙ…ØŒ ÙˆÙ„ÙƒÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ±ÙƒÙ‡ ÙˆØ£Ø®Ø±Ø¬ÙƒÙ…. ÙˆÙÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ØªØ¨ÙŠØ§Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ù„Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ø£Ù†Øª Ù…Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ù…Ù†Ø²Ù„Ø© Ù‡Ø§Ø±ÙˆÙ† Ù…Ù† Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰. Ù‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡: ÙØ£ÙŠÙ† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù†ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) Ø£Ùˆ Ø¬Ø¯ÙƒÙ… ÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ù‚Ø±Ø¤Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒÙ…ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: Ù‡Ø§Øª. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆØ£ÙˆØ­ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ ÙˆØ£Ø®ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ù† ØªØ¨ÙˆØ¡Ø§ Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ…ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø¨Ù…ØµØ± Ø¨ÙŠÙˆØªØ§ ÙˆØ§Ø¬Ø¹Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø¨ÙŠÙˆØªÙƒÙ… Ù‚Ø¨Ù„Ø©) (1) ÙÙÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ù…Ù†Ø²Ù„Ø© Ù‡Ø§Ø±ÙˆÙ† Ù…Ù† Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ØŒ ÙˆÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø£ÙŠØ¶Ø§ Ù…Ù†Ø²Ù„Ø© Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) Ù…Ù† Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡)ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø¹ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø¯Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø¸Ø§Ù‡Ø± ÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡)ØŒ Ø­ÙŠÙ† Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ù„Ø§ Ø¥Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø¬Ø¯ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ­Ù„ Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø¨ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡: ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ø¨Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù†ØŒ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø±Ø­ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ù†ØŒ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙˆØ¬Ø¯ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒÙ… Ù…Ø¹Ø´Ø± Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØª Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡). ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙˆÙ…Ù† ÙŠÙ†ÙƒØ± Ù„Ù†Ø§ Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŸ ÙˆØ±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„: Ø£Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø¯ÙŠÙ†Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø© ÙˆØ¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ø§Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ…Ù† Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¯ÙŠÙ†Ø© ÙÙ„ÙŠØ£ØªÙ‡Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ø§Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ Ø£ÙˆØ¶Ø­Ù†Ø§ ÙˆØ´Ø±Ø­Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´Ø±Ù ÙˆØ§Ù„ØªÙ‚Ø¯Ù…Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§ØµØ·ÙØ§Ø¡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø·Ù‡Ø§Ø±Ø© Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ†ÙƒØ±Ù‡ Ù…Ø¹Ø§Ù†Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø§Ø¨Ø¹Ø©. ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø§Ù…Ø³Ø© Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆØ¢Øª Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰ Ø­Ù‚Ù‡) (2) Ø®ØµÙˆØµÙŠØ© Ø®ØµÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø²ÙŠØ² Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø¨Ø§Ø± Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ§ØµØ·ÙØ§Ù‡Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ø²Ù„Øª Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø§Ø¯Ø¹ÙˆØ§ Ù„ÙŠ ÙØ§Ø·Ù…Ø©. ÙØ¯Ø¹ÙŠØª Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ ÙØ§Ø·Ù…Ø© Ù‚Ø§Ù„Øª: Ù„Ø¨ÙŠÙƒ ÙŠØ§ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ ÙØ¯ÙƒØŒ Ù‡ÙŠ Ù…Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙˆØ¬Ù Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¨Ø®ÙŠÙ„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø±ÙƒØ§Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡ÙŠ Ù„ÙŠ Ø®Ø§ØµØ© Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„ØªÙ‡Ø§ Ù„Ùƒ Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ®Ø°ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆÙ„ÙˆÙ„Ø¯ÙƒØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø§Ù…Ø³Ø©. ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø¯Ø³Ø©: Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¬Ù„ Ø¬Ù„Ø§Ù„Ù‡: (Ù‚Ù„ Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ø³Ø¦Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ø¬Ø±Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰) (3) ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø®ØµÙˆØµÙŠØ© Ù„Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ®ØµÙˆØµÙŠØ© Ù„Ù„Ø¢Ù„ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø­ÙƒÙ‰ ÙÙŠ Ø°ÙƒØ± Ù†ÙˆØ­ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡: (ÙŠØ§ Ù‚ÙˆÙ… Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ø³Ø¦Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ø§Ù„Ø§ Ø¥Ù† Ø£Ø¬Ø±ÙŠ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ù†Ø§ Ø¨Ø·Ø§Ø±Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¡Ø§Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ø¥Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù„Ø§Ù‚ÙˆØ§ Ø±Ø¨Ù‡Ù… ÙˆÙ„ÙƒÙ†ÙŠ Ø£Ø±Ø§ÙƒÙ… Ù‚ÙˆÙ…Ø§ ØªØ¬Ù‡Ù„ÙˆÙ†) (4) ÙˆØ­ÙƒÙ‰ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¹Ù† Ù‡ÙˆØ¯ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: (Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ø³Ø¦Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ø¬Ø±Ø§ Ø¥Ù† Ø£Ø¬Ø±ÙŠ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙØ·Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§ ØªØ¹Ù‚Ù„ÙˆÙ†) (1)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): (Ù‚Ù„) ÙŠØ§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ (Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ø³Ø¦Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ø¬Ø±Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰) ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠÙØ±Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…ÙˆØ¯ØªÙ‡Ù… Ø¥Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ±ØªØ¯ÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø£Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ±Ø¬Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¶Ù„Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ø¯Ø§. ÙˆØ£Ø®Ø±Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ø¯Ø§ Ù„Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ØŒ ÙÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ Ø¹Ø¯ÙˆØ§ Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ³Ù„Ù… Ù‚Ù„Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ£Ø­Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø£Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙÙŠ Ù‚Ù„Ø¨ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ø´Ø¦ØŒ ÙÙØ±Ø¶ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø© Ø°ÙˆÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰ØŒ ÙÙ…Ù† Ø£Ø®Ø° Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØ£Ø­Ø¨ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙˆØ£Ø­Ø¨ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ØŒ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ³ØªØ·Ø¹ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¨ØºØ¶Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† ØªØ±ÙƒÙ‡Ø§ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ£Ø®Ø° Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØ£Ø¨ØºØ¶ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¨ØºØ¶Ù‡ Ù„Ø§Ù†Ù‡ Ù‚Ø¯ ØªØ±Ùƒ ÙØ±ÙŠØ¶Ø© Ù…Ù† ÙØ±Ø§Ø¦Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ£ÙŠ ÙØ¶ÙŠÙ„Ø© ÙˆØ£ÙŠ Ø´Ø±Ù ÙŠØªÙ‚Ø¯Ù… Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠØ¯Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ‡ØŸ ÙØ£Ù†Ø²Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): (Ù‚Ù„ Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ø³Ø¦Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ø¬Ø±Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰) ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù… Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙÙŠ Ø£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ­Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ£Ø«Ù†Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ØŒ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù‚Ø¯ ÙØ±Ø¶ Ù„ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒÙ… ÙØ±Ø¶Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ù„ Ø£Ù†ØªÙ… Ù…Ø¤Ø¯ÙˆÙ‡ØŸ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ¬Ø¨Ù‡ Ø£Ø­Ø¯. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ØŒ Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ø¨Ø°Ù‡Ø¨ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙØ¶Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ø£ÙƒÙˆÙ„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ø´Ø±ÙˆØ¨. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: Ù‡Ø§Øª Ø¥Ø°Ù†. ÙØªÙ„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ©ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ù…Ø§ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ÙÙ†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ…Ø§ ÙˆÙÙ‰ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ø£ÙƒØ«Ø±Ù‡Ù…. ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹Ø« Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£ÙˆØ­Ù‰ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ³Ø£Ù„ Ù‚ÙˆÙ…Ù‡ Ø£Ø¬Ø±Ø§ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙŠÙˆÙÙŠ Ø£Ø¬Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ (2) (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙØ±Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø© Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø¨ØªÙ‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù…ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø±Ù‡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¬Ø¹Ù„ Ø£Ø¬Ø±Ù‡ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ù„ÙŠÙˆØ¯ÙˆÙ‡ ÙÙŠ Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø¨ØªÙ‡ Ø¨Ù…Ø¹Ø±ÙØ© ÙØ¶Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø£ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù„Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø© Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ØªÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‚Ø¯Ø± Ù…Ø¹Ø±ÙØ© Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„. ÙÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ø£ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø«Ù‚Ù„ Ù„Ø«Ù‚Ù„ (3) ÙˆØ¬ÙˆØ¨ Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ø¹Ø©ØŒ ÙØªÙ…Ø³Ùƒ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù‚ÙˆÙ… Ø£Ø®Ø° Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…ÙŠØ«Ø§Ù‚Ù‡Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙØ§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ø§Ù†Ø¯ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ù‚Ø§Ù‚ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†ÙØ§Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù„Ø­Ø¯ÙˆØ§ ÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙØµØ±ÙÙˆÙ‡ Ø¹Ù† Ø­Ø¯Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø­Ø¯Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø¨Ø© Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø±Ø¨ ÙƒÙ„Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØ£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¯Ø¹ÙˆØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠÙ† ÙƒØ§Ù†ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø© Ù‡ÙŠ Ù„Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø¨Ø©ØŒ ÙØ£Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø£ÙˆÙ„Ø§Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø©ØŒ ÙƒÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Øª Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø¨Ø© ÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‚Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ø§. ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ù†ØµÙÙˆØ§ Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙÙŠ Ø­ÙŠØ·ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ±Ø£ÙØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù…ØªÙ‡ØŒ Ù…Ù…Ø§ ØªØ¹Ø¬Ø² Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù† Ø¹Ù† ÙˆØµÙ Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙƒØ± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø£Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙˆØ¯ÙˆÙ‡ ÙÙŠ Ø°Ø±ÙŠØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬Ø¹Ù„ÙˆÙ‡Ù… Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù… ÙƒÙ…Ù†Ø²Ù„Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¹ÙŠÙ† Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø£Ø³ Ø­ÙØ¸Ø§ Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙˆØ­Ø¨Ø§ Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ (1)ØŒ ÙÙƒÙŠÙ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† ÙŠÙ†Ø·Ù‚ Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆÙŠØ¯Ø¹Ùˆ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŸ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ø± Ø«Ø§Ø¨ØªØ© Ø¨Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† ÙØ±Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…ÙˆØ¯ØªÙ‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙˆØ¹Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø²Ø§Ø¡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ØŒ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø§ ÙˆÙÙ‰ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø¨Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø© Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø®Ù„ØµØ§ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ø³ØªÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø©ØŒ Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ©: (ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¡Ø§Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§ ÙˆØ¹Ù…Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„ØµØ§Ù„Ø­Ø§Øª ÙÙŠ Ø±ÙˆØ¶Ø§Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø§Øª Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø±Ø¨Ù‡Ù… Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ¨ÙŠØ± * Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø°Ù‰ ÙŠØ¨Ø´Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ø¯Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¡Ø§Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§ ÙˆØ¹Ù…Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„ØµØ§Ù„Ø­Ø§Øª Ù‚Ù„ Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ø³Ø¦Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ø¬Ø±Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰) (2) Ù…ÙØ³Ø±Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ø¨ÙŠÙ†Ø§. Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø¨ÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¬Ø¯ÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¢Ø¨Ø§Ø¦Ù‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³ÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…)ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø§Ø¬ØªÙ…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‡Ø§Ø¬Ø±ÙˆÙ† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ù†ØµØ§Ø± Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: Ø¥Ù† Ù„Ùƒ - ÙŠØ§ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ - Ù…Ø¤ÙˆÙ†Ø© ÙÙŠ Ù†ÙÙ‚ØªÙƒ ÙˆÙÙŠÙ…Ù† ÙŠØ£ØªÙŠÙƒ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙÙˆØ¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø£Ù…ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø¹ Ø¯Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ù†Ø§ ÙØ§Ø­ÙƒÙ… ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ø±Ø§ØŒ Ù…Ø£Ø¬ÙˆØ±Ø§ØŒ Ø£Ø¹Ø· Ù…Ø§ Ø´Ø¦ØªØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø³Ùƒ Ù…Ø§ Ø´Ø¦ØªØŒ Ù…Ù† ØºÙŠØ± Ø­Ø±Ø¬ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ£Ù†Ø²Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø±ÙˆØ­ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…ÙŠÙ† ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ØŒ (Ù‚Ù„ Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ø³Ø¦Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ø¬Ø±Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¯Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰) ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ù† ØªÙˆØ¯ÙˆØ§ Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø¨ØªÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ÙŠØŒ ÙØ®Ø±Ø¬ÙˆØ§ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†Ø§ÙÙ‚ÙˆÙ†: Ù…Ø§ Ø­Ù…Ù„ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ØªØ±Ùƒ Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ø±Ø¶Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù„ÙŠØ­Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø¨ØªÙ‡ Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯Ù‡ØŒ Ø¥Ù† Ù‡Ùˆ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø´Ø¦ Ø§ÙØªØ±Ø§Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø¬Ù„Ø³Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡Ù… Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ…Ø§ØŒ ÙØ£Ù†Ø²Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¬Ø¨Ø±Ø¦ÙŠÙ„ Ø¨Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© (Ø£Ù… ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ÙˆÙ† Ø§ÙØªØ±Ø§Ù‡ Ù‚Ù„ Ø¥Ù† Ø§ÙØªØ±ÙŠØªÙ‡ ÙÙ„Ø§ ØªÙ…Ù„ÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù„ÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ØªÙÙŠØ¶ÙˆÙ† ÙÙŠÙ‡ ÙƒÙÙ‰ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø´Ù‡ÙŠØ¯Ø§ Ø¨ÙŠÙ†ÙŠ ÙˆØ¨ÙŠÙ†ÙƒÙ… ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„ØºÙÙˆØ± Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­ÙŠÙ…) (1) ÙØ¨Ø¹Ø« Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡Ù„ Ù…Ù† Ø­Ø¯Ø«ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: Ø¥ÙŠ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠØ§ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ù„Ù‚Ø¯ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ù†Ø§ ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù…Ø§ ØºÙ„ÙŠØ¸Ø§ ÙƒØ±Ù‡Ù†Ø§Ù‡ØŒ ÙØªÙ„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© ÙØ¨ÙƒÙˆØ§ ÙˆØ§Ø´ØªØ¯ Ø¨ÙƒØ§Ø¤Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ£Ù†Ø²Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ (ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø§Ù„ØªÙˆØ¨Ø© Ø¹Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ø¯Ù‡ ÙˆÙŠØ¹ÙÙˆ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙŠØ¦Ø§Øª ÙˆÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ù…Ø§ ØªÙØ¹Ù„ÙˆÙ†) (2)ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø¯Ø³Ø©. ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø¹Ø©: ÙÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰: (Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ù„Ø§Ø¦ÙƒØªÙ‡ ÙŠØµÙ„ÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ÙŠØ§ Ø£ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¡Ø§Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§ ØµÙ„ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ³Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ§ ØªØ³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§) (3) ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹Ø§Ù†Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ø²Ù„Øª Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ù‚ÙŠÙ„: ÙŠØ§ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø¯ Ø¹Ø±ÙÙ†Ø§ Ø§Ù„ØªØ³Ù„ÙŠÙ… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒØŒ ÙÙƒÙŠÙ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ„Ø§Ø© Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡Ù… ØµÙ„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ ÙˆØ¢Ù„ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ ØµÙ„ÙŠØª Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ùˆ (4) Ø¢Ù„ Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ø¥Ù†Ùƒ Ø­Ù…ÙŠØ¯ Ù…Ø¬ÙŠØ¯ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠÙ†ÙƒÙ… - Ù…Ø¹Ø§Ø´Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ - ÙÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø®Ù„Ø§ÙØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ù„Ø§. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†: Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ø§ (5) Ù„Ø§ Ø®Ù„Ø§Ù ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø£ØµÙ„Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¬Ù…Ø§Ø¹ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ù„ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯Ùƒ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù„ Ø´Ø¦ Ø£ÙˆØ¶Ø­ Ù…Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù†ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±ÙˆÙ†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙŠØ³ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙŠÙ… * Ø¥Ù†Ùƒ Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ† * Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ØµØ±Ø§Ø· Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ØªÙ‚ÙŠÙ…) (6)ØŒ ÙÙ…Ù† Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø¨Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡: (ÙŠØ³)ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡: (ÙŠØ³) Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡)ØŒ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ´Ùƒ ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ø­Ø¯. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): ÙØ¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ø¹Ø·Ù‰ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯Ø§ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙˆØ¢Ù„ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙØ¶Ù„Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¨Ù„Øº Ø£Ø­Ø¯ ÙƒÙ†Ù‡ ÙˆØµÙÙ‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ù‚Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ³Ù„Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¡ (ØµÙ„ÙˆØ§Øª Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…)ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰: (Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù†ÙˆØ­ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ†) (1)ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: (Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ…) (2) ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: (Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ ÙˆÙ‡Ø§Ø±ÙˆÙ†) (3)ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠÙ‚Ù„: Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¢Ù„ Ù†ÙˆØ­ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠÙ‚Ù„: Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¢Ù„ Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¢Ù„ Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ…ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: * (Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¢Ù„ ÙŠØ§Ø³ÙŠÙ†) (4)ØŒ ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø¢Ù„ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) - ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†: Ù‚Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Øª Ø£Ù† ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø¹Ø¯Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙˆØ© Ø´Ø±Ø­ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ÙˆØ¨ÙŠØ§Ù†Ù‡ - ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø¹Ø©. ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù…Ù†Ø©: ÙÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆØ§Ø¹Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ù†Ù…Ø§ ØºÙ†Ù…ØªÙ… Ù…Ù† Ø´Ø¦ ÙØ£Ù† Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø®Ù…Ø³Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ ÙˆÙ„Ø°ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰) ÙÙ‚Ø±Ù† Ø³Ù‡Ù… Ø°ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰ Ù…Ø¹ Ø³Ù‡Ù…Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ù‡Ù… Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ø§ ÙØµÙ„ Ø£ÙŠØ¶Ø§ Ø¨ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø©ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Ù‡Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø­ÙŠØ²ØŒ ÙˆØ¬Ø¹Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ ÙÙŠ Ø­ÙŠØ² Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙˆØ±Ø¶ÙŠ Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ø§ Ø±Ø¶ÙŠ Ù„Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§ØµØ·ÙØ§Ù‡Ù… ÙÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙØ¨Ø¯Ø£ Ø¨Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø¨Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø¨Ø°ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰ Ø¨ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙØ¦ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØºÙ†ÙŠÙ…Ø© ÙˆØºÙŠØ± Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ù…Ø§ Ø±Ø¶ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù„Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙˆØ±Ø¶ÙŠÙ‡ Ù„Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ ÙˆÙ‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚: (ÙˆØ§Ø¹Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ù†Ù…Ø§ ØºÙ†Ù…ØªÙ… Ù…Ù† Ø´Ø¦ ÙØ£Ù† Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø®Ù…Ø³Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ ÙˆÙ„Ø°ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰) ÙÙ‡Ø°Ø§ ØªØ£ÙƒÙŠØ¯ Ù…Ø¤ÙƒØ¯ ÙˆØ£Ø«Ø± Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù… Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø·Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ£ØªÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ø·Ù„ Ù…Ù† Ø¨ÙŠÙ† ÙŠØ¯ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø®Ù„ÙÙ‡ ØªÙ†Ø²ÙŠÙ„ Ù…Ù† Ø­ÙƒÙŠÙ… Ø­Ù…ÙŠØ¯. ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø§ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡: (ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙŠØªØ§Ù…Ù‰ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø§ÙƒÙŠÙ†) (5) ÙØ¥Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙŠØªÙŠÙ… Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù†Ù‚Ø·Ø¹ ÙŠØªÙ…Ù‡ Ø®Ø±Ø¬ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØºÙ†Ø§Ø¦Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ù†ØµÙŠØ¨ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙƒÙŠÙ† Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù†Ù‚Ø·Ø¹Øª Ù…Ø³ÙƒÙ†ØªÙ‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ù„Ù‡ Ù†ØµÙŠØ¨ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…ØºÙ†Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ­Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ø®Ø°Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ³Ù‡Ù… Ø°ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù… Ù„Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ù„Ù„ØºÙ†ÙŠ ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙŠØ± Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø£ØºÙ†Ù‰ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡)ØŒ ÙØ¬Ø¹Ù„ Ù„Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ù…Ø¹Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ø³Ù‡Ù…Ø§ ÙˆÙ„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø³Ù‡Ù…Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ…Ø§ Ø±Ø¶ÙŠÙ‡ Ù„Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø±Ø¶ÙŠÙ‡ Ù„Ù‡Ù…. ÙˆÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„ÙØ¦ Ù…Ø§ Ø±Ø¶ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ Ø±Ø¶ÙŠÙ‡ Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰ØŒ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ø¬Ø±Ø§Ù‡Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØºÙ†ÙŠÙ…Ø©ØŒ ÙØ¨Ø¯Ø£ Ø¨Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ø¬Ù„ Ø¬Ù„Ø§Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø¨Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø¨Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø±Ù† Ø³Ù‡Ù…Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ø³Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ù‡Ù… Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡. ÙˆÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ø¹Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: (ÙŠØ§ Ø£ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¡Ø§Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ø·ÙŠØ¹ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ£Ø·ÙŠØ¹ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ ÙˆØ£ÙˆÙ„ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø± Ù…Ù†ÙƒÙ…) (1)ØŒ ÙØ¨Ø¯Ø£ Ø¨Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø¨Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø¨Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡. ÙˆÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙ„Ø§ÙŠØ©: (Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¡Ø§Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§) (2) ÙØ¬Ø¹Ù„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ÙŠØªÙ‡Ù… Ù…Ø¹ Ø·Ø§Ø¹Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ù…Ù‚Ø±ÙˆÙ†Ø© Ø¨Ø·Ø§Ø¹ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„ Ø³Ù‡Ù…Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ø¹ Ø³Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ù…Ù‚Ø±ÙˆÙ†Ø§ Ø¨Ø³Ù‡Ù…Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØºÙ†ÙŠÙ…Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙØ¦ØŒ ÙØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø¹Ø¸Ù… Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØªÙ‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¨ÙŠØª! ÙÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ø¬Ø§Ø¡Øª Ù‚ØµØ© Ø§Ù„ØµØ¯Ù‚Ø© Ù†Ø²Ù‡ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ø²Ù‡ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ø²Ù‡ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: (Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„ØµØ¯Ù‚Ø§Øª Ù„Ù„ÙÙ‚Ø±Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø§ÙƒÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ù…Ù„ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù„ÙØ© Ù‚Ù„ÙˆØ¨Ù‡Ù… ÙˆÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‚Ø§Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØºØ§Ø±Ù…ÙŠÙ† ÙˆÙÙŠ Ø³Ø¨ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø¨ÙŠÙ„ ÙØ±ÙŠØ¶Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡) (3) ÙÙ‡Ù„ ØªØ¬Ø¯ ÙÙŠ Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø³Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ø£Ùˆ Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø£Ùˆ Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‰ØŸ Ù„Ø§Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ø²Ù‡ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ØµØ¯Ù‚Ø© ÙˆÙ†Ø²Ù‡ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ù†Ø²Ù‡ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡ØŒ Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ù„ Ø­Ø±Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„ØµØ¯Ù‚Ø© Ù…Ø­Ø±Ù…Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡ÙŠ Ø£ÙˆØ³Ø§Ø® Ø£ÙŠØ¯ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ù„Ø§ ØªØ­Ù„ Ù„Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø·Ù‡Ø±ÙˆØ§ Ù…Ù† ÙƒÙ„ Ø¯Ù†Ø³ ÙˆÙˆØ³Ø®ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ø·Ù‡Ø±Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ£ØµØ·ÙØ§Ù‡Ù… Ø±Ø¶ÙŠ Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ø§ Ø±Ø¶ÙŠ Ù„Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ±Ù‡ Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ø§ ÙƒØ±Ù‡ Ù„Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù…Ù†Ø©. ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„ØªØ§Ø³Ø¹Ø©: ÙÙ†Ø­Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙƒØ± Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø­ÙƒÙ… ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡: (ÙØ³Ø¦Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙƒØ± Ø¥Ù† ÙƒÙ†ØªÙ… Ù„Ø§ ØªØ¹Ù„Ù…ÙˆÙ†) (4) ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡: Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ÙˆØ¯ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†ØµØ§Ø±Ù‰. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) Ø³Ø¨Ø­Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡! ÙˆÙ‡Ù„ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŸ Ø¥Ø°Ù† ÙŠØ¯Ø¹ÙˆÙ†Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¯ÙŠÙ†Ù‡Ù…. ÙˆÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ÙˆÙ†: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ Ø£ÙØ¶Ù„ Ù…Ù† Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†: ÙÙ‡Ù„ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯Ùƒ ÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø´Ø±Ø­ Ø¨Ø®Ù„Ø§Ù Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ØŒ ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ø¨Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù†ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙƒØ±: Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡)ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ø­Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨ÙŠÙ† ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø­ÙŠØ« ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙÙŠ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø·Ù„Ø§Ù‚: (ÙØ§ØªÙ‚ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠØ§ Ø£ÙˆÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¡Ø§Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ù‚Ø¯ Ø£Ù†Ø²Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙƒÙ… Ø°ÙƒØ±Ø§ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØªÙ„ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒÙ… Ø¢ÙŠØ§Øª Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø¨ÙŠÙ†Ø§Øª) (1) ÙØ§Ù„Ø°ÙƒØ± Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ø­Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ØªØ§Ø³Ø¹Ø©. ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ø´Ø±Ø©: ÙÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„ØªØ­Ø±ÙŠÙ…: (Ø­Ø±Ù…Øª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒÙ… Ø£Ù…Ù‡Ø§ØªÙƒÙ… ÙˆØ¨Ù†Ø§ØªÙƒÙ… ÙˆØ£Ø®ÙˆØ§ØªÙƒÙ…) (2) Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙØ£Ø®Ø¨Ø±ÙˆÙ†ÙŠ Ù‡Ù„ ØªØµÙ„Ø­ Ø§Ø¨Ù†ØªÙŠ Ø£Ùˆ Ø§Ø¨Ù†Ø© Ø§Ø¨Ù†ÙŠ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ ØªÙ†Ø§Ø³Ù„ Ù…Ù† ØµÙ„Ø¨ÙŠ Ù„Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªØ²ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ø§ Ù„Ùˆ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø­ÙŠØ§ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: Ù„Ø§. Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ£Ø®Ø¨Ø±ÙˆÙ†ÙŠ Ù‡Ù„ ÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ø§Ø¨Ù†Ø© Ø£Ø­Ø¯ÙƒÙ… ØªØµÙ„Ø­ Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªØ²ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ø§ Ù„Ùˆ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø­ÙŠØ§ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§: Ù„Ø§. Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙÙÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ù†ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø³ØªÙ… Ù…Ù† Ø¢Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ùˆ ÙƒÙ†ØªÙ… Ù…Ù† Ø¢Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ø­Ø±Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¨Ù†Ø§ØªÙƒÙ… ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø­Ø±Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¨Ù†Ø§ØªÙŠØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù†ÙŠ (3) Ù…Ù† Ø¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ£Ù†ØªÙ… Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù…ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ø§ ÙØ±Ù‚ Ù…Ø§ Ø¨ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø©ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù„ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ØªÙƒÙ† Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù„ Ù„ÙŠØ³Øª Ù…Ù†Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ø´Ø±Ø©. ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø§Ø¯ÙŠØ© Ø¹Ø´Ø±Ø©: ÙÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù† Ø­ÙƒØ§ÙŠØ© Ø¹Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù† Ù…Ù† Ø¢Ù„ ÙØ±Ø¹ÙˆÙ†: (ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù† Ù…Ù† Ø¡Ø§Ù„ ÙØ±Ø¹ÙˆÙ† ÙŠÙƒØªÙ… Ø¥ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†Ù‡ Ø£ØªÙ‚ØªÙ„ÙˆÙ† Ø±Ø¬Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø±Ø¨ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¬Ø§Ø¡ÙƒÙ… Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¨ÙŠÙ†Ø§Øª Ù…Ù† Ø±Ø¨ÙƒÙ…) (4)ØŒ ØªÙ…Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ©ØŒ ÙÙƒØ§Ù† Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø®Ø§Ù„ ÙØ±Ø¹ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙÙ†Ø³Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ ÙØ±Ø¹ÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ¶ÙÙ‡ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¨Ø¯ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø®ØµØµÙ†Ø§ Ù†Ø­Ù† Ø¥Ø° ÙƒÙ†Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¢Ù„ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø¨ÙˆÙ„Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ†Ø§ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù…Ù…Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ø§ ÙØ±Ù‚ Ù…Ø§ Ø¨ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø§Ø¯ÙŠØ© Ø¹Ø´Ø±Ø©. ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ© Ø¹Ø´Ø±Ø©: ÙÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø± Ø£Ù‡Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ØµÙ„Ø§Ø© ÙˆØ§ØµØ·Ø¨Ø± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§) (1) ÙØ®ØµÙ†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø®ØµÙˆØµÙŠØ©ØŒ Ø£Ù† Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø¨Ø¥Ù‚Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø§Ù„ØµÙ„Ø§Ø©ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ø®ØµÙ†Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙÙƒØ§Ù† Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙŠØ¬ÙŠØ¦ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ ÙˆÙØ§Ø·Ù…Ø© Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ù†Ø²ÙˆÙ„ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© ØªØ³Ø¹Ø© Ø£Ø´Ù‡Ø± ÙƒÙ„ ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø­Ø¶ÙˆØ± ÙƒÙ„ ØµÙ„Ø§Ø© Ø®Ù…Ø³ Ù…Ø±Ø§ØªØŒ ÙÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„: Ø§Ù„ØµÙ„Ø§Ø© Ø±Ø­Ù…ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡. ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø£ÙƒØ±Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø°Ø±Ø§Ø±ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¡ Ø¨Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ±Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ Ø£ÙƒØ±Ù…Ù†Ø§ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ®ØµÙ†Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØªÙ‡. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡: Ø¬Ø²Ø§ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØª Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙƒÙ… Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø®ÙŠØ±Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ…Ø§ Ù†Ø¬Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø±Ø­ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ù† ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ Ø§Ø´ØªØ¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒÙ… (2).", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/29/1/79/1", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 79, "thaqalaynSanad": "Abu Ja`far Muhammad b. `Ali b. al-Husayn b. Musa b. Babuwayh al-Qummi (rh) narrated to us. He said: `Ali b. al-Husayn b. Shadhuwayh al-Muâ€™addab and Ja`far b. Muhammad b. Masrur (ra) narrated to us. They said: Muhammad b. `Abdullah b. Ja`far al-Himyari narrated to us from his father from al-Rayyan b. al-Salt. He said: ", "thaqalaynMatn": "Al-Rida (as) attended a gathering with al-Maâ€™mun in Marv, who had gathered a group of scholars from the people of Iraq and Khurasan. So, al-Maâ€™mun said: Inform me of the meaning of this verse, â€œThen, We bequeathed the Book to Our chosen servants.â€ (35:32) So, the scholars said: By this, Allah meant this entire Nation (Umma). So, al-Maâ€™mun said: What do you say, Abaâ€™l Hasan? So, al-Rida (as) said: I do not say as they have said, but rather I say: Allah meant the pure progeny (al-`itra al-tahira). So, al-Maâ€™mun said: How could have He meant the progeny without the Nation? So, al-Rida (as) said to him: Had He meant the Nation, then it would be going to Paradise in its entirety, as per the saying of Allah, â€œSome of them wrong themselves, some follow a middle course, and some are foremost in good deeds by the permission of Allah. That is the greatest bounty.â€ (35:32) Then, He included all of them in Paradise, saying, â€œThey will enter the Gardens of Eternity, where they will be adorned with bracelets of goldâ€ (35:33). Therefore, the bequeathal is to the pure progeny, not to others. Then, al-Maâ€™mun said: Who are the pure progeny? So, al-Rida (as) said: Those whom Allah described in His Book. \u003Cbr\u003E He says, â€œSurely, Allah only wishes to remove uncleanliness from you, O Ahl al-Bayt, and purify you with a thorough purification.â€ (33:33) They are the ones about whom the Messenger of Allah (s) said: â€œSurely, I leave behind the two heavyweights among you: (1) the Book of Allah, and (2) my progeny, my Ahl al-Bayt. Surely, they will not separate until they return to me at the Pond. So, watch how you handle them after me. O people! Do not teach them, for they know more than you.â€ The scholars said: Inform us, Abaâ€™l Hasan, about the progeny â€“ are they the Family (al-Aal) or are they different than the Family? So, al-Rida (as) said: They are the Family. So, the scholars said: It is reported that the Messenger of Allah (s) said: â€œMy Nation is my Family.â€ His companions have thoroughly reported that the Family of Muhammad is his Nation, to a point where it cannot be denied. So, Abuâ€™l Hasan (as) said: Inform me: is charity not forbidden for the Family? They said: Yes. He said: So, is it forbidden for the Nation? They said: No. He said: This is a difference that distinguishes the Family from the Nation. Woe to you for where you have been taken to! Have you deviated from the remembrance of the page (the Quran)? Are you an extravagant people?! Do you not know that [these verses on] bequeathal and purity apply to the chosen, guided ones and not the rest of you? They said: From where [did you read this], Abaâ€™l Hasan? He said: From the saying of Allah, â€œWe have sent Nuh and Ibrahim, and We have placed prophethood and the Book in their descendants. Among them are those who are guided, but many of them are transgressors.â€ (57:26) The inheritors of prophethood and the Book went to those who are guided, not the transgressors. Do you not know that, when Nuh (as) asked his Lord, â€œSo, he said: My Lord! Surely, my son is from my family, and surely, Your promise is true, and You are the most just of the judges.â€ (11:45) That was when Allah promised to save him and his family. So, his Lord said to him, â€œO Nuh! He is not of your family. Surely, he is one whose work was other than righteous; so do not ask about that which you have no knowledge of. I exhort you from being of the ignorant.â€ (11:46) Then, al-Maâ€™mun said: Has Allah favoured the progeny over the rest of the people? So, Abuâ€™l Hasan (as) said: Surely, Allah demonstrated the favour of the progeny over the rest of the people in the decisive [verses] of His Book. \u003Cbr\u003E So, al-Maâ€™mun said to him: Where is that in the Book of Allah? So, a-Rida (as) said: In His saying, â€œSurely, Allah has chosen Adam, Nuh, the Family of Ibrahim, and the Family of `Imran over the people. Offspring, one of the other.â€ (3:33-34) He said in another place, â€œDo they envy what Allah has given them of His favour? We have given the Family of Ibrahim the Book and the wisdom, and We have given them great authority.â€ (4:54) Then, He proceeded to address the rest of the believers in context to this, â€œO you who believe! Obey Allah and obey the Messenger and the Masters of Authority amongâ€ (4:59) â€“ meaning, those whom We bestowed with the Book and the wisdom, and they were envied upon that. So, His saying, â€œDo they envy what Allah has given them of His favour? We have given the Family of Ibrahim the Book and the wisdom, and We have given them great authorityâ€ (4:54) refers to obedience to the chosen and pure ones. Authority here refers to obedience to them. The scholars said: Inform us: Has Allah explained chosenness in His Book? \u003Cbr\u003E So, al-Rida (as) said: He explained this chosenness in twelve apparent places, not including [any] esoteric [places]. The first of those is His saying, â€œWarn your closest relatives *and your chosen group*â€ (26:214) â€“ this is in the recitation of Ubay b. Ka`b, and it is firm in the codex of `Abdullah b. Mas`ud. This is an elevated rank, a great favour, and an exalted honour that Allah used when referring to this Family. He mentioned it to the Messenger of Allah (s) â€“ and this is the first [verse]. The second verse in relation to chosenness is His saying, â€œSurely, Allah only wishes to remove uncleanliness from you, O Ahl al-Bayt, and purify you with a thorough purification.â€ (33:33) This is a favour that no stubborn person is ignorant of, because favour comes after purity. As for the third, it is when Allah distinguished the pure ones from His creation and ordered His Prophet to the imprecation (mubahala) in the Verse of Imprecation. He said: Say, O Muhammad, â€œCome, let us call our sons and your sons, our women and your women, our selves and your selves. Then, we will imprecate, and we will put the curse of Allah over the liars.â€ (3:61) \u003Cbr\u003E So, the Prophet (s) honoured `Ali, al-Hasan, al-Husayn, and Fatima (s) and compared their selves to his self. Do you comprehend the meaning of His saying, â€œour selves and your selvesâ€? The scholars said: It means themselves. \u003Cbr\u003E So, Abuâ€™l Hasan (as) said: You are incorrect. Surely, it only refers to `Ali b. Abi Talib (as). The saying of the Prophet (s) indicates this when he said: â€œBanu Wali`a will stop or I will send them a man like myselfâ€ â€“ meaning, `Ali b. Abi Talib (as). This specifically [is a virtue] that none surpass him in, and a favour that no human will follow him in, and an honour that no creature preceded him in; that he positioned `Ali to his own self â€“ this is the third. As for the fourth: he (s) ordered the people to leave his Mosque with exception to the progeny. The people talked about that, and [even] al-`Abbas [b. `Abd al-Muttalib] talked about it. He said: â€œO Messenger of Allah! You have left `Ali and you have ordered us to leave!â€ \u003Cbr\u003E So, the Messenger of Allah (s) said: â€œIt was not I who left him and ordered you to leave, but rather it was Allah that left him and ordered you to leave.â€ In this is an elucidation of his saying to `Ali (as): â€œYou are to me as Harun was to Musa.â€ The scholars said: Where is this in the Quran? Abuâ€™l Hasan (as) said: Shall I bring it to you from the Quran and recite it to you? They said: Bring it. He said: The saying of Allah, â€œWe revealed to Musa and his brother: settle your people in houses in Egypt and make your houses the qibla.â€ (10:87) In this verse is the status of Harun to Musa, and likewise therein is the status of `Ali (as) to the Messenger of Allah (s). From this is a clear indication regarding the saying of the Messenger of Allah (s) when he said: â€œSurely, none can be in a state of janaba in this Mosque except Muhammad and his Family.â€ \u003Cbr\u003E So, the scholars said: O Abaâ€™l Hasan! This interpretation and elucidation is not found except with you, the Ahl al-Bayt of the Messenger of Allah (s). So, he said: Who denies that of us? The Messenger of Allah (s) said: â€œI am the City of Wisdom and `Ali is its Gate, so whoever wants the City must come to it by its Gate.â€ We have clarified and explained this favour, honour, pre-eminence, chosenness, and purity in a way that cannot be denied by a stubborn person; and praise be to Allah for that â€“ this is the fourth. The fifth verse is the saying of Allah, â€œGive those near in kin their rightâ€ (17:26) â€“ Allah the Glorious and Powerful specified them in it, and He chose them over the Nation. When this verse was revealed to the Messenger of Allah (s), he said: â€œCall to Fatima for me.â€ \u003Cbr\u003E So, she was called for him, then he said: â€œO Fatima!â€ She said: â€œI am at your service, O Messenger of Allah.â€ So, he (s) said: â€œFadak is that which no horse nor camel rushed upon [to seize]. It belongs to me alone and not the Muslims. I have given it to you when Allah commanded me to. So, take it for yourself and your childrenâ€ â€“ this is the fifth. The sixth verse is the saying of Allah, â€œSay: I do not ask you for a reward for it except to love those near in kin.â€ (42:23) This is specifically for the Prophet (s) until the Day of Resurrection, and specifically to the Family and not anyone else. This is because Allah reported what Nuh (as) had said in His Book, â€œAnd O my people, I ask not of you for it any wealth. My reward is not but from Allah. And I am not one to drive away those who have believed. Surely, they will meet their Lord, but I see that you are a people behaving ignorantly.â€ (11:29) He reported what Hud (as) had said, â€œI do not ask you for any reward. My reward is only from the one who created me. Do you, then, not understand?â€ (11:51) He said to His Prophet (s), â€œSayâ€ â€“ O Muhammad â€“ â€œI do not ask you for a reward for it except to love those near in kin.â€ (42:23) Allah would not obligate their love without knowing that they will not ever apostate from the religion, nor will they ever go back to misguidance. A man may love a man, but if he is an enemy to a family member of his, the manâ€™s heart will not be at peace with him. \u003Cbr\u003E So, Allah did not want anything of malice in the heart of the Messenger of Allah (s) for the believers, thus he obligated loving those near in kin. Whoever fulfills this, loves the Messenger of Allah (s), and loves his Ahl al-Bayt, the Messenger of Allah (s) will not be able to hate him; but whoever abandons this, and does not fulfill it, and hates his Ahl al-Bayt, then it is incumbent on the Messenger of Allah (s) to hate him, for he will have abandoned an obligation set by Allah. \u003Cbr\u003E So, what favour and what honour supersedes or [even] comes close to this? When Allah revealed this verse upon His Prophet (s), â€œSay: I do not ask you for a reward for it except to love those near in kin.â€ (42:23), the Messenger of Allah (s) stood among his companions, praised Allah and commended Him, and said: â€œO people! Allah has obligated something for me upon you. Will you fulfill it?â€ None answered him. Then, he said: â€œO people! It is not [something fulfilled] by gold, silver, food, or drink. \u003Cbr\u003E So, they said: â€œGive it.â€ So, he recited this verse, and they said: â€œAs for this, then yes.â€ However, most of them did not fulfill it. Allah did not send a prophet except that he revealed to him that he is to not ask for a reward from his people, because Allah fulfills the reward of the prophets. For Muhammad (s), Allah obligated the love for his kin for his Nation, and He commanded him to make his reward with them their love for him through his relatives. [This can only be] by recognizing their favour, which Allah obligated for them, for love can only be at the level of recognition of their favour. When Allah obligated this, it was as heavy as the obligation of obeying them. Some who took a covenant with Allah held onto this to fulfill the promise, but the people of discord and hypocrisy were stubborn and disbelieved in it. They took it beyond the limit that Allah limited it with, and they said: â€œThe kin are all the Arabs and the people he called to.â€ Upon this, the two opinions came about. We know that the love is for the related, and the most related of them to the Prophet (s) is the most rightful of them to the love. The closer the relation is, the more love is in proportion to it. They were unjust to the Prophet of Allah (s) in honouring him and being affectionate to him and that which Allah [obligated] his Nation with regards to him and thanking him in a way that tongues cannot describe. They did not love him through his descendants and his Ahl al-Bayt, and they did not confer a status to them like that of the eye to the head, as a trust to the Messenger of Allah (s) and out of love for His Prophet. How is this when the Quran speaks about it and calls to it? The reports are sound that they are the people of this love, and they are the ones whose love Allah obligated. He promised the reward upon this â€“ there is not one sincere, believing person in this love except that Paradise becomes obligatory for him, as per the saying of Allah in this verse, â€œAnd those who have believed and done righteous deeds will be in lush regions of the gardens [in Paradise] having whatever they will in the presence of their Lord. That is what is the great bounty. That is the good news that Allah gives to His servants who believed and did righteous deeds. Say, â€œI do not ask you any fee for it, except the love of kinshipâ€ (42:22-23) â€“ interpreted and clarified. Then, Abuâ€™l Hasan (as) said: My father narrated to me from my grandfather from his forefathers from al-Husayn b. `Ali (as). He said: The Muhajirin and the Ansar gathered to the Messenger of Allah (s) and said: â€œO Messenger of Allah, you have difficulties and expenses with regards to those who visit you. Here is our wealth and our blood, so manage it how you will in righteousness and reward â€“ give what you wish and withhold what you wish, regardless of any need.â€ He said: So, Allah sent the Trustworthy Spirit down to him, who said: â€œO Muhammad! â€˜Say: I do not ask you for a reward for it except to love those near in kin.â€™ (42:23)â€ â€“ meaning, love my kin after me. \u003Cbr\u003E So, they left. The hypocrites said: â€œThe Messenger of Allah (s) did not abandon what we have presented to him except to urge us [to accept] his kin after him. It is but something that he concocted in his sitting place.â€ That was a great calumny of theirs, so Allah revealed this verse to Gabriel, â€œOr do they say that he concocted it? Say: â€˜If I have done so, then there is nothing whatsoever you can do to save me from Allah. He knows best what you indulge about it. Sufficient is He as a Witness between you and me. And He is the All-Forgiving, Most Merciful.â€™â€ (46:8) \u003Cbr\u003E So, the Prophet (s) sent for them and said: â€œDid anyone say anything?â€ They said: â€œYes, by Allah, O Messenger of Allah. Some of us said repugnant words that we hated.â€ So, the Messenger of Allah (s) recited the verse to them, and they wept, and their weeping intensified. Then, Allah revealed, â€œIt is He who accepts repentance from His servants and forgives sins and knows what they do.â€ (42:25) So, this is the sixth. As for the seventh verse, it is the saying of Allah, â€œSurely, Allah and His angels bless the Prophet. O you who believe! Bless him and bid peace.â€ (33:56) Those who were stubborn of them became known when this verse was revealed; it was said: â€œO Messenger of Allah! We know how to bid you peace (taslim), but how do we bless you?â€ \u003Cbr\u003E So, he said: â€œYou say: â€˜O Allah, bless Muhammad and the Family of Muhammad just as You blessed Ibrahim and the Family of Ibrahim. Surely, You are the Praiseworthy, the Great.â€™â€ O people! So, is there any among you who disagrees with this? They said: No. Al-Maâ€™mun said: There is no disagreement in this anyway, as there is a consensus on it. Do you have anything clearer than this in the Quran about the Family [in particular]? Abuâ€™l Hasan (as) said: Yes. Inform me of the saying of Allah, â€œYasin. By the Wise Quran, surely, you are of the messengers, upon a Straight Path.â€ (36:1-4) What did He mean when He said, â€œYasinâ€? The scholars said: Yasin is Muhammad (s). No one doubts this. Abuâ€™l Hasan (as) said: Surely, Allah has granted Muhammad (s) and the Family of Muhammad a favour that none can comprehend or describe except one who intelligizes it: Allah does not give salaam to anyone [in the Quran] except the prophets (as). He says, â€œPeace be with Nuh among the worldsâ€ (37:79), and He says, â€œPeace be with Ibrahimâ€ (37:109), and He says, â€œPeace be with Musa and Harunâ€ (37:120), but He did not say: â€œPeace be with the Family of Nuhâ€, nor did He say: â€œPeace be with the Family of Musaâ€ nor â€œwith the Family of Ibrahimâ€ â€“ yet He says, â€œPeace be with the Family of Yasinâ€ (37:130), meaning the Family of Muhammad (s). Then, al-Maâ€™mun said: I knew that in the goldmine of prophethood there was an explanation and clarification of this â€“ so this is the seventh. As for the eighth, Allah says, â€œKnow that when you gain a thing, then a fifth of it is for Allah, the Messenger, and those near of kin.â€ (8:41), so He compared the portion of those near of kin to His portion and His Messengerâ€™s portion. This is another difference between the Family and the Nation because Allah placed them in a position and placed the people in another position. He willed for them what He willed for Himself, and He chose them therein. He began with Himself, then His Messenger, then those near of kin in regard to the fayâ€™, the spoils, and other than that, decreeing for them what He decreed for Himself and for them. He says, and His saying is true, â€œKnow that when you gain a thing, then a fifth of it is for Allah, the Messenger, and those near of kin.â€ (8:41) This is a steadfast guarantee and a standing decree for them until the Day of Resurrection, [written] in the Speaking Book of Allah; which falsehood cannot come to before it or behind it, revealed by the Wise, the Praiseworthy. As for His saying, â€œand the orphans and the poorâ€ (8:41), when the orphan matures, he does not receive the khums and he does not have a right to it. It is the same with the poor: if his poverty goes, then he will not have a right to the khums, and it will not be permissible to take. The portion of those near in kin is established for them until the Day of Resurrection, whether they are wealthy or poor. There is none wealthier than Allah nor His Messenger (s), so He set a portion for Himself and His Messenger. Whatever He willed for Himself and His Messenger, He willed for them. It is the same with the fayâ€™: what He willed for Himself and His Prophet, He willed for those near in kin. He began with Himself, then His Messenger, then them; and He compared their portion with Allahâ€™s portion and His Messengerâ€™s portion. It is like that in obedience â€“ He says, â€œO you who believe! Obey Allah and obey the Messenger and the Masters of Authority amongâ€ (4:59) â€“ He began with Himself, then His Messenger, then his Ah al-Bayt. It is like that in the Verse of Wilaya, â€œSurely, your wali is only Allah, His Messenger, and those who believe â€¦â€ (5:55) \u003Cbr\u003E So, He made their wilaya, alongside the obedience owed to the Messenger, like the obedience owed to Him; just as He made their portion alongside the portion of the Messenger like His portion in the spoils and the fayâ€™. May Allah be glorified and exalted for making His blessing over this Ahl al-Bayt great! When the delineation for charity came, He exempted Himself, His Messenger, and his Ahl al-Bayt. He says, â€œSurely, charity is only for the poor, the needy, those employed to collect it, those whose hearts are attracted [to Islam], for freeing slaves, for those in debt, for Allahâ€™s cause, and for wayfarers. This is obligated by Allah.â€ (9:60) Do you see anything in this that is apportioned for Himself, His Messenger, or those near of kin? Because when He exempted Himself, His Messenger, and His Ahl al-Bayt from charity, He forbade it for them, for charity is forbidden for Muhammad and His Family. It is the impure [wealth] that is in the hands of the people, and it is forbidden for them, because they are purified from every uncleanliness and dirtiness. When Allah purified and chose them, He willed for them what He willed for Himself, and He disliked for them what He disliked for Himself. So, this is the eighth. As for the ninth: we are the People of the Reminder (Ahl al-Dhikr) about whom Allah says in the decisive [verse] of His Book, â€œSo, ask the People of the Reminder if you do not know.â€ (16:43) The scholars said: With this, He means the Jews and the Christians. So, Abuâ€™l Hasan (as) said: May Allah be glorified! Is that permissible? They would call us to their religion, and say that it is better than the religion of Islam. Al-Maâ€™mun said: Do you have an interpretation that opposes what they have said, Abaâ€™l Hasan? So, he (as) said: Yes. The Reminder is the Messenger of Allah (s), and we are his family (ahl). That is clarified in the Book of Allah where He says in Surat al-Talaq, â€œAllah has prepared a severe punishment for them. \u003Cbr\u003E So, fear Allah, O people of intellect and belief. Allah has bestowed a Reminder unto you; a messenger reciting Allahâ€™s revelation to you, making things clearâ€ (65:10-11) The Reminder is the Messenger of Allah, and we are his family, so this is the ninth. As for the tenth: it is the saying of Allah in the Verse of Prohibition, â€œForbidden to you for marriage are your mothers, your daughters, your sisters â€¦â€ (4:23) â€“ to the end of the verse. \u003Cbr\u003E So, inform me: had the Messenger of Allah (s) been alive, would he be able to marry my daughter or the daughter of my son from the progeny of the Messenger of Allah (s)? They said: No. He said: So, inform me: had the Messenger of Allah (s) been alive, would he be able to marry your daughter or the daughter of your son? They said: Yes. He said: In this is a sign, for I am from his Family, and you are not from his Family. Had you been from the Family, then he would have been prohibited from your daughters just as he is prohibited from my daughters, because I am from his Family and you are from his Nation. \u003Cbr\u003E So, this is a difference between the Family and the Nation, because the Family is from him, and the Nation â€“ those who are not from the Family â€“ are not from him. \u003Cbr\u003E So, this is the tenth. As for the eleventh: it is the saying of Allah in Surat al-Muâ€™min, which speaks about a believing man from the Family of Pharaoh, â€œA believing man from Pharaohâ€™s Family, who was hiding his faith, argued, â€˜Will you kill a man for saying: My Lord is Allah, while he has in fact come to you with clear proofs from your Lord? â€¦â€™â€ (40:28) â€“ to the end of the verse. He was maternal cousin of Pharaoh. He is related to Pharaoh in lineage but not in religion [and was called his Family member]. This is how we were specified as being part of the Family of the Messenger of Allah (s) through our birth from him. We are of the same religion as the people, but this is a distinction between the Family and the Nation. \u003Cbr\u003E So, this is the eleventh. As for the twelfth: it is the saying of Allah, â€œAnd enjoin prayer upon your family and be steadfast therein.â€ (20:132) Allah specified us in particular. He ordered us to establish prayer along with the Nation, then He specified us without the Nation. The Messenger of Allah (s) would come to the door of `Ali and Fatima for nine months after this verse was revealed, at the call to the five daily prayers. He would say: â€œThe prayer â€“ may Allah have mercy on you.â€ Allah did not honour anyone of the descendants of the prophets in the way that He honoured us; and he specified us among all the people of his household. \u003Cbr\u003E So, al-Maâ€™mun and the scholars said: On behalf of this Nation, may Allah reward you, the Ahl al-Bayt of your Prophet, with goodness. We did not find an explanation or an elucidation to quell our doubts except with you.", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 297, "bookId": "Al-Amali-Saduq", "book": "Al-AmÄlÄ«", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "The Thirty-Fourth Assembly, the Assembly of Tuesday, the Nineteenth of Muharram, 368 AH.", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bilal Muhammad", "englishText": "Abu Ja`far recited a poem to one of them: â€œThe intellectual scholar is the son of himself (self-taught), His knowledge has made him needless of his like, How different is one who does for others and one who does for himself!â€", "arabicText": "278 / 16 - ÙˆØ£Ù†Ø´Ø¯Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙŠØ® Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ù„Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ù‡Ù…: Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ù‚Ù„ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ * * Ø£ØºÙ†Ø§Ù‡ Ø¬Ù†Ø³ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ø¹Ù† Ø¬Ù†Ø³Ù‡ ÙƒÙ… Ø¨ÙŠÙ† Ù…Ù† ØªÙƒØ±Ù…Ù‡ Ù„ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ * * ÙˆØ¨ÙŠÙ† Ù…Ù† ØªÙƒØ±Ù…Ù‡ Ù„Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ (2)", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/29/1/34/16", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 34, "thaqalaynSanad": "", "thaqalaynMatn": "", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 175, "bookId": "Maani-al-Akhbar-Saduq", "book": "MaÊ¿ÄnÄ« al-Ê¾AkhbÄr", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "The meaning of the Infallibility of the Imam", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Basel Kadem", "englishText": "Abu Jaâ€™far, the compiler of this book, said: The evidence to the Imamâ€™s Infallibility is that since every speech that is transmitted of a sayer is possible to have indications of interpretations, and since most of the Qurâ€™an and the Tradition is what sects have gathered upon as being authentic, not having changed, nor replaced, nor having been increased with nor having been deducted from, are possible to have many indications of interpretation, it is necessary for there to be, with that, an informer who is truthful, protected from purposeful lying and mistake, predicting of what Allah and His Messenger meant in the Book and Tradition in its true and real sense. This is because the creation are disputed with regards to interpretation; every sect tendences along with the Qurâ€™an and the Tradition towards its own opinions. If Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, had left them in this case without an informer of His Book who is truthful about it, then He would have justified for them to be disputed in matters of religion, yet He would have called them to it, as He had sent down a Book that is possible to have several interpretations, and as His Prophet, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, established a Tradition that is possible to have several interpretations, and yet He has ordered them to act in accordance to it. It is as if He said: Interpret and act. In that lies permissibility of acting with contradictions and of relying on the truth and its opposite. Since that is impossible upon Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, it is necessary for there to be along with the Qurâ€™an and the Tradition, in every age, one who clarifies the meanings which Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, meant in the Qurâ€™an with His speech with other than what the terms of the Qurâ€™an carries of possible interpretation, and who clarifies the meanings which the Messenger of Allah, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, meant in his Traditions and reports with other than the possible interpretation of the terms of the reports narrated of him, peace be upon him, on whose authenticity of transmission there is a consensus. If it is necessary that there must be a truthful informer, it is necessary for it to be impossible for him to purposely lie and err in his informing of the intention of Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, in His Book and the intention of Allahâ€™s Messenger, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, in his reports and Traditions. Since this is necessary, it is necessary for him to be Infallible. What affirms this evidence is that it is not permissible to our opponents for Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, to have sent down the Qurâ€™an to the people of the era of the Prophet, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, while there was no Prophet among them and that He would command them to act with it in its true and real sense. Hence, if it is not possible that He had sent down the Qurâ€™an upon a people while there is no speaker on its behalf, no expressor on its behalf, nor interpreter of what is obscure of it nor clarifier of its indications, similarly, it is not possible for us to act with it except if there is, along with it, one who takes among us the position of the Prophet, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, in his people and the people of his era with regards to clarifying its abrogator, abrogated, specific and general elements, and the meanings which Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, intended with His Speech, with that which does not possibly contain interpretation, like how the Prophet, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, was a clarifier of all of that to the people of his age. That is a must, as long as they adhere to intellect and religion. If a sayer was to say: That which delivers to us what we need to know of the unclear elements of the Qurâ€™an and of the meanings intended by Allah, with other than that whose terms may not possibly contain of that, is the nation. That which negates this the most is the nationâ€™s dispute and testimony, in consensus, upon itself in many of the verses of the Qurâ€™an to their ignorance of its meaning which Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, intended. In that lies clarification that the nation is not the deliverer on behalf of Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, which clarifies the Qurâ€™an, and that in that it does not take the position of the Prophet, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family. If a daring was to dares and say: Certainly, it would be possible for Him to have sent down the Qurâ€™an on the people of the era of the Prophet, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, while there is no Prophet with them, and that He would command them to act in worship with what is in it, in spite that interpretation is possible in it. It would be said to him: Suppose that this had caused of dispute in its meanings what has occurred in this age, what would they do? If he would say: What they do at this hour. It would be said: What they have done at this hour is for every sect of the nation to take one side of the interpretation and act with it while declaring as aberrant the sect that opposes them in it and testifying against it that it is not on the truth. If he was to say: It is possible for there to have been so during the first stages of Islam, and in that lies wisdom from Allah and justice towards them. He would (in the case of this statement) have performed a major error and which I have not seen any of the creation daring to, and it would be said to him after that: Then tell us, if it was feasible for the fluent Arabs, the people of the language, to interpret the Qurâ€™an and for each one of them to act with what he interprets of the Arabic language, then what will they do, those of the people who do not know the language? And how will they non-Arabs, of the Turks and the Persians, do? And to what thing will they refer back with regards to knowledge of what Allah has obliged upon them in His Book? And from which sect will they accept, with the dispute among sects with regards to interpretation and your declaration of the permissibility for each sect to act in accordance with its interpretation? Hence, it would be a must for you make the non-Arabs and those who do not understand the language follow the path of the people of the language in the sense that they may follow whichever of the sects they wish. Otherwise, if you would bind upon those who do not understand the language to follow some sects and not others, it implies that you place all the truth with that sect and not others. Hence, if you place the truth in, you would have negated what you based your speech upon, and you would need for there to be with that sect a knowledge and proof by that recognize it (as the truth) from others, and that is not of your saying in which you make all sects equal with regards to the truth in spite of the contradiction between their interpretations. It would then be necessary for you to make for the non-Arabs and those who do not understand the language that they follow whichever of the sects they wish. If you do so, it would imply, at this time, that you do not bind upon any of your opponents, from the Shiâ€™a, Khawarij, people of interpretations and everyone who opposes you from those who have a sect and from innovators who do not have a sect, a condemnation. This is a negation of Islam and violation of the consensus, and it will be said to you: Is it not a condemned opinion that Allah commands the creation to act in worship with the content in a Book that is agreed upon, which none is able to read its content, and that He commands them to research and explore, and that each sect acts with what it sees is in the Book? If you had declared this as permissible, you would have declared frivolity as permissible for Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, because that is, indeed, among the characteristics of a frivolous. Also, it implies that you declare as permissible for everyone who ponders upon a thing with his intellect and considers something of religion as good, that he believes in it, because it would be equal; He would have permitted them to act with the foundations of what is allowable and forbidden and its branches by their opinions, or he would permit for them to ponder with their intellects into the roots of religion, all of it, and its branches, from its (tenet of) Monotheism and others, and that they also act with what they consider as good and rely on to be true. If you declare that as permissible, you would have declared it possible for Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, to allow for the creation that they testify for Him that He is the second of two, to believe in existentialism and to knowingly reject the Creator, Glorious and Exalted is He. This is the last there is of this speech, because the one who declares as possible that Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, commands us to act in worship by the Book whilst there being the possibility of interpretation and there not being an informer who is truthful to us about its meanings, implies that he declares as permissible for the people of the era of the Prophet, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, the same as that, and if he declares the same as that as permissible, it implies that Allah, Exalted and Glorious is He, allows for every sect to act in accordance to what it believes and interprets, because they would not have other than that if they were not to have any proof with regards to this interpretation being more correct than that interpretation. If He has allowed that for them, (it implies that) He has allowed for their follower who does not know the knowledge, and if He allows for those as well, it implies that He allows for us in this age. If He allows that for us with regards to the Book, it implies that He allows that for us with regards to the foundations of what is allowable and forbidden and analogies of the intellect, and that is an exiting of the Religion, all of it. If it is necessary with what we have previously mentioned with regards to that there must be an interpreter on behalf of the Qurâ€™an and the reports of the Prophet, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, it is necessary that he is Infallible, in order for it to be obligatory to accept from him, and if it is necessary that he is Infallible, it is invalidated that this applies to the nation due to what we have clarified of its dispute in the interpretation of the Qurâ€™an and the reports, its quarreling with regards to that and its declaration of each other to be disbelievers. If that is affirmed, it is necessary for the Infallible to be the one that we mentioned, and that is the Imam. We have proved that the Imam is not but Infallible, and we have shown that if Infallibility is necessary to be in the Imam, there is no escape from that the Prophet, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, to have confirmed his case, because Infallibility is not in the apparent disposition by which it is recognized by the creation through observation. Hence, it is obligatory that it is affirmed by the Knower of unseen things, Blessed and Exalted is He, on the tongue of His Prophet, Allahâ€™s blessings be upon him and his Family, and that is because the Imam is not but affirmed of. The affirmation has been authenticated to us, in accordance to what we have clarified of arguments and what we have narrated of authentic reports.", "arabicText": "Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ù…ØµÙ†Ù Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨: Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹ØµÙ…Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ù…Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙƒÙ„ ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… ÙŠÙ†Ù‚Ù„ Ø¹Ù† Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠØ­ØªÙ…Ù„ ÙˆØ¬ÙˆÙ‡Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† Ø£ÙƒØ«Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø³Ù†Ø© Ù…Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø¬Ù…Ø¹Øª Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ù‚ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ØµØ­ÙŠØ­ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØºÙŠØ± ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ¨Ø¯Ù„ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ø¯ ÙÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠÙ†Ù‚Øµ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø­ØªÙ…Ù„Ø§ Ù„ÙˆØ¬ÙˆÙ‡ ÙƒØ«ÙŠØ±Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø¹ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ø®Ø¨Ø± ØµØ§Ø¯Ù‚ Ù…Ø¹ØµÙˆÙ… Ù…Ù† ØªØ¹Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ°Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØºÙ„Ø·ØŒ Ù…Ù†Ø¨Ø¦ Ø¹Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø³Ù†Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø­Ù‚ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØµØ¯Ù‚Ù‡ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ù…Ø®ØªÙ„ÙÙˆÙ† ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ØŒ ÙƒÙ„ ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© ØªÙ…ÙŠÙ„ Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø³Ù†Ø© Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø°Ù‡Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ„Ùˆ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ ØªØ±ÙƒÙ‡Ù… Ø¨Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ØµÙØ© Ù…Ù† ØºÙŠØ± Ù…Ø®Ø¨Ø± Ø¹Ù† ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡ ØµØ§Ø¯Ù‚ ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ù„ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù‚Ø¯ Ø³ÙˆØºÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø®ØªÙ„Ø§Ù ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ¯Ø¹Ø§Ù‡Ù… Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¥Ø° Ø£Ù†Ø²Ù„ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ø§ ÙŠØ­ØªÙ…Ù„ Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ ÙˆØ³Ù† Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ Ø³Ù†Ø© ÙŠØ­ØªÙ…Ù„ Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø±Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù…Ù„ Ø¨Ù‡Ù…Ø§ØŒ ÙÙƒØ£Ù†Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ØªØ£ÙˆÙ„ÙˆØ§ ÙˆØ§Ø¹Ù…Ù„ÙˆØ§. ÙˆÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¥Ø¨Ø§Ø­Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù…Ù„ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù…ØªÙ†Ø§Ù‚Ø¶Ø§Øª ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø¹ØªÙ…Ø§Ø¯ Ù„Ù„Ø­Ù‚ ÙˆØ®Ù„Ø§ÙÙ‡. ÙÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ø³ØªØ­Ø§Ù„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø³Ù†Ø© ÙÙŠ ÙƒÙ„ Ø¹ØµØ± Ù…Ù† ÙŠØ¨ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ Ø¹Ù†Ø§Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† Ø¨ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù‡ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ­ØªÙ…Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ù„ÙØ§Ø¸ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ ÙˆÙŠØ¨ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ Ø¹Ù†Ø§Ù‡Ø§ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø³Ù†Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØ£Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ø±Ù‡ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙŠØ­ØªÙ…Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ù„ÙØ§Ø¸ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙˆÙŠØ© Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¬Ù…Ø¹ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ØµØ­Ø© Ù†Ù‚Ù„Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ù…Ø®Ø¨Ø± ØµØ§Ø¯Ù‚ ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø£Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ°Ø¨ ØªØ¹Ù…Ø¯Ø§ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø§Ù„ØºÙ„Ø· ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ ÙŠØ®Ø¨Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ù† Ù…Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆØ¹Ù† Ù…Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ø±Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ù†Ù†Ù‡ØŒ Ùˆ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø¹ØµÙˆÙ…. ÙˆÙ…Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ¤ÙƒØ¯ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ù…Ø®Ø§Ù„ÙÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø£Ù†Ø²Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù†Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¹ØµØ± Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù… ÙˆÙŠØªØ¹Ø¨Ø¯Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù…Ù„ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø­Ù‚Ù‡ Ùˆ ØµØ¯Ù‚Ù‡ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¬Ø² Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†Ø²Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‚ÙˆÙ… ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù†Ø§Ø·Ù‚ Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ø¨Ø± Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…ÙØ³Ø± Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ø³ØªØ¹Ø¬Ù… Ù…Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ø¨ÙŠÙ† Ù„ÙˆØ¬Ù‡Ù‡ ÙÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø£Ù† Ù†ØªØ¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ù†Ø­Ù† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ø¹Ù‡ Ù…Ù† ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ… ÙÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ù…Ù‚Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙˆÙ…Ù‡ ÙˆØ£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¹ØµØ±Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªØ¨ÙŠÙŠÙ† Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³Ø®Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ù†Ø³ÙˆØ®Ù‡ ÙˆØ®Ø§ØµÙ‡ ÙˆØ¹Ø§Ù…Ù‡ØŒ Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ Ø¹Ù†Ø§Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¨ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù…Ù‡ØŒ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ­ØªÙ…Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ØŒ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø¨ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ù„Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙƒÙ„Ù‡ Ù„Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¹ØµØ±Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø²Ù…ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ†. ÙØ¥Ù† Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ¯ÙŠ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ø­ØªØ§Ø¬ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ù…ØªØ´Ø§Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ù…Ø¹Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ Ø¹Ù†Ø§Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ­ØªÙ…Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ù„ÙØ§Ø¸Ù‡ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø©. Ø£ÙƒØ°Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ø®ØªÙ„Ø§Ù Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø© ÙˆØ´Ù‡Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø£Ø¬Ù…Ø¹Ù‡Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙŠ ÙƒØ«ÙŠØ± Ù…Ù† Ø¢ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† Ù„Ø¬Ù‡Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ø§Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø¹Ù†Ø§Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ù† Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø© Ù„ÙŠØ³Øª Ù‡ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ø¯ÙŠØ© Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¨Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù†ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ù„ÙŠØ³Øª ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ… ÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ù‚Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡. ÙØ¥Ù† ØªØ¬Ø§Ø³Ø± Ù…ØªØ¬Ø§Ø³Ø± ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‚Ø¯ ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†Ø²Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¹ØµØ± Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ÙˆÙŠØªØ¹Ø¨Ø¯Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ø­ØªÙ…Ø§Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„. Ù‚ÙŠÙ„ Ù„Ù‡: ÙÙ‡Ø¨ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù‚Ø¯ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ø§Ù ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø¹Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø¯ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ ÙÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙ‚Øª Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙƒØ§Ù†ÙˆØ§ ÙŠØµÙ†Ø¹ÙˆÙ†ØŸ ÙØ¥Ù† Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø¯ ØµÙ†Ø¹ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø¹Ø©. Ù‚ÙŠÙ„: Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙØ¹Ù„ÙˆÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø¹Ø© Ø£Ø®Ø° ÙƒÙ„ ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø© Ø¬Ø§Ù†Ø¨Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ ÙˆØ¹Ù…Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØªØ¶Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø®Ø§Ù„ÙØ© Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØ´Ù‡Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ù„ÙŠØ³Øª Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚. ÙØ¥Ù† Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø£ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ùˆ Ø¹Ø¯Ù„ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù…. Ø±ÙƒØ¨ Ø®Ø·Ø£ Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ…Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ø±Ù‰ Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ù‚ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ:ÙØ­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ ØªÙ‡ÙŠØ£ Ù„Ù„Ø¹Ø±Ø¨ Ø§Ù„ÙØµØ­Ø§Ø¡ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„ØºØ© Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªØ£ÙˆÙ„ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† ÙˆÙŠØ¹Ù…Ù„ ÙƒÙ„ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØªØ£ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„ØºØ© Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø±Ø¨ÙŠØ© ÙÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠØµÙ†Ø¹ Ù…Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„ØºØ© Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ØŸ ÙˆÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠØµÙ†Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¬Ù… Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØªØ±Ùƒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙØ±Ø³ØŸ ÙˆØ¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø£ÙŠ Ø´Ø¦ ÙŠØ±Ø¬Ø¹ÙˆÙ† ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ù…Ø§ ÙØ±Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡ØŸ Ùˆ Ù…Ù† Ø£ÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ù‚ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¨Ù„ÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ø®ØªÙ„Ø§Ù Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ù‚ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ ÙˆØ¥Ø¨Ø§Ø­ØªÙƒ ÙƒÙ„ ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© Ø£Ù† ØªØ¹Ù…Ù„ Ø¨ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙ„Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯ Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù† ØªØ¬Ø±ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¬Ù… ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„ØºØ© Ù…Ø¬Ø±Ù‰ Ø£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„ØºØ© Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù† Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªØ¨Ø¹ÙˆØ§ Ø£ÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ù‚ Ø´Ø§Ø¤ÙˆØ§. Ùˆ [Ø¥Ù„Ø§] Ø¥Ù† Ø£Ù„Ø²Ù…Øª Ù…Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„ØºØ© Ø§ØªØ¨Ø§Ø¹ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶ Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ù‚ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶ Ù„Ø²Ù…Ùƒ Ø£Ù†Øª ØªØ¬Ø¹Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ ÙƒÙ„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ ØªÙ„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© Ø¯ÙˆÙ† ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ ÙÙŠ ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© Ø¯ÙˆÙ† ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© Ù†Ù‚Ø¶Øª Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ù†ÙŠØª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù…Ùƒ ÙˆØ§Ø­ØªØ¬Øª Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø¹ ØªÙ„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù… ÙˆØ­Ø¬Ø© ØªØ¨ÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ù† ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ùƒ Ù„Ùˆ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ù‚ ÙƒÙ„Ù‡Ø§ Ù…ØªØ³Ø§ÙˆÙŠØ© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ Ù…Ø¹ ØªÙ†Ø§Ù‚Ø¶ ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„Ø§ØªÙ‡Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ„Ø²Ù…Ùƒ Ø£ÙŠØ¶Ø§ Ø£Ù† ØªØ¬Ø¹Ù„ Ù„Ù„Ø¹Ø¬Ù… ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„ØºØ© Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªØ¨Ø¹ÙˆØ§ Ø£ÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ù‚ Ø´Ø§Ø¤ÙˆØ§ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ ÙØ¹Ù„Øª Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù„Ø²Ù…Ùƒ ÙÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙ‚Øª Ø£Ù† Ù„Ø§ ØªÙ„Ø²Ù… Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ù…Ø®Ø§Ù„ÙÙŠÙƒ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙŠØ¹Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø®ÙˆØ§Ø±Ø¬ ÙˆØ£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„Ø§Øª ÙˆØ¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ù…Ù† Ø®Ø§Ù„ÙÙƒ Ù…Ù…Ù† Ù„Ù‡ ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ù…Ø¨ØªØ¯Ø¹ Ù„Ø§ ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø®Ø§Ù„ÙÙŠÙƒ Ø°Ù…Ø§ ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ù†Ù‚Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø®Ø±ÙˆØ¬ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¬Ù…Ø§Ø¹ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ùƒ: ÙˆÙ…Ø§ ÙŠÙ†ÙƒØ± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¹Ø·Ø§Ø¡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªØ¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ù…Ø·Ø¨Ù‚ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ…ÙƒÙ† Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ‚Ø±Ø£ Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆÙŠØ£Ù…Ø± Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¨Ø­Ø«ÙˆØ§ ÙˆÙŠØ±ØªØ§Ø¯ÙˆØ§ ÙˆÙŠØ¹Ù…Ù„ ÙƒÙ„ ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ØªØ±Ù‰ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨. ÙØ¥Ù† Ø£Ø¬Ø²Øª Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ø¬Ø²Øª Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¨Ø« Ù„Ø§Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ØµÙØ© Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ø¨Ø«ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ„Ø²Ù…Ùƒ Ø£Ù† ØªØ¬ÙŠØ² Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ù† Ù†Ø¸Ø± Ø¨Ø¹Ù‚Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø´Ø¦ ÙˆØ§Ø³ØªØ­Ø³Ù† Ø£Ù…Ø±Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¹ØªÙ‚Ø¯Ù‡ Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø³ÙˆØ§Ø¡ Ø£Ø¨Ø§Ø­Ù‡Ù… Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¹Ù…Ù„ÙˆØ§ ÙÙŠ Ø£ØµÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù„Ø§Ù„ Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø±Ø§Ù… ÙˆÙØ±ÙˆØ¹Ù‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø¢Ø±Ø§Ø¦Ù‡Ù… [Ø£] ÙˆØ£Ø¨Ø§Ø­Ù‡Ù… Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†Ø¸Ø±ÙˆØ§ Ø¨Ø¹Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø£ØµÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ† ÙƒÙ„Ù‡ ÙˆÙØ±ÙˆØ¹Ù‡ Ù…Ù† ØªÙˆØ­ÙŠØ¯Ù‡ ÙˆØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ ÙˆØ£Ù† ÙŠØ¹Ù…Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø£ÙŠØ¶Ø§ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ø³ØªØ­Ø³Ù†ÙˆÙ‡ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† Ø¹Ù†Ø¯Ù‡Ù… Ø­Ù‚Ø§ ÙØ¥Ù† Ø£Ø¬Ø²Øª Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ø¬Ø²Øª Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¨ÙŠØ­ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ´Ù‡Ø¯ÙˆØ§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ø§Ø«Ù†ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù† ÙŠØ¹ØªÙ‚Ø¯ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‡Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ¬Ø­Ø¯ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ø±Ø¦ Ø¬Ù„ ÙˆØ¹Ø². ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ø¢Ø®Ø± Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… Ù„Ø§Ù† Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø¬Ø§Ø² Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªØ¹Ø¨Ø¯Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ø­ØªÙ…Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ø®Ø¨Ø± ØµØ§Ø¯Ù‚ Ù„Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ù† Ù…Ø¹Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ‡ Ù„Ø²Ù…Ù‡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¬ÙŠØ² Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¹ØµØ± Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø¬Ø§Ø² Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù„Ø²Ù…Ù‡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¨ÙŠØ­ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙƒÙ„ ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù…Ù„ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ø±Ø£Øª ÙˆØªØ£ÙˆÙ„Øª Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù„Ù‡Ù… ØºÙŠØ± Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ù…Ø¹Ù‡Ù… Ø­Ø¬Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø£Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ Ø£ØµØ­ Ù…Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø¨Ø§Ø­ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ø¨Ø§Ø­ Ù…ØªØ¨Ø¹Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù…Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„ØºØ© ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø¨Ø§Ø­ Ø£ÙˆÙ„Ø¦Ùƒ Ø£ÙŠØ¶Ø§ Ù„Ø²Ù…Ù‡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¨ÙŠØ­Ù†Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¹ØµØ±ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø¨Ø§Ø­Ù†Ø§ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ù„Ø²Ù…Ù‡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¨ÙŠØ­Ù†Ø§ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙÙŠ Ø£ØµÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù„Ø§Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­Ø±Ø§Ù… ÙˆÙ…Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙˆØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø®Ø±ÙˆØ¬ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ† ÙƒÙ„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø¯Ù…Ù†Ø§ Ø°ÙƒØ±Ù‡ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ù…ØªØ±Ø¬Ù… Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† ÙˆØ£Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø¹ØµÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù„ÙŠØ¬Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¨ÙˆÙ„ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø¹ØµÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø¨Ø·Ù„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø© Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ø¨ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ø®ØªÙ„Ø§ÙØ§ØªÙ‡Ø§ ÙÙŠ ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ø± ÙˆØªÙ†Ø§Ø²Ø¹Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø¥ÙƒÙØ§Ø± Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ù‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø«Ø¨Øª Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹ØµÙˆÙ… Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø°ÙƒØ±Ù†Ø§Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù…. ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¯Ù„Ù„Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ø¹ØµÙˆÙ…Ø§ ÙˆØ£Ø±ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ ÙˆØ¬Ø¨Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¹ØµÙ…Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ø¨Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†Øµ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù„Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹ØµÙ…Ø© Ù„ÙŠØ³Øª ÙÙŠ Ø¸Ø§Ù‡Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ù‚Ø© ÙÙŠØ¹Ø±ÙÙ‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø´Ø§Ù‡Ø¯Ø© ÙÙˆØ§Ø¬Ø¨ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†Øµ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„ØºÙŠÙˆØ¨ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù„Ø³Ø§Ù† Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ù„Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ù†ØµÙˆØµØ§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡.
