ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ¯Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ¯ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ¦Ù’Ø²ÙØ±Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ­ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ«ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØªÙÙŠ ØªÙØ¯Ù’Ø¹ÙÙˆ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙØµÙ’ÙÙÙŠÙ‚Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØ¬Ù’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¢Ù†ÙÙŠÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙØ¶Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ¨Ù’Ø³Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ±ÙÙŠØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙŠØ¨ÙØ§Ø¬Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ²Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙÙØ£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ³ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙÙÙ„Ø§Ù Ø¨ÙØ£Ù’Ø³Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø«Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ØªÙØ²Ù’Ù‡ÙÙˆÙØŒ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ ØªÙØµÙ’ÙÙØ±Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ ØªÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ­ÙØ§Ù‚ÙÙ„ÙØ©ÙØŒ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ·ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø²Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙÙŠØ¨Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ†ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØ´Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ±Ù’Ø¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ´Ù’ØªÙØ±ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ³Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù„ÙØ¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ ØºÙØ§Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙØ§ØµÙØ±ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø´ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙØ§Ù‚ÙÙŠÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¹ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ´Ù’ØªÙØ±ÙÙŠÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø¢ÙƒÙÙ„Ù Ø«ÙÙ…ÙÙ†ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ„ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø´ÙØ±ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ØµÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ©Ù‹ Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ§ØªÙ ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙØ·Ù’Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¡ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ø§Ù‹ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ³Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø·ÙÙŠÙ†ÙØ©Ù Ø®ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙŠÙ ØµÙØ¯ÙÙŠØ¯Ù Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ®Ù’Ø±ÙØ¬Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙÙØ±ÙÙˆØ¬Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø²Ù‘ÙÙ†ÙØ§Ø©Ù ÙÙÙŠÙØ¬Ù’ØªÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙØ¯ÙÙˆØ±Ù Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙŠÙØ´Ù’Ø±ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙÙâ€ ÙŠÙØµÙ’Ù‡ÙØ±Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…Ù°Ø§ ÙÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙØ·ÙÙˆÙ†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ„ÙÙˆØ¯Ù \"\nÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø´ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø²Ù‘ÙÙˆØ±Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙØ¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø¢ÙƒÙÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’ÙƒÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ§ØªÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø´ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¹Ù ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙÙ„ÙÙÙ ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¹Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¹Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¹Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ØªÙØ¶Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØµÙØ§ÙÙØ­ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’Ø´ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ¹Ù’Ø±Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’Ø´ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¶Ù‘ÙØ§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ³ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ’ÙÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¶ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙˆÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’Ø¸ÙØ±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ’Ø±ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙØ£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙ„Ù Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ’Ø±ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù Ù„ÙØ¹ÙÙ†ÙÙ‡Ù Ø³ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ\" ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ø£ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙ†Ù’Ø¸ÙØ±Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ’Ø±ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ø£ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’ÙÙØ®Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø·ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø´ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’ÙÙØ®Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¶ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙÙˆØ¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø·Ù‘ÙØ±ÙÙ‚Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø­ÙÙŠÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¯ÙÙŠÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ·Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¥ÙØ¨ÙÙ„Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¸ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙØ¹Ù’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù‚ÙØªÙ’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ­Ù’Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØ³Ù’Ù…Ù ÙÙÙŠ ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙˆÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ù„ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù Ø¨ÙØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙÙ„ÙÙÙ Ø¨ÙØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù \"ÙÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘Ù°Ù‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¡Ù\" \" ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ù„ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù Ø¨ÙØ³ÙÙˆØ±ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙÙ„ÙÙÙ Ø¨ÙØ³ÙÙˆØ±ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø¨ÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø¢ÙŠÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙØ§ ÙƒÙÙÙ‘ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ©Ù ÙŠÙÙ…ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø´ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø¨ÙØ±Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø´ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙÙØ¬ÙØ±Ù\" ØŒ\nÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ \"Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ‚ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù Ù„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙÙŠÙØ§ØªÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø©Ù ÙÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ†Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØ¨ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙØ¹ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ’Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ…ÙØ¹ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ…ÙØ¹ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¥ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù…Ù ÙŠÙØ®Ù’Ø·ÙØ¨Ù \"ÙÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙÙØ¹ÙÙ„Ù Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ù„ÙØºÙÙŠÙ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØºÙÙŠÙ ÙÙÙ„Ø§Ù Ø¬ÙÙ…ÙØ¹ÙØ©Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙØ®ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ…Ù Ø¨ÙØ®ÙØ§ØªÙÙ…Ù ØµÙÙÙ’Ø±Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø­ÙØ¯ÙÙŠØ¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’Ù‚ÙØ´Ù Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¡ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙÙŠÙÙˆÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙØ§ØªÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØµÙ‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø·ÙÙ„ÙÙˆØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù’Ø³Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù ØºÙØ±ÙÙˆØ¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ ØµÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø³ÙØªÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§Ù…ÙØŒ ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙØ·Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ‘Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ­Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙØ´Ù’Ø±ÙÙŠÙ‚Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ´Ù’Ø±ÙØ¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§ ØªÙØ´Ù’Ø±ÙØ¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ø§ÙØ´Ù’Ø±ÙØ¨ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¨ÙØ£ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¯ÙÙŠÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙÙ’Ø¶ÙÙ„Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù†ÙÙŠÙƒÙÙ…Ù’\" ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ²ÙØ§Ù‚Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¦Ù’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØªÙÙŠ ÙŠÙØ´Ù’Ø±ÙØ¨Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù Ø£ÙØ¬ÙÙŠØ±ÙŒ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±ÙØ§Ù†Ù \"ÙÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù„Ø§Ù Ø¨ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù ÙÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù’Ø¬ÙØ±Ù Ø£ÙØ®ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ø«ÙØ±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø«ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§Ù…Ù ÙÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù…ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¬ÙØ±Ø§Ù‹ Ù„ÙØ£ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ø«ÙØ±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù\" ØŒ ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ¨Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ¨Ù Ø²ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù‹ Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙØ²Ù’Ù†Ø§Ù‹ Ø¨ÙÙˆÙØ²Ù’Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¯Ù’Ø­Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ø§ÙØ­Ù’Ø«ÙÙˆØ§ ÙÙÙŠ ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙˆÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ§Ø­ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¨Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙˆÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø®ÙØµÙÙˆÙ…ÙØ©Ù Ø¸ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ…Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø£ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ù†ÙØ²ÙÙ„Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØ¨Ù’Ø´ÙØ±Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙ„ÙØ¹Ù’Ù†ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù \"ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ¦Ù’Ø³Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØµÙÙŠØ±Ù\" \" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ¯ÙØ­Ù Ø³ÙÙ„Ù’Ø·ÙØ§Ù†Ø§Ù‹ Ø¬ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ±Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ ØªÙØ®ÙÙÙ‘ÙÙÙ ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ¶ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¶ÙØ¹Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø·ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù‚ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ†ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù \" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù \"Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù \"ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù° ØªÙØ±Ù’ÙƒÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø¸ÙÙ„ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ§ ÙÙØªÙÙ…ÙØ³Ù‘ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘Ù°Ø§Ø±Ù \" \" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙˆÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ Ø¬ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ±Ø§Ù‹ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¬ÙÙˆÙ’Ø±Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù‚ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ù‡ÙØ§Ù…ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§Ù†Ø§Ù‹ Ø±ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¡Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙÙ…Ù’Ø¹ÙØ©Ù‹ Ø­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¶Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ù†ÙØ§Ø±ÙŒ ØªÙØ´Ù’ØªÙØ¹ÙÙ„Ù Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù ØªÙØ·ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙÙ‚Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ†ÙÙ‚ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ‰ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ø¨ÙØ³ÙÙ‡Ù Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¡ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø¯ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù‚ÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙÙˆØ¨Ù\"\nÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ„Ù ÙŠÙØ§ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙƒÙÙŠÙ’ÙÙ ÙŠÙØ¨Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø±ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¡Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙÙ…Ù’Ø¹ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"ÙŠÙØ¨Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ ÙÙØ¶Ù’Ù„Ø§Ù‹ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ§ ÙŠÙÙƒÙ’ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ·ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¬ÙÙŠØ±ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ§Ø©Ù‹ Ù„ÙØ¥ÙØ®Ù’ÙˆÙØ§Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¸ÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù Ø£ÙØ¬ÙÙŠØ±Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ø¨ÙØ·Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø±ÙÙŠØ­Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø±ÙÙŠØ­ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙŠÙÙˆØ¬ÙØ¯Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ³ÙÙŠØ±ÙØ©Ù Ø®ÙÙ…Ù’Ø³ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙØ§Ù…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¬ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø´ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±Ø§Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¶Ù Ø¬ÙØ¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø·ÙÙˆÙ’Ù‚Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ†ÙÙ‚ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙØ®ÙÙˆÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¶Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ©Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ·ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù‹ Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙÙˆØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ±Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¹Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙØ¹ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ±Ù’Ø¢Ù†Ù Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ù†ÙØ³ÙÙŠÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØºÙ’Ù„ÙÙˆÙ„Ø§Ù‹ ÙŠÙØ³ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ·Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø¨ÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø¢ÙŠÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø­ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù‹ ØªÙÙƒÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù‚ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ†ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØºÙ’ÙÙØ±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù‚ÙØ±ÙØ£Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ±Ù’Ø¢Ù†Ù Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ø´ÙØ±ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø­ÙØ±ÙØ§Ù…Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø¢Ø«ÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø­ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø²ÙÙŠÙ†ÙØªÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙÙˆØ¬ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø³ÙØ®ÙØ·Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙÙˆØ¨Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ§ØªÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù ØªÙÙˆÙ’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù Ø­ÙØ§Ø¬Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ²ÙØ§ÙŠÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ¯Ù’Ø­ÙÙˆØ¶Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø²ÙÙ†ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù…Ù’Ø±ÙØ£ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ ÙŠÙÙ‡ÙÙˆØ¯ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ù†ÙØµÙ’Ø±ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ù…ÙØ¬ÙÙˆØ³ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ø­ÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø£ÙÙ…ÙØ©Ù Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙØ¨Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ØªÙ Ù…ÙØµÙØ±Ù‘Ø§Ù‹ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙÙØªÙØ­Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø«ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ«ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ©Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¨Ù ØªÙØ®Ù’Ø±ÙØ¬Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø­ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§ØªÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø«ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙÙÙ‡ÙÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’ØªÙØ±ÙÙ‚Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ«Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ£ÙØ°Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù†ÙØªÙ’Ù†Ù Ø±ÙÙŠØ­ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙÙ Ø¨ÙØ°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¯ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø­ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ±ÙØ§Ù…Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ¯ÙÙˆØ¯Ù ÙÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ¯ÙŒ Ø£ÙØºÙ’ÙŠÙØ±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙÙˆÙØ§Ø­ÙØ´Ù\"\nÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ·Ù‘ÙÙ„ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’ØªÙ Ø¬ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù†ÙØ¸ÙØ±Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ’Ø±ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ’Ø±ÙØ©Ù ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØªÙØ¹ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙØ¯Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù†ÙÙˆØ§ ÙŠÙØ¨Ù’Ø­ÙØ«ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ’Ø±ÙØ§ØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ®Ù’Ø±ÙØ¬Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙÙÙ’Ø¶ÙØ­ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙÙˆØ¨Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ±Ù’Ø¶Ù Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ù‚ÙØ³ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ²Ù’Ù‚Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ«Ù‘Ù Ø´ÙÙƒÙ’ÙˆÙØ§Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØµÙ’Ø¨ÙØ±Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’ØªÙØ³ÙØ¨Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ØªÙØ±Ù’ÙÙØ¹Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†ÙØ©ÙŒ ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ØºÙØ¶Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙÙˆØ¨Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ®Ù’ØªÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù…ÙØ´Ù’ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ¨ÙØ³Ù Ø«ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¨Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙØ§Ø®Ù’ØªÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø®ÙØ³ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø´ÙÙÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù‚ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù„ÙØ£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙÙ„Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØ®Ù’ØªÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙÙØ®ÙØ³ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù \"Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ¯Ù°Ø§Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¶Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØ®Ù’ØªÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ù†ÙØ§Ø²ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¬ÙØ¨ÙØ±ÙÙˆØªÙÙ‡Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¸ÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙØ£ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙÙÙ‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø²ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙŠÙÙ‚ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù \"Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯ÙÙŠ Ø²ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ¬Ù’ØªÙÙƒÙ Ø£ÙÙ…ÙØªÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø¯ÙÙŠ ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù’ ØªÙÙˆÙÙ Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø¯ÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ Ø¸ÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙÙ…ÙØªÙÙŠ\" ÙÙÙŠÙØ¤Ù’Ø®ÙØ°Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†ÙØ§ØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠÙØ¯Ù’ÙÙØ¹Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’Ø±Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙÙØ¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ØªÙØ¨Ù’Ù‚Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†ÙØ©ÙŒ Ø£ÙÙ…ÙØ±Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙÙƒÙ’Ø«ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø¯Ù \"Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø¯Ù ÙƒÙ°Ø§Ù†Ù Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ø¤ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‹\" \"\nÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØªÙ’Ù…ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØªÙÙ…ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØ·Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø±ÙØ¡ÙÙˆØ³Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ¦ÙÙ‚Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù \"ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù° ØªÙÙƒÙ’ØªÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù°Ø§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙƒÙ’ØªÙÙ…Ù’Ù‡Ù°Ø§ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¢Ø«ÙÙ…ÙŒ Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘Ù°Ù‡Ù Ø¨ÙÙ…Ù°Ø§ ØªÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ…ÙŒ\" \" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¢Ø°ÙÙ‰ Ø¬ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø±ÙÙŠØ­Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù \"ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ£Ù’ÙˆÙ°Ø§Ù‡Ù Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ¦Ù’Ø³Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØµÙÙŠØ±Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¶ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ¹Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù Ø¬ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ø²ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¬ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±ÙØ¦ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù ÙŠÙÙˆØµÙÙŠÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¸ÙÙ†ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø³ÙÙŠÙÙˆÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ø²ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙŠÙÙˆØµÙÙŠÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙŠÙƒÙ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¸ÙÙ†ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø³ÙÙŠÙØ¬Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙÙ‚Ù’ØªØ§Ù‹ Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ„ÙØºÙÙˆØ§ Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙÙ‚Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙÙ‚ÙÙˆØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ø²ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙŠÙÙˆØµÙÙŠÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙˆÙØ§ÙƒÙ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¸ÙÙ†ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø³ÙÙŠÙØ¬Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ±ÙÙŠØ¶ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ø²ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙŠÙÙˆØµÙÙŠÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ’Ù„Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¸ÙÙ†ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø®ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØªÙÙŠ Ù„ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ†ÙØ§Ù…ÙÙˆØ§ Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ®ÙÙÙ‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙÙÙ‚ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ®ÙÙÙ‘Ù Ø¨ÙØ­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ®ÙÙÙ‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙÙˆØ¨Ù \" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙÙŠØ±Ø§Ù‹ Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ø§Ù‹ Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø±ÙØ§Ø¶Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙØ±ÙØ¶ÙØªÙ’ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ§Ø­ÙØ´ÙØ©ÙŒ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø´ÙÙ‡Ù’ÙˆÙØ©ÙŒ ÙÙØ§Ø¬Ù’ØªÙÙ†ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ®ÙØ§ÙÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø­ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙØ²ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ø¨ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¬ÙØ²Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ§ ÙˆÙØ¹ÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‰ \"ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®Ù°Ø§ÙÙ Ù…ÙÙ‚Ù°Ø§Ù…Ù Ø±ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØªÙ°Ø§Ù†Ù\"\nØ£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙØ±ÙØ¶ÙØªÙ’ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¯ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ø®ÙØ±ÙØ©ÙŒ ÙÙØ§Ø®Ù’ØªÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¢Ø®ÙØ±ÙØ©Ù Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³ÙØªÙ’ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†ÙØ©ÙŒ ÙŠÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØ®Ù’ØªÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¢Ø®ÙØ±ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ±ÙÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ Ø±ÙØ¶ÙÙŠÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ ØºÙÙÙØ±Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ³ÙØ§ÙˆÙÙŠÙ Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ„ÙØ£Ù Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙØ±ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ù…ÙÙ„ÙØ£Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙÙˆØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ±Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¹Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØµÙØ§ÙÙØ­Ù Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙØ£ÙØ©Ù‹ ØªÙØ­Ù’Ø±ÙÙ…Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’ \"Ø¨Ù°Ø§Ø¡Ù Ø¨ÙØ³ÙØ®ÙØ·Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘Ù°Ù‡Ù\" Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙØ²ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙØ£ÙØ©Ù‹ Ø­ÙØ±ÙØ§Ù…Ø§Ù‹ Ù‚ÙØ±ÙÙ†Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø³ÙÙ„Ù’Ø³ÙÙ„ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù†ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ù…ÙØ¹Ù Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø·ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙÙÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø°ÙÙÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØºÙØ´Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙÙŠ Ø´ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¹Ù ÙÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ø´ÙØ±Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙŠÙÙ‡ÙÙˆØ¯Ù Ù„ÙØ£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø£ÙØºÙØ´Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙŠÙ†Ù \" ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ…Ù’Ù†ÙØ¹Ù Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ¯ÙŒ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø¬ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø¬ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ¹ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙˆÙÙƒÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙˆÙÙƒÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØ³Ù’ÙˆÙØ£Ù Ø­ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù\"\nÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙØ£ÙØ©Ù Ø¢Ø°ÙØªÙ’ Ø²ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ„ÙØ³ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙØ§ ØµÙØ±Ù’ÙØ§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø¹ÙØ¯Ù’Ù„Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ØªÙØ±Ù’Ø¶ÙÙŠÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ ØµÙØ§Ù…ÙØªÙ’ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù…ÙØªÙ’ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙÙ‚ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙÙ…ÙÙ„ÙØªÙ’ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¬ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ù„Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø³ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†ÙØªÙ’ ÙÙÙŠ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙÙ„Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ±ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¸ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ…Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ·ÙÙ…Ù Ø®ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙØ¦Ù Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ ÙˆÙØ¬Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ¸ÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙØ´ÙØ±Ù Ù…ÙØºÙ’Ù„ÙÙˆÙ„Ø§Ù‹ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙØ¯Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„Ù Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙÙˆØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ§ØªÙ ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ØºÙØ´Ù‘ÙŒ Ù„ÙØ£ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù Ø¨ÙØ§ØªÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ø³ÙØ®ÙØ·Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØµÙ’Ø¨ÙØ­Ù ÙƒÙØ°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙØªÙÙˆØ¨Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ØºÙÙŠØ¨ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØºÙ’ØªÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙØ£Ù‹ Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ø§Ù‹ Ø¨ÙØ·ÙÙ„Ù ØµÙÙˆÙ’Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‚ÙØ¶Ù ÙˆÙØ¶ÙÙˆØ¤ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ØªÙÙÙÙˆØ­Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø±ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ­ÙØ©ÙŒ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙÙ†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙŠÙÙØ©Ù ÙŠÙØªÙØ£ÙØ°Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ù‚ÙÙÙ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ§ØªÙ Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙÙˆØ¨Ù Ù…ÙØ§ØªÙ Ù…ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ­ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù‹ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø­ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù\"\nÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ¸ÙÙ…Ù ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø¸Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ±ÙŒ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ÙÙØ§Ø°ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ø·ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±Ù Ø´ÙÙ‡ÙÙŠØ¯Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙØ·ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙÙ„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ ØºÙÙŠØ¨ÙØ©Ù Ø³ÙÙ…ÙØ¹ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù…ÙØ¬Ù’Ù„ÙØ³Ù ÙÙØ±ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø±ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ±Ù‘Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¢Ø®ÙØ±ÙØ©Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ±ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ±ÙŒ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø±ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙƒÙÙˆÙØ²Ù’Ø±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØºÙ’ØªÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø³ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ù…ÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ©Ù‹\" ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù†ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø£ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù†ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ±ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙØ¯Ù’Ø±ÙÙƒÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ Ù…ÙØ§ØªÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ù…ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØªÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ØºÙØ¶Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ù†Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø´ÙÙ‡ÙØ¯Ù Ø´ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù Ø²ÙÙˆØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ¯Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‚Ù Ø¨ÙÙ„ÙØ³ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ†Ù \"ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙØ±Ù’ÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ³Ù’ÙÙÙ„Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘Ù°Ø§Ø±Ù \"\nÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØ´Ù’ØªÙØ±ÙÙ‰ Ø®ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù†ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙ‡ÙÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ø®ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙØ¨ÙØ³Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¦Ø§Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ±ÙÙƒÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ²Ù’Ù‚Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙÙˆØ¨Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø³ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù ÙÙØ§Ø­ÙØ´ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙÙØ£ÙÙÙ’Ø´ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ§ ÙÙÙ‡ÙÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ø£ÙØªÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØ­Ù’ØªÙØ§Ø¬Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø£ÙØ®ÙÙˆÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙØ±Ù’Ø¶Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¯ÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙÙ’Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’ Ø­ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø±ÙÙŠØ­Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØµÙØ¨ÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙ‚Ù Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙØ£ÙØ©Ù Ø³ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ¦ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙ‚Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ­Ù’ØªÙØ³ÙØ¨Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±Ù Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ø·ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø«ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ§ÙƒÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙØ£ÙØ©Ù Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ØªÙØ±Ù’ÙÙÙ‚Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ²ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙÙ…ÙÙ„ÙØªÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¯ÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ·ÙÙŠÙ‚Ù Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙˆÙ ØªÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙØ§ ØºÙØ¶Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±ÙÙ…Ù Ø£ÙØ®ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØ§ ÙŠÙÙƒÙ’Ø±ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ‰ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ¤ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ø§Ù‹ Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙØ¥ÙØ°Ù’Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ø§Ù‹ Ø¨ÙØ¥ÙØ°Ù’Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø±ÙØ§Ø¶ÙÙˆÙ†Ù ÙÙØ§Ù‚Ù’ØªÙØµÙØ¯Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙÙÙŠ Ø­ÙØ¶ÙÙˆØ±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ø³ÙÙ†Ù ØµÙÙ„Ø§ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¡ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙÙƒÙÙˆØ¹ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙØ¬ÙÙˆØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ¹ÙÙˆØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ«Ù’Ù„Ù Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’Ù‚ÙØµÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¬ÙÙˆØ±ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¡ÙŒ \"\nÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ´ÙÙ‰ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø°ÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ©Ù Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙŠÙØµÙÙ„Ù Ø±ÙØ­ÙÙ…ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ø·ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±Ù Ù…ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ©Ù Ø´ÙÙ‡ÙÙŠØ¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø®ÙØ·Ù’ÙˆÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙŠÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ Ø³ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ¦ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙÙÙØ¹Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙØ±ÙØ¬ÙØ§ØªÙ Ù…ÙØ«Ù’Ù„Ù Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙƒÙØ£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙØ¨ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ©Ù Ø³ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù ØµÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ±Ø§Ù‹ Ù…ÙØ­Ù’ØªÙØ³ÙØ¨Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙÙÙÙ‰ Ø¶ÙØ±ÙÙŠØ±Ø§Ù‹ Ø­ÙØ§Ø¬ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¬Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ´ÙÙ‰ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¶ÙÙŠÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØ§Ø¬ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ø·ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¡ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙÙØ§Ù‚Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¡ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ¶ÙÙ‰ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø³ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø­ÙØ§Ø¬ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¬Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ²ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙŠÙØ®ÙÙˆØ¶Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø±ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙØ±Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¹Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ±ÙØ¶Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù„ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ´Ù’ÙƒÙ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ«ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ¹Ù Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±ÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙŠÙ…Ù Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙØ¬ÙÙˆØ²Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØµÙ‘ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø·Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ±Ù’Ù‚Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ø§Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø³ÙØ¹ÙÙ‰ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙØ±ÙÙŠØ¶Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø­ÙØ§Ø¬ÙØ©Ù Ù‚ÙØ¶ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¶ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø®ÙØ±ÙØ¬Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø°ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙƒÙÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù ÙˆÙÙ„ÙØ¯ÙØªÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù\" ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø±ÙØ¬ÙÙ„ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØµÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø¨ÙØ£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙŠ ÙŠÙØ§ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ±ÙÙŠØ¶Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø£Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¸ÙÙ…Ù Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±Ø§Ù‹ Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø³ÙØ¹ÙÙ‰ ÙÙÙŠ Ø­ÙØ§Ø¬ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù†ÙØ¹ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ¬Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù ÙƒÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ±ÙØ¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ ÙÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ¬Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙØ«Ù’Ù†ÙØªÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙƒÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ±ÙØ¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¢Ø®ÙØ±ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ«Ù’Ù†ÙØªÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙƒÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ±ÙØ¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’ÙˆÙÙ†ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØºÙ’ØµÙ\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ…Ù’Ø·ÙÙ„Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø°ÙÙŠ Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¯ÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙØ¯ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø®ÙØ·ÙÙŠØ¦ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙØ´Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‚Ù Ø³ÙÙˆÙ’Ø·Ø§Ù‹ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙŠÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ’ Ø³ÙÙ„Ù’Ø·ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¬ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ±Ù Ø¬ÙØ¹ÙÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙˆÙ’Ø·Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ø«ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ù†Ø§Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù†ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø·ÙÙˆÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø³ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø°ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¹Ø§Ù‹ ÙŠÙØ³ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ·ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù†ÙØ§Ø±Ù \" Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ¦Ù’Ø³Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØµÙÙŠØ±Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØµÙ’Ø·ÙÙ†ÙØ¹Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø£ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù‹ ÙÙØ§Ù…Ù’ØªÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ø¨ÙØ·Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø«ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØªÙ ÙˆÙØ²Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ´Ù’ÙƒÙØ±Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø³ÙØ¹Ù’ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù\" Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"ÙŠÙÙ‚ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù \"Ø­ÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ®ÙÙŠÙ„Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØªÙ‘ÙØ§ØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ§Ù…Ù\" Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙØµÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙ‚Ù Ø¨ÙØµÙØ¯ÙÙ‚ÙØ©Ù ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙÙˆÙØ²Ù’Ù†Ù ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø¯ÙØ±Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù Ù…ÙØ«Ù’Ù„Ù Ø¬ÙØ¨ÙÙ„Ù Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ¯Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù†ÙØ¹ÙÙŠÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ´ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙØµÙØ¯ÙÙ‚ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ­Ù’ØªÙØ§Ø¬Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙƒÙØ£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±Ù ØµÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’Ù‚ÙØµÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¡ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØªÙ ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø³ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ ØºÙÙÙØ±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ§ ØªÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø°ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ ØªÙØ£ÙØ®Ù‘ÙØ±Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙØ¯Ù’ÙÙÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ø«ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù‚ÙØ¯ÙÙ…Ù Ù†ÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ù‚ÙÙŠØ±ÙØ§Ø·ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠØ±ÙØ§Ø·Ù Ù…ÙØ«Ù’Ù„Ù Ø¬ÙØ¨ÙÙ„Ù Ø£ÙØ­ÙØ¯Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø°ÙØ±ÙÙÙØªÙ’ Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®ÙØ´Ù’ÙŠÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù‚ÙØ·Ù’Ø±ÙØ©Ù Ù‚ÙØ·ÙØ±ÙØªÙ’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¯ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ¹ÙÙ‡Ù Ù‚ÙØµÙ’Ø±ÙŒ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‹ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙØ±Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙˆÙ’Ù‡ÙØ±Ù ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†ÙŒ Ø±ÙØ£ÙØªÙ’ ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø£ÙØ°ÙÙ†ÙŒ Ø³ÙÙ…ÙØ¹ÙØªÙ’ ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø®ÙØ·ÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨Ù Ø¨ÙØ´ÙØ±Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ´ÙÙ‰ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¯Ù ÙŠÙØ·Ù’Ù„ÙØ¨Ù ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ©Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø®ÙØ·Ù’ÙˆÙØ©Ù Ø³ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ±Ù’ÙÙØ¹Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙØ±ÙØ¬ÙØ§ØªÙ Ù…ÙØ«Ù’Ù„Ù Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ§ØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙÙƒÙ‘ÙÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø³ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙŠÙØ¹ÙÙˆØ¯ÙÙˆÙ†ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ¨ÙØ´Ù‘ÙØ±ÙÙˆÙ†ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ¤Ù’Ù†ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ†ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ ÙˆÙØ­Ù’Ø¯ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØºÙ’ÙÙØ±ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙØ«Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ°Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù Ù…ÙØ­Ù’ØªÙØ³ÙØ¨Ø§Ù‹ ÙŠÙØ±ÙÙŠØ¯Ù Ø¨ÙØ°ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙØ¬Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ø·ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø«ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ Ø´ÙÙ‡ÙÙŠØ¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ ØµÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ‚Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ¯Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø´ÙÙÙØ§Ø¹ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ Ù…ÙØ³ÙÙŠØ¡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØªÙÙŠ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤ÙØ°Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù -: Ø£ÙØ´Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø³ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØºÙ’ÙÙØ±ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¸ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ±Ù’Ø´Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙÙÙ’Ø±ÙØºÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙØ³ÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ¦ÙÙ‚Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙÙƒÙ’ØªÙØ¨Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø«ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù: Ø£ÙØ´Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙ Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙØ§ÙÙØ¸Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„ØµÙ‘ÙÙÙ‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙÙ„Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙÙƒÙ’Ø¨ÙÙŠØ±ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙˆÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ¤Ù’Ø°ÙÙŠ Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ø·ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±Ù Ù…ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ø·ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤ÙØ°Ù‘ÙÙ†ÙÙˆÙ†Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¢Ø®ÙØ±ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙˆÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙØ±ÙØ§ÙÙØ©Ù Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø£ÙØªÙÙŠÙ ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ¯ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ù…ÙØºÙ’Ù„ÙÙˆÙ„ÙØªÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†ÙÙ‚ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù…Ù ÙÙÙŠÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙØ·Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‚ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¸ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ…Ø§Ù‹ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙÙŠÙ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù†ÙØ§Ø±Ù \" Ø¬ÙÙ‡ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ¦Ù’Ø³Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØµÙÙŠØ±Ù\" \" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \"Ù„Ø§Ù ØªÙØ­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙØ±ÙÙˆØ§ Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¦Ø§Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ±Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ ØµÙØºÙØ±Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’ÙŠÙÙ†ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ØªÙØ³Ù’ØªÙÙƒÙ’Ø«ÙØ±ÙÙˆØ§ Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¦Ø§Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ¨ÙØ±Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’ÙŠÙÙ†ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„Ø§Ù ÙƒÙØ¨ÙÙŠØ±ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØºÙ’ÙÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ØµÙØºÙÙŠØ±ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¥ÙØµÙ’Ø±ÙØ§Ø±Ù\". Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø´ÙØ¹ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¨Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù ÙˆÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù Ø³ÙØ£ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø²ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¯Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø·ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ù‡ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ¯ÙÙŠØ«Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø¬ÙØ¹Ù’ÙÙØ±Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø·ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù : Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¬ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù Ù‡ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ¯ÙÙŠØ«Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ…Ù’Ù„Ø§ÙØ¡Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø®ÙØ·Ù‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø·ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù.", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/34/1/2/4968", "volume": 4, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 2, "thaqalaynSanad": "Hadith.4968 - Abu Ja'far Muhammad ibn Al-Husayn ibn Musa ibn Babawayh Al-Qummi, the jurist residing in Rayy and the author of this book (may Allah (swt) be pleased with him and grant him His satisfaction), narrated from Shu'ayb ibn Waqid, from Al-Husayn ibn Zayd, from Imam Jafar ibn Muhammad Al-Sadiq (as) from his father, Imam Muhammad ibn Ali Al-Baqir (as), from his forefathers, from Commander of the Faithful Imam Ali ibn Abi Talib (as), who said:\n", "thaqalaynMatn": "\"The Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) forbade eating while in a state of major ritual impurity (janabah)\" and said: \"It leads to poverty.\"\nHe (sw) also forbade trimming the nails with teeth, using the miswak (tooth-stick) in the bathhouse, and spitting in the mosques.\nHe (sw) forbade eating (drinking) the leftovers of a mouse and said: \"Do not make the mosques pathways; rather, pray two units of prayer in them before passing through.\"\nHe (sw) prohibited urinating under fruit-bearing trees or on public roads.\nHe (sw) forbade a person from eating with his left hand and from eating while reclining.\nHe (sw) forbade plastering graves and praying upon them.\nHe (sw) said: \"If one of you bathes in an open area, let him guard his private parts, and do not drink water from the handle of a container, for it is where dirt accumulates.\"\nHe (sw) prohibited urinating in stagnant water, saying, \"It causes the loss of intellect.\"\nHe (sw) forbade walking with only one shoe or putting on shoes while standing.\nHe (sw) forbade a man from urinating while his private parts are exposed to the sun or the moon.\nHe (sw) said: \"When you enter the place of relieving yourself, avoid facing the qiblah.'\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) forbade wailing loudly (Al-rannah) during calamities and prohibited lamentation (Al-niyahah) and listening to it.\nHe (sw) forbade women from following funeral processions.\nHe (sw) prohibited wiping off anything from the Book of Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, with saliva or writing with it.\nHe (sw) forbade a man from intentionally lying about his dreams and said: \"Allah (swt) will burden him on the Day of Judgment to tie a grain of barley, and he will not be able to do so.\"\nHe (sw) prohibited making images and said: \"Whoever creates an image, Allah (swt) will task him on the Day of Judgment to breathe life into it, and he will not be able to do so.\"\nHe (sw) forbade burning any living creature with fire.\nHe (sw) prohibited cursing the rooster and said: \"Indeed, it awakens for prayer.\"\nHe (sw) forbade a man from interfering in the sale of his Muslim brother.\nHe (sw) prohibited excessive talking during intimate relations and said: \"It results in a child being born mute.\"\nHe (sw) said: \"Do not leave garbage in your homes overnight. Take it out during the day, for it is the seat of Satan.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) said:\n\"Let none of you sleep while his hand is unwashed from grease (or impurities). If he does and something harmful happens to him from Satan, he should blame no one but himself.\"\nHe (sw) forbade a man from performing istinja (cleaning after relieving oneself) with dung or bones.\nHe (sw) forbade a woman from leaving her house without her husband's permission. If she does, every angel in the sky and everything she passes from among the jinn and humans will curse her until she returns to her home.\nHe (sw) forbade a woman from adorning herself for anyone other than her husband, saying: \"If she does so, it becomes a right upon Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, to burn her in the Fire.\"\nHe (sw) prohibited a woman from speaking to a man who is not her husband or a mahram (unmarriageable kin) more than five necessary words.\nHe (sw) forbade a woman from directly touching another woman without a cloth between them.\nHe (sw) forbade women from describing their intimate relations with their husbands to other women.\nHe (sw) prohibited a man from having intimate relations with his wife while facing the Qiblah or on a public road. He (sw) said: \"Whoever does so, upon him is the curse of Allah (swt), the angels, and all people.\"\nHe (sw) forbade a man from saying to another man, \"Marry me your sister, and I will marry you mine.\"\nHe (sw) prohibited visiting fortune-tellers and said: \"Whoever visits one and believes in them has disbelieved in what Allah (swt) revealed to Muhammad.\"\nHe (sw) forbade playing with dice, chess, drums (Al-kubah), and stringed instruments (Al-ará¹­abah, referring to the lute and oud).\nHe (sw) forbade backbiting and listening to it, as well as gossiping and listening to it. He (sw) said: \"A tale-bearer will not enter Paradise.\"\nHe (sw) forbade accepting invitations to the meals of corrupt individuals.\nHe (sw) prohibited taking false oaths.\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) said:\n\"Indeed, false oaths leave lands desolate.\"\nAnd he (sw) said: \"Whoever swears a false oath deliberately to unlawfully seize the wealth of a Muslim will meet Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, while He (swt) is angry with him - unless he repents and returns the right.\"\nHe (sw) forbade sitting at a table where alcohol is being consumed.\nHe (sw) prohibited a man from taking his wife into the bathhouse and said: \"Let none of you enter the bathhouse without wearing a waistcloth (loincloth).\"\nHe (sw) forbade conversations that lead to anything other than the remembrance of Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic.\nHe (sw) prohibited slapping the face and drinking from gold and silver vessels.\nHe (sw) forbade men from wearing silk, brocade, and fine silk (qazz), though it is permissible for women.\nHe (sw) forbade selling fruits before they ripen, meaning before they turn yellow or red.\nHe (sw) prohibited muhaqala, which is selling dates for fresh dates and raisins for grapes or similar transactions.\nHe (sw) forbade selling dice games (nard) and purchasing or serving alcohol.\nHe (as) said: \"May Allah (swt) curse alcohol, its planter, its presser, its drinker, its server, its seller, its buyer, the one who consumes its price, its carrier, and the one to whom it is carried.\"\nHe (as) also said: \"Whoever drinks it, Allah (swt) will not accept his prayer for forty days. If he dies with any of it in his stomach, it becomes a right upon Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, to make him drink from the mud of filth, which is the pus of the people of Hell and what comes out of the private parts of the adulterers. This mixture will collect in the cauldrons of Hell, and the people of Hell will drink it, causing their insides and skins to melt.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) forbade consuming usury, bearing false witness, and writing contracts involving usury.\nHe (sw) said: \"Indeed, Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, has cursed the one who consumes usury, the one who pays it, the one who records it, and its two witnesses.\"\nHe (sw) forbade combining a sale with a loan and prohibited two sales in one transaction.\nHe (sw) forbade selling what one does not possess and selling what has not been guaranteed.\nHe (sw) prohibited shaking hands with a non-Muslim under a protection pact (dhimmi).\nHe (sw) forbade reciting poetry or announcing lost items in the mosque.\nHe (sw) prohibited drawing swords in the mosque.\nHe (sw) forbade striking animals on their faces.\nHe (sw) prohibited a man from looking at the private parts of his Muslim brother and said:\n\"Whoever intentionally looks at the private parts of his Muslim brother, seventy thousand angels will curse him.\"\nHe (sw) forbade a woman from looking at the private parts of another woman.\nHe (sw) prohibited blowing into food or drink and blowing on the place of prostration.\nHe (sw) forbade praying in graveyards, on pathways, at mills, in valleys, at camel enclosures, and on the roof of the Kaaba.\nHe (sw) prohibited killing bees and branding animals on their faces.\nHe (sw) forbade swearing an oath by anything other than Allah (swt) and said:\n\"Whoever swears by anything other than Allah (swt) is not connected to Allah (swt) in any way.\"\nHe (sw) prohibited swearing by a chapter (Surah) of the Book of Allah (swt) and said:\n\"Whoever swears by a Surah from the Book of Allah (swt), for every verse in it, there is an expiation for the oath. Whoever wishes may fulfill it, and whoever wishes may break it.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) forbade a man from saying to another, \"No, by your life\" or \"by the life of so-and-so.\"\nHe (sw) prohibited a man from sitting in the mosque while in a state of major ritual impurity (janabah).\nHe (sw) forbade exposing oneself naked during the night or day.\nHe (sw) prohibited cupping (hijama) on Wednesdays and Fridays.\nHe (sw) forbade speaking while the Imam is delivering the Friday sermon and said: \"Whoever does so has engaged in idle talk, and whoever engages in idle talk, his Friday prayer is void.\"\nHe (sw) prohibited wearing rings made of brass or iron and forbade engraving images of living creatures on rings.\nHe (sw) forbade performing prayer at sunrise, sunset, and when the sun is at its zenith.\nHe (sw) prohibited fasting on six specific days: the Day of Eid Al-Fitr, the Day of Doubt (the 30th of Sha'ban when uncertain if Ramadan has begun), the Day of Eid Al-Adha, and the Days of Tashreeq (the three days following Eid Al-Adha).\nHe (sw) forbade drinking water in the manner of animals and said: \"Drink with your hands, for it is the best of your vessels.\"\nHe (sw) prohibited spitting into a well from which water is drawn for drinking.\nHe (sw) forbade hiring a worker without first agreeing on his wage.\nHe (sw) prohibited severing ties and said: \"Whoever must do so should not abandon his brother for more than three days. Whoever abandons his brother for more than that, the Fire will be more deserving of him.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) forbade selling gold for gold with any increase, except when it is weight for weight.\nHe (sw) prohibited excessive praise and said: \"Throw dust in the faces of those who excessively praise others.\"\nHe (sw) also said: \"Whoever supports the argument of a wrongdoer or assists him, when the Angel of Death comes to him, it will be said to him: 'Receive the glad tidings of Allah's (swt) curse and the Fire of Hell, and what a terrible destination!'\"\nHe (sw) said: \"Whoever praises a tyrannical ruler or humbles himself before him out of greed will be his companion in the Fire.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) also said: \"Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, says: 'Do not incline towards the wrongdoers, lest the Fire touch you.'\"\nHe (sw) said: \"Whoever supports an oppressor in his oppression will be the companion of Haman (the advisor of Pharaoh) in Hell. And whoever builds a structure for show and reputation will be burdened with it on the Day of Judgment, carried from the seventh layer of the earth while it blazes with fire. It will then be placed around his neck and he will be thrown into the Fire, where nothing will stop him from reaching its depths unless he repents.\"\nIt was asked: \"O' Messenger of Allah (swt), how does one build (for) show and reputation?\"\nHe (sw) replied: \"By constructing more than what is necessary for him, to boast over his neighbours and to show off to his brothers.\"\nHe (sw) also said: \"Whoever wrongs a worker by withholding his due wages, Allah (swt) will nullify his deeds and forbid him from the fragrance of Paradise, and indeed, its fragrance is detected from a distance of five hundred years.\"\n\"Whoever betrays his neighbour over a handspan of land, Allah (swt) will place it as a collar around his neck from the lowest depths of the earth until he meets Allah (swt) on the Day of Judgment, unless he repents and turns back.\"\n\"Beware! Whoever learns the Qur'an and then forgets it will meet Allah (swt) on the Day of Judgment shackled, and for every verse he forgot, Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, will assign a snake as his companion leading him to Hell, unless Allah (swt) forgives him.\"\nHe (sw) also said: \"Whoever recites the Qur'an and then drinks alcohol or prefers the love of this world and its adornments over it, the wrath of Allah (swt) becomes obligatory upon him, unless he repents. Beware! If he dies without repenting, the Qur'an will argue against him on the Day of Judgment and will not leave him until it defeats him.\"\n\"Beware! Whoever commits adultery with a Muslim woman, or a Jewish, Christian, or Magian woman, whether free or a slave, and does not repent before death, Allah (swt) will open for him in his grave three hundred doors from which snakes, scorpions, and the serpents of the Fire will enter, burning him until the Day of Judgment. When he is resurrected from his grave, people will be harmed by the stench of his odor, and he will be recognized by this and his evil deeds in the worldly life until he is commanded to be thrown into the Fire.\"\n\"Beware! Indeed, Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, has forbidden what is unlawful and set limits. No one is more protective (ghayoor) than Allah (swt), and out of His (swt) protectiveness, He (swt) has forbidden immoralities.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) forbade a man from peeking into his neighbor's house and said:\n\"Whoever intentionally looks at the private parts of his Muslim brother or at those not permissible for him to see, Allah (swt) the Exalted will place him among the hypocrites who used to search for people's faults. He will not leave this world until Allah (swt) disgraces him - unless he repents.\"\nHe (sw) also said: \"Whoever is not content with what Allah (swt) has allotted for him in sustenance, complains about it, does not show patience, and does not seek reward from Allah (swt), none of his good deeds will be accepted, and he will meet Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, while He (swt) is angry with him - unless he repents.\"\nHe (sw) forbade arrogance in walking and said: \"Whoever wears a garment and walks arrogantly in it, Allah (swt) will cause him to sink from the edge of Hell, and he will be the companion of Qarun (Korah), for he was the first to act arrogantly, and Allah (swt) caused the earth to swallow him and his home. Whoever behaves arrogantly has indeed challenged Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, in His (swt) supreme authority.\"\nHe (sw) also said: \"Whoever wrongs a woman regarding her dowry is considered by Allah (swt) as an adulterer. Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, will say to him on the Day of Judgment:\n'My servant, I married you to My maidservant on My covenant, but you did not fulfill My covenant and wronged My maidservant.' Her due will be taken from his good deeds and given to her according to what she is owed. If he has no more good deeds, he will be commanded to enter the Fire for breaking the covenant, for 'Indeed, the covenant will be questioned about.'\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) forbade concealing testimony and said: \"Whoever conceals it, Allah (swt) will make him eat his own flesh in front of all creation. This is in accordance with Allah's (swt) saying:\n'And do not conceal testimony, for whoever conceals it - his heart is sinful, and Allah (swt) is Knowing of what you do.'\" (Surah Al-Baqarah 2:283)\nHe (sw) also said: \"Whoever harms his neighbour, Allah (swt) will forbid him from the fragrance of Paradise, 'and his abode will be Hell, and what a miserable destination.'\nWhoever neglects the rights of his neighbour is not from us.\nArchangel Jibril (as) continued to advise me regarding the neighbour until I thought he would make him an heir.\nHe (Jibril (as)) kept advising me about slaves until I thought a time would be set when they would automatically be freed.\nHe (Jibril (as)) kept advising me about the use of the toothstick (siwak) until I thought it would be made obligatory.\nHe (Jibril (as)) kept advising me about praying at night until I thought the best of my nation would never sleep.\"\n\"Beware! Whoever belittles a poor Muslim has belittled the right of Allah (swt), and Allah (swt) will belittle him on the Day of Judgment unless he repents.\"\nHe (sw) also said: \"Whoever honors a poor Muslim will meet Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, on the Day of Judgment while He (swt) is pleased with him.\"\n\"Whoever is faced with an indecent act or desire and refrains from it out of fear of Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, Allah (swt) will forbid the Fire upon him, grant him safety from the greatest terror, and fulfill for him what He (swt) promised in His Book in His (swt) saying:\n'But for he who has feared the standing before his Lord (azj) are two gardens.'\"\n(Surah Ar-Rahman 55:46)\n\"Beware! Whoever is presented with the choice between this world and the Hereafter and chooses the world over the Hereafter will meet Allah (swt) on the Day of Judgment without a single good deed to shield him from the Fire. But whoever chooses the Hereafter over this world and abandons worldly desires, Allah (swt) will be pleased with him and will forgive his past misdeeds.\"\n\"Whoever fills his eyes with what is forbidden, Allah (swt) will fill his eyes with fire on the Day of Judgment - unless he repents and turns back.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt), peace be upon him and his family, also said:\n\"Whoever shakes hands with a woman who is unlawful for him has indeed incurred the wrath of Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic. And whoever embraces a forbidden woman will be chained with a shackle of fire alongside a devil, and both will be cast into the Fire.\"\n\"Whoever cheats a Muslim in buying or selling is not from us and will be resurrected on the Day of Judgment with the Jews, for they are the most deceitful people towards Muslims.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) forbade anyone from withholding necessary items (ma'oon) from his neighbour and said:\n\"Whoever withholds useful items from his neighbour, Allah (swt) will withhold His (swt) goodness from him on the Day of Judgment and will leave him to his own self. And whoever is left to his own self - how miserable will be his state!\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt), peace be upon him and his family, said:\n\"Any woman who harms her husband with her tongue, Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, will not accept any obligatory or voluntary acts of worship from her until she pleases him. Even if she fasts during the day, prays during the night, frees slaves, and spends in the way of Allah (swt) by supporting horses for jihad, she will still be among the first to enter the Fire - unless she seeks his satisfaction. Likewise, the same applies to a man if he wrongs his wife.\"\n\"Beware! Whoever slaps the cheek or face of a Muslim, Allah (swt) will scatter his bones on the Day of Judgment, and he will be resurrected in chains until he is thrown into Hell - unless he repents.\"\n\"Whoever sleeps with malice in his heart towards his Muslim brother, he sleeps under the wrath of Allah (swt) and will awaken in the same state until he repents.\"\nHe (sw) also forbade backbiting and said: \"Whoever backbites a Muslim, his fast becomes void, his ablution is invalidated, and he will come on the Day of Judgment with a stench emanating from his mouth more foul than that of a decaying corpse, causing discomfort to the people at the gathering. If he dies before repenting, he dies considering lawful what Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, has forbidden.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt), peace be upon him and his family, said:\n\"Whoever suppresses his anger while being capable of acting upon it and chooses patience, Allah (swt) will grant him the reward of a martyr.\"\n\"Beware! Whoever defends his brother in his absence when he hears someone backbiting him in a gathering, Allah (swt) will turn away from him a thousand doors of harm in this world and the Hereafter. But if he does not defend him while being capable of doing so, he will bear the sin of backbiting seventy times.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) also forbade betrayal and said:\n\"Whoever betrays a trust in this world and does not return it to its rightful owner, then death overtakes him, he will die outside of my faith and will meet Allah (swt) while He is angry with him.\"\nHe (sw) further said: \"Whoever gives false testimony against someone will be hung by his tongue among the hypocrites in the lowest depths of Hell.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt), peace be upon him and his family, said: \"Whoever purchases something that was acquired through betrayal, knowing its origin, is like the one who committed the betrayal.\"\n\"Whoever withholds a rightful due from his Muslim brother, Allah (swt) will deprive him of the blessings of sustenance - unless he repents.\"\n\"Beware! Whoever hears of an indecent act and spreads it is like the one who committed it.\"\n\"Whoever's Muslim brother is in need of a loan and he has the means but refuses to help, Allah (swt) will forbid him from the fragrance of Paradise.\"\n\"Beware! Whoever patiently endures the bad character of his wife and seeks reward for it, Allah (swt) will grant him the reward of the grateful ones.\"\n\"Beware! Any woman who does not treat her husband kindly and burdens him with what he cannot bear or handle, Allah (swt) will not accept any of her good deeds, and she will meet Allah (swt) while He is angry with her.\"\n\"Beware! Whoever honors his Muslim brother is indeed honoring Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) also forbade a man from leading a group in prayer without their permission and said:\n\"Whoever leads a group in prayer with their permission, and they are pleased with him, and he is moderate in leading them - perfecting his prayer with proper standing, recitation, bowing, prostration, and sitting - will receive a reward equal to theirs, without their reward being diminished in the least.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) said:\n\"Whoever goes to visit a relative, using himself and his wealth to maintain family ties, Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, will grant him the reward of one hundred martyrs. For every step he takes, he will receive forty thousand good deeds, forty thousand sins will be erased from him, and his rank will be elevated by forty thousand degrees. It will be as if he worshiped Allah (swt) for one hundred years with patience and seeking reward.\"\n\"Whoever fulfills the need of a blind person from the needs of this world and walks with him until Allah (swt) fulfills his need, Allah (swt) will grant him freedom from hypocrisy and freedom from the Fire, fulfill seventy of his worldly needs, and he will continue to be immersed in Allah's (swt) mercy until he returns.\"\n\"Whoever falls ill for a day and night and does not complain to his visitors, Allah (swt) will raise him on the Day of Judgment with His close friend, Ibrahim, the Friend of the Most Merciful (as), allowing him to cross the bridge (Sirat) like a flashing lightning bolt.\"\n\"Whoever strives to fulfill the need of a sick person - whether he completes it or not - will leave his sins as pure as the day his mother gave birth to him.\"\nA man from the Ansar said: \"May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, O' Messenger of Allah (swt)! If the sick person is from his own household, isn't that more rewarding when he strives to fulfill their need?\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) replied: \"Yes! Indeed, whoever relieves a believer of a worldly hardship, Allah (swt) will relieve him of seventy-two hardships in the Hereafter and seventy-two hardships in this world, the least of which is Abdominal pain.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) said:\n\"Whoever delays giving the due right to someone while being capable of fulfilling it, every day that passes upon him will be recorded as the sin of a tax collector (oppressor).\"\n\"Beware! Whoever hangs a whip before a tyrannical ruler (to intimidate others), Allah (swt) will turn that whip into a serpent of fire on the Day of Judgment, seventy cubits long, which Allah (swt) will unleash upon him in the Fire of Hell - and what a terrible destination!\"\n\"Whoever does a good deed for his brother but then reminds him of it (to boast), Allah (swt) will nullify his good deed, record his sin, and will not reward him for his effort.\"\nThen he (peace be upon him and his family) said:\n\"Allah (swt), the Mighty and Majestic, says: 'I have forbidden Paradise to the one who reminds others of his favors, the miser, and the tale-bearer (slanderer).'\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) said:\n\"Indeed, whoever gives charity, for every dirham he donates, he will receive in return the equivalent of Mount Uhud from the blessings of Paradise. And whoever personally delivers charity to a needy person will have the same reward as the giver, without the giver's reward being diminished in the slightest.\"\n\"Whoever offers the funeral prayer (Salat Al-Janazah) for a deceased person, seventy thousand angels will pray for him, and Allah (swt) will forgive his past and future sins. If he remains until the deceased is buried and the earth is placed over him, for every step he takes, he will earn a qirat of reward, and one qirat is like Mount Uhud.\"\n\"Whoever sheds tears out of fear of Allah (swt), for every drop of his tears, Allah (swt) will build for him a palace in Paradise adorned with pearls and jewels, filled with what no eye has seen, no ear has heard, and no mind has imagined.\"\n\"Whoever walks to the mosque seeking to join the congregation, for every step he takes, seventy thousand good deeds will be recorded for him, and his rank will be raised by the same number. If he dies in this state, Allah (swt) will appoint seventy thousand angels to visit him in his grave, to give him glad tidings, comfort him in his loneliness, and seek forgiveness for him until he is resurrected.\"\n\"Whoever calls the Adhan (the call to prayer) sincerely, seeking Allah's (swt) pleasure, Allah (swt) will reward him with the reward of forty thousand martyrs and forty thousand truthful ones (siddeeqin), and through his intercession, forty thousand sinners from my nation will enter Paradise.\"\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) said:\n\"Whoever says: 'I bear witness that there is no God but Allah (swt),' seventy thousand angels will send blessings upon him and seek forgiveness for him. On the Day of Judgment, he will be under the shade of the Throne until Allah (swt) completes the reckoning of all creation. And whoever says: 'I bear witness that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah (swt),' forty thousand angels will write the reward for his statement.\"\n\"Whoever maintains the first row (in prayer) and safeguards the first Takbir (opening declaration of prayer) without harming any Muslim, Allah (swt) will grant him the reward equal to that of the callers to prayer (Mu'adhins) in this world and the hereafter.\"\n\"Whoever takes responsibility over a group of people (leadership) will be brought on the Day of Judgment with his hands chained to his neck. If he governed them according to Allah's (swt) command, Allah (swt) will release him. But if he ruled unjustly, he will be cast into the Fire of Hell, and what an evil destination it is.\"\nThe Prophet (peace be upon him and his family) also said: \"Do not belittle any act of evil, even if it seems small in your eyes, and do not think lightly of any act of goodness, even if it appears great in your eyes. For there is no major sin with repentance, and no minor sin with persistence.\"\nShuayb ibn Waqid said: \"I asked Husayn ibn Zayd about the length of this narration, and he replied: ' Imam Jafar ibn Muhammad Al-Sadiq (as) ibn Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Al-Husayn ibn Ali ibn Abi Talib (as) narrated to me that Imam (as) compiled this narration from the book that was dictated by the Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) and written in the handwriting of Imam Ali ibn Abi Talib (as).'\"", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 182, "bookId": "Man-La-Yahduruh-al-Faqih-Volume-4-Saduq", "book": "Man LÄ Yaá¸¥á¸uruh al-FaqÄ«h", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "Chapter on Blood Money for the Limbs and Joints, and Blood Money for the Nutfah (sperm), Alaqah (clinging clot), Mudghah (embryonic lump), Bones, and the Soul", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bab Ul Qaim Publications", "englishText": "Hadith.5150 - Al-Hasan ibn Ali ibn Fadhal narrated from Zharif ibn Nasih from Abdullah ibn Ayyub, who said Al-Husayn Al-Rawwasi narrated to me from Ibn Abi Umayr, the physician, who said: I presented this narration to Abu Abdullah (as), and Imam(as) said:\n\"Yes, it is true. Indeed, the Commander of the Faithful (as) used to instruct his officials with this.\"\nHe said:\n\"Imam (as) gave a ruling that for every bone that contains marrow, there is a specified obligatory compensation if it is broken and healed without any defect or flaw.\nImam (as) divided the obligatory blood money (diyyah) into six parts and established for wounds, the fetus, the eyelashes, paralysis, limbs, and the thumb, assigning six categories for each.\nFetus\nHe set the blood money for a fetus at one hundred dinars.\nFor the sperm of a man until it becomes a fetus, he set five parts, and when it becomes a fetus before the soul enters it, he set it at one hundred dinars.\nHe allocated twenty dinars for the sperm drop (nutfah), which refers to a man discharging with his wife who does not desire it. Thus, the Commander of the Faithful (as) set this ruling for it.\"\nHe (as) set the compensation for the nutfah (sperm drop) at twenty dinars, which is equivalent to one-fifth (khumus), and for the clot of blood (alaqah), he set it at two-fifths of that, forty dinars. This ruling also applies if a woman is struck or harmed and subsequently miscarries.\n- For the muá¸ghah (chewed-like lump of flesh), he established sixty dinars if she also miscarried under similar circumstances.\n- For the bone stage (idham), he set eighty dinars if the woman miscarried.\n- For the fully formed fetus (janin), he set one hundred dinars if an enemy attacked them, causing the women to miscarry. He obligated this compensation upon the women from the responsible family (aqilah) accordingly.\nIf a child is born alive and cries (istihlal, the first cry), and they were attacked during the night, leading to the killing of the children, the compensation for each male child is one thousand dinars, and for each female child, it is calculated accordingly at five hundred dinars.\nAs for a woman who is killed while pregnant with a fully formed fetus, and the fetus does not miscarry, and it is unknown whether the fetus is male or female, and whether it died before or after the mother, then the compensation for the fetus is half of the male blood money and half of the female blood money, while the woman's full blood money remains obligatory.\nHe (as) also ruled regarding a man who discharges outside his wife during intercourse without her consent. In this case, he imposed half of one-fifth of the fetus's blood money, amounting to ten dinars.\nIf he discharges inside her without her consent, the compensation is twenty dinars.\nHe established retaliation (qisas) for injuries and the related compensation according to the extent of the blood money, which is one hundred dinars.\nHe ruled on the blood money for fetal injuries proportionally from the scale of one hundred dinars, corresponding to what applies to the injuries of a man or a woman in full.\nSensory Organs and Paralysis\nHe (as) also gave rulings concerning the body.\nHe (as) established six obligatory compensations: life (nafs), vision (baá¹£ar), hearing (samÊ¿), speech (kalam), impairment of voice due to nasal sound (ghanan) or hoarseness (bahah), and paralysis of the hands and legs.\nHe aligned these rulings with the same principles as the previous laws. Additionally, he prescribed the practice of qasamah (oath-taking) for each of these matters, proportional to the amount of blood money owed.\nFor intentional murder, qasamah involves fifty men, and for accidental killing, twenty-five men, corresponding to the blood money of one thousand dinars for life.\nFor wounds requiring qasamah, six people are involved, and anything less follows this calculation.\nThe qasamah applies to life, hearing, vision, intellect, voice due to hoarseness or harshness, and the loss of hands and legs. These are the six major parts of a person.\nDiyyah - Blood Money\nThe blood money for;\n- a life is one thousand dinars,\n- for the Nose (if completely severed) one thousand dinars,\n- for the complete Total loss of voice (ghanan or bahah) one thousand dinars,\n- for paralysis of both hands one thousand dinars,\n- for the total loss of hearing one thousand dinars,\n- for the complete loss of vision one thousand dinars,\n- for loss of both legs together one thousand dinars,\n- for the Total removal of both lips one thousand dinars,\n- for a severe bent hunchback of the back thousand dinars,\n- for the Complete severance of the male genital organ one thousand dinars,\n- for the complete removal of the tongue one thousand dinars,\n- for Loss of both testicles one thousand dinars.\nInjuries; amputation, fractures, cracks, depressions, open wounds (muá¸ihah), bleeding wounds (damiyah), dislocation of bones, and deep wounds (naqibah)\nHe (as) also established the compensation for injuries to all body parts - whether on the head, face, or the rest of the body - including the senses of hearing, vision, and voice.\nHe (as) also established rulings for the intellect (Aql), the hands, and the legs concerning cases of amputation, fractures, cracks, depressions, open wounds (muá¸ihah), bleeding wounds (damiyah), dislocation of bones, and deep wounds (naqibah).\nIf a bone is broken and heals without any deformity or defect and without any bone being displaced, its compensation is clearly defined.\nIn the case of an open wound (muá¸ihah) where the bone is exposed but not displaced, both the compensation for the fracture and the open wound are due.\nFor every bone that is broken, there is a set compensation, and for the dislocation of bones, half of the compensation for a fracture is due.\nThe compensation for a visible wound (mudihah) is one-fourth of the compensation for a fracture, particularly for those body parts covered by clothing, except for the two forearm bones (qaá¹£abatay Al-saÊ¿id) and the fingers.\nFor an ulcer (qarhah) that does not heal, the compensation is one-third of the blood money of the bone where the ulcer is located.\nVision\nIf a man suffers an injury to one of his eyes, its compensation is measured by placing an eggshell over the injured eye and determining the range of vision of the healthy eye. Then, the healthy eye is covered, and the range of vision of the injured eye is assessed. Compensation is calculated based on this comparison.\nThe practice of qasamah (oath-taking) applies in these six categories, involving six individuals according to the degree of injury to the eye.\n- If one-sixth of the vision is lost, the individual alone swears an oath and receives the compensation.\n- If one-third of the vision is lost, he and another man swear and receive the compensation.\n- If half of the vision is lost, he and two other men swear.\n- If two-thirds of the vision is lost, he and three other men swear.\n- If four-fifths of his vision was lost, he would swear an oath along with four other men.\n- If all of his vision was lost, he would swear an oath along with five other men.\nThis was the ruling of qasamah (oath-taking) in the matter of the eye.\nHe (as) also ruled that if someone had no one to swear an oath with him and he was not trusted regarding the extent of his vision loss, the number of oaths he would take would be increased.\n- If one-sixth of his vision was lost, he would swear once;\n- if one-third, he would swear twice;\n- if half, he would swear three times;\n- if two-thirds, he would swear four times;\n- if five-sixths, he would swear five times;\n- and if all of his vision was lost, he would swear six times, after which he would be granted compensation.\nHowever, if he refused to swear, he would only be granted compensation corresponding to what he had sworn for and was trusted upon.\nThe governor (wali) would assist in this matter by investigating, questioning, and verifying in cases of retaliation (qisas), legal punishments (hudud), and equivalent retribution (qawad).\nHearing\nIf a person suffered any harm to his hearing, a similar method would be applied. An object would be used to measure the extent of his hearing loss, and compensation would be determined accordingly. If all of his hearing was lost, it would be handled in the same manner.\nIf there was suspicion of dishonesty, the individual would be left alone until he was caught off-guard, then someone would call out to him. If he responded, his opponents would bring the case back to the judge. The judge would act based on his judgment and could reduce part of the compensation taken.\nThigh or Upper Arm\nIf the damage was in the thigh (fakhidh) or upper arm (Aá¸ud), it would be measured with a thread by comparing the healthy leg or arm to the injured one to determine the extent of the loss. If the injury was to the shin (saq) or forearm (saÊ¿id), the comparison would be made using the thigh or upper arm.\nThe judge would assess the extent of the injury to the thigh.\nTemple\nHe (as) ruled that if a man sustained an Injury to the Temple (á¹¢udgh), causing him to be unable to turn his head except by shifting his entire body, half of the full blood money (diyyah) was due, which is five hundred dinars. If the injury was less severe, the compensation would be calculated accordingly.\nUpper Eyelid\nHe (as) ruled that if the Upper Eyelid (Shufr Al-Ayn Al-Ala) was injured and split, its compensation was one-third of the blood money for the eye, amounting to one hundred sixty-six and two-thirds dinars.\nLower Eyelid\nIf the Lower Eyelid (Shufr Al-Ayn Al-Asfal) was injured, its compensation was half of the blood money for the eye, which is two hundred fifty dinars.\nEyebrow\nIf the eyebrow (Al-hajib) was injured and all its hair was lost, the compensation was half of the blood money for the eye, amounting to two hundred fifty dinars. For any partial damage, the compensation would be calculated proportionally.\nNasal Cartilage\nIf the Nasal Cartilage (Rawthah Al-Anf) of the nose was cut off, the compensation was five hundred dinars, which is half of the full blood money.\nThe compiler of this book (may Allah (swt) have mercy on him) explained that the rawthah is the soft, flexible part of the nose.\nNose\nIf there was a penetrating wound in the Nose (Nafidhah) that could not heal, caused by an arrow or spear, the compensation was three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\nHowever, if the wound healed completely, the compensation was one-fifth of the blood money for the rawthah of the nose, which is one hundred dinars, with proportional compensation for lesser injuries.\nIf the penetrating wound affected one nostril and extended to the nasal septum (khayshoom), the divider between the nostrils, the compensation was one-tenth of the blood money for the rawthah, which is fifty dinars because the septum represents half.\nIf a projectile passed through one nostril, the septum, and exited through the other nostril, the compensation was sixty-six dinars.\nUpper Lip\nIf the Upper Lip (Al-Shafah Al-Ulya) was completely cut off, its compensation was half of the full blood money, amounting to five hundred dinars.\nFor any portion that was cut, the compensation would be calculated proportionally.\nIf the upper lip was split and the teeth became visible but the wound healed and closed, the compensation for the injury was one-fifth of the blood money for the lip, which is one hundred dinars. The compensation for any portion of it would be determined accordingly.\nIf the lip was split and became severely disfigured, its compensation was one hundred sixty-six and two-thirds dinars.\nThe compiler of this book (may Allah (swt) have mercy on him) explained that shatar refers to the splitting of the lip from its lower part, either naturally or due to an injury. A lip in such a condition is referred to as shafah shatraa.\nLower Lip\nIf the Lower Lip (Al-Shafah Al-Sufla) was completely cut off, its compensation was two-thirds of the full blood money, amounting to six hundred sixty-six and two-thirds dinars.\nFor any part of it that was cut, the compensation would be calculated proportionally.\nIf it was split, exposing the teeth, and then healed and closed, the compensation was one hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\nIf the injury caused severe and ugly disfigurement, the compensation was three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\nI asked Abu Jafar Imam Muhammad ibn Ali Al-Baqir (as) about this, and he said: \"It has reached us that the Commander of the Faithful (as) favored the lower lip in compensation because it holds water and food along with the teeth. For this reason, he gave it greater compensation in his rulings.\"\nCheek\nIf there was a penetrating wound in the Cheek (Al-Khadd) that exposed the inside of the mouth, its compensation was one hundred dinars.\nIf the wound healed but left a clear and severe disfigurement, the compensation was fifty dinars.\nIf both cheeks had penetrating wounds, the compensation was one hundred dinars, which is half the compensation for a wound that exposes the mouth.\nWounds with Blades or Arrows\nIf a sharp object, like an arrowhead, became lodged in the bone and penetrated to the palate, the compensation was one hundred fifty dinars - fifty dinars for the visible wound (mudihah) and the rest for the deeper injury.\nIf it was a deep wound (naqibah) that did not fully penetrate, the compensation was one hundred dinars.\nFor any visible wound (mudihah) on the face, the compensation was fifty dinars.\nIf this wound caused disfigurement, the compensation for the disfigurement was one-fourth of the blood money for the visible wound.\nIf there was a wound that did not expose the bone but healed, leaving a scar on the cheeks, the compensation was ten dinars.\nHead and Skull Injuries\nIf there was a fracture (á¹£adÊ¿) in the face, the compensation was eighty dinars.\nIf a piece of flesh fell off without exposing the bone, about the size of a dirham or larger, the compensation was thirty dinars.\nFor a wound that exposed the bone (mudihah) on the body, the compensation was forty dinars, and for the same injury on the head, it was fifty dinars.\nIf the bone was displaced due to the injury, the compensation was one hundred fifty dinars.\nIf there was a penetrating skull wound (naqibah) reaching the brain, known as ma'mumah, and the compensation was one-third of the full blood money, amounting to three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\nTeeth Injuries\nFor each tooth that was lost, the compensation was fifty dinars, and all teeth were treated equally in compensation;\n- the compensation for the central incisor (thaniyyah) was set at fifty dinars.\n- the compensation for the lateral incisor (rabaÊ¿iyyah) was forty dinars,\n- for the canine tooth (nawb) it was thirty dinars,\n- and for the molar tooth (dars) it was twenty-five dinars.\n- If a tooth turned black within a year but did not fall out, its compensation was equal to that of a fallen tooth, which is fifty dinars.\n- If the tooth was cracked but did not fall out, its compensation was twenty-five dinars.\n- If part of it broke, the compensation was calculated proportionally from the fifty dinars.\n- If the tooth later fell out while it was blackened, the compensation was twenty-five dinars.\n- If it was cracked while blackened, the compensation was twelve and a half dinars.\n- For any portion that broke off, the compensation was calculated proportionally from the twenty-five dinars.\nCollarbone (Tarquwah) Injuries\nRegarding the collarbone (tarquwah);\n- if it was broken and healed without any deformity or defect, the compensation was forty dinars.\n- If it was fractured, the compensation was four-fifths of the full compensation for its break, which is thirty-two dinars.\n- If there was a visible wound (mudihah) on it, the compensation was twenty-five dinars, which is five-eighths of its full compensation for a break.\n- If the bone was displaced, the compensation was half the blood money for its break, amounting to twenty dinars.\n- If it was deeply wounded (naqibah), the compensation was one-fourth of the blood money for its break, totaling ten dinars.\nShoulder (Mankib) Injuries\nThe compensation for a broken shoulder (mankib) was set at one-fifth of the blood money for the hand, amounting to one hundred dinars.\n- If there was a fracture (á¹£adÊ¿) in the shoulder, the compensation was four-fifths of the compensation for its break, which is eighty dinars.\n- If there was a visible wound (muá¸ihah), the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, totaling twenty-five dinars.\n- If the bones were displaced, the compensation was one hundred seventy-five dinars, divided as follows: one hundred dinars for the break, fifty dinars for the displacement of the bones, and twenty-five dinars for the visible wound.\n- If there was a deep wound (naqibah), the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for the break, which is twenty-five dinars.\n- If the shoulder was crushed, resulting in deformity, the compensation was one-third of the full blood money for life, amounting to three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- If it was merely loosened (fukk), the compensation was thirty dinars.\nUpper Arm (Adud) Injuries\nFor the upper arm (Adud);\n- if it was broken and healed without deformity or defect, the compensation was one-fifth of the blood money for the hand, totaling one hundred dinars.\n- For a visible wound on the upper arm, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, amounting to twenty-five dinars.\n- If the bones were displaced, the compensation was half of the compensation for its break, which is fifty dinars.\n- For a deep wound (naqibah), the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, equaling twenty-five dinars.\nElbow (Mirfaq) Injuries\nFor the elbow (mirfaq);\n- if it was broken and healed without any deformity or defect, the compensation was one hundred dinars, which is one-fifth of the blood money for the hand.\n- If it was fractured, the compensation was four-fifths of the compensation for its break, totaling eighty dinars.\n- If there was a visible wound, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, amounting to twenty-five dinars.\n- If the bones of the elbow (mirfaq) were displaced, the total compensation would be one hundred seventy-five dinars: one hundred dinars for the fracture, fifty dinars for the displacement of the bones, and twenty-five dinars for the visible wound (muá¸ihah).\n- If there was a deep wound (naqibah) in the elbow, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, amounting to twenty-five dinars.\n- If the elbow was crushed, resulting in deformity, the compensation was one-third of the full blood money, which is three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- If it was merely loosened (fukk), the compensation was thirty dinars.\nThe same rulings apply to the other elbow without distinction.\nForearm (SaÊ¿id) Injuries\nFor the forearm (saÊ¿id);\n- if it was broken and healed without any deformity or defect, the compensation was one-third of the full blood money, amounting to three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- If one of the two forearm bones (qasabatayn) was broken, the compensation was one-fifth of the blood money for the hand, totaling one hundred dinars.\n- If one of the two wrist bones (zandan) was fractured, the compensation was fifty dinars, and if both were fractured, it was one hundred dinars.\n- If one of the forearm bones was cracked, the compensation was four-fifths of the compensation for its break, totaling forty dinars.\n- For a visible wound, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, amounting to twenty-five dinars.\n- If the bones were displaced, the compensation was one hundred dinars, equaling one-fifth of the blood money for the hand.\n- If it was a deep wound (naqibah), the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, totaling twenty-five dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound (naqb), the compensation was half of the compensation for a visible wound, amounting to twelve and a half dinars.\n- The compensation for a deep penetrating wound (nafidhah) in the forearm was fifty dinars.\n- If this injury developed into a chronic ulcer that did not heal, the compensation was one-third of the blood money for the forearm, amounting to thirty-three and one-third dinars.
