A lip in such a condition is referred to as shafah shatraa.\nLower Lip\nIf the Lower Lip (Al-Shafah Al-Sufla) was completely cut off, its compensation was two-thirds of the full blood money, amounting to six hundred sixty-six and two-thirds dinars.\nFor any part of it that was cut, the compensation would be calculated proportionally.\nIf it was split, exposing the teeth, and then healed and closed, the compensation was one hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\nIf the injury caused severe and ugly disfigurement, the compensation was three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\nI asked Abu Jafar Imam Muhammad ibn Ali Al-Baqir (as) about this, and he said: \"It has reached us that the Commander of the Faithful (as) favored the lower lip in compensation because it holds water and food along with the teeth. For this reason, he gave it greater compensation in his rulings.\"\nCheek\nIf there was a penetrating wound in the Cheek (Al-Khadd) that exposed the inside of the mouth, its compensation was one hundred dinars.\nIf the wound healed but left a clear and severe disfigurement, the compensation was fifty dinars.\nIf both cheeks had penetrating wounds, the compensation was one hundred dinars, which is half the compensation for a wound that exposes the mouth.\nWounds with Blades or Arrows\nIf a sharp object, like an arrowhead, became lodged in the bone and penetrated to the palate, the compensation was one hundred fifty dinars - fifty dinars for the visible wound (mudihah) and the rest for the deeper injury.\nIf it was a deep wound (naqibah) that did not fully penetrate, the compensation was one hundred dinars.\nFor any visible wound (mudihah) on the face, the compensation was fifty dinars.\nIf this wound caused disfigurement, the compensation for the disfigurement was one-fourth of the blood money for the visible wound.\nIf there was a wound that did not expose the bone but healed, leaving a scar on the cheeks, the compensation was ten dinars.\nHead and Skull Injuries\nIf there was a fracture (á¹£adÊ¿) in the face, the compensation was eighty dinars.\nIf a piece of flesh fell off without exposing the bone, about the size of a dirham or larger, the compensation was thirty dinars.\nFor a wound that exposed the bone (mudihah) on the body, the compensation was forty dinars, and for the same injury on the head, it was fifty dinars.\nIf the bone was displaced due to the injury, the compensation was one hundred fifty dinars.\nIf there was a penetrating skull wound (naqibah) reaching the brain, known as ma'mumah, and the compensation was one-third of the full blood money, amounting to three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\nTeeth Injuries\nFor each tooth that was lost, the compensation was fifty dinars, and all teeth were treated equally in compensation;\n- the compensation for the central incisor (thaniyyah) was set at fifty dinars.\n- the compensation for the lateral incisor (rabaÊ¿iyyah) was forty dinars,\n- for the canine tooth (nawb) it was thirty dinars,\n- and for the molar tooth (dars) it was twenty-five dinars.\n- If a tooth turned black within a year but did not fall out, its compensation was equal to that of a fallen tooth, which is fifty dinars.\n- If the tooth was cracked but did not fall out, its compensation was twenty-five dinars.\n- If part of it broke, the compensation was calculated proportionally from the fifty dinars.\n- If the tooth later fell out while it was blackened, the compensation was twenty-five dinars.\n- If it was cracked while blackened, the compensation was twelve and a half dinars.\n- For any portion that broke off, the compensation was calculated proportionally from the twenty-five dinars.\nCollarbone (Tarquwah) Injuries\nRegarding the collarbone (tarquwah);\n- if it was broken and healed without any deformity or defect, the compensation was forty dinars.\n- If it was fractured, the compensation was four-fifths of the full compensation for its break, which is thirty-two dinars.\n- If there was a visible wound (mudihah) on it, the compensation was twenty-five dinars, which is five-eighths of its full compensation for a break.\n- If the bone was displaced, the compensation was half the blood money for its break, amounting to twenty dinars.\n- If it was deeply wounded (naqibah), the compensation was one-fourth of the blood money for its break, totaling ten dinars.\nShoulder (Mankib) Injuries\nThe compensation for a broken shoulder (mankib) was set at one-fifth of the blood money for the hand, amounting to one hundred dinars.\n- If there was a fracture (á¹£adÊ¿) in the shoulder, the compensation was four-fifths of the compensation for its break, which is eighty dinars.\n- If there was a visible wound (muá¸ihah), the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, totaling twenty-five dinars.\n- If the bones were displaced, the compensation was one hundred seventy-five dinars, divided as follows: one hundred dinars for the break, fifty dinars for the displacement of the bones, and twenty-five dinars for the visible wound.\n- If there was a deep wound (naqibah), the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for the break, which is twenty-five dinars.\n- If the shoulder was crushed, resulting in deformity, the compensation was one-third of the full blood money for life, amounting to three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- If it was merely loosened (fukk), the compensation was thirty dinars.\nUpper Arm (Adud) Injuries\nFor the upper arm (Adud);\n- if it was broken and healed without deformity or defect, the compensation was one-fifth of the blood money for the hand, totaling one hundred dinars.\n- For a visible wound on the upper arm, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, amounting to twenty-five dinars.\n- If the bones were displaced, the compensation was half of the compensation for its break, which is fifty dinars.\n- For a deep wound (naqibah), the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, equaling twenty-five dinars.\nElbow (Mirfaq) Injuries\nFor the elbow (mirfaq);\n- if it was broken and healed without any deformity or defect, the compensation was one hundred dinars, which is one-fifth of the blood money for the hand.\n- If it was fractured, the compensation was four-fifths of the compensation for its break, totaling eighty dinars.\n- If there was a visible wound, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, amounting to twenty-five dinars.\n- If the bones of the elbow (mirfaq) were displaced, the total compensation would be one hundred seventy-five dinars: one hundred dinars for the fracture, fifty dinars for the displacement of the bones, and twenty-five dinars for the visible wound (muá¸ihah).\n- If there was a deep wound (naqibah) in the elbow, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, amounting to twenty-five dinars.\n- If the elbow was crushed, resulting in deformity, the compensation was one-third of the full blood money, which is three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- If it was merely loosened (fukk), the compensation was thirty dinars.\nThe same rulings apply to the other elbow without distinction.\nForearm (SaÊ¿id) Injuries\nFor the forearm (saÊ¿id);\n- if it was broken and healed without any deformity or defect, the compensation was one-third of the full blood money, amounting to three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- If one of the two forearm bones (qasabatayn) was broken, the compensation was one-fifth of the blood money for the hand, totaling one hundred dinars.\n- If one of the two wrist bones (zandan) was fractured, the compensation was fifty dinars, and if both were fractured, it was one hundred dinars.\n- If one of the forearm bones was cracked, the compensation was four-fifths of the compensation for its break, totaling forty dinars.\n- For a visible wound, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, amounting to twenty-five dinars.\n- If the bones were displaced, the compensation was one hundred dinars, equaling one-fifth of the blood money for the hand.\n- If it was a deep wound (naqibah), the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, totaling twenty-five dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound (naqb), the compensation was half of the compensation for a visible wound, amounting to twelve and a half dinars.\n- The compensation for a deep penetrating wound (nafidhah) in the forearm was fifty dinars.\n- If this injury developed into a chronic ulcer that did not heal, the compensation was one-third of the blood money for the forearm, amounting to thirty-three and one-third dinars. This amount reflects one-third of the compensation for the affected area.\nWrist (Rusgh) Injuries\nIf the wrist (rusgh) was crushed and healed without any deformity or defect, the compensation was one-third of the blood money for the hand, which is one hundred sixty-six and two-thirds dinars.\nAl-Khalil ibn Ahmad explained that the rusgh is the joint connecting the forearm (saÊ¿id) to the hand (kaf), and in human anatomy, it refers to the wrist area.\nHand (Kaf) Injuries\nIf the hand (kaf);\n- was broken and healed without any deformity or defect, the compensation was one-fifth of the blood money for the hand, amounting to one hundred dinars.\n- If the hand was loosened (fukkah), the compensation was one-third of the blood money for the hand, totaling one hundred sixty-six and two-thirds dinars.\n- For a visible wound (muá¸ihah) in the hand, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, which is twenty-five dinars.\n- If the bones of the hand were displaced, the compensation was one hundred eighty-eight dinars - this being half the compensation for the hand's break.\n- If there was a deep penetrating wound (nafidhah) in the hand that did not close, the compensation was one-fifth of the blood money for the hand, totaling one hundred dinars.\n- If the wound was penetrating but did not remain open, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its break, which is twenty-five dinars.\nThumb Injuries\nThe compensation for the fingers and the bone (qasabah) in the hand is as follows:\n- if the thumb (ibham) is completely cut off, the compensation is one-third of the blood money for the hand, amounting to one hundred sixty-six and two-thirds dinars.\n- If the thumb bone in the hand is broken and heals without deformity or defect, the compensation is one-fifth of the thumb's blood money, totaling thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- If the thumb bone is cracked, the compensation is twenty-six and two-thirds dinars. For a visible wound (muá¸ihah), the compensation is eight and one-third dinars.\n- If the bones are displaced, the compensation is sixteen and two-thirds dinars.\n- For a deep wound (naqibah), the compensation is eight and one-third dinars, which is half of the compensation for bone displacement.\n- The compensation for a visible wound is half the compensation for the displacement, amounting to eight and one-third dinars.\n- If the thumb is loosened (fukk), the compensation is ten dinars.\n- If the joint at the top of the thumb is broken and heals without deformity or defect, the compensation is sixteen and two-thirds dinars.\n- For a visible wound in this joint, the compensation is four and one-sixth dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound in this area, the compensation is also four and one-sixth dinars.\n- If the joint is cracked, the compensation is thirteen and one-third dinars.\n- If the bones are displaced, the compensation is five dinars.\nAny portion that is cut off will have its compensation calculated proportionally based on its significance.\nFinger Injuries\n- For each finger, the compensation is one-sixth of the blood money for the hand, amounting to eighty-three and one-third dinars.\n- For each of the four fingers of the hand (excluding the thumb), the compensation for each finger bone (qasabah) is twenty dinars.\n- The compensation for each visible wound (muá¸ihah) on any of the four finger bones (qasabah) is four and one-sixth dinars.\n- If the bones of any of these finger bones are displaced, the compensation is eight and one-third dinars.\n- The compensation for a fracture of any joint in the four fingers connected to the hand is sixteen and two-thirds dinars.\n- If there is a crack (á¹£adÊ¿) in any of these finger bones, the compensation is thirteen and one-third dinars.\n- If there is a chronic ulcer in the hand that does not heal, the compensation is thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- For the displacement of the bones in the hand, the compensation is eight and one-third dinars.\n- For a visible wound on the hand, the compensation is four and one-sixth dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound (naqibah), compensation is also four and one-sixth dinars.\n- If the hand was loosened (fukk), the compensation is five dinars.\nMiddle joint of any of the four fingers Injuries\n- if it is completely severed, the compensation is fifty-five and one-third dinars.\n- If it is fractured, the compensation is eleven and one-third dinars.\n- If it is cracked, the compensation is eight and a half dinars.\n- For a visible wound, the compensation is one and two-thirds dinars.\n- If the bones are displaced, the compensation is five and one-third dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound in this joint, the compensation is two and two-thirds dinars.\n- If the joint is loosened, the compensation is three and two-thirds dinars.\nFor the top joint of any of the four fingers Injuries\n- if it is cut off, the compensation is twenty-seven and a half dinars and a quarter of a tenth of a dinar.\n- If it is fractured, the compensation is five and four-fifths dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound, the compensation is one dinar.\n- For loosening (fakk) of the upper finger joint, the compensation is one and four-fifths dinars.\n- For the loss of a fingernail on any finger, the compensation is five dinars.\nPalm (Kaf) Injuries\nIf the palm (kaf);\n- is broken and heals without deformity or defect, its compensation is forty dinars.\n- For a crack (á¹£adÊ¿) in the palm, the compensation is four-fifths of the compensation for its fracture, totaling thirty-two dinars.\n- For a visible wound (muá¸ihah) in the palm, the compensation is twenty-five dinars.\n- If the bones in the palm are displaced, the compensation is twenty and a half dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound (naqibah), the compensation is one-fourth of the compensation for its fracture, which is ten dinars.\n- For a chronic ulcer in the palm that does not heal, the compensation is thirteen and one-third dinars.\nChest Injuries\n- If the chest is crushed, causing both sides to bend inward, the compensation is five hundred dinars.\n- If only one side of the chest bends inward, the compensation is two hundred fifty dinars.\n- If both the chest and shoulders are bent inward, the total compensation is one thousand dinars.\n- If one shoulder and one side of the chest are bent, the compensation is five hundred dinars.\n- Bone Exposure (Muá¸ihah) in the Chest or Shoulders, the compensation is twenty-five dinars.\n- The same compensation applies to a visible wound on the shoulders and back, which is also twenty-five dinars.\n- If the injury causes the man to suffer from stiffness (á¹£aar) that prevents him from turning his head, the compensation is five hundred dinars.\nSpinal Injuries\n- If the backbone (á¹£ulb) is broken and heals without any deformity or defect, the compensation is similarly determined.\n- If the backbone (á¹£ulb) was broken and healed without deformity or defect, the compensation was one hundred dinars.\n- However, if injury caused a deformity (Atham), compensation was one thousand dinars.\nRib Injuries\nFor the ribs (aá¸laÊ¿) near the heart;\n- If one rib was broken, the compensation was twenty-five dinars.\n- If it was cracked (á¹£adÊ¿), the compensation was twelve and a half dinars.\n- If the bone was displaced, the compensation was seven and a half dinars.\n- For a visible wound (muá¸ihah), the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for the fracture, and the same applies to a deep puncture wound (naqibah).\nFor the ribs near the upper arms (Aá¸udayn);\n- the compensation for each broken rib was ten dinars.\n- For a crack in one of these ribs, the compensation was seven dinars.\n- If the bone was displaced, the compensation was five dinars.\n- A visible wound on these ribs had a compensation of two and a half dinars, which is one-fourth of the compensation for the fracture.\n- For a puncture wound in these ribs, the compensation was also two and a half dinars.\nInternal Penetrating Wounds (JaÊ¾ifah)\n- For a deep penetrating wound (ja'ifah) that reaches internal organs, compensation was one-third of full blood money, which is three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- If both sides of the body were penetrated by a shot or stab wound causing a split, the compensation was four hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\nEar Injuries\nIf the ear (udhun);\n- completely cut off, the compensation was five hundred dinars.\n- If only a part of the ear was cut, the compensation was calculated proportionally.\nHip (Wariq) Injuries\nFor the hip (warik);\n- if it was broken and healed without deformity or defect, the compensation was one-fifth of the blood money for both legs, amounting to two hundred dinars.\n- If the hip was cracked, the compensation was one hundred sixty dinars, which is four-fifths of the compensation for its fracture.\n- For a visible wound on the hip, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its fracture, totaling fifty dinars.\n- If the hip bone was displaced, the compensation was one hundred dinars.\nOut of the total compensation for the hip injury, one hundred dinars are allocated for the fracture, fifty dinars for the displacement of the bones, and twenty-five dinars for visible wound (muá¸ihah).\n- If the hip was loosened (fakk), the compensation was thirty dinars.\n- If the hip was crushed and resulted in deformity (Atham), the compensation was three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\nThigh (Fakhdh) Injuries\nFor the thigh (fakhdh);\n- if it was broken and healed without deformity or defect, the compensation was one-fifth of the blood money for both legs, amounting to two hundred dinars.\n- If the thigh became deformed (Atham), the compensation was three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars, which is one-third of the full blood money for life.\n- For a crack (á¹£adÊ¿) in the thigh, the compensation was four-fifths of the compensation for its fracture, totaling one hundred sixty dinars.\n- If there was a chronic ulcer in the thigh that did not heal, the compensation was one-third of the compensation for its fracture, amounting to sixty-six and two-thirds dinars.\n- For a visible Bone Exposure (Muá¸ihah), the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for the fracture, totaling fifty dinars.\n- If the bones were displaced (Naql), the compensation was half of the compensation for its fracture, which is one hundred dinars.\n- For a Deep Puncture (Naqbah) wound, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for the fracture, amounting to fifty dinars.\nKnee (Rukbah) Injuries\nFor the knee (rukbah);\n- if it was broken and healed without deformity or defect, the compensation was one-fifth of the blood money for both legs, totaling two hundred dinars.\n- If it was cracked, the compensation was four-fifths of the compensation for its fracture, which is one hundred sixty dinars.\n- For a visible wound in the knee, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its fracture, amounting to fifty dinars.\n- If the bones in the knee were displaced, the compensation was one hundred dinars.\nOut of the total compensation for the knee injury, one hundred dinars are allocated for the fracture, fifty dinars for the displacement of the bones, and twenty-five dinars for the visible wound (muá¸ihah).\n- For a deep puncture wound (naqibah), the compensation is one-fourth of the compensation for the fracture, totaling fifty dinars.\n- If the knee was crushed and resulted in deformity (Atham), the compensation is one-third of the full blood money, amounting to three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- If the knee was merely loosened (fakk), the compensation is three parts of the compensation for its fracture, totaling thirty dinars.\nShin (Saq) Injuries\nFor the shin (saq);\n- if it was broken and healed without deformity or defect, the compensation was one-fifth of the blood money for both legs, amounting to two hundred dinars.\n- If the shin was cracked, the compensation was four-fifths of the compensation for its fracture, totaling one hundred sixty dinars.\n- For a visible wound in the shin, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its fracture, amounting to fifty dinars.\n- If the bones in the shin were displaced, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its fracture, which is fifty dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound (naqibah) in the shin, the compensation was half the compensation for a visible wound, amounting to twenty-five dinars.\n- For a severe injury (taawwur) in the shin, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its fracture, totaling fifty dinars.\n- If there was a chronic ulcer in the shin that did not heal, the compensation was thirty-three dinars.\n- If the shin was crushed and resulted in deformity (Atham), the compensation was one-third of the full blood money, totaling three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\nAnkle and Foot Injuries\n- If the ankle (kaÊ¿b) was crushed and healed without deformity or defect, the compensation was one-third of the blood money for both legs, totaling three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- If the foot (qadam) was broken and healed without deformity or defect, the compensation was one-fifth of the blood money for both legs, amounting to two hundred dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound (naqibah) in the foot, the compensation was one-fourth of the compensation for its fracture, totaling fifty dinars.\nToe Injuries\nFor the toes and the bones (qasab) in the foot, the compensation for;\nThe big toe;\n- the big toe (ibham) was one-third of the blood money for both legs, totaling three hundred thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- If the bone connected to the big toe was broken, the compensation was one-fifth of the compensation for the big toe, amounting to sixty-six and two-thirds dinars.\n- If this bone was cracked (á¹£adÊ¿), the compensation was twenty-six and two-thirds dinars.\n- For a visible wound (muá¸ihah), the compensation was eight and one-third dinars.\n- If the bones were displaced, the compensation was twenty-six and two-thirds dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound (naqibah), the compensation was eight and one-third dinars.\n- If the bone was loosened (fakk), the compensation was ten dinars.\nUpper Joint of the Big Toe;\nFor the upper joint of the big toe (Al-mafá¹£il Al-aÊ¿la), which is the second joint where the nail is located;\n- if it was broken and healed without deformity, the compensation was sixteen and two-thirds dinars.\n- For a visible wound in this joint, the compensation was four and one-sixth dinars.\n- If the bones in this joint were displaced, the compensation was eight and one-third dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound in this joint, the compensation was four and one-sixth dinars.\n- If the upper joint of the big toe was cracked (á¹£adÊ¿), the compensation was thirteen and one-third dinars.\n- If it was loosened (fakk), the compensation was five dinars.\nAll other toes;\nFor each toe of the foot;\n- the compensation was one-sixth of the blood money for the leg, amounting to eighty-three and one-third dinars.\n- For the bones (qasabah) of the other four toes, excluding the big toe, the compensation for breaking each bone was sixteen and one-third dinars.\n- For a visible wound (muá¸ihah) on any of these bones, the compensation was four and one-sixth dinars.\n- If the bone was displaced, the compensation was eight and one-third dinars.\n- If the bone was cracked, the compensation was thirteen and one-third dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound (naqibah) in any of these bones, the compensation was four and one-sixth dinars.\n- If there was a chronic ulcer in the foot that did not heal, the compensation was thirty-three and one-third dinars.\n- For a fracture of the joint next to the foot from the toes, the compensation was sixteen and one-third dinars.\n- If this joint was cracked, the compensation was thirteen and one-third dinars.\n- For displacement of the bone in these finger bones, compensation was eight and one-third dinars.\n- For a visible wound in these bones, the compensation was four and one-sixth dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound, the compensation was also four and one-sixth dinars.\n- If the joint was loosened (fakk), the compensation was five dinars.\nMiddle of Toe Joints;\nFor the middle joint of any of the four toes,\n- if it was cut off, the compensation was fifty-five and two-thirds dinars.\n- If it was fractured, the compensation was eleven dinars.\n- If the middle joint of the four toes was cracked (á¹£adÊ¿), the compensation was eight and four-fifths dinars.\n- For a visible wound (muá¸ihah) in this joint, the compensation was two dinars.\n- If the bones in this joint were displaced, the compensation was five and two-thirds dinars.\n- For loosening (fakk), the compensation was three and two-thirds dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound (naqibah), the compensation was two and two-thirds dinars.\nUpper of Toe Joints;\nFor the upper joint of the four toes, which contains the nail;\n- if it was cut off, the compensation was twenty-seven and four-fifths dinars.\n- If it was fractured, the compensation was five and four-fifths dinars.\n- For a crack in this joint, the compensation was four and one-fifth dinars.\n- For a visible wound in this joint, the compensation was one and one-third dinars.\n- If the bones in this joint were displaced, the compensation was two and one-fifth dinars.\n- For a deep puncture wound, the compensation was one and one-third dinars.\n- If the joint was loosened, the compensation was one and four-fifths dinars.\n- For the loss of any toenail, the compensation was ten dinars.\nMale Chest (Nipple Injury)\nImam Jafar ibn Muhammad Al-Sadiq (as) ruled that the compensation for the loss of the nipple of a man's chest is one-eighth of the full blood money, totaling one hundred twenty-five dinars.\nTesticle Injury\nThe compensation for the loss of one testicle (khuá¹£yah) of a man was five hundred dinars.\nIf both testicles were injured and became swollen, the compensation was four hundred dinars.\nSevere Hip Injury Leading to Disability\nIf a man became bowlegged (fahij) and was unable to walk except in a way that was of no benefit to him, the compensation was set at four-fifths of the full blood money, amounting to eight hundred dinars.\nIf this condition caused his back to become hunched (ahdab), the compensation was then completed to the full blood money, totaling one thousand dinars.\nThe practice of qasamah (oath-taking) in all such cases involved six individuals, based on the amount of blood money owed.\nInjury to Pubic Area\nImam Jafar ibn Muhammad Al-Sadiq (as) ruled that;\n- In the case of a severe injury (wajah) to the pubic area (Anah) that pierced the Abdominal lining (á¹£ifaq), causing swelling in one of the testicles, the compensation was two hundred dinars, which is one-fifth of the full blood money.\n- For a penetrating wound (nafidhah) inflicted by a spear or dagger on any limb of a man, compensation was one-tenth of the full blood money, amounting to one hundred dinars.\nInjuries by Parents\nHe (as) also ruled that there is no retaliation (qawad) for a man injured by his father in a matter where the father was disciplining him, even if the injury caused permanent damage such as a cut or other harm. In such cases, only compensation (diyyah) is due, and no retribution is allowed.\nInjuries by Spouses\nSimilarly, there is no retaliation for a husband who causes injury to his wife. However, the husband must pay compensation for the injury, but no retribution is applied.\nHe (as) ruled that if a husband kicked his wife, rendering her permanently disabled (aÊ¿fala), she was entitled to half of her full blood money, amounting to two hundred fifty dinars.\nViolation Against a Female Slave\nAdditionally, He (as) ruled that if a man assaulted a bondwoman (jariyah) by inserting his finger and ruptured her bladder (mathanah), leaving her unable to control her urination, the compensation was set at one-third of half the full blood money, which is one hundred sixty-six and two-thirds dinars. Furthermore, he ruled that the man must also pay her dowry (á¹£adaq) equal to that of the women of her people.", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 313, "bookId": "Man-La-Yahduruh-al-Faqih-Volume-4-Saduq", "book": "Man LÄ Yaá¸¥á¸uruh al-FaqÄ«h", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "Chapter on What Requires Full Blood Money and Half Blood Money in Cases Other Than the Taking of a Life", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bab Ul Qaim Publications", "englishText": "Hadith.5283 - Ibn Mahbub narrated from Jamil ibn Salih from Abu Ubaydah Al-Hadhdha' who said: I asked Abu Jafar Imam Muhammad ibn Ali Al-Baqir (as) about a man who struck another man on his head with the pole of a tent, delivering a single blow that penetrated to his brain, causing him to lose his mind.\nImam (as) said: \"If the struck man can no longer comprehend the prayer, nor understand what is said to him or what he says, then he should be observed for a year. If he dies within that year, the striker is subject to retaliation (qisas). However, if he does not die within that period and his mind does not return, the striker must pay the full blood money (diyya) from his wealth due to the loss of the victim's intellect.\"\nI said to Imam (as): What do you rule upon him regarding the head injury (shajja)?\nImam (as) replied: \"Nothing, because he only struck him once, and that single blow caused two injuries. Therefore, I imposed upon him the more severe of the two injuries, which is the blood money (diyya).\nHad he struck him twice, causing two separate injuries, I would have imposed upon him compensation for both injuries, whatever they may have been - except if one of them resulted in death, in which case the striker would face retaliation (qisas), and the second injury would be disregarded.\"\nImam (as) further said: \"If he struck him three times, one after the other, resulting in three injuries, I would impose upon him the liability for whatever the three injuries amounted to, unless one of them led to death, in which case the striker would face retaliation.\"\nImam (as) added: \"And if he struck him ten times, but they resulted in a single injury, I would hold him accountable only for that single injury caused by the ten blows, regardless of its severity, as long as it did not result in death.\"", "arabicText": "5283 - ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙÙˆÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙØ¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ù…ÙØ­Ù’Ø¨ÙÙˆØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¬ÙÙ…ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù ØµÙØ§Ù„ÙØ­Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¯ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ°Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù: Ø³ÙØ£ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙØ§ Ø¬ÙØ¹Ù’ÙÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø±ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù Ø¶ÙØ±ÙØ¨Ù Ø±ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‹ Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ¯Ù ÙÙØ³Ù’Ø·ÙØ§Ø·Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø±ÙØ£Ù’Ø³ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¶ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙˆÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¯ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙÙØ£ÙØ¬ÙØ§ÙÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙØµÙÙ„ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¶Ù‘ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¯ÙÙ…ÙØ§ØºÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ°ÙÙ‡ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¶Ù’Ø±ÙÙˆØ¨Ù Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„ØµÙ‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù‚ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙØ¸ÙØ±Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø³ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ§ØªÙ ÙÙÙŠÙ…ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠØ¯Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¶ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ…ÙØªÙ’ ÙÙÙŠÙ…ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ±Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¹Ù’ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØºÙ’Ø±ÙÙ…Ù Ø¶ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙŠÙØ©Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù…ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙØ°ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù\"\nÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ…ÙØ§ ØªÙØ±ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ¬Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¦Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ù„Ø§Ù Ù„ÙØ£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø¶ÙØ±ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¶ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙˆÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¯ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙÙØ¬ÙÙ†ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¶Ù‘ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙŠÙØªÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙÙØ£ÙÙ„Ù’Ø²ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØºÙ’Ù„ÙØ¸Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙŠÙØªÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙŠÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙŠÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙˆÙ’ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¶ÙØ±ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¶ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØªÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙÙØ¬ÙÙ†ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¶Ù‘ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØªÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙŠÙØªÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ù„ÙØ£ÙÙ„Ù’Ø²ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙŠÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¶Ù‘ÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØªÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ†Ø§Ù‹ Ù…ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†ÙØªÙØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙƒÙÙˆÙ†Ù ÙÙÙŠÙ‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ ÙÙÙŠÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¶ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ·Ù’Ø±ÙØ­Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ®Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‰ \" Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¶ÙØ±ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø«ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ«Ù Ø¶ÙØ±ÙØ¨ÙØ§ØªÙ ÙˆÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¯ÙØ©Ù‹ Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù ÙˆÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¯ÙØ©Ù ÙÙØ¬ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø«ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ«Ù Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙŠÙØ§ØªÙ Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’Ø²ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙŠÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø«Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ«Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¶Ù‘ÙØ±ÙØ¨ÙØ§ØªÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ†ÙØ§ØªÙ Ù…ÙØ§ ÙƒÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ ÙÙÙŠÙ‡ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ ÙÙÙŠÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¶ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù\" Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¶ÙØ±ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ´Ù’Ø±Ù Ø¶ÙØ±ÙØ¨ÙØ§ØªÙ ÙÙØ¬ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙŠÙØ©Ù‹ ÙˆÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¯ÙØ©Ù‹ Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’Ø²ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØ§ÙŠÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØªÙÙŠ Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØªÙ’Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ´Ù’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¶Ù‘ÙØ±ÙØ¨ÙØ§ØªÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù…ÙØ§ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†ÙØªÙ’ Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ ÙÙÙŠÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ\".", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/34/1/30/5283", "volume": 4, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 30, "thaqalaynSanad": "Hadith.5283 - Ibn Mahbub narrated from Jamil ibn Salih from Abu Ubaydah Al-Hadhdha' who said:", "thaqalaynMatn": " I asked Abu Jafar Imam Muhammad ibn Ali Al-Baqir (as) about a man who struck another man on his head with the pole of a tent, delivering a single blow that penetrated to his brain, causing him to lose his mind.\nImam (as) said: \"If the struck man can no longer comprehend the prayer, nor understand what is said to him or what he says, then he should be observed for a year. If he dies within that year, the striker is subject to retaliation (qisas). However, if he does not die within that period and his mind does not return, the striker must pay the full blood money (diyya) from his wealth due to the loss of the victim's intellect.\"\nI said to Imam (as): What do you rule upon him regarding the head injury (shajja)?\nImam (as) replied: \"Nothing, because he only struck him once, and that single blow caused two injuries. Therefore, I imposed upon him the more severe of the two injuries, which is the blood money (diyya).\nHad he struck him twice, causing two separate injuries, I would have imposed upon him compensation for both injuries, whatever they may have been - except if one of them resulted in death, in which case the striker would face retaliation (qisas), and the second injury would be disregarded.\"\nImam (as) further said: \"If he struck him three times, one after the other, resulting in three injuries, I would impose upon him the liability for whatever the three injuries amounted to, unless one of them led to death, in which case the striker would face retaliation.\"\nImam (as) added: \"And if he struck him ten times, but they resulted in a single injury, I would hold him accountable only for that single injury caused by the ten blows, regardless of its severity, as long as it did not result in death.\"", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 441, "bookId": "Man-La-Yahduruh-al-Faqih-Volume-4-Saduq", "book": "Man LÄ Yaá¸¥á¸uruh al-FaqÄ«h", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "Chapter on the Favor That Allah {swt}, Blessed and Exalted, Bestows Upon His Servant at the Time of Death by Restoring His Sight, Hearing, and Intellect So That He May Make a Bequest", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bab Ul Qaim Publications", "englishText": "Hadith.5409 - Muhammad ibn Abi Umayr narrated from Hammad ibn Uthman who said that Abu Abdullah Imam Jafar ibn Muhammad Al-Sadiq (as) said:\n\"There is no dying person approaching death except that Allah (swt) restores to him his hearing, sight, and intellect for the purpose of making a will - whether he chooses to make the will or not. This is the state referred to as the 'relief of death,' and it is a duty upon every Muslim.\"", "arabicText": "5409 - Ø±ÙÙˆÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙØ«Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙˆ Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù : \"Ù…ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØªÙ ØªÙØ­Ù’Ø¶ÙØ±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙÙÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø±ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø³ÙÙ…Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØµÙØ±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙØ®ÙØ°Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ ØªÙØ±ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙŠÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ§Ø­ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØªÙÙŠ ÙŠÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø±ÙØ§Ø­ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ ÙÙÙ‡ÙÙŠÙ Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙŒ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù \".", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/34/1/73/5409", "volume": 4, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 73, "thaqalaynSanad": "Hadith.5409 - Muhammad ibn Abi Umayr narrated from Hammad ibn Uthman who said that Abu Abdullah Imam Jafar ibn Muhammad Al-Sadiq (as) said:\n", "thaqalaynMatn": "\"There is no dying person approaching death except that Allah (swt) restores to him his hearing, sight, and intellect for the purpose of making a will - whether he chooses to make the will or not. This is the state referred to as the 'relief of death,' and it is a duty upon every Muslim.\"", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 448, "bookId": "Man-La-Yahduruh-al-Faqih-Volume-4-Saduq", "book": "Man LÄ Yaá¸¥á¸uruh al-FaqÄ«h", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "Chapter on What Has Been Reported Regarding One Who Does Not Make a Proper Bequest at the Time of Death", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bab Ul Qaim Publications", "englishText": "Hadith.5416 - Al-Abbas ibn Amir narrated from Aban from Abu Basir from Abu Abdullah Imam Jafar ibn Muhammad Al-Sadiq (as), who said:\n\"Whoever does not make a proper will at the time of death, it is a deficiency in his dignity and intellect.\"\nImam (as) also said: \"Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) made a will to Ali (as), and Ali (as) made a will to Al-Hasan (as), and Al-Hasan (as) made a will to Al-Hussain (as), and Al-Hussain (as) made a will to Ali ibn Al-Hussain (as), and Ali ibn Al-Hussain (as) made a will to Muhammad ibn Ali Al-Baqir (as).\"", "arabicText": "5416 - Ø±ÙÙˆÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙØ§Ù…ÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙØµÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù : \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ø³ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù†ÙÙ‚Ù’ØµØ§Ù‹ ÙÙÙŠ Ù…ÙØ±ÙÙˆØ¡ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù \" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ØµÙÙ‰ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ØµÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙŒ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ØµÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ØµÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ØµÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡ÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù \".", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/34/1/79/5416", "volume": 4, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 79, "thaqalaynSanad": "Hadith.5416 - Al-Abbas ibn Amir narrated from Aban from Abu Basir from Abu Abdullah Imam Jafar ibn Muhammad Al-Sadiq (as), who said:\n", "thaqalaynMatn": "\"Whoever does not make a proper will at the time of death, it is a deficiency in his dignity and intellect.\"\nImam (as) also said: \"Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) made a will to Ali (as), and Ali (as) made a will to Al-Hasan (as), and Al-Hasan (as) made a will to Al-Hussain (as), and Al-Hussain (as) made a will to Ali ibn Al-Hussain (as), and Ali ibn Al-Hussain (as) made a will to Muhammad ibn Ali Al-Baqir (as).\"", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 462, "bookId": "Man-La-Yahduruh-al-Faqih-Volume-4-Saduq", "book": "Man LÄ Yaá¸¥á¸uruh al-FaqÄ«h", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "Chapter on the Formulation of the Bequest", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bab Ul Qaim Publications", "englishText": "Hadith.5431 - Ali ibn Ibrahim ibn Hashim narrated from Ali ibn Ishaq, from Al-Hasan ibn Hazim Al-Kalbi, the nephew of Hisham ibn Salim, from Sulayman ibn Ja'far (who was not from the Ja'fari lineage), from Abu Abdullah (as), who said:\nThe Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) said: \"Whoever does not make a proper will at the time of death, it is a deficiency in his dignity and intellect.\"\nIt was asked: \"O' Messenger of Allah (swt), how does a dying person make a will?\"\nProphet (sw) replied: \"When his death approaches and people gather around him, he should say:\n\"O' Allah (swt), Creator of the heavens and the earth, Knower of the unseen and the seen, the Most Merciful, the Most Compassionate.\nO' Allah (swt), I make a covenant with You (swt) in this worldly life that I bear witness there is no God but You (swt), alone with no partner. And that Muhammad (sw) is Your (swt) servant and Your Messenger (sw).\nParadise is true, Hellfire is true, resurrection is true, reckoning is true, the path (Sirat) is true, divine decree and the scale (Mizan) are true.\nIndeed, the religion is as You (swt) have described, Islam is as You (swt) have legislated, the word is as You (swt) have conveyed, and the Qur'an is as You (swt) have revealed.\nAnd You (swt) are Allah (swt), the True and Manifest.\nMay Allah (swt) reward Muhammad (sw) on our behalf with the best reward, and may Allah (swt) send peace upon Muhammad (sw) and the family of Muhammad (sw).\nO' Allah (swt), You (swt) are my refuge in my hardship, my companion in my difficulty, and the guardian of my blessings.\nMy God (swt) and the God (swt) of my forefathers, do not leave me to myself for the blink of an eye, for if You (swt) abandon me to myself, I will be closer to evil and farther from good. Bring comfort to my loneliness in the grave, and grant me a written covenant on the Day I meet You (swt).\nThen he should state his wishes (in his will).\nThe confirmation of this will is found in the Quran, in the chapter where Maryam {s.a} is mentioned, in the words of Allah (swt), the Almighty and Majestic:\n\"They do not possess [the right of] intercession except for those who have taken a covenant with the Most Merciful.\" (Surah Maryam 19:87)\nThis is the covenant of the dying person, and making a will is an obligation upon every Muslim.\nIt is a duty to preserve this will and to teach it to others.\nCommander of the Faithful Imam Ali ibn Abi Talib (as) said:\n\"The Messenger of Allah (swt), peace be upon him and his family, taught it to me.\"\nAnd the Messenger of Allah (swt), said: \"Jibril (as) taught it to me (from Allah (swt)).\"", "arabicText": "5431 - Ø±ÙÙˆÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¥ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±ÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙŠÙ…Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ù‡ÙØ§Ø´ÙÙ…Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¥ÙØ³Ù’Ø­ÙØ§Ù‚Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙ†Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø­ÙØ§Ø²ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø§ÙØ¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø£ÙØ®Ù’ØªÙ Ù‡ÙØ´ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø³ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ…Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø³ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù…ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¬ÙØ¹Ù’ÙÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¹Ù’ÙÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù: \"Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù : \"Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ø³ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù†ÙÙ‚Ù’ØµØ§Ù‹ ÙÙÙŠ Ù…ÙØ±ÙÙˆØ¡ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù\" Ù‚ÙÙŠÙ„Ù ÙŠÙØ§ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙÙŠÙ’ÙÙ ÙŠÙÙˆØµÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØªÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø­ÙØ¶ÙØ±ÙØªÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙÙÙØ§ØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ¬Ù’ØªÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù -:\n\"Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘Ù°Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù ÙÙ°Ø§Ø·ÙØ±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù°Ø§ÙˆÙ°Ø§ØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¶Ù Ø¹Ù°Ø§Ù„ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù°Ø§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù\" Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ­ÙÙŠÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙŠ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’ÙƒÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ø¯ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙŠ Ø£ÙØ´Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ ÙˆÙØ­Ù’Ø¯ÙÙƒÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø´ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙƒÙ Ù„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø«Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„ØµÙ‘ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø·Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ¯ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙŠØ²ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§ ÙˆÙØµÙÙÙ’ØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¥ÙØ³Ù’Ù„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø´ÙØ±ÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„Ù ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«Ù’ØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ±Ù’Ø¢Ù†Ù ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’Ø²ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø¬ÙØ²ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ§ Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ²ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù„Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù ÙŠÙØ§ Ø¹ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØªÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù ÙƒÙØ±Ù’Ø¨ÙØªÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ§ ØµÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø´ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØªÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ§ ÙˆÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ù†ÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙØªÙÙŠ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡ÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¢Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙŠ Ù„Ø§Ù ØªÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙŠ Ø·ÙØ±Ù’ÙÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙŠ Ø£ÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±ÙØ¨Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ±Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¯Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù ÙÙØ¢Ù†ÙØ³Ù’ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙØ­Ù’Ø´ÙØªÙÙŠ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ¬Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’ Ù„ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø¯Ø§Ù‹ ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§ÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ø´ÙÙˆØ±Ø§Ù‹ Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù ÙŠÙÙˆØµÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙØ­ÙØ§Ø¬ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ØªÙØµÙ’Ø¯ÙÙŠÙ‚Ù Ù‡ÙØ°ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ±Ù’Ø¢Ù†Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙˆØ±ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØªÙÙŠ ØªÙØ°Ù’ÙƒÙØ±Ù ÙÙÙŠÙ‡ÙØ§ Ù…ÙØ±Ù’ÙŠÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Û Ù„Ø§Ù° ÙŠÙÙ…Ù’Ù„ÙÙƒÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙÙÙ°Ø§Ø¹ÙØ©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù° Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØªÙ‘ÙØ®ÙØ°Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ­Ù’Ù…Ù°Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø¯Ø§Ù‹ Û ÙÙÙ‡ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙŒ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙŒ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’ÙÙØ¸Ù Ù‡ÙØ°ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ¹ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙÙ‡ÙØ§\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø·ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ¨Ù ØµÙÙ„ÙÙˆÙØ§ØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù \"Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù \" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØµÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¢Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù \"Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¬ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±ÙØ¦ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù\"\".", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/34/1/86/5431", "volume": 4, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 86, "thaqalaynSanad": "Hadith.5431 - Ali ibn Ibrahim ibn Hashim narrated from Ali ibn Ishaq, from Al-Hasan ibn Hazim Al-Kalbi, the nephew of Hisham ibn Salim, from Sulayman ibn Ja'far (who was not from the Ja'fari lineage), from Abu Abdullah (as), who said:\n", "thaqalaynMatn": "The Messenger of Allah (swt) (peace be upon him and his family) said: \"Whoever does not make a proper will at the time of death, it is a deficiency in his dignity and intellect.\"\nIt was asked: \"O' Messenger of Allah (swt), how does a dying person make a will?\"\nProphet (sw) replied: \"When his death approaches and people gather around him, he should say:\n\"O' Allah (swt), Creator of the heavens and the earth, Knower of the unseen and the seen, the Most Merciful, the Most Compassionate.\nO' Allah (swt), I make a covenant with You (swt) in this worldly life that I bear witness there is no God but You (swt), alone with no partner. And that Muhammad (sw) is Your (swt) servant and Your Messenger (sw).\nParadise is true, Hellfire is true, resurrection is true, reckoning is true, the path (Sirat) is true, divine decree and the scale (Mizan) are true.\nIndeed, the religion is as You (swt) have described, Islam is as You (swt) have legislated, the word is as You (swt) have conveyed, and the Qur'an is as You (swt) have revealed.\nAnd You (swt) are Allah (swt), the True and Manifest.\nMay Allah (swt) reward Muhammad (sw) on our behalf with the best reward, and may Allah (swt) send peace upon Muhammad (sw) and the family of Muhammad (sw).\nO' Allah (swt), You (swt) are my refuge in my hardship, my companion in my difficulty, and the guardian of my blessings.\nMy God (swt) and the God (swt) of my forefathers, do not leave me to myself for the blink of an eye, for if You (swt) abandon me to myself, I will be closer to evil and farther from good. Bring comfort to my loneliness in the grave, and grant me a written covenant on the Day I meet You (swt).\nThen he should state his wishes (in his will).\nThe confirmation of this will is found in the Quran, in the chapter where Maryam {s.a} is mentioned, in the words of Allah (swt), the Almighty and Majestic:\n\"They do not possess [the right of] intercession except for those who have taken a covenant with the Most Merciful.\" (Surah Maryam 19:87)\nThis is the covenant of the dying person, and making a will is an obligation upon every Muslim.\nIt is a duty to preserve this will and to teach it to others.\nCommander of the Faithful Imam Ali ibn Abi Talib (as) said:\n\"The Messenger of Allah (swt), peace be upon him and his family, taught it to me.\"\nAnd the Messenger of Allah (swt), said: \"Jibril (as) taught it to me (from Allah (swt)).\"", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 547, "bookId": "Man-La-Yahduruh-al-Faqih-Volume-4-Saduq", "book": "Man LÄ Yaá¸¥á¸uruh al-FaqÄ«h", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "Chapter on the Cessation of an orphan's Orphanhood", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bab Ul Qaim Publications", "englishText": "Hadith.5518 - Ibn Abi Umayr narrated from Mathanna ibn Rashid from Abu Basir from Abu Abdullah (as), who said: I asked Imam (as) about an orphan who had memorized the Qur'an and had no deficiency in his intellect. The one holding his wealth wishes to invest it until the orphan reaches puberty and then hand over his wealth to him.\nImam (as) said: \"Even if he reaches puberty but does not have sound intellect, nothing should ever be handed over to him.\"", "arabicText": "5518 - ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙÙˆÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙØ¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ«ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø±ÙØ§Ø´ÙØ¯Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø¨ÙØµÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù : Ø³ÙØ£ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØªÙÙŠÙ…Ù Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ù‚ÙØ±ÙØ£Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ±Ù’Ø¢Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ£Ù’Ø³ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ§Ù„ÙŒ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ’ Ø±ÙØ¬ÙÙ„Ù ÙÙØ£ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’ØªÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ ÙŠÙØ¯Ù’ÙÙØ¹Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ù…ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù \"ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØ­Ù’ØªÙÙ„ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„ÙŒ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ¯Ù’ÙÙØ¹Ù’ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¡ÙŒ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹\".", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/34/1/112/5518", "volume": 4, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 112, "thaqalaynSanad": "Hadith.5518 - Ibn Abi Umayr narrated from Mathanna ibn Rashid from Abu Basir from Abu Abdullah (as), who said: I asked Imam (as) about an orphan who had memorized the Qur'an and had no deficiency in his intellect. The one holding his wealth wishes to invest it until the orphan reaches puberty and then hand over his wealth to him.", "thaqalaynMatn": "\nImam (as) said: \"Even if he reaches puberty but does not have sound intellect, nothing should ever be handed over to him.\"", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 880, "bookId": "Man-La-Yahduruh-al-Faqih-Volume-4-Saduq", "book": "Man LÄ Yaá¸¥á¸uruh al-FaqÄ«h", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "Among the Concise Words of the Messenger of Allah (peace Be Upon him)", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bab Ul Qaim Publications", "englishText": "Hadith.5834 - The Commander of the Faithful, peace be upon him, said in his will to his son Muhammad ibn Al-Hanafiyyah, may Allah (swt) be pleased with him:\n\"O' my son, beware of relying on vain hopes, for they are the merchandise of the foolish and a hindrance from the Hereafter.\nOne of the best fortunes a person can have is a righteous companion - sit with the people of goodness, and you will be one of them; separate yourself from the people of evil.\nKeep away from those who divert you from the remembrance of Allah (swt), Mighty and Majestic, and the remembrance of death with embellished falsehoods and fabricated rumors.\nDo not let ill thoughts about Allah (swt), Mighty and Majestic, overpower you, for they will not leave any reconciliation between you and your friend.\nDiscipline your heart with good manners as fire is kindled with wood, for good manners are a great aid for one's nature, and experiences are a guide for the wise.\nCombine the opinions of different men, then choose the one closest to correctness and farthest from doubt.\nO' my son, there is no honor higher than Islam,\nno dignity greater than piety, n\no stronghold more secure than restraint,\nno intercessor more effective than repentance,\nno garment more beautiful than well-being,\nno protection stronger than safety,\nand no treasure wealthier than contentment.\nAnd there is no wealth that removes poverty better than contentment with sustenance.\nWhoever suffices with the bare necessities has attained ease and settled in comfort.\nGreed leads to plunging into sins.\nCast away intrusive worries with firm resolve in patience.\nAccustom yourself to patience, for it is the best of manners, and endure the hardships and concerns of this world.\nThe successful ones have triumphed, and those for whom Allah (swt) has decreed goodness have been saved, for patience is a shield against poverty.\nEntrust all your affairs to Allah (swt), the One (swt), the All-Dominant (swt), for in doing so, you take refuge in a fortified cave, a secure stronghold, and an invincible protector.\nSincerely direct your supplications to your Lord (swt), for in His (swt) hands are all good and evil, giving and withholding, granting and depriving.\"\nAnd Commander of the Faithful Imam Ali ibn Abi Talib (as), said in this will:\n\"O' my son, sustenance is of two kinds: one that you seek, and one that seeks you. If you do not go to it, it will come to you. So do not burden yourself with the worries of your entire year upon the concern of your day; each day is sufficient with what it holds.\nIf the year is part of your life, then Allah (swt), Mighty and Majestic, will bring to you each day what He (swt) has apportioned for you.\nAnd if the year is not part of your life, then why concern yourself with grief and anxiety over what is not yours?\nKnow that no seeker can overtake you in your sustenance, nor can anyone overpower you in it, and what has been decreed for you will not be kept from you. How many seekers have you seen exhausting themselves, yet their provision remains restricted, while others who seek with moderation find that destiny aids them? And everything is accompanied by its end.\nToday is yours, but you have no certainty of reaching tomorrow. How many have awaited a day they never lived to see? How many were envied at the beginning of a night, yet by its end, they were mourned? So do not be deceived by the prolonged presence of blessings from Allah (swt) or by the delay in the arrival of punishment, for if He (swt) feared missing the opportunity, He (swt) would hasten the punishment before death.\nO' my son, accept the wisdom of the wise, reflect upon their judgments, and be the one who adheres most to what you command others and refrains most from what you forbid.\nEnjoin what is good so that you may be among its people, for the completion of matters lies with Allah (swt), Blessed and Exalted.\"\nEnjoin what is good and forbid what is evil, and seek understanding in religion, for the jurists are the inheritors of the prophets. The prophets did not leave behind dinars or dirhams, but rather, they left behind knowledge, and whoever takes from it has taken a great share.\nKnow that the seeker of knowledge is prayed for by those in the heavens and the earth, even the birds in the sky and the fish in the sea. The angels lower their wings for the seeker of knowledge out of pleasure for him. In knowledge, there is the honor of this world and success in Paradise on the Day of Judgment, for the jurists are the callers to Paradise and the guides to Allah (swt), Blessed and Exalted.\nTreat all people kindly just as you would like to be treated, and be pleased for them with what you are pleased with for yourself.\nDislike for yourself what you dislike in others, and perfect your character with all people so that if you are absent, they long for you, and if you die, they weep for you and say, 'Indeed, we belong to Allah (swt), and indeed, to Him we shall return.'\"\nAnd do not be among those about whom it is said at their death: 'All praise is due to Allah (swt), the Lord of the worlds.' (being grateful of your demise)\nKnow that the essence of intellect, after faith in Allah (swt), Mighty and Majestic, is managing relationships with people. There is no good in one who does not deal kindly with those whom he must interact with, until Allah (swt) provides a way for deliverance from them. Indeed, I have found that everything by which people live and associate with one another fills a measure - two-thirds of it is appreciation, and one-third of it is overlooking faults.\nAllah (swt), Mighty and Majestic, has created nothing better than speech, and nothing more disgraceful than it. With speech, faces are brightened, and with speech, faces are blackened.\nKnow that speech remains under your control as long as you have not spoken it, but once you have spoken it, you become under its control. So guard your tongue as you would guard your gold and silver, for the tongue is a vicious dog - if you release it, it will bite. Many a word has stripped a person of blessings.\nWhoever lets go of his restraint is led to every undesirable and disgraceful act, and he will not be saved from his time except with the wrath of Allah (swt), Mighty and Majestic and blame from people will follow the one who risks himself by relying solely on his own opinion.\nWhoever considers multiple perspectives will recognize where mistakes lie.\nWhoever rushes into matters without looking at the consequences exposes himself to devastating calamities.\nPlanning before action protects you from regret.\nThe intelligent one is he who learns from experiences, for in experiences lies new knowledge, and in the changes of circumstances lies the knowledge of the true nature of men.\nThe passing of days reveals hidden secrets.\nUnderstand this will of mine, and do not disregard it, for the best speech is that which benefits. Know, O' my son, that you must carefully seek provision and take only what is necessary while keeping your burden light. Do not load upon your back more than you can bear, lest it becomes a heavy burden upon you in your resurrection on the Day of Judgment.\nThe worst provision for the Hereafter is oppression against the servants of Allah (swt).\nKnow that ahead of you are dangers, pitfalls, bridges, and a steep ascent, which you will inevitably descend. Its descent will either lead to Paradise or to Hell. So prepare yourself before you reach it. If you find among those in need someone who can carry your provision to the Hereafter, so that he may deliver it to you when you are in dire need of it, then take advantage of this opportunity, and let him carry it for you while you have the ability. Perhaps a time will come when you seek such an opportunity but will not find it.\nBeware of entrusting your provisions to one who lacks piety and honesty, lest your condition be like that of a thirsty person who sees a mirage, but when he reaches it, he finds nothing, and so he remains stranded in the Hereafter with nothing to sustain him.\"\nAnd Commander of the Faithful Imam Ali ibn Abi Talib (as) said in this will:\n\"O' my son, oppression leads to ruin.\nNo one will perish who knows his own worth.\nWhoever safeguards his desires preserves his dignity.\nThe worth of every person is in what they excel at.\nReflection brings guidance.\nThe noblest wealth is to abandon false hopes.\nGreed is present poverty.\nAffection is an acquired kinship.\nYour true friend is your brother from your father and mother, but not every sibling from your parents is your friend.\nDo not take the enemy of your friend as a friend, lest you become an enemy to your own friend.\nHow many distant people are closer to you than those who are near?\nA generous yet poor person is better than a wealthy but rude one.\nAdmonition is a refuge for those who heed it.\nWhoever boasts of his favor (to others) spoils it (their reward).\nWhoever has bad manners torments himself, and resentment is more fitting for him.\nIt is unjust to judge based on suspicion when trust is required.\nHow ugly is arrogance in victory, despair in hardship, cruelty to a neighbor, betrayal of a companion, breaking an oath by a noble person, and treachery from a ruler.\nDenying blessings leads to destruction, and keeping company with a fool is misfortune.\nAcknowledge the right of those who uphold it, whether they are noble or lowly.\nWhoever abandons moderation goes astray.\nWhoever oversteps justice finds his path narrow. How many ailing people have survived, and how many healthy ones have perished? Sometimes despair leads to success, and greed leads to destruction.\nReconcile with those whom you hope will accept your apology.\nNever sleep with betrayal in your heart toward anyone, for betrayal is the worst trait of a Muslim.\nWhoever betrays is likely to never be trusted again.\nCorruption ruins abundance, while moderation increases little.\nOf nobility is fulfilling covenants.\nWhoever is generous will lead, and whoever seeks understanding will increase in wisdom.\nBe sincere in advising your brother and support him in all matters, as long as he does not lead you into disobedience to Allah (swt), Mighty and Majestic.\"\nStay with your brother wherever he goes. Do not sever ties with him over doubt, nor cut him off without first seeking reconciliation - perhaps he has an excuse while you blame him.\nAccept the apology of one who seeks pardon, so that intercession may reach you.\nHonor those through whom you gain strength, and lengthen your companionship with them in kindness, respect, reverence, and esteem.\nThe recompense of one who elevates your status is not that you lower his, and the reward of one who brings you joy is not that you cause him sorrow.\nShow as much kindness as you can to your companion, for when you wish, you will find his guidance.\nThe faults of one clothed in modesty remain hidden from sight.\nWhoever maintains moderation finds his burdens lightened. Whoever does not grant his soul its desires attains wisdom.\nWith every hardship, there is ease, and with every meal, there may be choking. No blessing is attained except after hardship.\nBe gentle with one who angers you, and you will achieve your goal.\nThe hours of distress are hours of atonement, and time gradually consumes your life.\nThere is no good in a pleasure that is followed by the Fire. And no good is truly good if it is followed by the Fire, and no evil is truly evil if it is followed by Paradise.\nEvery pleasure besides Paradise is insignificant, and every hardship besides the Fire is a form of well-being.\nDo not neglect your brother's right, relying on the bond between you and him, for he is not truly your brother if you disregard his right.\nDo not let your brother be stronger in cutting ties with you than you are in maintaining them, nor let him be more capable of harming you than you are of showing kindness to him.\nO' my son, when you are strong, then be strong in obedience to Allah (swt), Mighty and Majestic, and when you are weak, then let your weakness be in avoiding disobedience to Allah (swt), Mighty and Majestic.\nIf you can, do not grant a woman authority over her affairs beyond herself, for that preserves her beauty longer, brings her more peace of mind, and improves her condition.\nA woman is like a delicate flower, not a steward - so treat her kindly in every situation, and be good in your companionship with her so that your life may be peaceful.\nAccept fate with contentment.\nIf you wish to gather the best of this world and the Hereafter, then cut your expectations from what is in the hands of people.\nAnd peace be upon you, and the mercy of Allah (swt), and His (swt) blessings.\"", "arabicText": "5834 - ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙŠ ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ù„Ø§ÙØ¨Ù’Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ†ÙÙÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ø±ÙØ¶ÙÙŠÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù: \"ÙŠÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¥ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§ÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙƒÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙØ¶ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙˆÙ’ÙƒÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ«Ù’Ø¨ÙÙŠØ·ÙŒ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¢Ø®ÙØ±ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø­ÙØ¸Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ø¡Ù Ù‚ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ†ÙŒ ØµÙØ§Ù„ÙØ­ÙŒ Ø¬ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ³Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù ØªÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ§ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ±Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØµÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø°ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø°ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø·ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ²ÙØ®Ù’Ø±ÙÙÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¬ÙÙŠÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙÙ‘ÙÙ‚ÙØ©Ù ØªÙØ¨ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØºÙ’Ù„ÙØ¨ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’ÙƒÙ Ø³ÙÙˆØ¡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¸Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ¯ÙØ¹Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ„ÙÙƒÙ ØµÙÙ„Ù’Ø­Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙØ°Ù’ÙƒÙ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¯ÙØ¨Ù Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙÙƒÙ ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§ ØªÙØ°Ù’ÙƒÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø­ÙØ·ÙØ¨Ù ÙÙÙ†ÙØ¹Ù’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ’Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¯ÙØ¨Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ­ÙÙŠØ²ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¨Ù Ù„ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙØ¶Ù’Ù…ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¢Ø±ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¶ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¶Ù Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙØ®Ù’ØªÙØ±Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„ØµÙ‘ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¯ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ±Ù’ØªÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙŠÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ù„Ø§Ù Ø´ÙØ±ÙÙÙ Ø£ÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¥ÙØ³Ù’Ù„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙƒÙØ±ÙÙ…Ù Ø£ÙØ¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙÙ‚Ù’ÙˆÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ø±ÙØ²Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØ±ÙØ¹Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø´ÙÙÙÙŠØ¹Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¬ÙØ­Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ù„ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ§ÙÙÙŠÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙØ§ÙŠÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ù†ÙØ¹Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙƒÙÙ†Ù’Ø²Ù Ø£ÙØºÙ’Ù†ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ¹Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ù…ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø£ÙØ°Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¨Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¶ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ‚Ù’ØªÙØµÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙÙ„Ù’ØºÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙÙÙØ§ÙÙ ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙØ¸ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ§Ø­ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ¨ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ£Ù Ø®ÙÙÙ’Ø¶Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙØ¹ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ±Ù’ØµÙ Ø¯ÙØ§Ø¹Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙÙ‚ÙØ­Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙ†ÙÙˆØ¨Ù Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ÙƒÙ ÙˆÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¯ÙØ§ØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ…ÙÙˆÙ…Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ²ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØµÙ‘ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±Ù Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ¯Ù’ Ù†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„ØµÙ‘ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±Ù ÙÙÙ†ÙØ¹Ù’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙ‚Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØµÙ‘ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‡ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØµÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’ÙˆÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙ…ÙÙˆÙ…ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙÙØ§Ø²Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ²ÙÙˆÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙØ¬ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø³ÙØ¨ÙÙ‚ÙØªÙ’ Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³Ù’Ù†ÙÙ‰ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¦Ù’ Ù†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ±Ù ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ‡Ù‘ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ ØªÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ¦ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ÙƒÙÙ‡Ù’ÙÙ Ø­ÙØµÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙØ±Ù’Ø²Ù Ø­ÙØ±ÙÙŠØ²Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§Ù†ÙØ¹Ù Ø¹ÙØ²ÙÙŠØ²Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙØµÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ø£ÙÙ„ÙØ©Ù Ù„ÙØ±ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙØ±Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¥ÙØ¹Ù’Ø·ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¹Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„ØµÙ‘ÙÙ„ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ±Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ù†Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù‡ÙØ°ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù \"ÙŠÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ²Ù’Ù‚Ù Ø±ÙØ²Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø±ÙØ²Ù’Ù‚ÙŒ ØªÙØ·Ù’Ù„ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ²Ù’Ù‚ÙŒ ÙŠÙØ·Ù’Ù„ÙØ¨ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ØªÙØ£Ù’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙØªÙØ§ÙƒÙ ÙÙÙ„Ø§Ù ØªÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù’ Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ø³ÙÙ†ÙØªÙÙƒÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙÙÙØ§ÙƒÙ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙØ±ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø³ÙÙŠÙØ£Ù’ØªÙÙŠÙƒÙ ÙÙÙŠ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ØºÙØ¯Ù Ø¨ÙØ¬ÙØ¯ÙÙŠØ¯Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù‚ÙØ³ÙÙ…Ù Ù„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ØªÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙØ±ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙÙ…ÙØ§ ØªÙØµÙ’Ù†ÙØ¹Ù Ø¨ÙØºÙÙ…Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ù„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ³Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‚ÙÙƒÙ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø±ÙØ²Ù’Ù‚ÙÙƒÙ Ø·ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ¨ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØºÙ’Ù„ÙØ¨ÙÙƒÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ØºÙØ§Ù„ÙØ¨ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’ØªÙØ¬ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ÙƒÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ±Ù Ù„ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ Ø±ÙØ£ÙÙŠÙ’ØªÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø·ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ¨Ù Ù…ÙØªÙ’Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù Ù†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ‚Ù’ØªÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø±ÙØ²Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ‚Ù’ØªÙØµÙØ¯Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø·Ù‘ÙÙ„ÙØ¨Ù Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ø³ÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ¯ÙØªÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙŠØ±Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±ÙÙˆÙ†ÙŒ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙÙ†ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ù„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙ„ÙÙˆØºÙ ØºÙØ¯Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù ÙŠÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙØ±ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ„Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ø§Ù‹ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ¯Ù’Ø¨ÙØ±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØºÙ’Ø¨ÙÙˆØ·Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙÙ„Ù Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù„ÙØ©Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù…Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¢Ø®ÙØ±ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙˆÙØ§ÙƒÙÙŠÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØºÙØ±Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø·ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø­ÙÙ„ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¹ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙØ¨Ù’Ø·ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ù…ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙ‚ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø®ÙØ´ÙÙŠÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ Ø¹ÙØ§Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ‚ÙÙˆØ¨ÙØ©Ù Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ ÙŠÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ„Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ù…ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ¸ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ¯ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØ±Ù’ Ø£ÙØ­Ù’ÙƒÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¢Ø®ÙØ°Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ§ ØªÙØ£Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙƒÙÙÙ‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø¹ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ§ ØªÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ‰ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙˆÙÙ ØªÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØªÙ’Ù…ÙØ§Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙˆÙÙ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù’ÙŠÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ÙƒÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ ØªÙÙÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù’ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙÙ‚ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙˆÙØ±ÙØ«ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¨ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¨ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙÙˆÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¯ÙÙŠÙ†ÙØ§Ø±Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø¯ÙØ±Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙˆØ§ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù ÙÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ®ÙØ°Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø£ÙØ®ÙØ°Ù Ø¨ÙØ­ÙØ¸Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙØ§ÙÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø·ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù ÙŠÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØºÙ’ÙÙØ±Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØ§ÙˆÙØ§ØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¶Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø·Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø¬ÙÙˆÙ‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ø¡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙÙˆØªÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ­Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ¦ÙÙƒÙØ©Ù Ù„ÙØªÙØ¶ÙØ¹Ù Ø£ÙØ¬Ù’Ù†ÙØ­ÙØªÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ù„ÙØ·ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù Ø±ÙØ¶Ù‹Ø§ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠÙ‡Ù Ø´ÙØ±ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ÙŠÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙÙˆÙ’Ø²Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙ’Ù…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù„ÙØ£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙÙ‚ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ†ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¯ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘ÙØ¡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ ØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‰ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ø³ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¬ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§ ØªÙØ­ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ø³ÙÙ†Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’ÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ±Ù’Ø¶Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ù…ÙØ§ ØªÙØ±Ù’Ø¶ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙØ­Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙØ§ ØªÙØ³Ù’ØªÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙØ­ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙØ³Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ¹Ù Ø¬ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙ‚ÙÙƒÙ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ ØºÙØ¨Ù’ØªÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø­ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’ÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ù…ÙØªÙ‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙƒÙÙˆÙ’Ø§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’ÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ \"Ù‚Ù°Ø§Ù„ÙÙˆØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù°Ø§ Ù„ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù°Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù°Ø§ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø±Ù°Ø§Ø¬ÙØ¹ÙÙˆÙ†Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ØªÙÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙŠÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙÙ‡Ù \"Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ…Ù’Ø¯Ù Ù„ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù°Ù‡Ù Ø±ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹Ù°Ø§Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙŠÙ†Ù\" ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø±ÙØ£Ù’Ø³Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¥ÙÙŠÙ…ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙØ¯ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù ÙÙÙŠÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ¹ÙØ§Ø´ÙØ±Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙˆÙÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø¨ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ø´ÙØ±ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ ÙŠÙØ¬Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØµÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø³ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ„Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙŠ ÙˆÙØ¬ÙØ¯Ù’ØªÙ Ø¬ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ¹Ù Ù…ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØªÙØ¹ÙØ§ÙŠÙØ´Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ø´ÙØ±ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù…ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¡Ù Ù…ÙÙƒÙ’ÙŠÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø«ÙÙ„ÙØ«ÙØ§Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ­Ù’Ø³ÙØ§Ù†ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ø«ÙÙ„ÙØ«ÙÙ‡Ù ØªÙØºÙØ§ÙÙÙ„ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙ‚Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¦Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ø³ÙÙ†Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø£ÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙØ­Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙØ¨Ù’ÙŠÙØ¶Ù‘ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙˆÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’ÙƒÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ÙˆÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙˆÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙŠ ÙˆÙØ«ÙØ§Ù‚ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ØªÙØªÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ ØªÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù’ØªÙ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ØµÙØ±Ù’ØªÙ ÙÙÙŠ ÙˆÙØ«ÙØ§Ù‚ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØ§Ø®Ù’Ø²ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„ÙØ³ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙƒÙ ÙƒÙÙ…ÙØ§ ØªÙØ®Ù’Ø²ÙÙ†Ù Ø°ÙÙ‡ÙØ¨ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ ÙˆÙØ±ÙÙ‚ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙØ³ÙØ§Ù†Ù ÙƒÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙŒ Ø¹ÙÙ‚ÙÙˆØ±ÙŒ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ø®ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ’ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ‚ÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ¨Ù‘Ù ÙƒÙÙ„ÙÙ…ÙØ©Ù Ø³ÙÙ„ÙØ¨ÙØªÙ’ Ù†ÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙØ©Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø³ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙØ°ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙƒÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ‡ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ ÙÙØ¶ÙÙŠØ­ÙØ©Ù Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙØµÙ’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙÙ‚Ù’ØªÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø°ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ø®ÙØ§Ø·ÙØ±Ù Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØºÙ’Ù†ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙØ±ÙØ£Ù’ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ„Ù ÙˆÙØ¬ÙÙˆÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¢Ø±ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø¹ÙØ±ÙÙÙ Ù…ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙØ·ÙØ¥Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙˆÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ·Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…ÙÙˆØ±Ù ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ù†ÙØ§Ø¸ÙØ±Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’ ØªÙØ¹ÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ¶Ù Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙÙ’Ø¸ÙØ¹ÙØ§ØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙÙˆÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙØ¯Ù’Ø¨ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙÙ…ÙÙ„Ù ÙŠÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¯ÙÙ…Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ§Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙˆÙØ¹ÙØ¸ÙØªÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„ØªÙ‘ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙŒ Ù…ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ£Ù’Ù†ÙÙÙŒ ÙˆÙ ÙÙÙŠ ØªÙÙ‚ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ­Ù’ÙˆÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù Ø¬ÙÙˆÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§Ù…Ù ØªÙÙ‡Ù’ØªÙÙƒÙ Ù„ÙÙƒÙ Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ†ÙØ©Ù ØªÙÙÙÙ‡Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØªÙÙŠ Ù‡ÙØ°ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ØªÙØ°Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¨ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’ÙƒÙ ØµÙÙÙ’Ø­Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙØ¥ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù†ÙÙÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„Ø§Ù Ø¨ÙØ¯Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙØ³Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ±Ù’ØªÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØºÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø²Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ù…ÙØ¹Ù Ø®ÙÙÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¸Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø±Ù ÙÙÙ„Ø§Ù ØªÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù’ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¸ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙÙˆÙ’Ù‚Ù Ø·ÙØ§Ù‚ÙØªÙÙƒÙ ÙÙÙŠÙÙƒÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’ÙƒÙ Ø«ÙÙ‚Ù’Ù„Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙÙŠ Ø­ÙØ´Ù’Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙØ´Ù’Ø±ÙÙƒÙ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙÙØ¨ÙØ¦Ù’Ø³Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø²Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¯Ù’ÙˆÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù…ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ÙˆÙÙŠÙ ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙØ³ÙÙˆØ±Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ‚ÙØ¨ÙØ©Ù‹ ÙƒÙØ¦ÙÙˆØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ù„Ø§Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ù‡ÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ·ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù’Ø¨ÙØ·ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ§ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø¬ÙÙ†Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù†ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙÙØ§Ø±Ù’ØªÙØ¯Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙƒÙ Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ù„Ù Ù†ÙØ²ÙÙˆÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ø¥ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ ÙˆÙØ¬ÙØ¯Ù’ØªÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙØ§Ù‚ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù Ø²ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙƒÙ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù ÙÙÙŠÙÙˆÙØ§ÙÙÙŠÙƒÙ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ØºÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ø­ÙÙŠÙ’Ø«Ù ØªÙØ­Ù’ØªÙØ§Ø¬Ù Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙÙØ§ØºÙ’ØªÙÙ†ÙÙ…Ù’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ø«ÙØ±Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙØ²ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ±ÙŒ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù ÙÙÙ„ÙØ¹ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ ØªÙØ·Ù’Ù„ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙÙ„Ø§Ù ØªÙØ¬ÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¥ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ§ÙƒÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙØ«ÙÙ‚Ù Ù„ÙØªÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ø²ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙƒÙ Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙˆÙØ±ÙØ¹Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù Ø£ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ù†ÙØ©Ù ÙÙÙŠÙÙƒÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ù…ÙØ«ÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙØ«ÙÙ„Ù Ø¸ÙÙ…Ù’Ø¢Ù†Ù Ø±ÙØ£ÙÙ‰ Ø³ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¨Ø§Ù‹ Ø­ÙØªÙ‘ÙÙ‰ Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø¬ÙØ§Ø¡ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ¬ÙØ¯Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø´ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¦Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙØªÙØ¨Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ‰ ÙÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ù‚ÙØ·ÙØ¹Ø§Ù‹ Ø¨ÙÙƒÙ\" ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù ÙÙÙŠ Ù‡ÙØ°ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙØµÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù \"ÙŠÙØ§ Ø¨ÙÙ†ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙØºÙ’ÙŠÙ Ø³ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ‚ÙŒ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ù„ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„ÙÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙØ¤ÙŒ Ø¹ÙØ±ÙÙÙ Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø­ÙØµÙ‘ÙÙ†Ù Ø´ÙÙ‡Ù’ÙˆÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ØµÙØ§Ù†Ù Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù Ù‚ÙÙŠÙ…ÙØ©Ù ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙØ¦Ù Ù…ÙØ§ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ø³ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙŠÙÙÙÙŠØ¯ÙÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ´ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø£ÙØ´Ù’Ø±ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ØºÙÙ†ÙÙ‰ ØªÙØ±Ù’ÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ±Ù’ØµÙ ÙÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±ÙŒ Ø­ÙØ§Ø¶ÙØ±ÙŒ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ù‚ÙØ±ÙØ§Ø¨ÙØ©ÙŒ Ù…ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙÙÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©ÙŒ ØµÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ‚ÙÙƒÙ Ø£ÙØ®ÙÙˆÙƒÙ Ù„ÙØ£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø£ÙØ®Ù Ù„ÙÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙƒÙ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ ØµÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ‚ÙÙƒÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ØªÙØªÙ‘ÙØ®ÙØ°ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø¹ÙØ¯ÙÙˆÙ‘Ù ØµÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ‚ÙƒÙ ØµÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù‹ ÙÙØªÙØ¹ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙŠÙ ØµÙØ¯ÙÙŠÙ‚ÙÙƒÙ ÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙÙŠØ¯Ù Ø£ÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±ÙØ¨Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ÙƒÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù‚ÙØ±ÙÙŠØ¨Ù ÙˆÙØµÙÙˆÙ„ÙŒ Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙÙ…ÙŒ Ø®ÙÙŠÙ’Ø±ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØ«Ù’Ø±Ù Ø¬ÙØ§ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¹ÙØ¸ÙØ©Ù ÙƒÙÙ‡Ù’ÙÙŒ Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙˆÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù‡ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø¨ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙˆÙÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙØ¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙØ³ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø®ÙÙ„ÙÙ‚ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ°Ù‘ÙØ¨Ù Ù†ÙÙÙ’Ø³ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙØºÙ’Ø¶ÙØ©Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„ÙÙ‰ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ¯Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ¶ÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ø¸Ù‘ÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø«Ù‘ÙÙ‚ÙØ©Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙØ­Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ´ÙØ±Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¸Ù‘ÙÙÙØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙØ¢Ø¨ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ¨ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¶ÙÙ„ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ³Ù’ÙˆÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø®ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„ØµÙ‘ÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ†Ù’Ø«Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø°ÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ±ÙÙˆØ¡ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ØºÙØ¯Ù’Ø±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ù’Ø·ÙØ§Ù†ÙØŒ ÙƒÙÙÙ’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¹ÙÙ…Ù Ù…ÙÙˆÙ‚ÙŒ ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ³ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‚Ù Ø´ÙØ¤Ù’Ù…ÙŒ Ø§ÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙÙ…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¹ÙØ±ÙÙÙÙ‡Ù Ù„ÙÙƒÙ Ø´ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙØ§Ù‹ ÙƒÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø£ÙÙˆÙ’ ÙˆÙØ¶ÙÙŠØ¹Ø§Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙØ±ÙÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØµÙ’Ø¯Ù Ø¬ÙØ§Ø±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙØ¹ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘Ù Ø¶ÙØ§Ù‚Ù Ù…ÙØ°Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¯ÙÙ†ÙÙÙ Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ù†ÙØ¬ÙØ§ ÙˆÙ ØµÙØ­ÙÙŠØ­Ù Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ Ù‡ÙÙˆÙÙ‰ Ù‚ÙØ¯Ù’ ÙŠÙÙƒÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙŠÙØ£Ù’Ø³Ù Ø¥ÙØ¯Ù’Ø±ÙØ§ÙƒØ§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø·Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙØ¹Ù Ù‡ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙƒØ§Ù‹ Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙØ¨Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø±ÙØ¬ÙÙˆÙ’ØªÙ Ø¹ÙØªÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù Ù„Ø§Ù ØªÙØ¨ÙÙŠØªÙÙ†Ù‘Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙØ¦Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ØºÙØ¯Ù’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ØºÙØ¯Ù’Ø±Ù Ø´ÙØ±Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø³Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù’Ø¡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’Ù„ÙÙ…Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØºÙØ¯ÙØ±Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙÙ‚Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙÙˆÙÙÙ‰ Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙÙØ³ÙØ§Ø¯Ù ÙŠÙØ¨ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙØ«ÙÙŠØ±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ‚Ù’ØªÙØµÙØ§Ø¯Ù ÙŠÙÙ†Ù’Ù…ÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙŠÙØ³ÙÙŠØ±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙØ±ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙÙÙØ§Ø¡Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙ…ÙÙ…Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ÙƒÙØ±ÙÙ…Ù Ø³ÙØ§Ø¯Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ ØªÙÙÙÙ‡Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙØ²Ù’Ø¯ÙØ§Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø­ÙØ¶Ù’ Ø£ÙØ®ÙØ§ÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØµÙÙŠØ­ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø³ÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ¯Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø­ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù…ÙØ§ Ù„ÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„Ù’ÙƒÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’ØµÙÙŠÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ²Ù‘Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¬ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ø²ÙÙ„Ù’ Ù…ÙØ¹ÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙÙŠÙ’Ø«Ù Ø²ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ù„Ø§Ù ØªÙØµÙ’Ø±ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø£ÙØ®ÙØ§ÙƒÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙØ±Ù’ØªÙÙŠÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙˆÙ Ù„Ø§Ù ØªÙÙ‚Ù’Ø·ÙØ¹Ù’Ù‡Ù Ø¯ÙÙˆÙ†Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ù’ØªÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ù„ÙØ¹ÙÙ„Ù‘Ù Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¹ÙØ°Ù’Ø±Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ ØªÙÙ„ÙÙˆÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ‚Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ„Ù’ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ù…ÙØªÙÙ†ÙØµÙ‘ÙÙ„Ù Ø¹ÙØ°Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙÙØªÙÙ†ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙÙÙØ§Ø¹ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±ÙÙ…Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ ØªÙØµÙÙˆÙ„Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ²Ù’Ø¯ÙØ¯Ù’ Ù„ÙÙ‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø·ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„ØµÙ‘ÙØ­Ù’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù Ø¨ÙØ±Ù‘Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ
