Ø®Ø´Ø¹ÙˆØ§ (3) Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø§Ø¹Ø© ÙØªÙ‡Ø¨ÙˆØ§ (4)ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ù… ØºØ§Ø¶ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ø¨ØµØ§Ø±Ù‡Ù… Ø¹Ù…Ø§ Ø­Ø±Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù‚ÙÙŠÙ† Ø£Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¹Ù‡Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ù†Ø²Ù„Øª Ø£Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ù„Ø§Ø¡ ÙƒØ§Ù„ØªÙŠ Ù†Ø²Ù„Øª Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø®Ø§Ø¡ØŒ Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¶Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ø¬Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ ÙƒØªØ¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (1) Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ù„Ù… ØªØ³ØªÙ‚Ø± Ø£Ø±ÙˆØ§Ø­Ù‡Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø£Ø¬Ø³Ø§Ø¯Ù‡Ù… Ø·Ø±ÙØ© Ø¹ÙŠÙ†ØŒ Ø´ÙˆÙ‚Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø«ÙˆØ§Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆØ®ÙˆÙØ§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚Ø§Ø¨. Ø¹Ø¸Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø§Ù„Ù‚ ÙÙŠ Ø£Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙˆØ¶Ø¹ (2) Ù…Ø§ Ø¯ÙˆÙ†Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø£Ø¹ÙŠÙ†Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø© ÙƒÙ…Ù† Ø±Ø¢Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ù… ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ù…ØªÙƒØ¦ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø± ÙƒÙ…Ù† Ø±Ø¢Ù‡Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ù… ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ø°Ø¨ÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ù‚Ù„ÙˆØ¨Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ø­Ø²ÙˆÙ†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ´Ø±ÙˆØ±Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø¬Ø³Ø§Ø¯Ù‡Ù… Ù†Ø­ÙŠÙØ©ØŒ ÙˆØ­ÙˆØ§Ø¦Ø¬Ù‡Ù… Ø®ÙÙŠÙØ©ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡Ù… Ø¹ÙÙŠÙØ©ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø¤Ù†ØªÙ‡Ù… Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ…Ø©ØŒ ØµØ¨Ø±ÙˆØ§ Ø£ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø§ Ù‚ØµØ§Ø±Ø§ Ø£Ø¹Ù‚Ø¨ØªÙ‡Ù… Ø±Ø§Ø­Ø© Ø·ÙˆÙŠÙ„Ø©ØŒ ØªØ¬Ø§Ø±Ø© Ù…Ø±Ø¨Ø­Ø© ÙŠØ³Ø±Ù‡Ø§ Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ø±Ø¨ ÙƒØ±ÙŠÙ…ØŒ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯ÙˆÙ‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ·Ù„Ø¨ØªÙ‡Ù… ÙØ£Ø¹Ø¬Ø²ÙˆÙ‡Ø§. Ø£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„ÙŠÙ„ ÙØµØ§ÙÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù‚Ø¯Ø§Ù…Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ØªØ§Ù„ÙŠÙ† Ù„Ø§Ø¬Ø²Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù†ØŒ ÙŠØ±ØªÙ„ÙˆÙ†Ù‡ ØªØ±ØªÙŠÙ„Ø§ØŒ ÙŠØ­Ø²Ù†ÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø£Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ³ØªØ«ÙŠØ±ÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¯ÙˆØ§Ø¡ Ø¯Ø§Ø¦Ù‡Ù… ÙˆÙŠÙ‡ÙŠØ¬ Ø£Ø­Ø²Ø§Ù†Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ø¨ÙƒØ§Ø¡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø°Ù†ÙˆØ¨Ù‡Ù… ÙˆÙˆØ¬Ø¹ ÙƒÙ„ÙˆÙ… Ø¬Ø±Ø§Ø­Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ø±ÙˆØ§ Ø¨Ø¢ÙŠØ© ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ ØªØ®ÙˆÙŠÙØŒ Ø£ØµØºÙˆØ§ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ù…Ø³Ø§Ù…Ø¹ Ù‚Ù„ÙˆØ¨Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ£Ø¨ØµØ§Ø±Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ§Ù‚Ø´Ø¹Ø±Øª Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø¬Ù„ÙˆØ¯Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙˆØ¬Ù„Øª Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ù‚Ù„ÙˆØ¨Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ¸Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ù† ØµÙ‡ÙŠÙ„ Ø¬Ù‡Ù†Ù… ÙˆØ²ÙÙŠØ±Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØ´Ù‡ÙŠÙ‚Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø£ØµÙˆÙ„ Ø¢Ø°Ø§Ù†Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ø±ÙˆØ§ Ø¨Ø¢ÙŠØ© ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ ØªØ´ÙˆÙŠÙ‚ Ø±ÙƒÙ†ÙˆØ§ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø·Ù…Ø¹Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØªØ·Ù„Ø¹Øª Ø§Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡Ù… Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø´ÙˆÙ‚Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ¸Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ù†ØµØ¨ Ø£Ø¹ÙŠÙ†Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ø¬Ø§Ø«ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£ÙˆØ³Ø§Ø·Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙŠÙ…Ø¬Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø¬Ø¨Ø§Ø±Ø§ Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ…Ø§ØŒ Ù…ÙØªØ±Ø´ÙŠÙ† Ø¬Ø¨Ø§Ù‡Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ£ÙƒÙÙ‡Ù… ÙˆØ±ÙƒØ¨Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ£Ø·Ø±Ø§Ù Ø£Ù‚Ø¯Ø§Ù…Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ØªØ¬Ø±ÙŠ Ø¯Ù…ÙˆØ¹Ù‡Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø®Ø¯ÙˆØ¯Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙŠØ¬Ø£Ø±ÙˆÙ† Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ ÙÙƒØ§Ùƒ Ø±Ù‚Ø§Ø¨Ù‡Ù…. Ø£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‡Ø§Ø± ÙØ­Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ø¨Ø±Ø±Ø© Ø£ØªÙ‚ÙŠØ§ØŒ Ù‚Ø¯ Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙˆÙØŒ ÙÙ‡Ù… Ø£Ù…Ø«Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¯Ø§Ø­ØŒ ÙŠÙ†Ø¸Ø± Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø¸Ø± ÙÙŠØ­Ø³Ø¨Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ø±Ø¶Ù‰ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ… Ù…Ù† Ù…Ø±Ø¶ØŒ Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„: Ù‚Ø¯ Ø®ÙˆÙ„Ø·ÙˆØ§ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø®Ø§Ù„Ø· Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ… Ø£Ù…Ø± Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ…ØŒ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ ÙÙƒØ±ÙˆØ§ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø¸Ù…Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ´Ø¯Ø© Ø³Ù„Ø·Ø§Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø¹ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ®Ø§Ù„Ø·Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù† Ø°ÙƒØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØª ÙˆØ£Ù‡ÙˆØ§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙØ²Ø¹ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù‚Ù„ÙˆØ¨Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ·Ø§Ø´Øª Ø­Ù„ÙˆÙ…Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ°Ù‡Ù„Øª Ø¹Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ø³ØªÙØ§Ù‚ÙˆØ§ Ø¨Ø§Ø¯Ø±ÙˆØ§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¹Ù…Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø²ÙƒÙŠØ©. Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ±Ø¶ÙˆÙ† Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ù„ÙŠÙ„ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ³ØªÙƒØ«Ø±ÙˆÙ† Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø²ÙŠÙ„ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ù… Ù„Ø§Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡Ù… Ù…ØªÙ‡Ù…ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø£Ø¹Ù…Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ø´ÙÙ‚ÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ø¥Ù† Ø²ÙƒÙŠ Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ù‡Ù… Ø®Ø§Ù Ù…Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ³ØªØºÙØ± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù…ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø¨Ù†ÙØ³ÙŠ Ù…Ù† ØºÙŠØ±ÙŠØŒ ÙˆØ±Ø¨ÙŠ Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ù…Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ù†ÙØ³ÙŠ (1)ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ù„Ø§ ØªØ¤Ø§Ø®Ø°Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ùˆ Ø§Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Ù†ÙŠ Ø®ÙŠØ±Ø§ Ù…Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ¸Ù†ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ§ØºÙØ± Ù„ÙŠ Ù…Ø§Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù…ÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù†Ùƒ Ø¹Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„ØºÙŠÙˆØ¨ØŒ ÙˆØ³Ø§ØªØ± Ø§Ù„Ø¹ÙŠÙˆØ¨. ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø¹Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ù‡Ù… Ø£Ù†Ùƒ ØªØ±Ù‰ Ù„Ù‡ Ù‚ÙˆØ© ÙÙŠ Ø¯ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø²Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ù„ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ¥ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†Ø§ ÙÙŠ ÙŠÙ‚ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø±ØµØ§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙÙ‡Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠ ÙÙ‚Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø­Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ³Ø¨Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø±ÙÙ‚ØŒ ÙˆØ´ÙÙ‚Ø© ÙÙŠ Ù†ÙÙ‚Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚ØµØ¯Ø§ ÙÙŠ ØºÙ†Ù‰ØŒ ÙˆØ®Ø´ÙˆØ¹Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø¨Ø§Ø¯Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØªØ¬Ù…Ù„Ø§ ÙÙŠ ÙØ§Ù‚Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØµØ¨Ø±Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø´Ø¯Ø©ØŒ Ùˆ Ø±Ø­Ù…Ø© Ù„Ù„Ù…Ø¬Ù‡ÙˆØ¯ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø¹Ø·Ø§Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø­Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆØ±ÙÙ‚Ø§ ÙÙŠ ÙƒØ³Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆØ·Ù„Ø¨Ø§ Ù„Ù„Ø­Ù„Ø§Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ø´Ø§Ø·Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ø¯Ù‰ØŒ ÙˆØªØ­Ø±Ø¬Ø§ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø·Ù…Ø¹ØŒ ÙˆØ¨Ø±Ø£ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ø³ØªÙ‚Ø§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ¥ØºÙ…Ø§Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø´Ù‡ÙˆØ©. Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØºØ±Ù‡ Ø«Ù†Ø§Ø¡ Ù…Ù† Ø¬Ù‡Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø¹ Ø¥Ø­ØµØ§Ø¡ Ø¹Ù…Ù„Ù‡ (2)ØŒ Ù…Ø³ØªØ¨Ø·Ø¦Ø§ Ù„Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù…Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ¹Ù…Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¹Ù…Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„ØµØ§Ù„Ø­Ø© ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙˆØ¬Ù„ØŒ ÙŠÙ…Ø³ÙŠ ÙˆÙ‡Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙƒØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØµØ¨Ø­ ÙˆØ´ØºÙ„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙƒØ±ØŒ ÙŠØ¨ÙŠØª Ø­Ø°Ø±Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ø­Ø°Ø± Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØºÙÙ„Ø©ØŒ ÙØ±Ø­Ø§ Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ø£ØµØ§Ø¨ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø±Ø­Ù…Ø©ØŒ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ø³ØªØµØ¹Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¹Ø·Ù‡Ø§ Ø³Ø¤Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ø¶Ø±ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙÙØ±Ø­Ù‡ ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ ÙŠØ®Ù„Ø¯ ÙˆÙŠØ¯ÙˆÙ…ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø±Ø© Ø¹ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ²ÙˆÙ„ØŒ ÙˆØ±ØºØ¨Ø© ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ ÙŠØ¨Ù‚Ù‰ØŒ ÙˆØ²Ù‡Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ ÙŠÙÙ†Ù‰ØŒ ÙŠÙ…Ø±Ø¬ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ…Ø²Ø¬ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù„Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚Ù„. ØªØ±Ø§Ù‡ Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠØ¯ ÙƒØ³Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø¯Ø§Ø¦Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ø´Ø§Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø±ÙŠØ¨Ø§ Ø£Ù…Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ù„ÙŠÙ„Ø§ Ø²Ù„ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ØŒ Ù…ØªÙˆÙ‚Ø¹Ø§ Ø£Ø¬Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø®Ø§Ø´Ø¹Ø§ Ù‚Ù„Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ Ø°Ø§ÙƒØ±Ø§ Ø±Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ Ø®Ø§Ø¦ÙØ§ Ø°Ù†Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù†Ø¹Ø© Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ Ù…ØªØºÙŠØ¨Ø§ Ø¬Ù‡Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø³Ù‡Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù‡ØŒ Ø­Ø±ÙŠØ²Ø§ Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ØŒ Ù…ÙŠØªØ© Ø´Ù‡ÙˆØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙƒØ§Ø¸Ù…Ø§ ØºÙŠØ¸Ù‡ØŒ ØµØ§ÙÙŠØ§ Ø®Ù„Ù‚Ù‡ØŒ Ø¢Ù…Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø¬Ø§Ø±Ù‡ØŒ Ø¶Ø¹ÙŠÙØ§ ÙƒØ¨Ø±Ù‡ØŒ Ù…ØªÙŠÙ†Ø§ ØµØ¨Ø±Ù‡ØŒ ÙƒØ«ÙŠØ±Ø§ Ø°ÙƒØ±Ù‡ØŒ Ù…Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù‡. Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ­Ø¯Ø« Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ¤ØªÙ…Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø§ØµØ¯Ù‚Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒØªÙ… Ø´Ù‡Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¹Ø¯Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ù…Ù„ Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ØŒ Ø±ÙŠØ§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØªØ±ÙƒÙ‡ Ø­ÙŠØ§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙŠØ± Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ„ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´Ø± Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ø¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØºØ§ÙÙ„ÙŠÙ† ÙƒØªØ¨ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø°Ø§ÙƒØ±ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø°Ø§ÙƒØ±ÙŠÙ† Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒØªØ¨ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØºØ§ÙÙ„ÙŠÙ†. ÙŠØ¹ÙÙˆ Ø¹Ù…Ù† Ø¸Ù„Ù…Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ¹Ø·ÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø­Ø±Ù…Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØµÙ„ Ù…Ù† Ù‚Ø·Ø¹Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø²Ø¨ Ø­Ù„Ù…Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø¬Ù„ ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØµÙØ­ Ø¹Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø¯ ØªØ¨ÙŠÙ† Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠØ¯Ø§ Ø¬Ù‡Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ù„ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ØŒ ØºØ§Ø¦Ø¨Ø§ Ù…ÙƒØ±Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø±ÙŠØ¨Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ø±ÙˆÙÙ‡ØŒ ØµØ§Ø¯Ù‚Ø§ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ØŒ Ø­Ø³Ù†Ø§ ÙØ¹Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ù…Ù‚Ø¨Ù„Ø§ Ø®ÙŠØ±Ù‡ØŒ Ù…Ø¯Ø¨Ø±Ø§ Ø´Ø±Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø²Ù„Ø§Ø²Ù„ ÙˆÙ‚ÙˆØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙƒØ§Ø±Ù‡ ØµØ¨ÙˆØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø®Ø§Ø¡ Ø´ÙƒÙˆØ±ØŒ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ­ÙŠÙ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ù† ÙŠØ¨ØºØ¶ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ£Ø«Ù… ÙÙŠÙ…Ù† ÙŠØ­Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø¹ÙŠ Ù…Ø§ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬Ø­Ø¯ Ø­Ù‚Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙŠØ¹ØªØ±Ù Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ´Ù‡Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¶ÙŠØ¹ Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ø³ØªØ­ÙØ¸ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØªÙ†Ø§Ø¨Ø² Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¨ØŒ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¨ØºÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¶Ø± Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ù…Øª Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù…ØµØ§Ø¦Ø¨ØŒ Ø³Ø±ÙŠØ¹ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ØµÙˆØ§Ø¨ØŒ Ù…Ø¤Ø¯ Ù„Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§Ù†Ø§ØªØŒ Ø¨Ø·Ø¦ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†ÙƒØ±Ø§Øª. ÙŠØ£Ù…Ø± Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹Ø±ÙˆÙØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ†Ù‡Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†ÙƒØ±ØŒ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø®Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…ÙˆØ± Ø¨Ø¬Ù‡Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ®Ø±Ø¬ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¬Ø²ØŒ Ø¥Ù† ØµÙ…Øª Ù„Ù… ÙŠØºÙ…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ØµÙ…ØªØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ù†Ø·Ù‚ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙ‚Ù„ Ø®Ø·Ø£ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ø¶Ø­Ùƒ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¹Ø¯ ØµÙˆØªÙ‡ Ø³Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù†Ø¹Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù‚Ø¯Ø± Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬Ù…Ø¹ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ØºÙŠØ¸ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØºÙ„Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù‡ÙˆÙ‰ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙ‚Ù‡Ø±Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø­ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ·Ù…Ø¹ ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙŠØ®Ø§Ù„Ø· Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ù„ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØµÙ…Øª Ù„ÙŠØ³Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ³Ø£Ù„ Ù„ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ¨Ø­Ø« Ù„ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ†ØµØª Ù„Ù„Ø®ÙŠØ± Ù„ÙŠÙØ®Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØªÙƒÙ„Ù… Ø¨Ù‡ Ù„ÙŠØªØ¬Ø¨Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ù† Ø³ÙˆØ§Ù‡ØŒ Ø¥Ù† Ø¨ØºÙŠ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ØµØ¨Ø± Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ [ Ù‡Ùˆ ] (1) Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙŠÙ†ØªÙ‚Ù… Ù„Ù‡. Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ù†Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø±Ø§Ø­Ø©ØŒ Ø£ØªØ¹Ø¨ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø±Ø§Ø­ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ù…Ù† Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯Ù‡ Ù…Ù…Ù† ØªØ¨Ø§Ø¹Ø¯ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡ Ø²Ù‡Ø¯ ÙˆÙ†Ø²Ø§Ù‡Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ¯ÙˆÙ†Ù‡ Ù…Ù…Ù† Ø¯Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ù„ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ±Ø­Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø¹Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¨ÙƒØ¨Ø± ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¹Ø¸Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¯Ù†ÙˆÙ‡ Ù„Ø®Ø¯ÙŠØ¹Ø© ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø®Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ø© (2)ØŒ Ø¨Ù„ ÙŠÙ‚ØªØ¯ÙŠ Ø¨Ù…Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù‚Ø¨Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¥Ù…Ø§Ù… Ù„Ù…Ù† Ø®Ù„ÙÙ‡ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø±. Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØµØ¹Ù‚ Ù‡Ù…Ø§Ù… ØµØ¹Ù‚Ø© ÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): Ø£Ù…Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ù‚Ø¯ ÙƒÙ†Øª Ø£Ø®Ø§ÙÙ‡Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡. ÙˆØ£Ù…Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ ÙØ¬Ù‡Ø² ÙˆØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡ÙƒØ°Ø§ ØªØµÙ†Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØ§Ø¹Ø¸ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ù„ØºØ© Ø¨Ø£Ù‡Ù„Ù‡Ø§. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù„: ÙÙ…Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù†Øª ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ†ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙˆÙŠÙ„Ùƒ! Ø¥Ù† Ù„ÙƒÙ„ Ø£Ø¬Ù„Ø§ Ù„Ù† ÙŠØ¹Ø¯ÙˆÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØ³Ø¨Ø¨Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬Ø§ÙˆØ²Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ…Ù‡Ù„Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ØªØ¹Ø¯ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡ Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ù†ÙØ« Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù„Ø³Ø§Ù†Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙŠØ·Ø§Ù† (1).", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/29/1/84/2", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 84, "thaqalaynSanad": "Muhammad b. al-Hasan b. Ahmad b. al-Walid narrated to me. He said: Muhammad b. al-Hasan al-Saffar narrated to me. He said: `Ali b. Hassan al-Wasiti narrated to us from his uncle `Abd al-Rahman b. Kathir al-Hashimi from Ja`far b. Muhammad from his father (as). He said: ", "thaqalaynMatn": "A man from the companions of Amir al-Muâ€™minin (as) called Hammam, who was a worshiper, stood up and said: O Amir al-Muâ€™minin! Describe the Godfearing ones to me in such a way that it is as though I am looking at them. So, Amir al-Muâ€™minin (as) did not reply. Then, he said to him: Woe to you, Hammam, fear Allah and beautify, for Allah is with the Godfearing who beautify. So, Hammam said: O Amir al-Muâ€™minin! I ask you by Him who honoured you with that which He distinguished you with, and preferred you with what He gave you, and granted you with what you describe to me. So, Amir al-Muâ€™minin (as) stood on his feet, praised Allah and commended Him, blessed the Prophet and his Family, then said: As for that which comes after: Surely, Allah created the creation, and He was needless of their obedience and safe from their disobedience; for the disobedience of one who disobeys Him does not harm Him, and the obedience of one who obeys Him does not benefit Him. He apportioned their livelihood between them and placed them in their position in the world. Surely, Allah only caused Adam and Hawwaâ€™ (as) to fall from Paradise as a punishment for what they had done when He prohibited them [from the fruit] and they defied Him; when He commanded them and they disobeyed Him. The pious therein (in the world) are of the people of virtue â€“ their logic is sound, their apparel is prudence, and their sojourn is humility. They humble themselves before Allah through obedience, and they empty themselves [of this world]. They lower their gaze from that which Allah forbade them from. Their ears are set upon knowledge. They remedy their souls in calamity just as they remedy their souls in tranquility. They are content with the predestination of Allah. Had it not been for the time that Allah has ordained for them, their souls would not remain in their bodies for [the duration of] a twinkling of the eye out of desire for reward and fear of punishment. The greatness of the Creator is in their souls, and everything else is insignificant in their eyes. It is as though they could see Paradise and are reclining in it. It is as though they could see the Fire and are suffering in it. Their hearts are in grief, their evil is harmless, their bodies are thin, their needs are trivial, their souls are pure, and their restraint from this world is great. They are patient for a short number of days, followed by [a] long [period of] rest â€“ [it is a] good trade that the Generous Lord eased for them. This world wanted them, but they did not want it; it sought them, but they escaped it. At night, they line up their legs and recite and hymn sections (ajzaâ€™) of the Quran. With it, they bring grief to their souls, and they use it to treat their ailments, the agitation of their grief, their weeping over their sins, and the pain of their wounds. When they come across a verse that frightens, they attend to it with their hearts and their sights. Their skin shudders from it, their hearts tremble from it, and they feel as though the roar, exhalation, and inhalation of Hell is in their ears. When they come across a verse that gives glad tidings, they incline toward it with hope, their souls [almost] leave [their body] out of desire for it, and they feel as though it is before their eyes. They kneel, glorifying the Great and Powerful God, [prostrating with] their foreheads, hands, knees, and the tips of their feet. Their tears flow down their cheeks, pleading to Allah that He unfastens their necks. In the day, they are wise, scholarly, righteous, and pious. Fear has made them thin like arrows. When one looks at them, he will think that they are ill, even though they are not ill; or he will say: â€œthey are bewilderedâ€, and [yes,] they are bewildered by a great matter. When they think about the greatness of Allah and the intensity of His power along with their bewilderment at the thought of death and the horrors of the Resurrection, their hearts panic. So, their thoughts become overwhelmed and their minds become astounded. When they awake, they hasten to Allah with pure deeds. They are not satisfied with doing few deeds for Allah, and they do not regard their many deeds as great. They cast blame on their own selves, and they pity their own deeds. If one of them is praised [by the people], he fears what they say, and he repents to Allah for what they do not know about, and he says: â€œI know more about myself than others, and Allah knows more about me than myself. O Allah! Do not hold me account to what they say, make me better than what they think, and forgive me of that which they do not know about me, for You are the Knower of the Unseen and the Concealer of Flaws.â€ One of their signs is that you will see that they have strength in religion, determination with leniency, faith with certainty, protectiveness over knowledge, the comprehension of understanding, knowledge with forbearance, favourable in good times, sorrowful in loss, moderate when they are wealthy, humble in worship, elegant in poverty, patient in tough times, graceful in effort, giving in the rights [of others], friendly in good times, seeking the permissible, lively in guidance, ashamed of greediness, healed by uprightness, and neglectful of desires. He is not deceived by the compliments of those ignorant of him, and he does not stop counting his deeds. He takes his time in his deeds, and he does righteous deeds whilst he is fearful. When he sleeps, his concern is gratitude, and when he awakes, he busies himself with the remembrance [of Allah]. He sleeps with caution lest he becomes heedless, and he becomes happy when he receives bounties and grace. When his soul burdens him, he does not give it that which ails it. His happiness is in the Immortal and the Everlasting. The joy of his eye is in Him who does not recede. His desire is in Him who remains. He is ascetic to that which is fleeting. He intertwines knowledge with forbearance, and he intertwines forbearance with intellect. You find him far removed from laziness, for he is always active. He inclines toward hope. He makes few slips. He is expectant of his death. He humbles his heart. He remembers his Lord. He fears his sin. He is content in his soul. His ignorance is absent. His demeanor is easygoing. He is protective of his religion. His lust is deadened. He withholds his wrath. His character is serene. His neighbours are safe from him. His arrogance is feeble. His patience is strong. His remembrance [of his Lord] is much. He is orderly. He does not speak about that which his friends have entrusted him with, and he does not hide what he sees of the enemy. He does not do the right thing to flaunt. Modesty never leaves him. Goodness is expected from him, and [people consider themselves] safe from his evil. When he is heedless, he is considered among those who remember; and when he is considered among those who remember, he will not be considered heedless. He forgives those who wrong him, he gives to those who deprive him, and he connects to those who cut him off. He does not cease in his forbearance. He does not come down on those who doubt him, and he pardons them once they see him [properly]. His ignorance is far removed. His speech is tender. His plotting is absent. His established virtues are imminent. His speech is honest. His actions are beautiful. His goodness is accepted [by Allah]. He has turned away from evil. In earthquakes, he is solemn. In bad times, he is patient. In relaxation, he is thankful. He does not treat one that he hates unfairly. He does not harm one that he loves. He does not claim what does not belong to him. He does not deny a right that he must give [to others]. He confesses to the truth before witnesses testify against him. He does not lose what he is entrusted with. He does not call people by hateful nicknames. He does not betray anyone. He does not concern himself with envy. He does not harm the neighbour. He does not gloat over misfortunes. He is quick to reason. He fulfills trusts. He avoids evil. He enjoins in the established virtues and prohibits evil. He does not enter matters ignorantly, and he does not depart from the truth out of weakness. When he is silent, silence does not overwhelm him, and when he speaks, he does not speak wrongly. When he laughs, his voice is not heard. He is content with what has been apportioned for him. Anger does not build up in him, nor is he overcome by desire. He is not overwhelmed by scarcity, nor does he covet that which is not his. He mixes with the people so that he may learn. He is silent so that he may be peaceable. He asks so that he may understand. He seeks so that he may learn. He does not harken to goodness to seek pride from it, nor does he speak of it to coerce others to behave like him. When he is betrayed, he is patient, so that Allah may be the one to seek vengeance for him. He troubles over himself, while the people are at rest because of him. He tires himself for the Hereafter, while the people are at rest because of him. His keeping away from those who distance themselves from him is asceticism and purification. His nearness to those who draw near to him is lenience and grace. Thus, his distancing is not out of arrogance or haughtiness, nor is his nearness out of trickery or manipulation. Rather, he behaves like the people of goodness before him, and thusly, he becomes an example for the people of righteousness after him. He said: So, Hammam swooned to the point where his soul passed with it. So, Amir al-Muâ€™minin (as) said: By Allah, I feared that this may happen to him. So, he called for his [funeral] preparation and prayed over him. Then, he said: This is what goodly exhortations do when they reach their rightful audience. So, a person said: Why hasnâ€™t this happened to you, Amir al-Muâ€™minin? So, he said: Woe to you! For every person is an apportioned time that cannot be surpassed and a cause that cannot be exceeded. So, be at ease, and do not repeat this, for Satan has placed this saying upon your tongue.", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 1073, "bookId": "Al-Amali-Saduq", "book": "Al-AmÄlÄ«", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "The Ninety-Sixth Assembly, Another Assembly of Wednesday, Twelve Nights Remain from Sha`ban, 368 AH, at `Asr Time", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bilal Muhammad", "englishText": "My father (ra) narrated to us. He said: Ahmad b. Idris narrated to us. He said: Muhammad b. Abi Ahmad b. Yahya b. `Imran al-Ash`ari narrated to us from Ahmad b. Abi `Abdillah from `Ali b. Ja`far al-Jawhari from Ibrahim b. `Abdillah al-Kufi from Abi Sa`id `Aqaysa. He said: Al-Hasan b. `Ali b. Abi Talib (as) was asked about intellect, so he said: It is suppressing grief and speaking gently to enemies.", "arabicText": "2 - Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ (Ø±Ø¶ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡)ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¥Ø¯Ø±ÙŠØ³ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† ÙŠØ­ÙŠÙ‰ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ø±Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø´Ø¹Ø±ÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø§Ù„Ø¬ÙˆÙ‡Ø±ÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙˆÙÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø³Ø¹ÙŠØ¯ Ø¹Ù‚ÙŠØµØ§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø³Ø¦Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…) Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚Ù„ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø§Ù„ØªØ¬Ø±Ø¹ Ù„Ù„ØºØµØ© ÙˆÙ…Ø¯Ø§Ù‡Ù†Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¹Ø¯Ø§Ø¡ (1).", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/29/1/96/2", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 96, "thaqalaynSanad": "My father (ra) narrated to us. He said: Ahmad b. Idris narrated to us. He said: Muhammad b. Abi Ahmad b. Yahya b. `Imran al-Ash`ari narrated to us from Ahmad b. Abi `Abdillah from `Ali b. Ja`far al-Jawhari from Ibrahim b. `Abdillah al-Kufi from Abi Sa`id `Aqaysa. He said: Al-Hasan b. `Ali b. Abi Talib (as) was asked about intellect, so he said:", "thaqalaynMatn": " It is suppressing grief and speaking gently to enemies.", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 147, "bookId": "Al-Amali-Saduq", "book": "Al-AmÄlÄ«", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "The Seventeenth Assembly, which is Friday, the Middle of the Month of Ramadan, 367 AH.", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bilal Muhammad", "englishText": "My father (rh) narrated to us. He said: Muhammad b. Ahmad b. `Ali b. al-Salt narrated to us from his uncle `Abdullah b. al-Salt from Yunus b. `Abd al-Rahman from `Amr b. Shimr from Jabir b. Yazid al-Ju`fi from Abi Ja`far Muhammad b. `Ali al-Baqir (as). He said: Allah revealed to His Messenger (s): I have thanked Ja`far b. Abi Talib for four characteristics. So, the Prophet (s) called for him and informed him. So, he said: Had Allah not informed you, I would not have informed you: (1) I have never drank wine, because I know that if I were to drink it, my intellect would fall. (2) I have never lied, because lying diminishes chivalry. (3) I have never committed adultery because I feared that it would be done to me. (4) I have never worshiped an idol because I know that it does not harm, nor does it benefit. So, the Prophet (s) put his hand on his shoulder and said: It is Allah's responsibility to give you two wings so that you may fly with the angels in Paradise.", "arabicText": "12 - Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ (Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡)ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„ØµÙ„ØªØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ù‡ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„ØµÙ„ØªØŒ Ø¹Ù† ÙŠÙˆÙ†Ø³ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù†ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ø±Ùˆ Ø¨Ù† Ø´Ù…Ø±ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¬Ø§Ø¨Ø± Ø¨Ù† ÙŠØ²ÙŠØ¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø¹ÙÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ù‚Ø± (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…)ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£ÙˆØ­Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡): Ø£Ù†ÙŠ Ø´ÙƒØ±Øª Ù„Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹ Ø®ØµØ§Ù„ØŒ ÙØ¯Ø¹Ø§Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙØ£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù„Ùˆ Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ùƒ Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±ØªÙƒØŒ Ù…Ø§ Ø´Ø±Ø¨Øª Ø®Ù…Ø±Ø§ Ù‚Ø·ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Øª Ø£Ù† Ù„Ùˆ Ø´Ø±Ø¨ØªÙ‡Ø§ Ø²Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù‚Ù„ÙŠØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ ÙƒØ°Ø¨Øª Ù‚Ø·ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ°Ø¨ ÙŠÙ†Ù‚Øµ (3) Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙˆØ¡Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø²Ù†ÙŠØª Ù‚Ø·ØŒ Ù„Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ø®ÙØª Ø£Ù†ÙŠ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø¹Ù…Ù„Øª Ø¹Ù…Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯Øª ØµÙ†Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø· Ù„Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Øª Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¶Ø± ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙ†ÙØ¹. Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ¶Ø±Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) ÙŠØ¯Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹Ø§ØªÙ‚Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ù‚ Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø²ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¬Ø¹Ù„ Ù„Ùƒ Ø¬Ù†Ø§Ø­ÙŠÙ† ØªØ·ÙŠØ± Ø¨Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù„Ø§Ø¦ÙƒØ© ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø© (4).", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/29/1/17/12", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 17, "thaqalaynSanad": "My father (rh) narrated to us. He said: Muhammad b. Ahmad b. `Ali b. al-Salt narrated to us from his uncle `Abdullah b. al-Salt from Yunus b. `Abd al-Rahman from `Amr b. Shimr from Jabir b. Yazid al-Ju`fi from Abi Ja`far Muhammad b. `Ali al-Baqir (as).", "thaqalaynMatn": " He said: Allah revealed to His Messenger (s): I have thanked Ja`far b. Abi Talib for four characteristics. So, the Prophet (s) called for him and informed him. So, he said: Had Allah not informed you, I would not have informed you: (1) I have never drank wine, because I know that if I were to drink it, my intellect would fall. (2) I have never lied, because lying diminishes chivalry. (3) I have never committed adultery because I feared that it would be done to me. (4) I have never worshiped an idol because I know that it does not harm, nor does it benefit. So, the Prophet (s) put his hand on his shoulder and said: It is Allah's responsibility to give you two wings so that you may fly with the angels in Paradise.", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 15, "bookId": "Nahj-al-Balagha-Radi", "book": "Nahj al-BalÄgha", "category": "Sermons", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "Creation of Universe", "author": "al-SharÄ«f al-Raá¸Ä«", "translator": "Sayed Ali Raza", "englishText": "Praise is due to AllÄh whose worth cannot be described by speakers, whose bounties cannot be counted by calculators and whose claim (to obedience) cannot be satisfied by those who attempt to do so, whom the height of intellectual courage cannot appreciate, and the divings of understanding cannot reach; He for whose description no limit has been laid down, no eulogy exists, no time is ordained and no duration is fixed. He brought forth creation through His Omnipotence, dispersed winds through His Compassion, and made firm the shaking earth with rocks.", "arabicText": "Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙÙ…Ù’Ø¯Ù Ù„Ù„Ù‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ¨Ù’Ù„ÙØºÙ Ù…ÙØ¯Ù’Ø­ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ„ÙÙˆÙ†ÙØŒ ÙˆÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ­Ù’ØµÙÙŠ Ù†ÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ø¡ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¹ÙØ§Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙˆÙ†ÙØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ¤ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙÙŠ Ø­ÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§Ù„ÙÙ…Ø¬Ù’ØªÙÙ‡ÙØ¯ÙÙˆÙ†ÙØŒ Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ù„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙØ¯Ù’Ø±ÙƒÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§Ù„Ù‡ÙÙ…ÙÙ…ÙØŒ ÙˆÙÙ„Ø§Ù ÙŠÙÙ†ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙ‡Ù ØºÙÙˆÙ’ØµÙ Ø§Ù„ÙÙØ·ÙÙ†ÙØŒ Ø§Ù„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠ Ù„ÙÙŠÙ’Ø³Ù Ù„ÙØµÙÙÙØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙŒ Ù…ÙØ­Ù’Ø¯ÙÙˆØ¯ÙŒØŒ ÙˆÙÙ„Ø§Ù Ù†ÙØ¹Ù’ØªÙŒ Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¬ÙÙˆØ¯ÙŒØŒ ÙˆÙÙ„Ø§ ÙˆÙÙ‚Ù’ØªÙŒ Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ø¯ÙÙˆØ¯ÙŒØŒ ÙˆÙÙ„Ø§ Ø£ÙØ¬ÙÙ„ÙŒ Ù…ÙÙ…Ù’Ø¯ÙÙˆØ¯ÙŒ. ÙÙØ·ÙØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙÙ„Ø§Ø¦ÙÙ‚Ù Ø¨ÙÙ‚ÙØ¯Ù’Ø±ÙØªÙÙ‡ÙØŒ ÙˆÙÙ†ÙØ´ÙØ±Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù‘ÙÙŠÙØ§Ø­Ù Ø¨ÙØ±ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙØªÙÙ‡ÙØŒ ÙˆÙÙˆÙØªÙ‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙØ®ÙÙˆØ±Ù Ù…ÙÙŠÙØ¯ÙØ§Ù†Ù Ø£ÙØ±Ù’Ø¶ÙÙ‡Ù.", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/32/1/1/2", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 1, "thaqalaynSanad": "", "thaqalaynMatn": "", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 498, "bookId": "Al-Amali-Saduq", "book": "Al-AmÄlÄ«", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "The Fifty-First Assembly, the Assembly of Friday, the [Nineteenth] of Rabi` al-Awwal, 368 AH.", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bilal Muhammad", "englishText": "Salih b. `Isa b. Ahmad b. Muhammad al-`Ijli narrated to us. He said: Muhammad b. Muhammad b. `Ali narrated to us. He said: Muhammad b. al-Faraj al-Rowyani narrated to us. He said: `Abdullah b. Muhammad al-`Ijli narrated to us. He said: `Abd al-`Athim b. `Abdullah al-Hasani narrated to me from his father from Aban the slave of Zayd b. `Ali from `Asim b. Bahdala. He said: Shurayh the Judge said to me: I bought a [luxurious] house with eighty gold coins. I wrote a letter and had two just witnesses testify to it. So, Amir al-Muâ€™minin `Ali b. Abi Talib (as) was told about that, so he sent his client Qanbar to me, and I gave it to him. When he (as) visited me, he said: O Shurayh! You bought a house, you wrote a letter, you had two just witnesses testify to it, and you measured the money? He said: I said: Yes. He said: O Shurayh! Fear Allah, for one [angel] will come to you who will not look at your letter, nor ask for your evidence; and he will take you out of your house and deposit you wholly into your grave. So, make sure that you have not bought this house from other than its rightful owner, and that you have not measured unlawful money, or else you will have lost both abodes together: this world and the Hereafter. Then, he (as) said: O Shurayh! If you had come to me when you had bought this house, I would have written a letter on this sheet, and you would not have even bought it for two silver coins. He said: I said: What would you have written, Amir al-Muâ€™minin? He said: I would have written this letter to you: â€œIn the name of Allah, the Beneficent, the Merciful. This is what was purchased by a lowly slave from a mortal that is ready to depart. He bought a house in the Abode of Vanity, from the side of mortals to the garrison of the perished ones. This house has four barriers: (1) its first barrier is destruction, (2) its second barrier is impairment, (3) its third barrier is calamity, (4) and its fourth barrier is caprice that leads to Satan the deceiver. Then, there is the door that is the opening of the house. This deceived person purchases this with wishful thinking from one who is pursued by death. He withdraws from the splendour of being content with modest needs. The buyer does not understand what he has bought at all. He is afflicted with what afflicted the bodies of kings and he is cursed with what cursed the oppressors; like Khosrow, Caesar, Tubba`, Himyar, and all who amass wealth upon wealth and go on increasing it, building high houses and decorating them, collecting treasures and preserving them. According to their own thinking, they claimed these things for children to take them to the place of accounting and judgement and the position of reward and punishment. When the verdict will be passed, â€œthose who stood on falsehood would then be at a total loss.â€ (40:78) This document is witnessed by the intellect when it is free from the shackles of desires, and safe from the attachments to this world, and hearing of the voice of asceticism as it calls: â€œHow clear is the truth for one with eyes!â€ Surely, oneâ€™s journey is of two days, so increase in your righteous deeds and unite your hopeful expectations with the reality of imminent death, for the journey is dwindling and diminishing.â€", "arabicText": "10 - Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ ØµØ§Ù„Ø­ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹ÙŠØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¬Ù„ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ø¬ Ø§Ù„Ø±ÙˆÙŠØ§Ù†ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¬Ù„ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø¸ÙŠÙ… Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù†ÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨Ø§Ù† Ù…ÙˆÙ„Ù‰ Ø²ÙŠØ¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¹Ø§ØµÙ… Ø¨Ù† Ø¨Ù‡Ø¯Ù„Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„ÙŠ Ø´Ø±ÙŠØ­ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ø¶ÙŠ: Ø§Ø´ØªØ±ÙŠØª Ø¯Ø§Ø±Ø§ Ø¨Ø«Ù…Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ø¯ÙŠÙ†Ø§Ø±Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØªØ¨Øª ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø´Ù‡Ø¯Øª Ø¹Ø¯ÙˆÙ„Ø§ØŒ ÙØ¨Ù„Øº Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…)ØŒ ÙØ¨Ø¹Ø« Ø¥Ù„ÙŠ Ù…ÙˆÙ„Ø§Ù‡ Ù‚Ù†Ø¨Ø±Ø§ ÙØ£ØªÙŠØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ù† Ø¯Ø®Ù„Øª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø´Ø±ÙŠØ­ØŒ Ø§Ø´ØªØ±ÙŠØª Ø¯Ø§Ø±Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØªØ¨Øª ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø´Ù‡Ø¯Øª Ø¹Ø¯ÙˆÙ„Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙˆØ²Ù†Øª Ù…Ø§Ù„Ø§ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‚Ù„Øª: Ù†Ø¹Ù…. Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø´Ø±ÙŠØ­ØŒ Ø§ØªÙ‚ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡ Ø³ÙŠØ£ØªÙŠÙƒ Ù…Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ†Ø¸Ø± ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ùƒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ³Ø£Ù„ Ø¹Ù† Ø¨ÙŠÙ†ØªÙƒ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠØ®Ø±Ø¬Ùƒ Ù…Ù† Ø¯Ø§Ø±Ùƒ Ø´Ø§Ø®ØµØ§ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ³Ù„Ù…Ùƒ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù‚Ø¨Ø±Ùƒ Ø®Ø§Ù„ØµØ§ØŒ ÙØ§Ù†Ø¸Ø± Ø£Ù† Ù„Ø§ ØªÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ø´ØªØ±ÙŠØª Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø§Ø± Ù…Ù† ØºÙŠØ± Ù…Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙˆØ²Ù†Øª Ù…Ø§Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ù† ØºÙŠØ± Ø­Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ù† Ø£Ù†Øª Ù‚Ø¯ Ø®Ø³Ø±Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø§Ø±ÙŠÙ† Ø¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ø©. Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ (Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…): ÙŠØ§ Ø´Ø±ÙŠØ­ØŒ ÙÙ„Ùˆ ÙƒÙ†Øª Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ø´ØªØ±ÙŠØª Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø§Ø± Ø£ØªÙŠØªÙ†ÙŠØŒ ÙÙƒØªØ¨Øª Ù„Ùƒ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø³Ø®Ø©ØŒ Ø¥Ø°Ù† Ù„Ù… ØªØ´ØªØ±Ù‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ù‡Ù…ÙŠÙ†. Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‚Ù„Øª: ÙˆÙ…Ø§ ÙƒÙ†Øª ØªÙƒØªØ¨ØŒ ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ†ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙƒÙ†Øª Ø£ÙƒØªØ¨ Ù„Ùƒ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨: Ø¨Ø³Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­ÙŠÙ… Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ø´ØªØ±Ù‰ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø°Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ù…Ù† Ù…ÙŠØª Ø£Ø²Ø¹Ø¬ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­ÙŠÙ„ØŒ Ø§Ø´ØªØ±Ù‰ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø¯Ø§Ø±Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø¯Ø§Ø± Ø§Ù„ØºØ±ÙˆØ±ØŒ Ù…Ù† Ø¬Ø§Ù†Ø¨ Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹Ø³ÙƒØ± Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙˆØªØ¬Ù…Ø¹ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø§Ø± Ø­Ø¯ÙˆØ¯Ø§ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹Ø©: ÙØ§Ù„Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø§ÙˆÙ„ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙŠÙ†ØªÙ‡ÙŠ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¯ÙˆØ§Ø¹ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙØ§ØªØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙŠÙ†ØªÙ‡ÙŠ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¯ÙˆØ§Ø¹ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ù‡Ø§ØªØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø«Ø§Ù„Ø« Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙŠÙ†ØªÙ‡ÙŠ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø¯ÙˆØ§Ø¹ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…ØµÙŠØ¨Ø§ØªØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø§Ø¨Ø¹ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙŠÙ†ØªÙ‡ÙŠ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù‡ÙˆÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø¯ÙŠ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´ÙŠØ·Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…ØºÙˆÙŠØŒ ÙˆÙÙŠÙ‡ ÙŠØ´Ø±Ø¹ Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø§Ø±ØŒ Ø§Ø´ØªØ±Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙØªÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù…Ù„ Ù…Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø²Ø¹Ø¬ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¬Ù„ Ø¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø§Ø±ØŒ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø®Ø±ÙˆØ¬ Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ø² Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ù†ÙˆØ¹ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¯Ø®ÙˆÙ„ ÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø·Ù„Ø¨ØŒ ÙÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ø¯Ø±Ùƒ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø´ØªØ±ÙŠ ÙÙŠÙ…Ø§ Ø§Ø´ØªØ±Ù‰ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø¯Ø±ÙƒØŒ ÙØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø¨Ù„ÙŠ Ø£Ø¬Ø³Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù„ÙˆÙƒØŒ ÙˆØ³Ø§Ù„Ø¨ Ù†ÙÙˆØ³ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø¨Ø§Ø¨Ø±Ø© Ù…Ø«Ù„ ÙƒØ³Ø±Ù‰ ÙˆÙ‚ÙŠØµØ± ÙˆØªØ¨Ø¹ ÙˆØ­Ù…ÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø¬Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§Ù„ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø§Ù„ ÙØ£ÙƒØ«Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ¨Ù†Ù‰ ÙØ´ÙŠØ¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ†Ø¬Ø¯ (1) ÙØ²Ø®Ø±ÙØŒ ÙˆØ£Ø¯Ø®Ø± Ø¨Ø²Ø¹Ù…Ù‡ Ù„Ù„ÙˆÙ„Ø¯ØŒ Ø¥Ø´Ø®Ø§ØµÙ‡Ù… Ø¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ù Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø±Ø¶ Ù„ÙØµÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¶Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆØ®Ø³Ø± Ù‡Ù†Ø§ Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¨Ø·Ù„ÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ø´Ù‡Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚Ù„ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø®Ø±Ø¬ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø³Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù‡ÙˆÙ‰ ÙˆÙ†Ø¸Ø± Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø²ÙˆØ§Ù„ Ù„Ø§Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ØŒ ÙˆØ³Ù…Ø¹ Ù…Ù†Ø§Ø¯ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø²Ù‡Ø¯ ÙŠÙ†Ø§Ø¯ÙŠ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø±ØµØ§ØªÙ‡Ø§: Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø¨ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø¹ÙŠÙ†ÙŠÙ†! Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­ÙŠÙ„ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙˆÙ…ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ØªØ²ÙˆØ¯ÙˆØ§ Ù…Ù† ØµØ§Ù„Ø­ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¹Ù…Ø§Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø±Ø¨ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ù…Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ø¬Ø§Ù„ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¯Ù†Øª Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­Ù„Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø²ÙˆØ§Ù„ (2).", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/29/1/51/10", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 51, "thaqalaynSanad": "Salih b. `Isa b. Ahmad b. Muhammad al-`Ijli narrated to us. He said: Muhammad b. Muhammad b. `Ali narrated to us. He said: Muhammad b. al-Faraj al-Rowyani narrated to us. He said: `Abdullah b. Muhammad al-`Ijli narrated to us. He said: `Abd al-`Athim b. `Abdullah al-Hasani narrated to me from his father from Aban the slave of Zayd b. `Ali from `Asim b. Bahdala. He said: Shurayh the Judge said to me:", "thaqalaynMatn": " I bought a [luxurious] house with eighty gold coins. I wrote a letter and had two just witnesses testify to it. So, Amir al-Muâ€™minin `Ali b. Abi Talib (as) was told about that, so he sent his client Qanbar to me, and I gave it to him. When he (as) visited me, he said: O Shurayh! You bought a house, you wrote a letter, you had two just witnesses testify to it, and you measured the money? He said: I said: Yes. He said: O Shurayh! Fear Allah, for one [angel] will come to you who will not look at your letter, nor ask for your evidence; and he will take you out of your house and deposit you wholly into your grave. So, make sure that you have not bought this house from other than its rightful owner, and that you have not measured unlawful money, or else you will have lost both abodes together: this world and the Hereafter. Then, he (as) said: O Shurayh! If you had come to me when you had bought this house, I would have written a letter on this sheet, and you would not have even bought it for two silver coins. He said: I said: What would you have written, Amir al-Muâ€™minin? He said: I would have written this letter to you: â€œIn the name of Allah, the Beneficent, the Merciful. This is what was purchased by a lowly slave from a mortal that is ready to depart. He bought a house in the Abode of Vanity, from the side of mortals to the garrison of the perished ones. This house has four barriers: (1) its first barrier is destruction, (2) its second barrier is impairment, (3) its third barrier is calamity, (4) and its fourth barrier is caprice that leads to Satan the deceiver. Then, there is the door that is the opening of the house. This deceived person purchases this with wishful thinking from one who is pursued by death. He withdraws from the splendour of being content with modest needs. The buyer does not understand what he has bought at all. He is afflicted with what afflicted the bodies of kings and he is cursed with what cursed the oppressors; like Khosrow, Caesar, Tubba`, Himyar, and all who amass wealth upon wealth and go on increasing it, building high houses and decorating them, collecting treasures and preserving them. According to their own thinking, they claimed these things for children to take them to the place of accounting and judgement and the position of reward and punishment. When the verdict will be passed, â€œthose who stood on falsehood would then be at a total loss.â€ (40:78) This document is witnessed by the intellect when it is free from the shackles of desires, and safe from the attachments to this world, and hearing of the voice of asceticism as it calls: â€œHow clear is the truth for one with eyes!â€ Surely, oneâ€™s journey is of two days, so increase in your righteous deeds and unite your hopeful expectations with the reality of imminent death, for the journey is dwindling and diminishing.â€", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 1019, "bookId": "Al-Amali-Saduq", "book": "Al-AmÄlÄ«", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "The Ninety-Third Assembly, the Assembly of Friday, the Thirteenth of Sha`ban, 368 AH.", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bilal Muhammad", "englishText": "The wudu is not broken but by what exits out from the two ends of urine or feces or wind or semen, and the sleep which removes the intellect. The wiping (al-masH) is not permissible [to be done] upon the turban nor upon the cap nor upon the khuffs or the socks except for from (i.e. because of) an enemy from one is doing taqiyya or ice/snow from which one fears for the feet, so the khuffs take the place of the splints (al-jabaâ€™ir, pl. of jabira) and one wipes upon them. `Aâ€™isha narrated from the Prophet (s) that he said: The most severe in regret of mankind on the Day of the Resurrection will be the one who sees his wudu upon the skin of [someone/something] other than himself. `Aâ€™isha said: That I should wipe upon the back of a wild donkey in the waterless desert is preferable to me than that I should wipe upon my khuff.", "arabicText": "ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙ†Ù‚Ø¶ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ¶ÙˆØ¡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ø§ Ø®Ø±Ø¬ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø±ÙÙŠÙ† Ù…Ù† Ø¨ÙˆÙ„ Ø£Ùˆ ØºØ§Ø¦Ø· Ø£Ùˆ Ø±ÙŠØ­ Ø£Ùˆ Ù…Ù†ÙŠØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†ÙˆÙ… Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø°Ù‡Ø¨ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø­ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ù„Ù†Ø³ÙˆØ©ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø­ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬ÙˆØ±Ø¨ÙŠÙ† Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ø¯Ùˆ ÙŠØªÙ‚Ù‰ Ø£Ùˆ Ø«Ù„Ø¬ ÙŠØ®Ø§Ù Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ÙŠÙ†ØŒ ÙÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙØ§Ù† Ù…Ù‚Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø¨Ø§Ø¦Ø± ÙÙŠÙ…Ø³Ø­ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ±ÙˆØª Ø¹Ø§Ø¦Ø´Ø© Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ (ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡) Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ø´Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø­Ø³Ø±Ø© ÙŠÙˆÙ… Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù…Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø±Ø£Ù‰ ÙˆØ¶ÙˆØ¡Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¬Ù„Ø¯ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡. ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ø¹Ø§Ø¦Ø´Ø©: Ù„Ø¦Ù† Ø£Ù…Ø³Ø­ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¸Ù‡Ø± Ø¹ÙŠØ± Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙÙ„Ø§Ø© Ø£Ø­Ø¨ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù† Ø£Ù…Ø³Ø­ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø®ÙÙŠ.", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/29/1/93/21", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 93, "thaqalaynSanad": "The wudu is not broken but by what exits out from the two ends of urine or feces or wind or semen, and the sleep which removes the intellect. The wiping (al-masH) is not permissible [to be done] upon the turban nor upon the cap nor upon the khuffs or the socks except for from (i.e. because of) an enemy from one is doing taqiyya or ice/snow from which one fears for the feet, so the khuffs take the place of the splints (al-jabaâ€™ir, pl. of jabira) and one wipes upon them. `Aâ€™isha narrated from the Prophet (s) that he said: ", "thaqalaynMatn": "The most severe in regret of mankind on the Day of the Resurrection will be the one who sees his wudu upon the skin of [someone/something] other than himself. `Aâ€™isha said: That I should wipe upon the back of a wild donkey in the waterless desert is preferable to me than that I should wipe upon my khuff.", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 769, "bookId": "Nahj-al-Balagha-Radi", "book": "Nahj al-BalÄgha", "category": "Sermons", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "Observing courtesy and kindness, the autocracy of the Umayyads", "author": "al-SharÄ«f al-Raá¸Ä«", "translator": "Sayed Ali Raza", "englishText": "The young among you should follow the elders while the elders should be kind to the young. Do not be like those rude people of the pre-Islamic (al-jÄhiliyyah) period who did not exert themselves in religion nor use their intellects in the matter of AllÄh. They [1] are like the breaking of eggs in the nest of a dangerous bird, because their breaking looks bad, but keeping them intact would mean the production of dangerous young ones.", "arabicText": "[Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø«Ù‘ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ØªØ¢Ù„Ù :] Ù„ÙÙŠÙØªÙØ£ÙØ³Ù‘Ù ØµÙØºÙÙŠØ±ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙƒÙØ¨ÙÙŠØ±ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ØŒ ÙˆÙÙ„Ù’ÙŠÙØ±Ø£ÙÙÙ’ ÙƒÙØ¨ÙÙŠØ±ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¨ÙØµÙØºÙŠØ±ÙÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ØŒ ÙˆÙÙ„Ø§Ù ØªÙÙƒÙÙˆÙ†ÙÙˆØ§ ÙƒÙØ¬ÙÙÙØ§Ø©Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø¬ÙØ§Ù‡ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù: Ù„Ø§Ù ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù‘ÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙŠÙØªÙÙÙÙ‚Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙÙˆÙ†ÙØŒ ÙˆÙÙ„Ø§Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡Ù ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù‚ÙÙ„ÙÙˆÙ†ÙØŒ ÙƒÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¶Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¶ ÙÙŠ Ø£ÙØ¯ÙØ§Ø­ ÙŠÙÙƒÙÙˆÙ†Ù ÙƒÙØ³Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ ÙˆÙØ²Ù’Ø±Ø§Ù‹ØŒ ÙˆÙÙŠÙØ®Ù’Ø±ÙØ¬Ù Ø­ÙØ¶ÙØ§Ù†ÙÙ‡ÙØ§ Ø´ÙØ±Ù‘Ø§Ù‹.", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/32/1/166/2", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 166, "thaqalaynSanad": "", "thaqalaynMatn": "", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 190, "bookId": "Kitab-al-Ghayba-Tusi", "book": "KitÄb al-Ghayba", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "Discerning truth during occultation of the Imam", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. al-á¸¤asan al-á¹¬Å«sÄ«", "translator": "Sayyid Athar Husain S. H. Rizvi", "englishText": "We will say: True propositions are of two types: One is supported by rational arguments and the other is based on narrated proofs. Propositions based on intellectual premises are established and discerned through their proofs, and propositions based on narrations are substantiated through their proofs, which comprise the sayings of the Prophet (s) and the Imams, who have explained the subjects and elaborated them and left nothing unexplained.", "arabicText": "Ù‚Ù„Ù†Ø§: Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¶Ø±Ø¨ÙŠÙ†Ø› Ø¹Ù‚Ù„ÙŠ ÙˆØ³Ù…Ø¹ÙŠ. ÙØ§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚Ù„ÙŠ ÙŠØµØ§Ø¨ Ø¨Ø£Ø¯Ù„ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø¹ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ø¯Ù„Ø© Ù…Ù†ØµÙˆØ¨Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù‚ÙˆØ§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ù„Ù… ÙˆÙ†ØµÙˆØµÙ‡ ÙˆØ£Ù‚ÙˆØ§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¦Ù…Ø© Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ù…Ù† ÙˆÙ„Ø¯Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¨ÙŠÙ†ÙˆØ§ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØ£ÙˆØ¶Ø­ÙˆÙ‡ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØªØ±ÙƒÙˆØ§ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ Ù„Ø§ Ø¯Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡.", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/27/1/20/2", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 20, "thaqalaynSanad": "", "thaqalaynMatn": "", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 170, "bookId": "Kitab-al-Ghayba-Tusi", "book": "KitÄb al-Ghayba", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "1", "chapter": "Philosophy and wisdom of Occultation", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. al-á¸¤asan al-á¹¬Å«sÄ«", "translator": "Sayyid Athar Husain S. H. Rizvi", "englishText": "We would reply: There is no such choice, because a person who doubts the Imamate of Ibn Hasan, the discourse with him must be about the explicit narrations of his Imamate and one must provide him proofs of his Imamate. It is not rational to discuss with him the reason of his occultation while he doubts his very Imamate, because the inquiry of the offshoots is not sensible, but after the authentication of fundamentals. We gave preference to inquiry of his Imamate over the inquiry of his occultation and its wisdom, because his Imamate is based on intellectual matters that are beyond skepticism, whereas, the wisdom of occultation may seem obscure and confusing.", "arabicText": "Ù‚Ù„Ù†Ø§: Ù„Ø§ Ø®ÙŠØ§Ø± ÙÙŠ Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ù…Ù† Ø´Ùƒ ÙÙŠ Ø¥Ù…Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙŠØ¬Ø¨ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ù†Øµ Ø¥Ù…Ø§Ù…ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØªØ´Ø§ØºÙ„ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù„Ø§Ù„Ø© Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ù…Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ùƒ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø£Ù† Ù†ØªÙƒÙ„Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø³Ø¨Ø¨ Ø§Ù„ØºÙŠØ¨Ø© Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙØ±ÙˆØ¹ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ³ÙˆØº Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø¥Ø­ÙƒØ§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø£ØµÙˆÙ„ Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ÙˆØ² Ø£Ù† ÙŠØªÙƒÙ„Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø³Ø¨Ø¨ Ø¥ÙŠÙ„Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø·ÙØ§Ù„ Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø«Ø¨ÙˆØª Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¯ÙŠÙ… ØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ ÙˆØ£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¨ÙŠØ­ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ø±Ø¬Ø­Ù†Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø¥Ù…Ø§Ù…ØªÙ‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… ÙÙŠ ØºÙŠØ¨ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ³Ø¨Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø¥Ù…Ø§Ù…ØªÙ‡ Ù…Ø¨Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù…ÙˆØ± Ø¹Ù‚Ù„ÙŠØ© Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø®Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø­ØªÙ…Ø§Ù„.", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/27/1/17/13", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 17, "thaqalaynSanad": "", "thaqalaynMatn": "", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 1693, "bookId": "Man-La-Yahduruh-al-Faqih-Volume-2-Saduq", "book": "Man LÄ Yaá¸¥á¸uruh al-FaqÄ«h", "category": "Book of Pilgrimage and Its Virtues", "categoryId": "3", "chapter": "What is Sufficient to Say When Visiting All the Imams {a.s}", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Bab Ul Qaim Publications", "englishText": "ZIYARAT JAMI'A FOR ALL THE IMAMS (as)\nHadith.3213 - It is narrated by Muhammad ibn Isma'il al-Barmaki, who said: Musa ibn Abdullah al-Nakha'i narrated, \"I said to Ali ibn Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Imam Musa ibn Jafar Al-Kadhim ibn Muhammad ibn Ali ibn al-Husayn ibn Ali ibn Abi Talib (as), 'Teach me, O son of the Messenger of Allah (swt), a complete and eloquent phrase to say when I visit any one of you.'\nImam (as) said:\n\"When you reach the entrance, stand and testify to the two testimonies of faith while in a state of ritual purity (ghusl). When you enter and see the grave, stand and say 'Allah (swt) is the Greatest, Allah (swt) is the Greatest' thirty times. Walk forward slowly with tranquility and dignity, keeping your steps close together. Then stand and say 'Allah (swt) is the Greatest' thirty times again. Approach the grave and say 'Allah (swt) is the Greatest' forty times, completing one hundred takbirs. Then say:\nPeace be upon you, O people of the House of Prophethood,\nand the abode of the Message,\nthe place of the angels' frequent visits,\nthe descent of revelation,\nthe source of mercy,\nthe treasures of knowledge,\nthe culmination of forbearance,\nthe foundation of generosity,\nthe leaders of nations,\nthe custodians of blessings,\nthe essence of righteousness,\nthe pillars of virtue,\nthe guides of servants,\nthe anchors of lands,\nthe gates of faith,\nthe trustees of the Most Merciful,\nthe progeny of the Prophets,\nthe chosen ones among the messengers,\nthe family of the best of the Lord (azj) of the Worlds.\nMay Allahâ€™s (swt) mercy and blessings be upon you.\nPeace be upon the Imams of guidance,\nthe lamps in the darkness,\nthe standards of piety,\nthe possessors of wisdom,\nthe masters of intellect,\nthe refuge of humanity,\nthe inheritors of the Prophets,\nthe highest example,\nthe bearers of the best call,\nand the proofs of Allah (swt) for the inhabitants of the world,\nthe Hereafter, and this life.\nMay Allahâ€™s (swt) mercy and blessings be upon you.\"\nPeace be upon the repositories of Allahâ€™s (swt) knowledge,\nand the abodes of Allahâ€™s (swt) blessings,\nand the mines of Allahâ€™s (swt) wisdom,\nand the keepers of Allahâ€™s (swt) secrets,\nand the bearers of Allahâ€™s (swt) Book,\nand the successors of the Prophet of Allah (swt),\nand the progeny of the Messenger of Allah (swt), peace be upon him and his family.\nMay Allahâ€™s (swt) mercy and blessings be upon you.\nPeace be upon the callers to Allah (swt),\nand the guides to Allahâ€™s (swt) pleasure,\nand those who remain steadfast in Allahâ€™s (swt) command,\nand those who are perfect in their love for Allah (swt),\nand those who are sincere in Allahâ€™s (swt) oneness,\nand those who manifest Allahâ€™s (swt) command and prohibition,\nand His honored servants,\n\"who do not precede Him in speech and act according to His command\"\n(May Allahâ€™s (swt) mercy and blessings be upon them).\nPeace be upon the Imams who are callers (to the truth),\nthe leaders of guidance,\nthe noble masters,\nthe protectors and guardians,\nthe people of remembrance,\nthe possessors of authority,\nthe remnant of Allah (swt),\nHis chosen ones,\nHis party,\nthe repository of His knowledge,\nHis proof,\nHis path,\nand His light.\nMay Allahâ€™s (swt) mercy and blessings be upon them.\nI bear witness that there is no god but Allah (swt), alone, without partner,\nas Allah (swt) has testified for Himself,\nand as His angels and those endowed with knowledge among His creation have testified,\n\"There is no god but Him, the Mighty, the Wise.\"\nAnd I bear witness that Muhammad is His chosen servant and His approved Messenger.\nHe sent him \"with guidance and the religion of truth to make it prevail over all religions, even if the polytheists detest it.\"\nAnd I bear witness that you are the rightly guided, rightly guiding Imams,\nthe infallible, the honored, the close to Allah (swt),\nthe pious, the truthful, the chosen,\nobedient to Allah (swt), steadfast in His command,\nacting according to His will, victorious by His grace.\nHe selected you by His knowledge,\napproved you for His unseen matters,\nchose you for His secrets,\nand preferred you by His power.\nHe honored you with His guidance,\ndistinguished you with His proof,\nelected you by His light,\nsupported you by His spirit,\nand was pleased with you as successors on His earth,\nproofs over His creation,\nhelpers of His religion,\nguardians of His secrets,\ntreasurers of His knowledge,\nrepositories of His wisdom,\ninterpreters of His revelation,\npillars of His oneness,\nwitnesses over His creation,\nguiding beacons for His servants,\na shining light in His lands,\nand guides to His path.\nAllah (swt) protected you from errors,\nsecured you from trials,\npurified you from impurity,\nremoved from you any defilement, O People of the House,\nand purified you thoroughly.\nYou have magnified His majesty,\nexalted His status,\nglorified His generosity,\npersisted in remembering Him,\naffirmed His covenant,\nperfected the bond of obedience to Him,\nadvised for Him in private and in public,\nand called to His path.\n\"With wisdom and good counsel,\" you dedicated yourselves to seeking His pleasure,\nyou patiently endured what befell you for His sake,\nyou established prayer, gave zakat, enjoined good, forbade evil,\nand strove \"in the way of Allah (swt) with true striving.\"\nYou proclaimed His call, clarified His obligations,\nupheld His limits, disseminated His laws,\nand revived His traditions. In all this, you sought His approval,\nsubmitted to His decree, and affirmed the truth of His previous messengers.\nThus, whoever deviates from you has gone astray,\nwhoever adheres to you has attained success,\nand whoever falls short in recognizing your rights has perished.\nThe truth is with you, among you, from you, and returns to you.\nYou are its people, its source, and its inheritors.\nThe legacy of prophethood rests with you,\nthe return of creation is toward you,\ntheir reckoning is upon you,\ndecisive judgment lies with you,\nthe signs of Allah (swt) are with you,\nand His resolutions are within you.\nHis light and His proofs are with you,\nand His command belongs to you.\nWhoever befriends you has befriended Allah (swt),\nwhoever opposes you has opposed Allah (swt),\nwhoever loves you has loved Allah (swt),\nand whoever hates you has hated Allah (swt).\nWhoever holds fast to you has clung to Allah (swt).\nYou are the straight path,\nwitnesses in the transient world,\nintercessors in the eternal abode,\nthe constant mercy,\nthe concealed sign,\nthe preserved trust,\nand the gate through which people are tested.\nWhoever comes to you is saved,\nand whoever does not come to you is doomed.\nYou invite to Allah (swt),\nguide toward Him,\nbelieve in Him,\nsubmit to Him,\nact according to His command,\nguide others to His path,\nand judge by His word.\nBlessed is the one who befriends you,\nruined is the one who opposes you,\ndisappointed is the one who denies you,\nmisguided is the one who separates from you,\nand triumphant is the one who clings to you.\nSecure is the one who seeks refuge in you,\nat peace is the one who believes in you,\nand guided is the one who holds on to you.\nWhoever follows you, Paradise is his abode,\nand whoever opposes you, Hell is his destination.\nWhoever denies you is a disbeliever,\nwhoever fights you is a polytheist,\nand whoever rejects you resides in the lowest depths of Hell.\nI bear witness that this (virtue and status) was ordained for you in the past and continues for you in the future. I testify that your souls, your light, and your essence are one, pure and purified, \"one part derived from the other.\"\nAllah (swt) created you as luminous lights, encircling His Throne until He blessed us through you. He placed you \"in houses Allah (swt) permitted to be exalted and His name remembered therein.\"\nHe made our prayers upon you and what He has blessed us with through your guardianship a source of purity for our creation, a cleansing for our souls, an atonement for our sins, and a means of purification for us.\nThus, in His presence, we are recognized for our acceptance of your excellence and our affirmation of your truth. Allah (swt) elevated you to the most exalted station of the honored ones, the highest ranks of the near ones, and the most elevated degrees of the messengers, where none can surpass you, none can precede you, and none can aspire to equal your rank.\nNo angel brought near, no prophet sent forth, no truthful one, no martyr, no scholar, no ignorant person, no lowly one, no virtuous one, no believing righteous person, no sinful wretched person, no oppressive tyrant, no rebellious devil, nor any creation in between bears witness except that they have been made to recognize the majesty of your station, the grandeur of your status, the greatness of your position, the completion of your light, the truth of your seats (in divine presence), the firmness of your standing, the nobility of your rank, your elevated status with Him, your honor before Him, and your nearness to Him.\nMay my father, my mother, my family, my wealth, and my lineage be sacrificed for you.\nI call Allah (swt) to witness, and I call you to witness, that I believe in you and in what you believe in, disbelieve in your enemies and in what they disbelieve in, and have clarity about your status and the misguidance of those who oppose you. I am loyal to you and your friends, and I bear enmity toward your enemies. I am at peace with those who are at peace with you and at war with those who are at war with you. I affirm what you affirm and reject what you reject.\nI obey you, acknowledge your right, admit your superiority, uphold your knowledge, seek protection under your covenant, recognize you, and believe in your return. I affirm your reappearance and await your command. I look forward to your governance, adhere to your word, act upon your instruction, seek refuge with you, and visit you. I seek sanctuary and protection at your graves and seek intercession with Allah (swt), the Exalted, through you. I draw near to Him by your means, and I present you before all my needs, wishes, and aspirations in all my circumstances and affairs.\nI believe in your hidden and manifest (realities), your presence and absence, your first and last. I entrust all matters to you, align myself with you, and my heart is in peace with you. My views follow yours, and my support is prepared for you until Allah (swt) revives His religion through you, returns you in His days (of divine rule), manifests you for His justice, and grants you authority on His earth.\nWith you, with you, not with your enemies! I believe in you and hold your last (Imam) in the same regard as your first, and I distance myself from your enemies and from al-Jibt and al-Taghut, the devils and their followers, the oppressors against you, those who reject your rights, those who deviate from your guardianship, usurpers of your inheritance, those who doubt you, those who turn away from you, and from every entity that substitutes for you, every leader who invites to the fire.\nMay Allah (swt) keep me steadfast throughout my life in your loyalty, love, and religion. May He grant me success in obeying you, provide me with your intercession, and make me among the best of your followers who adhere to what you call towards. May He make me among those who emulate your path, walk in your way, are guided by your guidance, and are gathered in your company. May He return me during your return, allow me to rule during your government, honor me in your well-being, empower me in your days, and let my eyes be delighted tomorrow by seeing you.\nMay my father, mother, self, family, and wealth be ransomed for you. Whoever seeks Allah (swt) begins with you; whoever declares His oneness accepts from you; whoever aims towards Him turns to you. My masters, I cannot count your praises, nor can I reach the depths of your commendation or the height of your description.\nYou are the light of the righteous, guides of the virtuous, and proofs of the Almighty. Through you, Allah (swt) opens and through you, He concludes. Through you, He sends down rain, and through you, He holds the sky from falling on the earth except by His permission.\nThrough you, Allah (swt) alleviates grief and removes hardships. With you rests what His messengers conveyed and what His angels descended with. To your grandfather, the Trustworthy Spirit (Jibreel) was sent, and if the visitation is for Amir al-Mu'minin (as), say: \"To your brother, the Trustworthy Spirit was sent.\" Allah (swt) granted you what He has not granted anyone from the worlds. Every noble being bows before your nobility, every arrogant soul submits to your obedience, every tyrant yields to your excellence, and everything is humbled before you. The earth is illuminated by your light, and the successful ones attain salvation through your guardianship.\nThrough you, the path to divine satisfaction is tread, while upon those who deny your guardianship is the wrath of the Most Merciful.\nMay my father, mother, self, family, and wealth be ransomed for you. Your mention is in the remembrance of those who remember, your names are among the finest of names, your bodies among the most honored of bodies, your souls among the most purified of souls, your selves among the noblest of selves, your legacy among the greatest of legacies, and your graves among the holiest of graves.\nHow sweet are your names, how noble your selves, how exalted your station, how magnificent your rank, how fulfilled your promise! Your words are light, your commands are guidance, your teachings are piety, your actions are goodness, your habit is benevolence, your nature is generosity, your conduct is truth and kindness. Your speech is wisdom and decisive, your judgment is knowledge, patience, and resolve.\nWhen goodness is mentioned, you are its beginning, its origin, its root, its essence, and its ultimate end.\nMay my father, mother, and self be sacrificed for you! How can I describe the beauty of your praise or count the favors you have bestowed? Through you, Allah (swt) removed us from humiliation, relieved us of overwhelming distress, saved us from the brink of destruction, and rescued us from the fire.\nBy my father, mother, and self, through your guardianship, Allah (swt) taught us the principles of our religion and rectified what was corrupted in our worldly matters.\nThrough your guardianship, the word of Allah (swt) was fulfilled, the blessings became magnified, and divisions were united. By your guardianship, the obligatory acts of worship are accepted. For you is the obligatory love, the elevated ranks, the praiseworthy station, and the well-known position before Allah (swt), the Mighty and Glorious. You possess the grand intercession, the great honor, and the lofty status.\nâ€œOur Lord (azj), we have believed in what You have revealed and have followed the Messenger, so register us among the witnesses.â€\nâ€œOur Lord (azj), do not let our hearts deviate after You have guided us, and grant us from Yourself mercy. Indeed, You are the Bestower.â€\nâ€œGlory to our Lord (azj); indeed, the promise of our Lord (azj) is ever fulfilled.â€\nO Wali of Allah (swt), there are sins between me and Allah (swt), the Mighty and Glorious, that no one can absolve except your satisfaction. By the right of the one who entrusted you with His secrets, appointed you as caretakers of His creation, and linked obedience to you with obedience to Him, I plead with you to intercede for my sins and be my intercessors. I pledge my obedience to you; whoever obeys you has obeyed Allah (swt), and whoever disobeys you has disobeyed Allah (swt). Whoever loves you loves Allah (swt), and whoever harbors hatred toward you harbors hatred toward Allah (swt).\nO Allah (swt), if I could find intercessors closer to You than Muhammad and his purified household, the righteous Imams, I would make them my intercessors. By their right, which You have made obligatory upon Yourself, I ask You to include me among those who recognize their rank and are graced by their intercession. Indeed, You are the Most Merciful of the merciful. May Allahâ€™s (swt) blessings and peace be upon Muhammad and his family abundantly. â€œSufficient for us is Allah (swt), and He is the best disposer of affairs.â€", "arabicText": "[Ø²ÙŠØ§Ø±Ø© Ø¬Ø§Ù…Ø¹Ø© Ù„Ø¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¦Ù…Ø© Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…]\n3213 - Ø±ÙÙˆÙÙ‰ Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¥ÙØ³Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ±Ù’Ù…ÙÙƒÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Ø­ÙØ¯Ù‘ÙØ«ÙÙ†ÙØ§ Ù…ÙÙˆØ³ÙÙ‰ Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙØ¨Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ®ÙØ¹ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ù‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù : Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙ Ù„ÙØ¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ù…ÙÙˆØ³ÙÙ‰ Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¬ÙØ¹Ù’ÙÙØ±Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ¯Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙØ³ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ‘Ù Ø¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø£ÙØ¨ÙÙŠ Ø·ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ ÙŠÙØ§ Ø§ÙØ¨Ù’Ù†Ù Ø±ÙØ³ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„Ø§Ù‹ Ø£ÙÙ‚ÙÙˆÙ„ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙÙ„ÙÙŠØºØ§Ù‹ ÙƒÙØ§Ù…ÙÙ„Ø§Ù‹ Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø²ÙØ±Ù’ØªÙ ÙˆÙØ§Ø­ÙØ¯Ø§Ù‹ Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ù„Ù Â«Ø¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ ØµÙØ±Ù’ØªÙ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¨Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙÙÙ’ ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙØ´Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø´Ù‘ÙÙ‡ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØªÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ ØºÙØ³Ù’Ù„Ù ÙÙØ¥ÙØ°ÙØ§ Ø¯ÙØ®ÙÙ„Ù’ØªÙ ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ£ÙÙŠÙ’ØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ¨Ù’Ø±Ù ÙÙÙ‚ÙÙÙ’ ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù’ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ø¨ÙØ±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ø£ÙÙƒÙ’Ø¨ÙØ±Ù Ø«ÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ«ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ù…ÙØ±Ù‘ÙØ©Ù‹ Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ø§ÙÙ…Ù’Ø´Ù Ù‚ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ„Ø§Ù‹ ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’ÙƒÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙƒÙÙŠÙ†ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙØ§Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‚ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¨Ù’ Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø®ÙØ·ÙØ§ÙƒÙ Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ù‚ÙÙÙ’ Ù…ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ©Ù ØªÙÙƒÙ’Ø¨ÙÙŠØ±ÙØ©Ù Ø«ÙÙ…Ù‘Ù Ù‚ÙÙ„Ù’\nØ§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’ÙƒÙÙ…Ù’ ÙŠÙØ§ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø¨ÙÙŠÙ’ØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù†Ù‘ÙØ¨ÙÙˆÙ‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¶ÙØ¹Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø±Ù‘ÙØ³ÙØ§Ù„ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ù…ÙØ®Ù’ØªÙÙ„ÙÙÙ Ù…ÙØ­ÙØ¨Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ®Ù’Ù„ÙØµÙÙŠÙ†Ù ÙÙÙŠ ØªÙÙˆÙ’Ø­ÙÙŠØ¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¸Ù’Ù‡ÙØ±ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ù„ÙØ£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ù†ÙÙ‡Ù’ÙŠÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¯ÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±ÙÙ…ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù‘ÙØ°ÙÙŠÙ†Ù Â«Ù„Ø§Ù° ÙŠÙØ³Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‚ÙÙˆÙ†ÙÙ‡Ù Ø¨ÙØ§Ù„Ù’Ù‚ÙÙˆÙ’Ù„Ù ÙˆÙ Ù‡ÙÙ…Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±ÙÙ‡Ù ÙŠÙØ¹Ù’Ù…ÙÙ„ÙÙˆÙ†ÙÂ» ÙˆÙ Ø±ÙØ­Ù’Ù…ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙØ±ÙÙƒÙØ§ØªÙÙ‡Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙÙ„Ø§ÙÙ…Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„ÙÙ‰ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙØ¦ÙÙ…Ù‘ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø¯Ù‘ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ø©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‚ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ù‡ÙØ¯ÙØ§Ø©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø³Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’ÙˆÙÙ„Ø§ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø§ÙÙ„Ø°Ù‘ÙØ§Ø¯ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø­ÙÙ…ÙØ§Ø©Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙ‡Ù’Ù„Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ø°Ù‘ÙÙƒÙ’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø£ÙÙˆÙ„ÙÙŠ Ø§ÙÙ„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¨ÙÙ‚ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù Ø§ÙÙ„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø®ÙÙŠÙØ±ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙØ²Ù’Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø¹ÙÙŠÙ’Ø¨ÙØ©Ù Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ Ø­ÙØ¬Ù‘ÙØªÙÙ‡Ù ÙˆÙ
