ï´¿Ùˆ Ø¢Ø®Ø±ÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø±Ø¬ÙˆÙ† Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¥Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø°Ø¨Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ¥Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØªÙˆØ¨ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…ï´¾ (Ù¦) ÙˆÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: ï´¿ÙˆÙ…Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ù…Ø± Ù…Ù† Ù…Ø¹Ù…Ø± ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙ†Ù‚Øµ Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ø±Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ï´¾ (Ù§) Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù‡Ù„ Ø±ÙˆÙŠØª ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ Ø¹Ù† Ø¢Ø¨Ø§Ø¦ÙƒØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ø±ÙˆÙŠØª Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: (Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ†: Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ù…Ø®Ø²ÙˆÙ†Ø§ Ù…ÙƒÙ†ÙˆÙ†Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ù‡ÙˆØŒ Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø¯Ø§Ø¡ØŒ Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ù…Ù„Ø§Ø¦ÙƒØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ±Ø³Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø¨ÙŠØª Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù…ÙˆÙ†Ù‡) (Ù¨) Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø£Ø­Ø¨ Ø£Ù† ØªÙ†Ø²Ø¹Ù‡ Ù„ÙŠ Ù…Ù† ÙƒÙ†Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ù„Ù…: ï´¿ÙØªÙˆÙ„ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ù… ÙÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ù†Øª Ø¨Ù…Ù„ÙˆÙ…ï´¾ (Ù©) Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ù‡Ù„Ø§ÙƒÙ‡Ù… Ø«Ù… Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ï´¿ÙˆØ°ÙƒØ± ÙØ¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙƒØ±Ù‰ ØªÙ†ÙØ¹ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ†ï´¾ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø²Ø¯Ù†ÙŠ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Øª ÙØ¯Ø§ÙƒØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù„Ù‚Ø¯ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø¹Ù† Ø¢Ø¨Ø§Ø¦Ù‡ Ø£Ù† Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØµÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ³Ù„Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø£ÙˆØ­Ù‰ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¦Ù‡: Ø£Ù† Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø± ÙÙ„Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù†ÙŠ Ù…ØªÙˆÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ ÙƒØ°Ø§ ÙˆÙƒØ°Ø§ØŒ ÙØ£ØªØ§Ù‡ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ ÙØ£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¯Ø¹Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø³Ø±ÙŠØ±Ù‡ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ø³Ù‚Ø· Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø±ÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø±Ø¨ Ø£Ø¬Ù„Ù†ÙŠ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙŠØ´Ø¨ Ø·ÙÙ„ÙŠ ÙˆØ£Ù‚Ø¶ÙŠ Ø£Ù…Ø±ÙŠØŒ ÙØ£ÙˆØ­Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ø¦Øª ÙÙ„Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù„Ùƒ (Ù¡) ÙØ£Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ø£Ù†ÙŠ Ù‚Ø¯ Ø£Ù†Ø³ÙŠØª ÙÙŠ Ø£Ø¬Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ²Ø¯Øª ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ù…Ø±Ù‡ Ø®Ù…Ø³ Ø¹Ø´Ø±Ø© Ø³Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¨ÙŠ: ÙŠØ§ Ø±Ø¨ Ø¥Ù†Ùƒ Ù„ØªØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù†ÙŠ Ù„Ù… Ø£ÙƒØ°Ø¨ Ù‚Ø·ØŒ ÙØ£ÙˆØ­Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡: Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ù†Øª Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆØ± ÙØ£Ø¨Ù„ØºÙ‡ Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ³Ø£Ù„ Ø¹Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù„ (Ù¢). Ø«Ù… Ø§Ù„ØªÙØª Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ø­Ø³Ø¨Ùƒ Ø¶Ø§Ù‡ÙŠØª Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ÙˆØ¯ ÙÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ø¹ÙˆØ° Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ÙˆØ¯ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‚Ø§Ù„Øª: (ÙŠØ¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…ØºÙ„ÙˆÙ„Ø©) ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù‚Ø¯ ÙØ±Øº Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø± ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ ÙŠØ­Ø¯Ø« Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: ï´¿ØºÙ„Øª Ø£ÙŠØ¯ÙŠÙ‡Ù… ÙˆÙ„Ø¹Ù†ÙˆØ§ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆØ§ï´¾ ÙˆÙ„Ù‚Ø¯ Ø³Ù…Ø¹Øª Ù‚ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø³Ø£Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø¯Ø§Ø¡ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ùˆ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙ†ÙƒØ± Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø¯Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ£Ù† ÙŠÙ‚Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù‚ÙˆÙ…Ø§ ÙŠØ±Ø¬ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù‡ ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø£Ù„Ø§ ØªØ®Ø¨Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù† (Ø¥Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ù†Ø²Ù„Ù†Ø§Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ù„ÙŠÙ„Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¯Ø±) ÙÙŠ Ø£ÙŠ Ø´Ø¦ Ø£Ù†Ø²Ù„ØªØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§: ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ù„ÙŠÙ„Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¯Ø± ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù†Ø© Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù†Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø­ÙŠØ§Ø© Ø£Ùˆ Ù…ÙˆØª Ø£Ùˆ Ø®ÙŠØ± Ø£Ùˆ Ø´Ø± Ø£Ùˆ Ø±Ø²Ù‚ØŒ ÙÙ…Ø§ Ù‚Ø¯Ø±Ù‡ Ù…Ù† ØªÙ„Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù„ÙŠÙ„Ø© ÙÙ‡Ùˆ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø­ØªÙˆÙ…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø£Ù„Ø¢Ù† Ù‚Ø¯ ÙÙ‡Ù…Øª Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Øª ÙØ¯Ø§Ùƒ ÙØ²Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø¥Ù† Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…ÙˆØ± Ø£Ù…ÙˆØ±Ø§ Ù…ÙˆÙ‚ÙˆÙØ© Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ù… Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆÙŠØ¤Ø®Ø± Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø¥Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠØ§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„: Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ù†: ÙØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ…Ù„Ø§Ø¦ÙƒØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ±Ø³Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ…Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ù…Ù„Ø§Ø¦ÙƒØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ±Ø³Ù„Ù‡ ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒØ°Ø¨ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ù„Ø§Ø¦ÙƒØªÙ‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø±Ø³Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø¹Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ù…Ø®Ø²ÙˆÙ† Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ·Ù„Ø¹ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø®Ù„Ù‚Ù‡ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ù… Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆÙŠØ¤Ø®Ø± Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ…Ø­Ùˆ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆÙŠØ«Ø¨Øª Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ù„Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†: ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ† Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù†ÙƒØ± Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ ÙŠÙˆÙ…ÙŠ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø¯Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙƒØ°Ø¨ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¥Ù† Ø´Ø§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ . ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†: ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø³Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø¹Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆØ¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒ Ø¨Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø³ØªÙ…Ø§Ø¹ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¥Ù†ØµØ§ÙØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: ÙŠØ§ Ø³ÙŠØ¯ÙŠ Ø£Ø³Ø£Ù„ÙƒØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø³Ù„ Ø¹Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ Ù„Ùƒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ø§ ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ ÙÙŠÙ…Ù† Ø¬Ø¹Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø§Ø³Ù…Ø§ ÙˆØµÙØ© Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø­ÙŠ ÙˆØ³Ù…ÙŠØ¹ ÙˆØ¨ØµÙŠØ± ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ÙŠØ±ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ù„ØªÙ… Ø­Ø¯Ø«Øª Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø´ÙŠØ§Ø¡ ÙˆØ§Ø®ØªÙ„ÙØª Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø´Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ÙˆØ§ Ø­Ø¯Ø«Øª ÙˆØ§Ø®ØªÙ„ÙØª Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø³Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ø¨ØµÙŠØ±ØŒ ÙÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ø¯Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ù„ÙŠØ³Øª Ø¨Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø³Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ø¨ØµÙŠØ± ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù‚Ø¯ÙŠØ±ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ù„ Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¯Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† ÙØ¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø£Ø«Ø¨Øª Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø«Ø¨ØªØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø£Ù‡ÙŠ Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø©ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ø§ Ù‡ÙŠ Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø©ØŒ ÙØµØ§Ø­ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ù…Ø«Ù„Ù‡ ÙŠØ¹Ø§ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠÙƒØ§Ø¨Ø±ØŒ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†ØµØ§Ù Ø£Ù…Ø§ ØªØ±Ù‰ Ù…Ù† Ø­ÙˆÙ„Ùƒ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¸Ø±ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙƒÙ„Ù…Ù‡ ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ø¨Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡ Ù…ØªÙƒÙ„Ù… Ø®Ø±Ø§Ø³Ø§Ù†ØŒ ÙØ£Ø¹Ø§Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø£Ù„Ø© ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡ÙŠ Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø© ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† ÙØ¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ø£Ø²Ù„ÙŠØ§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø§ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø£Ø²Ù„ÙŠØ§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø£Ù† Ø³Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØ¨ØµØ±Ù‡ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙØ¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù„Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¯ Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø¨ØµÙŠØ±ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø³Ù…Ø¹ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙˆØ£Ø¨ØµØ± Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù… Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù…Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ Ø£Ùˆ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø­ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ùˆ Ø³Ù…ÙŠØ¹Ø§ Ø£Ùˆ Ø¨ØµÙŠØ±Ø§ Ø£Ùˆ Ù‚Ø¯ÙŠØ±Ø§ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø£ÙØ¨Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù„Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ùƒ: Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø­ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù…ÙŠØ¹Ø§ Ø¨ØµÙŠØ±Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¨Ù„Ù‰ Ù‚Ø¯ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙØ¶Ø­Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† ÙˆÙ…Ù† Ø­ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ ÙˆØ¶Ø­Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡Ù…: Ø§Ø±ÙÙ‚ÙˆØ§ Ø¨Ù…ØªÙƒÙ„Ù… Ø®Ø±Ø§Ø³Ø§Ù† ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø­Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒÙ… Ø¹Ù† Ø­Ø§Ù„Ø© ÙˆØªØºÙŠØ± Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙˆØµÙ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ§Ù†Ù‚Ø·Ø¹. Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø£Ø³Ø£Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ø³Ø£Ù„Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø³Ù„ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Øª ÙØ¯Ø§Ùƒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù†Ùƒ ÙˆØ¹Ù† Ø£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨Ùƒ ØªÙƒÙ„Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù‡ÙˆÙ† ÙˆÙŠØ¹Ø±ÙÙˆÙ† Ø£Ùˆ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù‡ÙˆÙ† ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø±ÙÙˆÙ†ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¨Ù„ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù‡ÙˆÙ† ÙˆÙŠØ¹Ø±ÙÙˆÙ† Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙØ§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¯ ØºÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© ÙˆØ£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¯ Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© ÙˆØ£Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙØ§Ø¹Ù„ Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙØ¹ÙˆÙ„ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ ÙŠØ¨Ø·Ù„ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ÙƒÙ…: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¯ Ø´Ø¦ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Øª ÙØ¯Ø§Ùƒ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ø°Ø§Ùƒ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø³ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù‡ÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙØ£Ø±Ø§ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ø¯Ø¹ÙŠØªÙ… Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ø±ÙØ©ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ù„ØªÙ…: Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© ÙƒØ§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø¹ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¨ØµØ± Ø¥Ø°Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒÙ… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ø±Ù ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ù‚Ù„ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ­Ø± Ø¬ÙˆØ§Ø¨Ø§. Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ù‡Ù„ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£ÙÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¨Ù‚Ù‰ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø´Ø¦ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø£ÙŠØ²ÙŠØ¯Ù‡Ù… Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠØ·ÙˆÙŠÙ‡ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ù…ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¨Ù„ ÙŠØ²ÙŠØ¯Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ£Ø±Ø§Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ùƒ: Ù‚Ø¯ Ø²Ø§Ø¯Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Øª ÙØ¯Ø§Ùƒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø²ÙŠØ¯ Ù„Ø§ ØºØ§ÙŠØ© Ù„Ù‡ (Ù¡) Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ ÙŠØ­ÙŠØ· Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒÙ… Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¹Ø±Ù ØºØ§ÙŠØ© Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ Ùˆ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ­Ø· Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ†ØŒ ØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¹Ù„ÙˆØ§ ÙƒØ¨ÙŠØ±Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ù„Øª: Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ØºØ§ÙŠØ© Ù„Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙˆØµÙÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„ÙˆØ¯ ÙˆÙƒØ±Ù‡Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ù† Ù†Ø¬Ø¹Ù„ Ù„Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù†Ù‚Ø·Ø§Ø¹Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ù…ÙˆØ¬Ø¨ Ù„Ø§Ù†Ù‚Ø·Ø§Ø¹Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù‚Ø¯ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø«Ù… ÙŠØ²ÙŠØ¯Ù‡Ù… Ø«Ù… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙ‚Ø·Ø¹Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ùˆ ÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡: ï´¿ÙƒÙ„Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ø¶Ø¬Øª Ø¬Ù„ÙˆØ¯Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ø¯Ù„Ù†Ø§Ù‡Ù… Ø¬Ù„ÙˆØ¯Ø§ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡Ø§ Ù„ÙŠØ°ÙˆÙ‚ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø°Ø§Ø¨ï´¾ (Ù¢) ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ù„Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø©: ï´¿Ø¹Ø·Ø§Ø¡ ØºÙŠØ± Ù…Ø¬Ø°ÙˆØ°ï´¾ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆÙØ§ÙƒÙ‡Ø© ÙƒØ«ÙŠØ±Ø© * Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ù‚Ø·ÙˆØ¹Ø© ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ¹Ø©) ÙÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙ‚Ø·Ø¹ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø²ÙŠØ§Ø¯Ø©ØŒ Ø£Ø±Ø£ÙŠØª Ù…Ø§ Ø£ÙƒÙ„ Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ù†Ø© ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø´Ø±Ø¨ÙˆØ§ Ø£Ù„ÙŠØ³ ÙŠØ®Ù„Ù Ù…ÙƒØ§Ù†Ù‡ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ù„Ù‰ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£ÙÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙŠÙ‚Ø·Ø¹ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ù… ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ø£Ø®Ù„Ù Ù…ÙƒØ§Ù†Ù‡ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù„Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø®Ù„Ù Ù…ÙƒØ§Ù†Ù‡ ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ø¨Ù…Ù‚Ø·ÙˆØ¹ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø¨Ù„ ÙŠÙ‚Ø·Ø¹Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ù… ÙÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ²ÙŠØ¯Ù‡Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø¥Ø°Ø§ ÙŠØ¨ÙŠØ¯ Ù…Ø§ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ØŒ Ùˆ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø¥Ø¨Ø·Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„ÙˆØ¯ ÙˆØ®Ù„Ø§Ù Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„: (Ù„Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¤ÙˆÙ† ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ ÙˆÙ„Ø¯ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ù…Ø²ÙŠØ¯) (Ù¡) ÙˆÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (Ø¹Ø·Ø§Ø¡ ØºÙŠØ± Ù…Ø¬Ø°ÙˆØ°) ÙˆÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: ï´¿ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù‡Ù… Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø¨Ù…Ø®Ø±Ø¬ÙŠÙ†ï´¾ ÙˆÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (Ø®Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ† ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø­ Ø£Ø¨Ø¯Ø§) ÙˆÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (ÙˆÙØ§ÙƒÙ‡Ø© ÙƒØ«ÙŠØ±Ø© Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ù‚Ø·ÙˆØ¹Ø© ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ¹Ø©) ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ­Ø± Ø¬ÙˆØ§Ø¨Ø§. Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø£Ù„Ø§ ØªØ®Ø¨Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© ÙØ¹Ù„ Ù‡ÙŠ Ø£Ù… ØºÙŠØ± ÙØ¹Ù„ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¨Ù„ Ù‡ÙŠ ÙØ¹Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙÙ‡ÙŠ Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø© Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙØ¹Ù„ ÙƒÙ„Ù‡ Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù„ÙŠØ³Øª Ø¨ÙØ¹Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙÙ…Ø¹Ù‡ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ù‡ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ù†Ø´Ø§Ø¡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø§Ø¯Ø¹ÙŠØªÙ…ÙˆÙ‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¶Ø±Ø§Ø± ÙˆØ£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡Ù…: Ø¥Ù† ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ø§ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙÙŠ Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ø£Ùˆ Ø£Ø±Ø¶ Ø£Ùˆ Ø¨Ø­Ø± Ø£Ùˆ Ø¨Ø± Ù…Ù† ÙƒÙ„Ø¨ Ø£Ùˆ Ø®Ù†Ø²ÙŠØ± Ø£Ùˆ Ù‚Ø±Ø¯ Ø£Ùˆ Ø¥Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù† Ø£Ùˆ Ø¯Ø§Ø¨Ø© Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ØªØ­ÙŠÙŠ ÙˆØªÙ…ÙˆØª ÙˆØªØ°Ù‡Ø¨ ÙˆØªØ£ÙƒÙ„ ÙˆØªØ´Ø±Ø¨ ÙˆØªÙ†ÙƒØ­ ÙˆØªÙ„Ø¯ ÙˆØªØ¸Ù„Ù… ÙˆØªÙØ¹Ù„ Ø§Ù„ÙÙˆØ§Ø­Ø´ ÙˆØªÙƒÙØ±ØŒ ÙˆØªØ´Ø±ÙƒØŒ ÙØªØ¨Ø±Ø§Ø¡ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ùˆ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø­Ø¯Ù‡Ø§ . Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø¹ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¨ØµØ± ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù‚Ø¯ Ø±Ø¬Ø¹Øª Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø«Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ©ØŒ ÙØ£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø¹ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¨ØµØ± ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù…ØµÙ†ÙˆØ¹ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù„Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙÙƒÙŠÙ Ù†ÙÙŠØªÙ…ÙˆÙ‡ ÙÙ…Ø±Ø© Ù‚Ù„ØªÙ… Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ±Ø¯ ÙˆÙ…Ø±Ø© Ù‚Ù„ØªÙ… Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØŒ ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ³Øª Ø¨Ù…ÙØ¹ÙˆÙ„ Ù„Ù‡ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙƒÙ‚ÙˆÙ„Ù†Ø§ Ù…Ø±Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù… ÙˆÙ…Ø±Ø© Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… (Ù¡) Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø³ÙˆØ§Ø¡ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹Ù„ÙˆÙ… Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ø¨Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙ†ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø£Ù† ØªÙƒÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© (Ù¢) ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø«Ø§Ø¨ØªØ§ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹Ù„ÙˆÙ…ØŒ Ø¨Ù…Ù†Ø²Ù„Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¨ØµØ± ÙÙ‚Ø¯ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù† Ø¨ØµÙŠØ±Ø§ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¨ØµØ±ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø«Ø§Ø¨ØªØ§ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¹Ù„ÙˆÙ… (Ù£). Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ù…ØµÙ†ÙˆØ¹Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙÙ‡ÙŠ Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø© Ù„ÙŠØ³Øª ÙƒØ§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø¹ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¨ØµØ± Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø¹ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¨ØµØ± Ù„ÙŠØ³Ø§ Ø¨Ù…ØµÙ†ÙˆØ¹ÙŠÙ† ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ Ù…ØµÙ†ÙˆØ¹Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ØµÙØ© Ù…Ù† ØµÙØ§ØªÙ‡ Ù„Ù… ØªØ²Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙÙŠÙ†Ø¨ØºÙŠ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù† Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ù„ Ù„Ø£Ù† ØµÙØªÙ‡ Ù„Ù… ØªØ²Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù„Ø§ Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙØ¹Ù„Ù‡Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ø®Ø±Ø§Ø³Ø§Ù†ÙŠ Ù…Ø§ Ø£ÙƒØ«Ø± ØºÙ„Ø·ÙƒØŒ Ø£ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ø¨Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ ÙˆÙ‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ ØªÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø´ÙŠØ§Ø¡ØŸ! (Ù¤) Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù„Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ø¨Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ø´ÙŠØªÙ‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¨Ø§Ø´Ø±Ø© ÙÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŸ! ØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù† Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ­Ø± Ø¬ÙˆØ§Ø¨Ø§ (Ù¥). Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø£Ù„Ø§ ØªØ®Ø¨Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: ï´¿ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø±Ø¯Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ù† Ù†Ù‡Ù„Ùƒ Ù‚Ø±ÙŠØ© Ø£Ù…Ø±Ù†Ø§ Ù…ØªØ±ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ ÙÙØ³Ù‚ÙˆØ§ ÙÙŠÙ‡Ø§ï´¾ ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠØ­Ø¯Ø« Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø©ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ø« Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ùƒ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ù‡ÙŠ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø£Ù… Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø¨Ø§Ø·Ù„Ø§ Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ­Ø¯Ø« Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØªØºÙŠØ± Ø¹Ù† Ø­Ø§Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù† Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ø¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠØ­Ø¯Ø« Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙÙ…Ø§ Ø¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ù‡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¹Ù†ÙŠ ÙØ¹Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙˆÙŠÙ„Ùƒ ÙƒÙ… ØªØ±Ø¯Ø¯ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø£Ù„Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±ØªÙƒ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø© Ù„Ø£Ù† ÙØ¹Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù‚Ø¯ ÙˆØµÙ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒÙ… Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙˆØµÙÙ‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ù‚Ø¯ÙŠÙ… ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø­Ø¯ÙŠØ« Ø¨Ø·Ù„ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ÙƒÙ…: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ù„ Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¯Ø§. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù†ÙŠØª Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙØ¹Ù„ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ù„Ø§ ØªØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù† Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ù„ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…ÙØ¹ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙˆØ­Ø¯ÙŠØ«Ø§ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ÙŠÙ…Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø­Ø§Ù„Ø© ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø©ØŸ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ­Ø± Ø¬ÙˆØ§Ø¨Ø§. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø£Ø³ØŒ Ø£ØªÙ…Ù… Ù…Ø³Ø£Ù„ØªÙƒØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù‚Ù„Øª: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© ØµÙØ© Ù…Ù† ØµÙØ§ØªÙ‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙƒÙ… ØªØ±Ø¯Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ØµÙÙ‡ Ù…Ù† ØµÙØ§ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØµÙØªÙ‡ Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø© Ø£Ùˆ Ù„Ù… ØªØ²Ù„ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø£ÙƒØ¨Ø± ÙØ§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø© ÙˆØ£Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù†Øª ØµÙØ© Ù…Ù† ØµÙØ§ØªÙ‡ Ù„Ù… ØªØ²Ù„ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ±Ø¯ Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø¥Ù† Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ²Ù„ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…ÙØ¹ÙˆÙ„Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø´ÙŠØ§Ø¡ Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ±Ø¯ Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙˆØ³ÙˆØ³Øª ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† ÙÙ‚Ø¯ ÙØ¹Ù„ ÙˆØ®Ù„Ù‚ Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ±Ø¯ Ø®Ù„Ù‚Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙØ¹Ù„Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ ØµÙØ© Ù…Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø±ÙŠ Ù…Ø§ ÙØ¹Ù„ØŒ ØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: ÙŠØ§ Ø³ÙŠØ¯ÙŠ Ù‚Ø¯ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±ØªÙƒ Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø¹ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¨ØµØ± ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ†: ÙˆÙŠÙ„Ùƒ ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† ÙƒÙ… Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ØºÙ„Ø· ÙˆØ§Ù„ØªØ±Ø¯Ø¯ Ø§Ù‚Ø·Ø¹ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ÙˆØ®Ø° ÙÙŠ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ Ø¥Ø° Ù„ÙŠØ³Øª ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ‰ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¯ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø¯Ø¹Ù‡ ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ù…ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ†ØŒ Ù„Ø§ ØªÙ‚Ø·Ø¹ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ø³Ø£Ù„ØªÙ‡ ÙÙŠØ¬Ø¹Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ø­Ø¬Ø©ØŒ ØªÙƒÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‚Ø¯ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±ØªÙƒ Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø¹ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¨ØµØ± ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø£Ø³ØŒ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù† Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø£Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø£Ù… Ù…Ø¹Ø§Ù† Ù…Ø®ØªÙ„ÙØ©ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¨Ù„ Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙÙ…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø§Øª ÙƒÙ„Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ø§Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ù‰ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙŠØ§Ù… ÙˆØ¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù‚ÙˆØ¯ ÙˆØ¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙŠØ§Ø© ÙˆØ¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØª Ø¥Ø°Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø© Ù„Ù… ÙŠØªÙ‚Ø¯Ù… Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ù‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ø§ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ®Ø§Ù„Ù Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ù‡Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¥Ù† Ù…Ø¹Ù†Ø§Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ø®ØªÙ„ÙØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙØ£Ø®Ø¨Ø±Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¯ Ø£Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø£Ùˆ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡Ø§ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¨Ù„ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙØ§Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¯ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒÙ… ÙŠØ®ØªÙ„Ù Ø¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø³ÙŠØ¯ÙŠ Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¯ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙØ§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù„Ø§ ÙÙ…Ø¹Ù‡ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡. Ø§ÙÙ‡Ù… ÙˆØ²Ø¯ ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø³Ø£Ù„ØªÙƒ. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ø³Ù… Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù‡Ù„ Ø³Ù…Ù‰ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ø¨Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù„Ø§ØŒ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ³Ù… Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ø¨Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù† ØªØ³Ù…ÙŠÙ‡ Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ³Ù… Ø¨Ù‡ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‚Ø¯ ÙˆØµÙ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ø¨Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¯ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù„ÙŠØ³ ØµÙØªÙ‡ Ù†ÙØ³Ù‡ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ø±ÙŠØ¯ Ø¥Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ø± Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¥Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ø±Ø§ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø§Ø³Ù… Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ø¬Ø§Ù‡Ù„ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ù‡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø£Ø¬Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ±Ø¯Ù‡ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø£Ø¬Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù…Ù† Ø£ÙŠÙ† Ù‚Ù„Øª Ø°Ø§ÙƒØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù„ÙŠÙ„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ù† Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯ØªÙ‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ù‡. ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯Ù‡ Ø£Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: ï´¿ÙˆÙ„Ø¦Ù† Ø´Ø¦Ù†Ø§ Ù„Ù†Ø°Ù‡Ø¨Ù† Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø£ÙˆØ­ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙƒï´¾ (Ù¡) ÙÙ‡Ùˆ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… ÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠØ°Ù‡Ø¨ Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ°Ù‡Ø¨ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø£Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù‚Ø¯ ÙØ±Øº Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø± ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ ÙŠØ²ÙŠØ¯ ÙÙŠÙ‡ Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ (Ù¢) Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ÙˆØ¯ØŒ ÙÙƒÙŠÙ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: (Ø§Ø¯Ø¹ÙˆÙ†ÙŠ Ø£Ø³ØªØ¬Ø¨ Ù„ÙƒÙ…) (Ù£) Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø£ÙÙŠØ¹Ø¯ Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙÙŠ Ø¨Ù‡ØŸ! ÙÙƒÙŠÙ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: ï´¿ÙŠØ²ÙŠØ¯ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ï´¾ (Ù¤) Ùˆ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„: ï´¿ÙŠÙ…Ø­ÙˆØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ´Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆÙŠØ«Ø¨Øª ÙˆØ¹Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø£Ù… Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ï´¾ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ ÙØ±Øº Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø±ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ­Ø± Ø¬ÙˆØ§Ø¨Ø§. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ù‡Ù„ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù† Ø¥Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù†Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ®Ù„Ù‚ Ø¥Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù† Ø¥Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù†Ø§ ÙŠÙ…ÙˆØª Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙˆÙ… ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ…ÙˆØª Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙˆÙ…ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù†Ø¹Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø£Ùˆ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ†ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù†Ù‡Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ†Ø§Ù† Ø¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø¥Ø°Ù† ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù† Ø¥Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù†Ø§ Ø­ÙŠ Ù…ÙŠØªØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ø¹Ø¯ØŒ Ø£Ø¹Ù…Ù‰ Ø¨ØµÙŠØ± ÙÙŠ Ø­Ø§Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø­Ø§Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Øª ÙØ¯Ø§Ùƒ ÙØ¥Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø±ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø£Ø³ØŒ ÙØ£ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø£Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ±Ø¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ†ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ†ØŒ ÙØ¶Ø­Ùƒ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† ÙˆØ£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‚Ø§Ù„Ø§Øª. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ØºÙ„Ø·Øª ÙˆØªØ±ÙƒØª Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ùƒ: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù† Ø¥Ù†Ø³Ø§Ù†Ø§ ÙŠÙ…ÙˆØª Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙˆÙ… ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ…ÙˆØª Ø§Ù„ÙŠÙˆÙ… ÙˆØ£Ù†Ù‡ ÙŠØ®Ù„Ù‚ Ø®Ù„Ù‚Ø§ ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ®Ù„Ù‚Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¬Ø² Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒÙ… Ø¨Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ±Ø¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙØ¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† . Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: ÙØ¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ÙŠ: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ù„ÙŠØ³Øª Ù‡Ùˆ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ø¬Ø§Ù‡Ù„ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ù‚Ù„Øª: Ù„ÙŠØ³Øª Ù‡Ùˆ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„ØªÙ‡Ø§ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ù‚Ù„Øª: Ù„ÙŠØ³Øª Ù‡ÙŠ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„ØªÙ‡Ø§ Ù‡ÙˆØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: ÙÙ‡Ùˆ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… ÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠØµÙ†Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: ÙØ¥Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¥Ø«Ø¨Ø§Øª Ù„Ù„Ø´Ø¦ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø£Ø­Ù„Øª Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ù‚Ø¯ ÙŠØ­Ø³Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ù†Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ¨Ù† ÙˆÙŠØ­Ø³Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø®ÙŠØ§Ø·Ø© ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ù„Ù… ÙŠØ®Ø· ÙˆÙŠØ­Ø³Ù† ØµÙ†Ø¹Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ù„Ù… ÙŠØµÙ†Ø¹Ù‡ Ø£Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡: ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ù‡Ù„ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù„Ø§ Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£ÙÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¥Ø«Ø¨Ø§ØªØ§ Ù„Ù„Ø´Ø¦ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ù„ÙŠØ³ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù„Ø§ Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ø¹Ù‡. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: Ø£ÙØªØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø£Ù†Øª Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ£Ù†Øª ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø£Ù„Ø© Ù…Ø­Ø§Ù„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ø­Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯Ùƒ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù„Ø§ Ø´Ø¦ Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ ÙˆØ£Ù†Ù‡ Ø³Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ø¨ØµÙŠØ± Ø­ÙƒÙŠÙ… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ… Ù‚Ø§Ø¯Ø±ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙÙƒÙŠÙ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ Ø£Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø­ÙŠ Ø³Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ø¨ØµÙŠØ± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ… Ø®Ø¨ÙŠØ± ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŸ! ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ø±Ø¯ Ù…Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ ÙˆØªÙƒØ°ÙŠØ¨Ù‡ØŒ ØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù† Ø°Ù„ÙƒØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯ ØµÙ†Ø¹ Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø±ÙŠ ØµÙ†Ø¹Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ø§ Ù‡ÙˆØŸ! ÙˆØ¥Ø°Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø§Ù„ØµØ§Ù†Ø¹ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¯Ø±ÙŠ ÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠØµÙ†Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¦ Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØµÙ†Ø¹Ù‡ ÙØ¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ Ù‡Ùˆ Ù…ØªØ­ÙŠØ±ØŒ ØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†: ÙØ¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¯Ø±Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ÙˆÙ‡Ùˆ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯Ù‡ Ø£Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰: ï´¿ÙˆÙ„Ø¦Ù† Ø´Ø¦Ù†Ø§ Ù„Ù†Ø°Ù‡Ø¨Ù† Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø£ÙˆØ­ÙŠÙ†Ø§ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙƒï´¾ ÙÙ„Ùˆ ÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø±Ø§Ø¯Ø© Ù‡ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¯Ø±Ø© ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù‚Ø¯ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ø¯ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ°Ù‡Ø¨ Ø¨Ù‡ Ù„Ù‚Ø¯Ø±ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙØ§Ù†Ù‚Ø·Ø¹ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ: ÙŠØ§ Ø³Ù„ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ù‡Ø§Ø´Ù…ÙŠ. Ø«Ù… ØªÙØ±Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ…. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù…ØµÙ†Ù Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨: ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø£Ù…ÙˆÙ† ÙŠØ¬Ù„Ø¨ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ù…Ù† Ù…ØªÙƒÙ„Ù…ÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙØ±Ù‚ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø£Ù‡ÙˆØ§Ø¡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¶Ù„Ø© ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ù† Ø³Ù…Ø¹ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø­Ø±ØµØ§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù†Ù‚Ø·Ø§Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¬Ø© Ù…Ø¹ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ°Ù„Ùƒ Ø­Ø³Ø¯Ø§ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ù…Ù†Ø²Ù„Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙÙƒØ§Ù† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙ„Ù… Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ø§ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù‚Ø± Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØªØ²Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¬Ø© Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ ØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ Ø°ÙƒØ±Ù‡ Ø£Ø¨Ù‰ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ¹Ù„ÙŠ ÙƒÙ„Ù…ØªÙ‡ ÙˆÙŠØªÙ… Ù†ÙˆØ±Ù‡ ÙˆÙŠÙ†ØµØ± Ø­Ø¬ØªÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡ÙƒØ°Ø§ ÙˆØ¹Ø¯ ØªØ¨Ø§Ø±Ùƒ ÙˆØªØ¹Ø§Ù„Ù‰ ÙÙŠ ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨Ù‡ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: (Ø¥Ù†Ø§ Ù„Ù†Ù†ØµØ± Ø±Ø³Ù„Ù†Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¢Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙŠØ§Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§) ÙŠØ¹Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¢Ù…Ù†ÙˆØ§: (Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¦Ù…Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ø¯Ø§Ø© Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙˆØ£ØªØ¨Ø§Ø¹Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ø§Ø±ÙÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø°ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù†Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙŠÙ†ØµØ±Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¬Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø®Ø§Ù„ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ù…Ø§ Ø¯Ø§Ù…ÙˆØ§ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ù†ÙŠØ§ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù„ Ø¨Ù‡Ù… ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¢Ø®Ø±Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ®Ù„Ù ÙˆØ¹Ø¯Ù‡. Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ù‡ÙŠ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬Ø¯Ø§Ù„ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø§Ø¡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ø² ÙˆØ¬Ù„ ", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/14/2/66/1", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 66, "thaqalaynSanad": "â€«â€ª1. Abu Muhammad Ja`far ibn `Ali ibn Ahmad the Jurist (RA) said: Abu Muhammad al-Hasanâ€¬â€¬ â€«â€ªibn Muhammad ibn `Ali ibn Sadaqah al-Qummi reported to us that Abu `Amr Muhammad ibnâ€¬â€¬ â€«â€ª`Umar ibn `Abd al-`Aziz al-Ansari al-Kajji related to me that one who heard from al-Hasan ibnâ€¬â€¬ â€«â€ªMuhammad al-Nawfali related to me thatâ€¬â€¬ ", "thaqalaynMatn": "Sulayman al-Marwazi, the theologian in Khurasan went to see al-Ma`mun. He honored him, granted him gifts and said: â€œMy cousin `Ali ibn Musa al-Rida (AS) has come here from Hejaz. He likes theology and theologians. Thus, it would not be any trouble if you came on the Day of Tarwiyah to have a debate with him.â€ Sulayman said: â€œO Commander of the Faithful! I dislike questioning him in your session and among a group of Hashimites. The people will regard him as incapable when he debates with me on theology. Incapabilities are not permissible for him.â€ Al-Ma`mun said: â€œI have invited you because of my recognition of your strength. I have no intentions except for you t silence him in an argument.â€ Sulayman said: â€œO Commander of the Faithful! I will do it for you. Just bring us together, sit down, and watch.â€ Then al-Ma`mun sent someone after al-Rida (AS) and said: â€œA man from Marw who has no equal in Khurasan in theology has come, and asked for you to come to us. Come here if you do not mind.â€ The Imam (AS) made ablution and told us to go ahead. `Imran the Sabian was with us. We went until we arrived at al-Ma`munâ€™s court. Yasir and Khalid took me by the hand, and led me in to al-Mamun. When I greeted him, he asked, â€œWhere is my brother Abu alHasan? May Allah keep him alive!â€ I said: â€œWhen we were coming he was putting on his clothes. He ordered us to go ahead.â€ Then I added, â€œO Commander of the Faithful! Your servant `Imran is also with me. He is right outside.â€ He asked, â€œWho is `Imran?â€ I answered, â€œHe is the Sabian who became a Muslim because of you.â€ He said: â€œLet him in.â€ Then `Imran came in. Al-Ma`mun welcomed him, and then told him, â€œO Imran! You joined the Hashimites before your death!â€ `Imran said: â€œO Commander of the Faithful! Praise be to Allah who honored me by you.â€ Al-Ma`mun said: â€œO `Imran! This is Sulayman al-Marwazi, who is the theologian from Khurasan.â€ `Imran said: â€œO Commander of the Faithful! He thinks that he is the only one in Khurasan versed in theoretical principles, and he refutes appearance [bada`].â€ Al-Ma`mun said: â€œWhy do you not debate with him?â€ `Imran said: â€œThis depends on him.â€ Then al-Rida (AS) came in and asked, â€œWhat were you discussing?â€ `Imran said: â€œO son of the Prophet of Allah! This is Sulayman al-Marwazi.â€ Sulayman said to `Imran. â€œWill you be pleased with Abu al-Hasan and what he says about appearance.â€ `Imran said: â€œYes. I will, if he presents argument like those I can present when I debate with other theologians like myself.â€ Al-Ma`mun said: â€œO Abu al-Hasan! What is your opinion regarding what they argue about?â€ The Imam (AS) said: O Sulayman! How could you not believe in appearance while Allah, the Mighty and High, said: But does not man call to mind that We created him before out of nothing? And the Mighty and High said: It is He who originates the creation, then He causes it to recur again, and says: Originator of the heavens and the earth. Moreover, the Mighty and High said: He began the creation of man from clay. Also the mighty and High says: And others are mate to await Allahâ€™s Command, whether He will chastise them, or turn in mercy to them. And the Mighty and High says: None ages, nor any diminishes from oneâ€™s life except what is in a Book. Sulayman asked, â€œHas anything been narrated to you on this issue from your forefathers?â€ The Imam (AS) said: Yes. It has been narrated on the authority of Abu `Abd Allah al-Sadiq (AS) who said: Verily, Allah, the Mighty and High, possesses two types of knowledge: a Guarded or Hidden Knowledge, which no one knows but He. Appearance is rooted in that knowledge. And He possesses a second type of knowledge which he has taught to His Angels (AS) and his Messengers (AS), and which the learned members of the Household of the Prophet (AS) also know. Sulayman said: â€œI would like you to present this from the Book of Allah, the mighty and High.â€ The Imam (AS) said: That is the Word of Allah, the Mighty and High to His Prophet (SA0: So turn you back upon them for you are not to be blamed. Allah first intended to destroy them, then it appeared for Allah so He said: And remind them, for verily reminding avails the believers. Sulayman said: â€œMay I be your ransom! Tell me more.â€ Then al-Rida (AS) said: My father (AS) informed me on the authority of his forefathers (AS) that the Messenger of Allah (SA) said: Verily, Allah, the Mighty and High, revealed to one of His Prophets to let one of the kings know that I will take away his life at such and such a time. The Prophet went to see the King and told him that. Then the King pleaded to Allah, while he was on his until he fell off of it. He said: â€œO Lord! Postpone m demise until I see my son grow up to undertake my affairs.â€ Then Allah, the Mighty and High, revealed to that Prophet, â€œGo to that king and inform him that I have decided to postpone his death. I have added fifteen years to his life.â€ The Prophet said: â€œO Lord! You know very well that I have never lied.â€ Then Allah, the Mighty and High, revealed to him, â€œVerily, you are a servant ordained. Therefore, announce this to him. Allah is never questioned about what He does.â€ Then the Imam (AS) turned towards Sulayman and said: â€œI think you have the same opinion as the Jews in this regard.â€ Sulayman said: â€œI seek refuge in Allah from such a thing. What have the Jews said?â€ The Imam (AS) said: The Jews say, `Godâ€™s hand is tied up. They mean that Allah has finished working, is sitting back, and does not create anything else. However, Allah, the Mighty and High, has given them the following answer: Be their hands tied up, and be they cursed for what they say. I have also heard a group of people asking my father Musa ibn Ja`far (AS) about appearance, so he said: â€œWhat do the people refute from the appearance, while Allah mighty delay the affairs of some people for a decision regarding them?â€ Sulayman asked, â€œcan you tell me for what has the following verse been revealed? Verily, We have revealed this (Qurâ€™an) in the Night of Power. The Imam (AS) said: â€œO Sulayman! Allah, the Mighty and High, decides the destiny for that year including life or death, good or evil, and sustenance on the Night of Power. Whatever He destines on that night comes to be.â€ Sulayman said: â€œNow I understand. May I be your ransom! Please tell me more.â€ The Imam (AS) said: O Sulayman! Some of the affairs are up to Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, and what He wills. He can expedite what He wills, and delay what He wills. O Sulayman, `Ali (AS) used to say, â€œKnowledge is of two types: Knowledge which Allah has taught His Angels and His Messengers, and knowledge which He has hidden, and of which none of His Creation is aware. What Allah has taught His Angels and His Messengers will be done, for He does not belie Himself, His Angels or His Messengers. It is through His Hidden Knowledge that He expedites or delays what He wills, removes what He wills, and asserts what He wishes to assert. Sulayman told al-Ma`mun, â€œO Commander of the Faithful! Allah willing, from this day on I will not refute or deny the doctrine of appearance.â€ Al-Ma`mun said: â€O Sulayman! Ask Abu al-Hasan whatever you wish. Just listen carefully and be fair.â€ Sulayman said: â€œO my Mater! May I question you?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œAsk whatever you wish.â€ Sulayman said, â€œWhat is your view about someone who considers the Divine Will to be a name or an attribute like the `Ever-Living,â€™ the `All-Hearing,â€™ the `All-Seeing,â€™ and the `Omnipotentâ€™?â€ Al-Rida (AS) replied, You claim that things have emerged and become different because He so willed and intended. However, you do not say that things have emerged and become different, because He is All-Hearing and All-Seeing. This is a proof that they (i.e. Will and Intent) are not similar to attributes such as the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing, and the Omnipotent. Sulayman said: â€œHe has always been an Intender.â€ The Imam (AS) answered him, â€œO Sulayman! Is His Intent something other than Him?â€ He replied, â€œYes.â€ The Imam (A) said: â€œThen you have proved that there has always been something alongwith Him forever.â€ Sulayman said: â€œNo. I have not.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œHas intent emerged?â€ Sulayman said: â€œNo. It has not emerged.â€ Then al-Ma`mun shouted at him and said: â€œO Sulayman! Are you showing obstinacy, and giving vague answers to such a person as him. You must be fair. Do not you see that you are surrounded by intellectuals?â€ Then he said: â€œO Abu al-Hasan! Continue your speech, since he is the theologian of Khurasan.â€ So the Imam (AS) repeated his question, â€œO Sulayman! Has it (the intent) emerged? For verily, if a thing is not sempiternal, then it has emerged, and if it has not emerged, then it is sempiternal.â€ Sulayman said: â€œHis Intent is from Him just as His Hearing, His Seeing and His Knowledge are from Him.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œthen is He the same as His Intent?â€ Sulayman answered, â€œNo.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œTherefore, the intender is not like the hearing and the seeing.â€ Sulayman said: â€œsurely, He intended Himself, in the same way that He heard Himself, that He was Himself, and that He knew Himself.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œWhat is the meaning of `He intended Himself? Did He intend to be a Thing? Did He intend to be All-Living, All-Hearing, All-Seeing or All-Powerful?â€ Sulayman said: â€œYes.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œDid that occur through His Intent?â€ Sulayman answered, â€œNo.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œThen your statement, `He intended to be All-Living, All-Hearing, and All-Seeingâ€™ does not make any sense, since they were not done through His Intent.â€ Sulayman said: â€œYes. That was through His Intent.â€ Then al-Ma`mun and the people around him, burst into laughter. Al-Rida (AS) laughed as well and said: â€œDo not be too hard on the theologian from Khurasan. O Sulayman! Do you think that He has altered from state to state, and changed due to it? This is something by which Allah, the Mighty and High, cannot be described.â€ Sulayman remained silent. Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œO Sulayman! May I ask you a question?â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œTell me about you and your companions: Do you debate with the people on theology according to what you understand and know or according to what you do not understand and do not know?â€ Sulayman said: â€œYes! According to what w understand and know.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œWhat the people know is that the intender is different from the intent. The intender exists before the intent. The subject is before the object. This disproves y our statement, `The intender and the intended are the same thing.â€™â€ Sulayman said: â€œMay I be your ransom! This is not what the people know about and understand.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œI think you have claimed to have knowledge without understanding it. You have said: `Intending is like hearing and seeingâ€™ while this view is not based on knowledge and intellect.â€ Sulayman could not answer. Then Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œO Sulayman! Does Allah, the Mighty and High, have knowledge of all that is in Paradise and the Fire?â€ Sulayman said: â€œYes.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œIf Allah, the Mighty and High, knows that something will be created in the future, will He actually create it?â€ Sulayman answered, â€œYes.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œIf it is done to the extent that nothing else remains, can He add more to it or will He stop doing so?â€ Sulayman said: â€œHe will add to them.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œthen based on what you have said: He adds to them what He did not know would be crated.â€ He responded, â€œMay I be your ransom! There is no limit for adding.â€ The Imam (AS) said: Then in your opinion His Knowledge does not encompass what is in the two (Paradise and Hell)_, since He does not know the limit of that. IF His Knowledge does not encompass what is therein, then He would not know what will be there before it existed. Exalted is Allah, the Elevated and High, from that! Sulayman said: â€œWhen I said he does not know about them, it was because they have no limit, and Allah, the Mighty and High, Himself has described them as eternal. Therefore, we do not want to assume an end for them.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: His Knowledge of them will not limit them. There are many instances of which He has knowledge, then He adds to them, and does not take away what He has added to them. These are supported by the Word of Allah, the Mighty and High, in His Book: As often as their skins are burned away, We will change them for other skins, so that they may taste the torment. And the Mighty and High says to the inhabitants of Paradise: An unceasing gift. And the Mighty and High said: And abundant fruit, neither failing (be season) not forbidden. Therefore, the High and Mighty knows about these, and does not prevent them from accessing what is added. Will He not replace what the inhabitants of Paradise eat and drink? Sulayman said: â€œYes.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œDoes the fact that he replaces the consumed food and drink mean that He has stopped granting?â€ Sulayman said: â€œNo.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œTherefore, when whatever is consume in Paradise, Allah will replace it with other things. And the inhabitants of paradise will not be prevented from consuming them.â€ Sulayman said: â€œWell. He will limit what is added to them, and he will not give them anything else.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: Then whatever is in Paradise and hell will end. O Sulayman! This is against eternity and the Book since Allah, the Mighty and High, says: For them therein shall be whatever they desire, and with Us is yet eve more. The Mighty and High says: An unceasing gift. And the Mighty and High says: Not shall they (ever) be asked to leave. And the Mighty and High says: To abide therein forever. And the Mighty and High says: And abundant fruit, nether failing (by season) nor forbidden. Sulayman remained silent. Then al-Rida (AS) said: â€œO Sulayman, tell me about the intent: Is it an action or is it not?â€ Sulayman said: â€œIt is an action.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œtherefore, it has emerged, for all actions have emerged.â€ Sulayman said: â€œIt is not an action.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œHas there then been something else with Him that is eternal?â€ Sulayman said: â€œIntending is the same as originating.â€ The Imam (AS) said: O Sulayman! This is exactly what you criticized of Dirar and his companions when they said that everything that Allah, the Mighty and High, has created in the heavens, the earth, the oceans or on land, such as dogs, pigs, monkeys, humans or animals, forms part of the Intent of Allah, the Mighty and High, and that Allahâ€™s Intent lives, dies, goes away, eats , drinks, marries, gives birth, oppresses, commits immoral acts, disbelieves, and become a polytheist. You denounce this view, and oppose it. This is its limit. Sulayman said: â€œThe intent is like hearing, seeing, and knowledge.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œYou just returned to what you said before. Tell me: are hearing, seeing and knowledge created?â€ Sulayman said: â€œNo.â€ Al-Rida (AS) asked, â€œHow do you then refute Him? At times you say that He did not intend. At other times you say that He intended, and that His Intent is not His Action?â€ Sulayman said: â€œSurely, that is like saying, He sometimes knows, and sometimes does not know!â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: That is not the same, for negating the known is not like negating knowledge. However, negating the intended is negating the intent, for if the thing is not intended, there will be no intent. However, sometimes there is knowledge, but there may be no known thing. This is like seeing. Man may be able to see, but there may be nothing there for him to see. Likewise, there may be knowledge, while there is nothing to be known. Sulayman said: â€œthe intent is created.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œTherefore, it has emerged, and is not like hearing and seeing, for hearing and seeing are not created, and the intent is created.â€ Sulayman said: â€œThe Intent is one of His Eternal Attributes.â€ The Imam (AS) answered, â€œTherefore, man must be eternal, for his attribute is eternal.â€ Sulayman said: â€œNo, because He has not carried out of the intent.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œO Khurasani! How often you make mistakes! Are things not made according to His Intent and His Words?â€ Sulayman said: â€œNo.â€ The Imam (AS) said: If things are not made according to His Intent or Will, nor His Command or His Practice, then how are they made? Exalted is Allah from that!â€ Sulayman could not respond. Then al-Rida (AS) asked, â€œWill you not tell me about the Word of Allah, the Mighty and High: When We intend to destroy a town, We send Our commandment to those of its people who lead easy lives (to obey Us), and yet they transgress in it. By this `We intendâ€™ He means that He emerges the intent?â€ Sulayman said to him, â€œYes.â€ The Imam (AS) replied to him, â€œIf He crates the intent, then your statement that `the intent is He Himself or is a part of Him is futile, for it is not possible that He emerged Himself as His State never changes. Exalted is Allah from that!â€ Sulayman asked, â€œDoes He not mean by that that He caused the intent to emerge?â€ The Imam (AS) asked, â€œWhat would He man by that?â€ Sulayman said: â€œHe means doing something.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œWoe unto you! How many times have you repeated this issue? I have told you that the intent is emerged, since the action of a thing is emerged.â€ Sulayman said: â€œThen this has no meaning.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œDo you then think that He describes Himself with intent which has no meaning? If the intent has no eternal or emerged meaning, then that will nullify your statement, `Allah has always been the Intender.â€ Sulayman said: â€œI meant to say that the intent is one of the Eternal Actions of Allah.â€ The Imam (AS) said; â€œDo you know the eternal cannot be created or emerged and eternal simultaneously?â€ Sulayman could not answer. Al-Rida (AS) continued, â€œNever mind! Complete your questions.â€ Sulayman said: â€œDid you say that intent is one of His Attributes?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said; â€œHow many times will you repeat that the intent is one of His Attributes. Are His Attributes emerged or are they eternal?â€ Sulayman said: â€œthey are emerged.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œAllah is the Greatest! You are telling me that the intent in emerged, even though it is one of His Eternal Attributes. Therefore, He has not intended anything!â€ The Imam (AS) added, Whatever is eternal is not created.â€ Sulayman said: â€œThings are not the same as the intent, and He did not intend anything.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œO Sulayman! Are you suggesting that He created what He did not intend to create? This is an attribute of someone who does not know what he is doing. Exalted is Allah from that!â€ Sulayman said: â€œO my Master! I have already informed you that the intent is like hearing, seeing and knowing.â€ Al-Ma`mun said: â€œO Sulayman! Woe unto you! How often have you erred, and how often have you repeated yourself! Cease and address another issue since you seem unable to provide a proper answer.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œO Commander of the Faithful! Leave him alone! Do not interrupt his questions, since then he will regard it as an argument (against me). O Sulayman! Speak.â€ Sulayman said: â€œI have already informed you that the intent is like hearing, seeing and knowing.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œNever mind! Tell me whether the intent has one meaning or several meanings.â€ Sulayman said: â€œIt has one meaning.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œIs the meaning of all the intents then the same?â€ Sulayman said: â€œYes.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: If its meanings are the same, then it must be that the intent to stand up is the same as the intent to sit down, or that the intent to live is the same as the intent to die. If His Intent is all one thing, then none of His Desires will take precedence over any others. None will be any different from any others. They will all be one thing. Sulayman replied, â€œSurely, the meanings are different.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œThen, tell me about the Intender. Is it the same as the intent or is it something else?â€ Sulayman said: â€œYes. It is the same as the intent.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œThen according to you the intender is something else, since it is the same as the intent.â€ Sulayman said: â€œO my Master! The intent is not the same as the intender.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œThen the intent is emerged. Otherwise, it must be that something else existed along with Him. Understand this well, and continue on with your questions.â€ Sulayman said: â€œThe intent is one of His Names.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œDid He give Himself that name?â€ Sulayman replied, â€œNo, He did not give Himself that name.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œTherefore, you have not right to give Him a name which He did not give to Himself?â€ Sulayman said: â€œBut He has described Himself as the Intender.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œthe fact that He has described Himself as the Intender does not mean that He wanted to inform us that He is the Intent, or that the Intent is one of His Names.â€ Sulayman said: â€œthat is because His Intent is the same as His Knowledge.â€ AlRida (AS) said: â€œO ignorant man! If He knows something, does that not mean that He has intended it?â€ Sulayman said: â€œYes.â€ The Imam (AS) asked, â€œHowever, if He does not intent something, does that mean that He does not know it?â€ Sulayman said: â€œYes.â€ The Imam (AS) said: What is your source for that statement? What proof do you have that His Intent is the same as His Knowledge? He may know something, but never intent it. This is supported by His Word the Mighty and High: If We wished, We would certainly take away that which We revealed to you. He knows how to take it away, but He never will. Sulayman said: â€œThat is because He has finished administering the affairs of creation, and will not add anything to what He has destined.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œthis is what the Jews say. Then how has the Mighty and High said: Call unto Me; I will answer you. Sulayman said: â€œHe means that He has the power to do so.â€ The Imam (AS) said: Does He make a promise that He will not fulfill? And if so, then why has He said that He adds to creation whatever He wills. And the Mighty and High said: Allah effaces (of it) whatever He pleases, and confirms (what He wi9lls); with Him is the mother of the Book. Has He finished administering the affairs of creation?â€ Sulayman could not answer. Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œO Sulayman! Does He know that a human being will come into existence, while He does not intend to create a human being ever again? Can a person die today, while He does not intend for him to die today?â€ Sulayman said: â€œYes.â€ Al-Rida (AS) asked, â€œDoes He know what He intends exists? And does He know that what He has not intended does not exist?â€ Sulayman said: â€œHe knows that both of them exist.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œTherefore, He knows that man is simultaneously alive and dead, is standing and sitting, is blind and seeing. This is impossible.â€ Sulayman said: â€œMay I be your ransom! He knows that one of them will exist.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œDo not worry. Which one will exist? The one which He intended or the one which He did not intended?â€ Sulayman said: â€œThe one He intended will exist!â€ Al-Rida (AS), al-Ma`mun, and the scholars started to laugh. Al-Rida (AS) said: You have erred and strayed from your initial argument that `He knows that some people will die today, while He has not intended to make them die today, and that He creates creatures, while He does not intend to created them.â€™ If you hold that knowledge does not apply to what He has not intended, then He alone know what He has intended. Sulayman said; â€œMy statement is that the intent is neither Him nor something other than Him!â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œO ignorant man! If you say that He is separate from His Intent, then you are saying that His Intent is something other than Him. If you say that He is not separate from His Intent, then you have regarded His Intent equal to Him.â€ Sulayman asked, â€œDoes He know hoe He creates things?â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œYes.â€ Sulaymand said: â€œsurely this establishes something.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œwhat you have said is impossible because a man may know how to build a wall without building a wall; a man may know how to sew without sewing anything; or a man may know how t do something well without making it. Then al-Rida (AS) added, â€œO Sulayman! Does He know that He is One without anything with Him?â€ Sulayman replied, â€œYes.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œDoes this establish something?â€ Sulayman said: â€œHe does not know that He is One without anything with Him.â€ Al-Rida (AS) asked, â€œDo you know that?â€ Sulayman replied, â€œYes.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: â€œO Sulayman! Therefore, you are more knowledgeable than Him!â€ Sulayman said: â€œThis is impossible.â€ The Imam (AS) said: â€œIs it impossible in your view that He is One without anything with Him, that He is All-Hearing, All-Seeing, All-Wise, All-Knowing, and All-Powerful?â€ He replied, â€œYes.â€ The Imam (AS) said: Then how did Allah, the Mighty and High, inform that He is One, Ever-Living, AllHearing, All-Seeing, All-Knowing, All-Aware, if He did not know that? This rejects and belies what He has said. Exalted is Allah from that!â€ Then Al-Rida (AS) asked him, â€œHow does He intend to make something He does not know how to make? If a creator does not know how to create something before he creates it, then he is perplexed. Exalted is Allah from that! Sulayman said: â€œIntent is the same as Omnipotence.â€ Al-Rida (AS) said: He, the Mighty and High, has power over what He does not intend. There is no escape from that for He, the Blessed and Exalted, said: If it were Our Will, We could take away that which We have sent by inspiration. If intent is the same as omnipotence, He had intend to take it away for His Omnipotence. Sulayman remained silent. At this time Al-Ma`mun said: â€œO Sulayman! This is the most learned of the Hashimites!â€ Then the people dispersed. The Compiler of this book says: Al-Ma`mun was bringing together theologians of various schools of Islam and other religions who had deviated from the Straight Path, in an attempt to embarrass al-Rida and defeat him in debate. This was motivated by al-Ma`munâ€™s jealousy of him, and due to the stature that al-Rida`s (AS) knowledge gave him. However, all those who debated with him (AS) ended up acknowledging his nobility, and were convinced by the proofs presented by the Imam (AS). This was because Allah, Exalted by His Remembrance, honored His Word, accomplished His Light and assisted His Proof. This is what the Blessed and Exalted has promised in His Book: Verily, We help Our messengers and those who believe in the life of this world, by `those who believe,â€™ He mean the Immaculate Imams (AS), their followers, those who recognize them, and those who acquire knowledge from them. He assists them with proofs against their rivals for as long as they are in this world. He will treat them likewise in the Hereafter. Verily, Allah does not act against His Promise.", "gradingsFull": [] }, { "id": 307, "bookId": "Al-Tawhid-Saduq", "book": "Al-Tawá¸¥Ä«d", "category": "Content", "categoryId": "2", "chapter": "There is noâ€¬â€¬ god but the One God", "author": "Shaykh Muá¸¥ammad b. Ê¿AlÄ« al-á¹¢aduq", "translator": "Sayed Ali Raza Rizvi", "englishText": "â€«â€ª1. My father said: Ahmad ibn Idris and Muhammad ibn Yahya al-`Attar said, on the authority ofâ€¬â€¬ â€«â€ªMuhammad ibn Ahmad, on the authority of Ibrahim ibn Hashim, on the authority ofâ€¬â€¬ â€«â€ªMuhammad ibn Hammad, on the authority of al-Hasan ibn Ibrahim, on the authority of Yunusâ€¬â€¬ â€«â€ªibn `Abd al-Rahman, thatâ€¬â€¬ Hisham ibn al-Hakam related the story of the Catholicos, primate of the Armenian church of the Christians, who was named Burayhah, and had been the Catholicos for seventy years. He used to research Islam, and sought to debate those Muslims who were familiar with the Christian gospels, and who were familiar with the Messiah, his attributes, arguments, and signs. \u003Cbr\u003EHe says: He had been known for that until he became famous among the Christians, Muslims, Jews, and Zoroastrians. The Christians use to be so proud of him that they would say: â€œIf there was no one on earth in the Christian faith except Burayhah that would suffice us.â€ He was seeker of the truth and with that, of Islam. He had a woman with him that used to serve him and she had been with him for a long time. He use to secretly tell her about the weakness of Christianity and its weak proofs. He said: I came to know that from him. Thus, Burayhah put this matter behind him, and approached the various Muslim schools who differed a bout Islam, in search of the most learned one among them. He came asking about the Muslim leaders, their pious one, their scholars, and t heir leading intellectuals. He examined every Muslim school of though, and found nothing that satisfied him. He said: â€œIf you leaders were on the true path, then they would have some truth with them!â€ \u003Cbr\u003EFinally, he learned about the Shi`ites from Hisham ibn al-Hakam. Yunus ibn `Abd al-Rahman says: Hisham said to me. I was sitting in my shop at the door of al-Karkh while a group of people were reciting the Qurâ€™an to me. I was suddenly taken aback by a group of Christian clergymen. There were approximately one hundred men, dressed in the black clothing and chasubles (of the Coptic priests) and the Great Catholicos. Burayhah was among them. They came down around my shop and placed a chair for Burayhah to sit on. The bishops and monks stood learning over their staffs, and on their heads were their chasubles. Burayhah addressed me and said: â€œI have exhausted every single Muslim theologian in debate regarding Christianity, and they had nothing that impressed me. Hence, I have come to you wishing to debate Islam.â€ He says: Hisham laughed and said: â€œO Burayhah! If you expect me to give you the same type of signs that he Messiah gave, you have come to the wrong place as I am not the Messiah, not even close. I would never critics him, though, as he was one of the purified ones, who was humble in character, yet sublime in spirituality. The Signs of Allah wee manifest in him.â€ \u003Cbr\u003EBurayhah responded, â€œYour words astonish me.â€ Hisham said: â€œIf you want to argue then go ahead.â€ Burayhah said: â€œYes. I certainly want to question you: What is the physical tie between your Prophet and the Messiah?â€™ Hisham replied, â€œHe is the son of his maternal grandfather, because Jesus is from the children of Ishaq, and Muhammad (SA) is from the children of Isma`il.â€ Burayhah asked, How do you relate him to his father?â€ Hisham answered, â€œIf you want his lineage from your view, I will inform you of it, and if yo want his linage according to us, I will inform you of that.â€ Burayhah enquired, â€œI want his lineage according to us.â€ Burayhah says that I was thinking that if he described his lineage according to us, I would overpower him. So I said: â€œDescribe his lineage the way we relate it.â€ Hisham explained, â€œYes. You say: â€œHe is without beginning from the one without beginning. Then who is the Father and who is the Son?â€ Burayhah said: â€œHe who came unto the Earth is the Son.â€ Hisham asked, â€œHe who came unto the Earth is the Father.â€ He said: â€œThe Son is the messenger of the Father.â€ Hisham added, â€œVerily, the Father is wiser than the Son, because the Father is the Creator.â€ Burayhah said: â€œVerily, the Father and the Son are both the Creators.â€ Hisham continued, â€œWhat prevented them from coming down to Earth together like they were together when they created the world?â€ Burayhah replied, â€œHow do they associate while they are both one thing? They differ only by name.â€ Hisham responded, â€œVerily, they unite with the name.â€ Burayhah said: â€œThis statement is unknown.â€ Hisham said: â€œThis statement is well-known,â€ Burayhah responded, â€œVerily, the Son is connected to the Father.â€ Hisham replied, â€œVerily, the Son is disconnected from the Father.â€ He replied, â€œThis is contrary to what the people would think.â€ \u003Cbr\u003EHisham explained, â€œIf what the people think is true, then I have overcome you for the Father was when the Son was not. Is that what you are saying, O Burayhah?â€ He answered, â€œI do not say this.â€ Hisham responded, â€œThen why did you seek to confirm your beliefs on the beliefs of those whom you reject?â€ He said: â€œVerily, the Father is a name and the Son is a name, and the eternal has decreed them.â€ Hisham said: â€œAre the two names without beginning? Are they eternal like the Father and the Son? Burayhah declared, â€œNo, The names are originated.â€ He responded, â€œYou have certainly made the Father a Son, and the Son a Father. If the Son brought these names about, and not the Father, then he is the Father. And if the Father brought these names about, and not the Son, then he is the Father, and the Son is the Father. Thus, there is no Son here.â€ Burayhah said: â€œVerily, the Son is a name of the Holy Spirit when it came down to the Earth.â€ Hisham responded, â€œWhat was its name prior to coming down to Earth?â€ Burayhah continued on, baffled: â€œIts name is the Son whether it came down or did not came down.â€ Hisham advocated, â€œSo before the coming down of this Spirit, it was all one but it had two names.â€ He said: â€œIt is all one; one Spirit.â€ Hisham acclaimed, â€œYou are pleased to make some of it the Son and some of it the Father.â€ Burayhah replied, â€œNo, because the name of the Father and the name of the Son are one.â€ Hisham said: â€œTherefore, the Son is the Father of the Father, and the Father is Father of the Son, and there is one Son.â€ \u003Cbr\u003EThe bishops said to Burayhah with one voice: â€œNothing like this has ever happened to you, stand up!â€ Thus, Burayhah was confused and wanted to leave, so Hisham attached and said: What prevents you from embracing Islam? Is there any rancour in your heart? Then say it, otherwise I will ask you a question about Christianity. I will give you the night to think about it. Then, when you wake up, you will only be interested in me. The bishops said: â€œDo not ask him the question, for it may create doubts about your faith.â€ Burayhah said: â€œSay it, O Abu al-Hakam.â€ Hisham went on, â€œTell me, does the Son know everything that the Father does?â€ He answered, â€œYes.â€ Hisham asked, â€œTell me, does the Father know everything that is with the Son?â€ He answered, â€œYes.â€ Hisham asked, â€œTell me, does the Son have power over everything that the Father has power over?â€ He answered, â€œYes.â€ Hisham asked, â€œTell me, does the Father have power over everything which the Son has power over?â€ He answered, â€œYes.â€ \u003Cbr\u003EHisham responded, â€œThen how can one of them be the Son of his partner, while they are both equal, and how does each one of them oppress his partner?â€ Burayhah said; â€œThere is no oppression between them.â€ Hisham continued, â€œThe truth between them is that the Son is the Father of the Father, and the Father is the Son of the Son. Spend the night thinking about this, O Burayhah.â€ The Christians dispersed, and they were wishing that they had never seen Hisham and his friends. \u003Cbr\u003EYunus ibn `Abd al-Rahman says: Burayhah returned in grief and anxiety till he reached his home. The woman that served him asked him, â€œWhy is it that I see you grieved and anxious!â€ Hence, he related to her the debate between Hisham and him. She asked, â€œWoe unto you! Do you want to follow truth or falsehood?â€ Burayhah replied, â€œTruth, of course.â€ She said to him, â€œWherever you find truth, then turn to it. Be careful of obstinacy. For verily, obstinacy is doubt, doubt is calamity, and those with doubt are in Hell.â€ The reporter says: He agreed with her statement and decided to go to Hisham the next morning. \u003Cbr\u003EThe next morning he went to Hisham when none of his companions were with him. He enquired, â€œO Hisham! Do you have someone whose views and words you turn to, and profess his obedience?â€ Hisham answered, â€œYes, O Burayhah.â€ â€œWhat is his description?â€ â€œAre you asking about his lineage or his religion?â€ Hisham replied, He said: â€Both of them, the description of his lineage and his religion.â€ Hisham responded, As for his lineage, it is the best of the lineages: He is the leader of the Arabs, the best of the Quraysh, and the most distinguished of the Hashimites. Whoever argued about his lineage always found it to be better than his own, because the Quraysh are the best of the Arabs, and the Hashimites are the best of the Quraysh. And, as he is the best of the Hashimites, he is the most pious among them, and their master. He descends from the children of the master, who are better than all other children. He is the son of the master. \u003Cbr\u003EHe said: â€œDescribe his religion.â€ Hisham said: â€œHis law or description of body and his purity?â€ He said: â€œDescribe his body and his purity/â€ Hisham described, He is infallible; thus, he does not sin. He is generous; hence, he does not act miserly. He is brave; so he does not act cowardly. He has been bestowed with knowledge; therefore, he does not act ignorantly. He is the Protector of the Religion, firm in what is made mandatory. He is from the Progeny of the Prophets (AS), and the Vessel of Prophetic Knowledge (AS). He pardons when he is angry. He is fair in times of oppression. He helps when pleased, and is just towards both friend and foe. He does not ask of deviation for his enemy and foes not prohibit benefiting his friends. He practices the Book and speaks wonders. He is one of the Purified Ones. He relates the words of the Divinely Elected Leaders without violating their Proof. He is not ignorant of any question. He can derive a ruling [fatwa] from any tradition, and makes clear all darkness. \u003Cbr\u003EBurayhah responded, â€œYou have described the Messiah in his attributes, and proved him by his proofs and signs, except that you have applied this description to another person. If there is a person who fits this description, we will believe in him.â€ Hisham said: â€œIf you believe you will be guided, and if you follow the truth you will not be blamed.â€ He then added, â€œO Burayhah! There is not a proof which Allah establishes over the first of His Creation, except that He establishes it over the middle creation and the last creation. Therefore, Proofs do not become invalidated, just like nations and practices do not disappear.â€ Burayhah admitted, â€œHow close is this to righteousness, and how near it is to the truth. This is the attribute of the wise. They establish proof that negates suspicion.â€ Hisham said: â€œYes.â€ \u003Cbr\u003EThen they both departed together until they arrived at Medina. The woman was with them. They both wanted to see Abu `Abd Allah (AS). However, they met Musa ibn Ja`far (AS), so Hisham related to him the account. When he finished, Musa ibn Ja`far (AS) said: â€œO Burayhah! How is your knowledge of your Book (the Bible)?â€ He answered, â€œI am knowledgeable of it.â€ The Imam (AS) asked, â€œHow is your faith in its interpretation?â€ He replied. â€œI am confident that I am knowledgeable about it.â€ The reported says: Musa ibn Ja`far (AS) began reading the Bible. Burayhah responded, â€œThe Messiah must have read like this, and no one has read this recitation but the Messiah.â€ Burayhah then said: â€œI have been seeking you or someone like you for the past fifty years.â€ \u003Cbr\u003EThe reporter says: Therefore, he embraced Islam and so did the woman, and both were expediently faithful. The Hisham, Burayhah, and the woman entered the presence of Abu `Abd Allah (AS). Hisham related the account and the discussion that took place between Musa (AS) and Burayhah. Thus Abu `Abdillah (AS) read: Offspring one of the other; and Allah is Hearing, Knowing. So Burayhah asked, â€œMay I be your ransom! How do you view the Torah, the Bible and the Books of the Prophets?â€ Abu `Abdillah (AS) replied: â€œWe are their Heirs. We read them the way they were originally read, and we convey them as they were originally conveyed. Verily, Allah does not place a Proof [hujjat] on His earth who, when questioned about something, answers: `I do not know.â€™â€ \u003Cbr\u003EHence, Burayhah remained with Abu `Abdillah (AS) until Abu `Abdillah passed away. Then he remained with Musa ibn Ja`far (AS) until Burayhah died in his time. The Imam (AS) washed his corpse with his own hands, shrouded his body, and placed him in the grave and said: â€œThis is a disciple from the disciples of the Messiah, who recognized the right of Allah over him.â€ The reported says: Thus, most of the Companions of the Imam (AS) wished they were like him.", "arabicText": "1 - Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¥Ø¯Ø±ÙŠØ³ ÙˆÙ…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† ÙŠØ­ÙŠÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø·Ø§Ø±ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø­Ù…Ø¯ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ… Ø¨Ù† Ù‡Ø§Ø´Ù…ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø­Ù…Ø§Ø¯ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø³Ù† Ø¨Ù† Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù‡ÙŠÙ…ØŒ Ø¹Ù† ÙŠÙˆÙ†Ø³ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù†ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù… Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…ØŒ Ø¹Ù† Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ Ù…Ù† Ø¬Ø«Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ§Ø±Ù‰ ÙŠÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„Ù‡: Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø¯ Ù…ÙƒØ« Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ© Ø³Ø¨Ø¹ÙŠÙ† Ø³Ù†Ø© ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠØ·Ù„Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ùˆ ÙŠØ·Ù„Ø¨ Ù…Ù† ÙŠØ­ØªØ¬ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ù…Ù…Ù† ÙŠÙ‚Ø±Ø¡ ÙƒØªØ¨Ù‡ ÙˆÙŠØ¹Ø±Ù Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ Ø¨ØµÙØ§ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ¯Ù„Ø§Ø¦Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆØ¢ÙŠØ§ØªÙ‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙˆØ¹Ø±Ù Ø¨Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ø§Ø´ØªÙ‡Ø± ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ§Ø±Ù‰ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ÙˆØ¯ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø¬ÙˆØ³ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ø§ÙØªØ®Ø±Øª Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ§Ø±Ù‰ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„Øª: Ù„Ùˆ Ù„Ù… ÙŠÙƒÙ† ÙÙŠ Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ© Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø© Ù„Ø£Ø¬Ø²Ø£Ù†Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† Ø·Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø§ Ù„Ù„Ø­Ù‚ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¥Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ù…Ø¹ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ Ø§Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© ØªØ®Ø¯Ù…Ù‡ØŒ Ø·Ø§Ù„ Ù…ÙƒØ«Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠØ³Ø± Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ø¶Ø¹Ù Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ© ÙˆØ¶Ø¹Ù Ø­Ø¬ØªÙ‡Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ¹Ø±ÙØª Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ØŒ ÙØ¶Ø±Ø¨ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø± Ø¸Ù‡Ø±Ø§ Ù„Ø¨Ø·Ù† ÙˆØ£Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ ÙŠØ³Ø£Ù„ ÙØ±Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø®ØªÙ„ÙÙŠÙ† ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ù…Ù† Ø£Ø¹Ù„Ù…ÙƒÙ…ØŸ ÙˆØ£Ù‚Ø¨Ù„ ÙŠØ³Ø£Ù„ Ø¹Ù† Ø£Ø¦Ù…Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ† ÙˆØ¹Ù† ØµÙ„Ø­Ø§Ø¦Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¬Ù‰ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠØ³ØªÙ‚Ø±Ø¦ ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© ÙØ±Ù‚Ø© Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬Ø¯ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù‚ÙˆÙ… Ø´ÙŠØ¦Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù„Ùˆ ÙƒØ§Ù†Øª Ø£Ø¦Ù…ØªÙƒÙ… Ø£Ø¦Ù…Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ Ù„ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒÙ… Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ØŒ ÙÙˆØµÙØª Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙŠØ¹Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙˆØµÙ Ù„Ù‡ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù… Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…. ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ ÙŠÙˆÙ†Ø³ Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù†: ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ù„ÙŠ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø¨ÙŠÙ†Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ù†Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¯ÙƒØ§Ù†ÙŠ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ±Ø® Ø¬Ø§Ù„Ø³ ÙˆØ¹Ù†Ø¯ÙŠ Ù‚ÙˆÙ… ÙŠÙ‚Ø±Ø¤ÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø¢Ù† ÙØ¥Ø°Ø§ Ø£Ù†Ø§ Ø¨ÙÙˆØ¬ Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ§Ø±Ù‰ Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ Ù…Ø§ Ø¨ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø³ÙŠØ³ÙŠÙ† Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡Ù… Ù†Ø­Ùˆ Ù…Ù† Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ø© Ø±Ø¬Ù„ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙˆØ§Ø¯ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù†Ø³ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø«Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙƒØ¨Ø± ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù… Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø© Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ù†Ø²Ù„ÙˆØ§ Ø­ÙˆÙ„ Ø¯ÙƒØ§Ù†ÙŠ ÙˆØ¬Ø¹Ù„ Ù„Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø© ÙƒØ±Ø³ÙŠ ÙŠØ¬Ù„Ø³ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù…Øª Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø³Ø§Ù‚ÙØ© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø±Ù‡Ø§Ø¨Ù†Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¹ØµÙŠÙ‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø±Ø¤ÙˆØ³Ù‡Ù… Ø¨Ø±Ø§Ù†Ø³Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ù‚ÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ù„Ù…ÙŠÙ† Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù…Ù† ÙŠØ°ÙƒØ± Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… Ø¥Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ù†Ø§Ø¸Ø±ØªÙ‡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ© ÙÙ…Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯Ù‡Ù… Ø´Ø¦ ÙˆÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¬Ø¦Øª Ø£Ù†Ø§Ø¸Ø±Ùƒ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ¶Ø­Ùƒ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù… ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø© Ø¥Ù† ÙƒÙ†Øª ØªØ±ÙŠØ¯ Ù…Ù†ÙŠ Ø¢ÙŠØ§Øª ÙƒØ¢ÙŠØ§Øª Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ ÙÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ø£Ù†Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ù…Ø«Ù„Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø£Ø¯Ø§Ù†ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ø°Ø§Ùƒ Ø±ÙˆØ­ Ø·ÙŠØ¨Ø© Ø®Ù…ÙŠØµØ© Ù…Ø±ØªÙØ¹Ø©ØŒ Ø¢ÙŠØ§ØªÙ‡ Ø¸Ø§Ù‡Ø±Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ¹Ù„Ø§Ù…Ø§ØªÙ‡ Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù…Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: ÙØ£Ø¹Ø¬Ø¨Ù†ÙŠ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙˆØµÙ. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø¥Ù† Ø£Ø±Ø¯Øª Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¬Ø§Ø¬ ÙÙ‡Ù‡Ù†Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ù†Ø¹Ù… ÙØ¥Ù†ÙŠ Ø£Ø³Ø£Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ø© Ù†Ø¨ÙŠÙƒÙ… Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨Ø¯Ø§Ù†ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø¹Ù… Ø¬Ø¯Ù‡ (Ù„Ø£Ù…Ù‡) Ù„Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ù…Ù† ÙˆÙ„Ø¯ Ø¥Ø³Ø­Ø§Ù‚ ÙˆÙ…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ù…Ù† ÙˆÙ„Ø¯ Ø¥Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¹ÙŠÙ„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙƒÙŠÙ ØªÙ†Ø³Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø¨ÙŠÙ‡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø¥Ù† Ø£Ø±Ø¯Øª Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒÙ… Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±ØªÙƒØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† Ø£Ø±Ø¯Øª Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯Ù†Ø§ Ø£Ø®Ø¨Ø±ØªÙƒØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ø£Ø±ÙŠØ¯ Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯Ù†Ø§ØŒ ÙˆØ¸Ù†Ù†Øª Ø£Ù†Ù‡ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ù‡ Ù†Ø³Ø¨ØªÙ†Ø§ Ø£ØºÙ„Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ù„Øª: ÙØ§Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ø© Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ Ù†Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¨Ù‡Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ„ÙˆÙ†: Ø¥Ù†Ù‡ Ù‚Ø¯ÙŠÙ… Ù…Ù† Ù‚Ø¯ÙŠÙ… ÙØ£ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ ÙˆØ£ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù†Ø²Ù„ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø±Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù†ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ù†Ø²Ù„ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø±Ø¶ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ Ø£Ø­ÙƒÙ… Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø®Ù„Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ ÙˆØ®Ù„Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù†ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ù…Ø§ Ù…Ù†Ø¹Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙ†Ø²Ù„Ø§ Ø¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹Ø§ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ø®Ù„Ù‚Ø§ Ø¥Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ø´ØªØ±ÙƒØ§ØŸ! Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: ÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠØ´ØªØ±ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙˆÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø´Ø¦ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙØªØ±Ù‚Ø§Ù† Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø³Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø¥Ù†Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ¬ØªÙ…Ø¹Ø§Ù† Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø³Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ø¬Ù‡Ù„ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø¹Ø±Ù Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ù…ØªØµÙ„ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ù…Ù†ÙØµÙ„ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ø³Ù… ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ø± Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø¯ÙŠÙ… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø³Ù…Ø§Ù† Ù‚Ø¯ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù† ÙƒÙ‚Ø¯Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù†ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ù„Ø§ ÙˆÙ„ÙƒÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ù…Ø­Ø¯Ø«Ø© Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙÙ‚Ø¯ Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ Ø§Ø¨Ù†Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨Ø§ØŒ Ø¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ø« Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ø¯ÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ ÙÙ‡Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆØ¥Ù† ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ Ø£Ø­Ø¯Ø« Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø³Ù…Ø§Ø¡ Ø¯ÙˆÙ†
