Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø±Ø¶ ÙØ§Ø³Ù…Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ø§ Ù‡ÙˆØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: ÙØ§Ø³Ù…Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ù†Ø²Ù„Øª Ø£Ùˆ Ù„Ù… ØªÙ†Ø²Ù„: Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: ÙÙ‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø²ÙˆÙ„ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø±ÙˆØ­ ÙƒÙ„Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø© ÙˆØ§Ø³Ù…Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ø«Ù†Ø§Ù†ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ù‡ÙŠ ÙƒÙ„Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø© Ø±ÙˆØ­ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‚Ø¯ Ø±Ø¶ÙŠØª Ø£Ù† ØªØ¬Ø¹Ù„ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ø¨Ù†Ø§ ÙˆØ¨Ø¹Ø¶Ù‡Ø§ Ø£Ø¨Ø§ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ù„Ø§ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ø§Ø³Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ø³Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: ÙØ§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù†ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø³Ø§Ù‚ÙØ© Ø¨Ù„Ø³Ø§Ù†Ù‡Ø§ Ù„Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ù…Ø§ Ù…Ø± Ø¨Ùƒ Ù…Ø«Ù„ Ø°Ø§ Ù‚Ø· ØªÙ‚ÙˆÙ…ØŒ ÙØªØ­ÙŠØ± Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø© ÙˆØ°Ù‡Ø¨ Ù„ÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ… ÙØªØ¹Ù„Ù‚ Ø¨Ù‡ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙ…Ù†Ø¹Ùƒ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŸ Ø£ÙÙŠ Ù‚Ù„Ø¨Ùƒ Ø­Ø²Ø§Ø²Ø©ØŸ ÙÙ‚Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØ¥Ù„Ø§ Ø³Ø£Ù„ØªÙƒ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ±Ø§Ù†ÙŠØ© Ù…Ø³Ø£Ù„Ø© ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯Ø© ØªØ¨ÙŠØª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ Ù„ÙŠÙ„Ùƒ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ ÙØªØµØ¨Ø­ ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ù„Ùƒ Ù‡Ù…Ø© ØºÙŠØ±ÙŠØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø³Ø§Ù‚ÙØ©: Ù„Ø§ ØªØ±Ø¯ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø£Ù„Ø© Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ØªØ´ÙƒÙƒÙƒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ù‚Ù„Ù‡Ø§ ÙŠØ§ Ø£Ø¨Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø£ÙØ±Ø£ÙŠØªÙƒ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£ÙØ±Ø£ÙŠØªÙƒ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ ÙŠØ¹Ù„Ù… ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ø§ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù†ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£ÙØ±Ø£ÙŠØªÙƒ ØªØ®Ø¨Ø± Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø£ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø­Ù…Ù„ ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£ÙØ±Ø£ÙŠØªÙƒ ØªØ®Ø¨Ø± Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ Ø£ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙ‚Ø¯Ø± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù†ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: ÙÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ø¨Ù† ØµØ§Ø­Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ù…ØªØ³Ø§ÙˆÙŠØ§Ù† ÙˆÙƒÙŠÙ ÙŠØ¸Ù„Ù… ÙƒÙ„ ÙˆØ§Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù…Ø§ ØµØ§Ø­Ø¨Ù‡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ù„ÙŠØ³ Ù…Ù†Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ø¸Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ Ø¨ÙŠÙ†Ù‡Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø£Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø£Ø¨ Ø§Ø¨Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨Ù†ØŒ Ø¨Øª Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ø§ ÙŠØ§ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©ØŒ ÙˆØ§ÙØªØ±Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ù†ØµØ§Ø±Ù‰ ÙˆÙ‡Ù… ÙŠØªÙ…Ù†ÙˆÙ† Ø£Ù† Ù„Ø§ ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ†ÙˆØ§ Ø±Ø£ÙˆØ§ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…Ø§ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ Ø£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨Ù‡. Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ±Ø¬Ø¹ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø© Ù…ØºØªÙ…Ø§ Ù…Ù‡ØªÙ…Ø§ Ø­ØªÙ‰ ØµØ§Ø± Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ù†Ø²Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ø§Ù…Ø±Ø£ØªÙ‡ Ø§Ù„ØªÙŠ ØªØ®Ø¯Ù…Ù‡: Ù…Ø§ Ù„ÙŠ Ø£Ø±Ø§Ùƒ Ù…Ù‡ØªÙ…Ø§ Ù…ØºØªÙ…Ø§. ÙØ­ÙƒÙ‰ Ù„Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ø¨ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ ÙˆØ¨ÙŠÙ† Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ù„Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: ÙˆÙŠØ­Ùƒ Ø£ØªØ±ÙŠØ¯ Ø£Ù† ØªÙƒÙˆÙ† Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø­Ù‚ Ø£Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¨Ø§Ø·Ù„ØŸ! ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ø¨Ù„ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„Øª Ù„Ù‡: Ø£ÙŠÙ†Ù…Ø§ ÙˆØ¬Ø¯Øª Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ ÙÙ…Ù„ Ø¥Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙˆØ¥ÙŠØ§Ùƒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø¬Ø© ÙØ¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ø¬Ø© Ø´Ùƒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´Ùƒ Ø´Ø¤Ù… ÙˆØ£Ù‡Ù„Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø§Ø±ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØµÙˆØ¨ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡Ø§ ÙˆØ¹Ø²Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„ØºØ¯Ùˆ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…. Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØºØ¯Ø§ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ³ Ù…Ø¹Ù‡ Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ù…Ù† Ø£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨Ù‡ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„: ÙŠØ§ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù… Ø£Ù„Ùƒ Ù…Ù† ØªØµØ¯Ø± Ø¹Ù† Ø±Ø£ÙŠÙ‡ ÙˆØªØ±Ø¬Ø¹ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡ ÙˆØªØ¯ÙŠÙ† Ø¨Ø·Ø§Ø¹ØªÙ‡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ù†Ø¹Ù… ÙŠØ§ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙˆÙ…Ø§ ØµÙØªÙ‡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: ÙÙŠ Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ù‡ Ø£Ùˆ ÙÙŠ Ø¯ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø¬Ù…ÙŠØ¹Ø§ ØµÙØ© Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆØµÙØ© Ø¯ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø£Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø³Ø¨ Ø®ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù†Ø³Ø§Ø¨ : Ø±Ø£Ø³ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø±Ø¨ ÙˆØµÙÙˆØ© Ù‚Ø±ÙŠØ´ ÙˆÙØ§Ø¶Ù„ Ø¨Ù†ÙŠ Ù‡Ø§Ø´Ù… ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ù† Ù†Ø§Ø²Ø¹Ù‡ ÙÙŠ Ù†Ø³Ø¨Ù‡ ÙˆØ¬Ø¯Ù‡ Ø£ÙØ¶Ù„ Ù…Ù†Ù‡ Ù„Ø£Ù† Ù‚Ø±ÙŠØ´Ø§ Ø£ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø±Ø¨ ÙˆØ¨Ù†ÙŠ Ù‡Ø§Ø´Ù… Ø£ÙØ¶Ù„ Ù‚Ø±ÙŠØ´ØŒ ÙˆØ£ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø¨Ù†ÙŠ Ù‡Ø§Ø´Ù… Ø®Ø§ØµÙ‡Ù… ÙˆØ¯ÙŠÙ†Ù‡Ù… ÙˆØ³ÙŠØ¯Ù‡Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙƒØ°Ù„Ùƒ ÙˆÙ„Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙŠØ¯ Ø£ÙØ¶Ù„ Ù…Ù† ÙˆÙ„Ø¯ ØºÙŠØ±Ù‡ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ø§ Ù…Ù† ÙˆÙ„Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø³ÙŠØ¯ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØµÙ Ø¯ÙŠÙ†Ù‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø´Ø±Ø§Ø¦Ø¹Ù‡ Ø£Ùˆ ØµÙØ© Ø¨Ø¯Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØ·Ù‡Ø§Ø±ØªÙ‡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ØµÙØ© Ø¨Ø¯Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØ·Ù‡Ø§Ø±ØªÙ‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ù…Ø¹ØµÙˆÙ… ÙÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¹ØµÙŠØŒ Ùˆ Ø³Ø®ÙŠ ÙÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¨Ø®Ù„ØŒ Ø´Ø¬Ø§Ø¹ ÙÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬Ø¨Ù†ØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ø§Ø³ØªÙˆØ¯Ø¹ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù„Ù… ÙÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬Ù‡Ù„ØŒ Ø­Ø§ÙØ¸ Ù„Ù„Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù… Ø¨Ù…Ø§ ÙØ±Ø¶ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ù…Ù† Ø¹ØªØ±Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¡ØŒ ÙˆØ¬Ø§Ù…Ø¹ Ø¹Ù„Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¡ØŒ ÙŠØ­Ù„Ù… Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„ØºØ¶Ø¨ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ†ØµÙ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ù„Ù…ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ¹ÙŠÙ† Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ø±Ø¶Ø§ØŒ ÙˆÙŠÙ†ØµÙ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙ„ÙŠ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¹Ø¯ÙˆØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠØ³Ø£Ù„ Ø´Ø·Ø·Ø§ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø¯ÙˆÙ‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ÙŠÙ…Ù†Ø¹ Ø¥ÙØ§Ø¯Ø© ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ ÙŠØ¹Ù…Ù„ Ø¨Ø§Ù„ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ ÙˆÙŠØ­Ø¯Ø« Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¹Ø¬ÙˆØ¨Ø§ØªØŒ Ù…Ù† Ø£Ù‡Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø·Ù‡Ø§Ø±Ø§ØªØŒ ÙŠØ­ÙƒÙŠ Ù‚ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø¦Ù…Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø£ØµÙÙŠØ§Ø¡ØŒ Ù„Ù… ØªÙ†Ù‚Ø¶ Ù„Ù‡ Ø­Ø¬Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ù… ÙŠØ¬Ù‡Ù„ Ù…Ø³Ø£Ù„Ø©ØŒ ÙŠÙØªÙŠ ÙÙŠ ÙƒÙ„ Ø³Ù†Ø©ØŒ ÙˆÙŠØ¬Ù„Ùˆ ÙƒÙ„ Ù…Ø¯Ù„Ù‡Ù…Ø©. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: ÙˆØµÙØª Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ ÙÙŠ ØµÙØ§ØªÙ‡ ÙˆØ£Ø«Ø¨ØªÙ‡ Ø¨Ø­Ø¬Ø¬Ù‡ ÙˆØ¢ÙŠØ§ØªÙ‡ØŒ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø®Øµ Ø¨Ø§Ø¦Ù† Ø¹Ù† Ø´Ø®ØµÙ‡ ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙˆØµÙ Ù‚Ø§Ø¦Ù… Ø¨ÙˆØµÙÙ‡ØŒ ÙØ¥Ù† ÙŠØµØ¯Ù‚ Ø§Ù„ÙˆØµÙ Ù†Ø¤Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø®ØµØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ø¥Ù† ØªØ¤Ù…Ù† ØªØ±Ø´Ø¯ ÙˆØ¥Ù† ØªØªØ¨Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ Ù„Ø§ ØªØ¤Ù†Ø¨. Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: ÙŠØ§ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø© Ù…Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø­Ø¬Ø© Ø£Ù‚Ø§Ù…Ù‡Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£ÙˆÙ„ Ø®Ù„Ù‚Ù‡ Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ù‚Ø§Ù…Ù‡Ø§ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙˆØ³Ø· Ø®Ù„Ù‚Ù‡ ÙˆØ¢Ø®Ø± Ø®Ù„Ù‚Ù‡ ÙÙ„Ø§ ØªØ¨Ø·Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¬Ø¬ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØªØ°Ù‡Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù„Ù„ØŒ ÙˆÙ„Ø§ ØªØ°Ù‡Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù†Ù†. Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ù…Ø§ Ø£Ø´Ø¨Ù‡ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ ÙˆØ£Ù‚Ø±Ø¨Ù‡ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„ØµØ¯Ù‚ØŒ ÙˆÙ‡Ø°Ù‡ ØµÙØ© Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒÙ…Ø§Ø¡ ÙŠÙ‚ÙŠÙ…ÙˆÙ† Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¬Ø© Ù…Ø§ ÙŠÙ†ÙÙˆÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø´Ø¨Ù‡Ø©ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù…: Ù†Ø¹Ù…ØŒ ÙØ§Ø±ØªØ­Ù„Ø§ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ø£ØªÙŠØ§ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¯ÙŠÙ†Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ù…Ø¹Ù‡Ù…Ø§ ÙˆÙ‡Ù…Ø§ ÙŠØ±ÙŠØ¯Ø§Ù† Ø£Ø¨Ø§ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙÙ„Ù‚ÙŠØ§ Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ ÙØ­ÙƒÙ‰ Ù„Ù‡ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒØ§ÙŠØ©ØŒ ÙÙ„Ù…Ø§ ÙØ±Øº Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ: ÙŠØ§ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø© ÙƒÙŠÙ Ø¹Ù„Ù…Ùƒ Ø¨ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ÙƒØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ø£Ù†Ø§ Ø¨Ù‡ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù…ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙƒÙŠÙ Ø«Ù‚ØªÙƒ Ø¨ØªØ£ÙˆÙŠÙ„Ù‡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù…Ø§ Ø£ÙˆØ«Ù‚Ù†ÙŠ Ø¨Ø¹Ù„Ù…ÙŠ ÙÙŠÙ‡ (Ù¡) Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ§Ø¨ØªØ¯Ø£ Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ø¨Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø¡Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ Ù„Ù‚Ø¯ ÙƒØ§Ù† ÙŠÙ‚Ø±Ø¡ Ù‡ÙƒØ°Ø§ ÙˆÙ…Ø§ Ù‚Ø±Ø£ Ù‡Ø°Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø¡Ø© Ø¥Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ø¥ÙŠØ§Ùƒ ÙƒÙ†Øª Ø£Ø·Ù„Ø¨ Ù…Ù†Ø° Ø®Ù…Ø³ÙŠÙ† Ø³Ù†Ø© Ø£Ùˆ Ù…Ø«Ù„ÙƒØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ¢Ù…Ù† ÙˆØ­Ø³Ù† Ø¥ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†Ù‡ ÙˆØ¢Ù…Ù†Øª Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© ÙˆØ­Ø³Ù† Ø¥ÙŠÙ…Ø§Ù†Ù‡Ø§. Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØ¯Ø®Ù„ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù… ÙˆØ¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø±Ø£Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø£Ø¨ÙŠ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ ÙˆØ­ÙƒÙ‰ Ù‡Ø´Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø­ÙƒØ§ÙŠØ© ÙˆØ§Ù„ÙƒÙ„Ø§Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø°ÙŠ Ø¬Ø±Ù‰ Ø¨ÙŠÙ† Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… ÙˆØ¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©ØŒ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…: ï´¿Ø°Ø±ÙŠØ© Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶Ù‡Ø§ Ù…Ù† Ø¨Ø¹Ø¶ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø³Ù…ÙŠØ¹ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ…ï´¾ ÙÙ‚Ø§Ù„ Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø©: Ø¬Ø¹Ù„Øª ÙØ¯Ø§Ùƒ Ø£Ù†Ù‰ Ù„ÙƒÙ… Ø§Ù„ØªÙˆØ±Ø§Ø© ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬ÙŠÙ„ ÙˆÙƒØªØ¨ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù†Ø¨ÙŠØ§Ø¡ØŸ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡ÙŠ Ø¹Ù†Ø¯Ù†Ø§ ÙˆØ±Ø§Ø«Ø© Ù…Ù† Ø¹Ù†Ø¯Ù‡Ù… Ù†Ù‚Ø±Ø¤Ù‡Ø§ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ù‚Ø±Ø¤ÙˆÙ‡Ø§ ÙˆÙ†Ù‚ÙˆÙ„Ù‡Ø§ ÙƒÙ…Ø§ Ù‚Ø§Ù„ÙˆÙ‡Ø§ØŒ Ø¥Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ¬Ø¹Ù„ Ø­Ø¬Ø© ÙÙŠ Ø£Ø±Ø¶Ù‡ ÙŠØ³Ø£Ù„ Ø¹Ù† Ø´Ø¦ ÙÙŠÙ‚ÙˆÙ„: Ù„Ø§ Ø£Ø¯Ø±ÙŠ ÙÙ„Ø²Ù… Ø¨Ø±ÙŠÙ‡Ø© Ø£Ø¨Ø§ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ù…Ø§Øª Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ø«Ù… Ù„Ø²Ù… Ù…ÙˆØ³Ù‰ Ø¨Ù† Ø¬Ø¹ÙØ± Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡Ù…Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù…ØŒ Ø­ØªÙ‰ Ù…Ø§Øª ÙÙŠ Ø²Ù…Ø§Ù†Ù‡ ÙØºØ³Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨ÙŠØ¯Ù‡ ÙˆÙƒÙÙ†Ù‡ Ø¨ÙŠØ¯Ù‡ ÙˆÙ„Ø­Ø¯Ù‡ Ø¨ÙŠØ¯Ù‡ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚Ø§Ù„: Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø­ÙˆØ§Ø±ÙŠ Ù…Ù† Ø­ÙˆØ§Ø±ÙŠÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ­ ÙŠØ¹Ø±Ù Ø­Ù‚ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ØŒ Ù‚Ø§Ù„: ÙØªÙ…Ù†Ù‰ Ø£ÙƒØ«Ø± Ø£ØµØ­Ø§Ø¨Ù‡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠÙƒÙˆÙ†ÙˆØ§ Ù…Ø«Ù„Ù‡. Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ Ø°ÙƒØ± Ø¹Ø¸Ù…Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¬Ù„ Ø¬Ù„Ø§Ù„Ù‡ ", "majlisiGrading": "", "URL": "https://thaqalayn.net/hadith/14/2/37/1", "volume": 1, "frenchText": "", "mohseniGrading": "", "behbudiGrading": "", "chapterInCategoryId": 37, "thaqalaynSanad": "â€«â€ª1. My father said: Ahmad ibn Idris and Muhammad ibn Yahya al-`Attar said, on the authority ofâ€¬â€¬ â€«â€ªMuhammad ibn Ahmad, on the authority of Ibrahim ibn Hashim, on the authority ofâ€¬â€¬ â€«â€ªMuhammad ibn Hammad, on the authority of al-Hasan ibn Ibrahim, on the authority of Yunusâ€¬â€¬ â€«â€ªibn `Abd al-Rahman, thatâ€¬â€¬ ", "thaqalaynMatn": "Hisham ibn al-Hakam related the story of the Catholicos, primate of the Armenian church of the Christians, who was named Burayhah, and had been the Catholicos for seventy years. He used to research Islam, and sought to debate those Muslims who were familiar with the Christian gospels, and who were familiar with the Messiah, his attributes, arguments, and signs. \u003Cbr\u003EHe says: He had been known for that until he became famous among the Christians, Muslims, Jews, and Zoroastrians. The Christians use to be so proud of him that they would say: â€œIf there was no one on earth in the Christian faith except Burayhah that would suffice us.â€ He was seeker of the truth and with that, of Islam. He had a woman with him that used to serve him and she had been with him for a long time. He use to secretly tell her about the weakness of Christianity and its weak proofs. He said: I came to know that from him. Thus, Burayhah put this matter behind him, and approached the various Muslim schools who differed a bout Islam, in search of the most learned one among them. He came asking about the Muslim leaders, their pious one, their scholars, and t heir leading intellectuals. He examined every Muslim school of though, and found nothing that satisfied him. He said: â€œIf you leaders were on the true path, then they would have some truth with them!â€ \u003Cbr\u003EFinally, he learned about the Shi`ites from Hisham ibn al-Hakam. Yunus ibn `Abd al-Rahman says: Hisham said to me. I was sitting in my shop at the door of al-Karkh while a group of people were reciting the Qurâ€™an to me. I was suddenly taken aback by a group of Christian clergymen. There were approximately one hundred men, dressed in the black clothing and chasubles (of the Coptic priests) and the Great Catholicos. Burayhah was among them. They came down around my shop and placed a chair for Burayhah to sit on. The bishops and monks stood learning over their staffs, and on their heads were their chasubles. Burayhah addressed me and said: â€œI have exhausted every single Muslim theologian in debate regarding Christianity, and they had nothing that impressed me. Hence, I have come to you wishing to debate Islam.â€ He says: Hisham laughed and said: â€œO Burayhah! If you expect me to give you the same type of signs that he Messiah gave, you have come to the wrong place as I am not the Messiah, not even close. I would never critics him, though, as he was one of the purified ones, who was humble in character, yet sublime in spirituality. The Signs of Allah wee manifest in him.â€ \u003Cbr\u003EBurayhah responded, â€œYour words astonish me.â€ Hisham said: â€œIf you want to argue then go ahead.â€ Burayhah said: â€œYes. I certainly want to question you: What is the physical tie between your Prophet and the Messiah?â€™ Hisham replied, â€œHe is the son of his maternal grandfather, because Jesus is from the children of Ishaq, and Muhammad (SA) is from the children of Isma`il.â€ Burayhah asked, How do you relate him to his father?â€ Hisham answered, â€œIf you want his lineage from your view, I will inform you of it, and if yo want his linage according to us, I will inform you of that.â€ Burayhah enquired, â€œI want his lineage according to us.â€ Burayhah says that I was thinking that if he described his lineage according to us, I would overpower him. So I said: â€œDescribe his lineage the way we relate it.â€ Hisham explained, â€œYes. You say: â€œHe is without beginning from the one without beginning. Then who is the Father and who is the Son?â€ Burayhah said: â€œHe who came unto the Earth is the Son.â€ Hisham asked, â€œHe who came unto the Earth is the Father.â€ He said: â€œThe Son is the messenger of the Father.â€ Hisham added, â€œVerily, the Father is wiser than the Son, because the Father is the Creator.â€ Burayhah said: â€œVerily, the Father and the Son are both the Creators.â€ Hisham continued, â€œWhat prevented them from coming down to Earth together like they were together when they created the world?â€ Burayhah replied, â€œHow do they associate while they are both one thing? They differ only by name.â€ Hisham responded, â€œVerily, they unite with the name.â€ Burayhah said: â€œThis statement is unknown.â€ Hisham said: â€œThis statement is well-known,â€ Burayhah responded, â€œVerily, the Son is connected to the Father.â€ Hisham replied, â€œVerily, the Son is disconnected from the Father.â€ He replied, â€œThis is contrary to what the people would think.â€ \u003Cbr\u003EHisham explained, â€œIf what the people think is true, then I have overcome you for the Father was when the Son was not. Is that what you are saying, O Burayhah?â€ He answered, â€œI do not say this.â€ Hisham responded, â€œThen why did you seek to confirm your beliefs on the beliefs of those whom you reject?â€ He said: â€œVerily, the Father is a name and the Son is a name, and the eternal has decreed them.â€ Hisham said: â€œAre the two names without beginning? Are they eternal like the Father and the Son? Burayhah declared, â€œNo, The names are originated.â€ He responded, â€œYou have certainly made the Father a Son, and the Son a Father. If the Son brought these names about, and not the Father, then he is the Father. And if the Father brought these names about, and not the Son, then he is the Father, and the Son is the Father. Thus, there is no Son here.â€ Burayhah said: â€œVerily, the Son is a name of the Holy Spirit when it came down to the Earth.â€ Hisham responded, â€œWhat was its name prior to coming down to Earth?â€ Burayhah continued on, baffled: â€œIts name is the Son whether it came down or did not came down.â€ Hisham advocated, â€œSo before the coming down of this Spirit, it was all one but it had two names.â€ He said: â€œIt is all one; one Spirit.â€ Hisham acclaimed, â€œYou are pleased to make some of it the Son and some of it the Father.â€ Burayhah replied, â€œNo, because the name of the Father and the name of the Son are one.â€ Hisham said: â€œTherefore, the Son is the Father of the Father, and the Father is Father of the Son, and there is one Son.â€ \u003Cbr\u003EThe bishops said to Burayhah with one voice: â€œNothing like this has ever happened to you, stand up!â€ Thus, Burayhah was confused and wanted to leave, so Hisham attached and said: What prevents you from embracing Islam? Is there any rancour in your heart? Then say it, otherwise I will ask you a question about Christianity. I will give you the night to think about it. Then, when you wake up, you will only be interested in me. The bishops said: â€œDo not ask him the question, for it may create doubts about your faith.â€ Burayhah said: â€œSay it, O Abu al-Hakam.â€ Hisham went on, â€œTell me, does the Son know everything that the Father does?â€ He answered, â€œYes.â€ Hisham asked, â€œTell me, does the Father know everything that is with the Son?â€ He answered, â€œYes.â€ Hisham asked, â€œTell me, does the Son have power over everything that the Father has power over?â€ He answered, â€œYes.â€ Hisham asked, â€œTell me, does the Father have power over everything which the Son has power over?â€ He answered, â€œYes.â€ \u003Cbr\u003EHisham responded, â€œThen how can one of them be the Son of his partner, while they are both equal, and how does each one of them oppress his partner?â€ Burayhah said; â€œThere is no oppression between them.â€ Hisham continued, â€œThe truth between them is that the Son is the Father of the Father, and the Father is the Son of the Son. Spend the night thinking about this, O Burayhah.â€ The Christians dispersed, and they were wishing that they had never seen Hisham and his friends. \u003Cbr\u003EYunus ibn `Abd al-Rahman says: Burayhah returned in grief and anxiety till he reached his home. The woman that served him asked him, â€œWhy is it that I see you grieved and anxious!â€ Hence, he related to her the debate between Hisham and him. She asked, â€œWoe unto you! Do you want to follow truth or falsehood?â€ Burayhah replied, â€œTruth, of course.â€ She said to him, â€œWherever you find truth, then turn to it. Be careful of obstinacy. For verily, obstinacy is doubt, doubt is calamity, and those with doubt are in Hell.â€ The reporter says: He agreed with her statement and decided to go to Hisham the next morning. \u003Cbr\u003EThe next morning he went to Hisham when none of his companions were with him. He enquired, â€œO Hisham! Do you have someone whose views and words you turn to, and profess his obedience?â€ Hisham answered, â€œYes, O Burayhah.â€ â€œWhat is his description?â€ â€œAre you asking about his lineage or his religion?â€ Hisham replied, He said: â€Both of them, the description of his lineage and his religion.â€ Hisham responded, As for his lineage, it is the best of the lineages: He is the leader of the Arabs, the best of the Quraysh, and the most distinguished of the Hashimites. Whoever argued about his lineage always found it to be better than his own, because the Quraysh are the best of the Arabs, and the Hashimites are the best of the Quraysh. And, as he is the best of the Hashimites, he is the most pious among them, and their master. He descends from the children of the master, who are better than all other children. He is the son of the master. \u003Cbr\u003EHe said: â€œDescribe his religion.â€ Hisham said: â€œHis law or description of body and his purity?â€ He said: â€œDescribe his body and his purity/â€ Hisham described, He is infallible; thus, he does not sin. He is generous; hence, he does not act miserly. He is brave; so he does not act cowardly. He has been bestowed with knowledge; therefore, he does not act ignorantly. He is the Protector of the Religion, firm in what is made mandatory. He is from the Progeny of the Prophets (AS), and the Vessel of Prophetic Knowledge (AS). He pardons when he is angry. He is fair in times of oppression. He helps when pleased, and is just towards both friend and foe. He does not ask of deviation for his enemy and foes not prohibit benefiting his friends. He practices the Book and speaks wonders. He is one of the Purified Ones. He relates the words of the Divinely Elected Leaders without violating their Proof. He is not ignorant of any question. He can derive a ruling [fatwa] from any tradition, and makes clear all darkness. \u003Cbr\u003EBurayhah responded, â€œYou have described the Messiah in his attributes, and proved him by his proofs and signs, except that you have applied this description to another person. If there is a person who fits this description, we will believe in him.â€ Hisham said: â€œIf you believe you will be guided, and if you follow the truth you will not be blamed.â€ He then added, â€œO Burayhah! There is not a proof which Allah establishes over the first of His Creation, except that He establishes it over the middle creation and the last creation. Therefore, Proofs do not become invalidated, just like nations and practices do not disappear.â€ Burayhah admitted, â€œHow close is this to righteousness, and how near it is to the truth. This is the attribute of the wise. They establish proof that negates suspicion.â€ Hisham said: â€œYes.â€ \u003Cbr\u003EThen they both departed together until they arrived at Medina. The woman was with them. They both wanted to see Abu `Abd Allah (AS). However, they met Musa ibn Ja`far (AS), so Hisham related to him the account. When he finished, Musa ibn Ja`far (AS) said: â€œO Burayhah! How is your knowledge of your Book (the Bible)?â€ He answered, â€œI am knowledgeable of it.â€ The Imam (AS) asked, â€œHow is your faith in its interpretation?â€ He replied. â€œI am confident that I am knowledgeable about it.â€ The reported says: Musa ibn Ja`far (AS) began reading the Bible. Burayhah responded, â€œThe Messiah must have read like this, and no one has read this recitation but the Messiah.â€ Burayhah then said: â€œI have been seeking you or someone like you for the past fifty years.â€ \u003Cbr\u003EThe reporter says: Therefore, he embraced Islam and so did the woman, and both were expediently faithful. The Hisham, Burayhah, and the woman entered the presence of Abu `Abd Allah (AS). Hisham related the account and the discussion that took place between Musa (AS) and Burayhah. Thus Abu `Abdillah (AS) read: Offspring one of the other; and Allah is Hearing, Knowing. So Burayhah asked, â€œMay I be your ransom! How do you view the Torah, the Bible and the Books of the Prophets?â€ Abu `Abdillah (AS) replied: â€œWe are their Heirs. We read them the way they were originally read, and we convey them as they were originally conveyed. Verily, Allah does not place a Proof [hujjat] on His earth who, when questioned about something, answers: `I do not know.â€™â€ \u003Cbr\u003EHence, Burayhah remained with Abu `Abdillah (AS) until Abu `Abdillah passed away. Then he remained with Musa ibn Ja`far (AS) until Burayhah died in his time. The Imam (AS) washed his corpse with his own hands, shrouded his body, and placed him in the grave and said: â€œThis is a disciple from the disciples of the Messiah, who recognized the right of Allah over him.â€ The reported says: Thus, most of the Companions of the Imam (AS) wished they were like him.", "gradingsFull": [] } ]
